('72', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 1
('72', 0, 1, 2, 43) 1. SPEECH AT WORKING COMMITTEE MEETING, WARDHA July 6, 1937
('72', 0, 2, 3, 103) It is stated that at the outset Mahatmaji referred to the misgivings entertained by a not inconsiderable section of the Congressmen that his other Press statements issued prior to that in connection with the constitutional deadlock had, in effect, tended to whittle down the stand so far taken by the Congress.
('72', 0, 2, 4, 414) By a thorough analysis of his several statements Mahatmaji was able to satisfy the members of the Committee that they were simply meant to clarify the Congress position, which was being constantly misunderstood and misinterpreted by high officials here and in England.
('72', 0, 3, 5, 683) Mahatmaji then explained to the Committee the alternative course of action open to them in the circumstances confronting the Congress at present.
('72', 0, 3, 6, 829) It is understood Gandhiji made no secret of the fact that he had not found in Lord Linlithgow's message 1 the assurance which he had in mind when he inserted the assurance clause 2 in the A.I.C.C. resolution at Delhi.
('72', 0, 3, 7, 1047) With the Governor's special powers of interference thus left intact, Gandhiji apprehended that frictions were very likely to occur, sooner rather than later, as it would prove difficult to prevent the overlapping of the sphere of the Governor's special powers and the normal field of activities of Ministers.
('72', 0, 3, 8, 1356) Accordingly, the fear was expressed that, despite the wishes sincerely expressed by Lord Zetland and Lord Linlithgow, the new Constitution might not in actual practice be worked for long by the Congress Ministers in furtherance of the Congress objective.
('72', 0, 4, 9, 1611) Without committing himself to any definite opinion Mahatmaji is stated to have admitted that there was some force in the argument of those who maintained that the Congress should utilize the office of ministerships in the six majority Provinces with a view to generating strength in the masses of the country so that, when the final breakdown of the Constitution came–as it was bound to come–this newly developed mass strength and enthusiasm may be harnessed to good account, should the Congress find it necessary to launch upon any mass movement in the future.
('72', 0, 5, 10, 2173) In conclusion, Gandhiji is reported to have expressed himself as being in complete agreement with Mr. Jawaharlal Nehru's opinion that there must be no lowering of the Congress flag whether the Congress representatives are in office or out of it.
('72', 0, 5, 11, 2419) The Hindu, 7 7 1937
('72', 0, 6, 12, 2439) 1 Vide “Viceroy’s speech”, 21 6 1937 2 Vide “Extract from A.I.C.C. Resolution”,16 3 1937
('72', 1, 0, 1, 2528) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 2
('72', 1, 1, 2, 2568) 2. CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION 1
('72', 1, 2, 3, 2611) WARDHA, July 7. 1937 The All India Congress Committee, at its meeting held in Delhi on March 18 2 1937, passed a resolution affirming the basic Congress policy in regard to the new constitution and laying down the programme to be followed inside and outside the Legislatures by Congress members of such Legislatures.
('72', 1, 2, 4, 2928) It further directed that in pursuance of that policy permission should be given for congressmen to accept office in provinces where the Congress commanded a majority in the Legislature, and the leader of the Congress Party was satisfied and could state publicly that the Governor would not use his special powers of interference or set aside the advice of Ministers in regard to their constitutional activities.
('72', 1, 2, 5, 3340) In accordance with these directions, the leaders of Congress party who were invited by Governors to form ministries, asked for the necessary assurances.
('72', 1, 2, 6, 3493) These not having been given, the leaders expressed their inability to undertake the formation of Ministries.
('72', 1, 2, 7, 3602) But since the meeting of the Working Committee on April 28 last, Lord Zetland, Lord Stanley and Viceroy have made declarations 3 on this issue on behalf of the British Government.
('72', 1, 2, 8, 3782) The Working Committee has carefully considered these declarations and is of opinion that though they exhibit a desire to make an approach to the Congress demand they fall short of the assurances demanded in terms of the A.I.C.C. resolution as interpreted by the Working Committee resolution 4 of April 28. Again the Working Committee is unable to subscribe to the doctrine or partnership propounded in some ot the aforesaid declarations.
('72', 1, 2, 9, 4220) The proper description of the existing relationship between the British Government and the people of India is that of the exploiter and the exploited, and hence they have a different outlook upon almost everything of vital importance.
('72', 1, 2, 10, 4455) The Committee feels however that the situation created as the result of the circumstances and events that have
('72', 1, 3, 11, 4566) 1 This was drafted by Gandhiji.
('72', 1, 3, 12, 4598) The date line is reproduced from The Hitavada, 9 7 1937. 2 Actually on March 16; vide“Extract from A.I.C.C. Resolution”,16 3 1937 3 For Lord Zetland's and the Viceroy's speeches, vide “Viceroy’s speech”, 21 6 1937 4 Passed at Allahabad; vide footnote 1, “Interview to Associated Press of India”, 6 5 1937
('72', 2, 0, 1, 4903) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 3
('72', 2, 1, 2, 4946) since occured, warrants the belief that it will not be easy for the Governors to use their special powers.
('72', 2, 1, 3, 5053) The Committee has moreover considered the views of Congress members of the Legislatures and of Congressmen generally.
('72', 2, 1, 4, 5171) The Committee has therefore come to the conclusion and resolves that Congressmen be permitted to accept office where they may be invited thereto.
('72', 2, 1, 5, 5317) But it desires to make it clear that office is to be accepted and utilized for the purpose of working in accordance with lines laid down in the Congress election manifesto and to further in every possible way the Congress policy of combating the new Act on the one hand and of prosecuting the constructive programme on the other.
('72', 2, 1, 6, 5647) The Working Committee is confident that it has the support and backing of the A.I.C.C. in this decision and that this resolution is in furtherance of the general policy laid down by the Congress and the A.I.C.C. The Committee would have welcomed the opportunity of taking the direction of the A.I.C.C. in this matter but it is of opinion that delay in taking a decision at this stage would be injurious to the country's interests and would create confusion in the public mind at a time when prompt and decisive action is necessary.
('72', 2, 2, 7, 6179) Congress Bulletin No.
('72', 2, 2, 8, 6201) 5, July 1937. Also Home Department, Political Branch, File No.
('72', 2, 2, 9, 6264) 4/15/37. Courtesy: National Archives of India

('72', 3, 1, 2, 6587) 4. SPEECH AT RASHTRABHASHA ADHYAPAN MANDIR, WARDHA 1
('72', 3, 2, 3, 6640) July 7, 1937 Rajendra Babu has lightened my task by saying that the pracharaks should be men of character.
('72', 3, 2, 4, 6747) It goes without saying that those who have not the literary qualifications would not do, but it is necessary to bear in mind that even literary qualifications would be of no use where the essential qualification of character was wanting.
('72', 3, 2, 5, 6985) They will have to master the Hindi language as defined by Indore Sahitya Sammelan, i.e., the language spoken by the Hindus and Mussalmans of North India and written in Devanagari or Persian script.
('72', 3, 2, 6, 7183) Mastery of this language will mean mastery not only of the easy Hindi Hindustani spoken by the masses but also of the high flown Hindi full of Sanskrit words and the high flown Urdu full of Persian and Arabic words.
('72', 3, 2, 7, 7399) Without a knowledge of these, mastery of the language would be incomplete even as one could not claim to be master of the English language without a knowledge of the English of Chaucer, Swift and Johnson, or mastery of the Sanskrit language without a knowledge of the Sanskrit of Valmiki and Kalidas.
('72', 3, 2, 8, 7700) But I should be prepared to put up with their ignorance of Devanagari or Persian scripts, or ignorance of Hindi grammar, but I should not tolerate for a moment lack of character.
('72', 3, 2, 9, 7879) We do not need such men here and, if there is anyone among the candidates who is not likely to stand the test, let him leave betimes.
('72', 3, 2, 10, 8013) The work they are called to is no easy thing.
('72', 3, 2, 11, 8059) There is a strong body of English knowing people who say that English alone can be the lingua franca of India.
('72', 3, 2, 12, 8170) There are the pundits of Benares and Allahabad and the alims of Delhi and Lucknow who want a Sanskritized Hindi and Persianized Urdu.
('72', 3, 2, 13, 8304) The third group we have to contend against is that which has raised the cry of ‘provincial languages in danger’.
('72', 3, 2, 14, 8417) Mere learning cannot successfully grapple with these forces.
('72', 3, 2, 15, 8478) It is the work not of learned men, but of fakirs men of incorruptible character and with no axe to grind.
('72', 3, 2, 16, 8584) If you are found wanting in this respect and the people amongst whom you are working were to lay
('72', 3, 3, 17, 8681) 1 The speech is extracted from "Weekly Letter" by Mahadev Desai, who had reported its "verbatim" translation.
('72', 3, 3, 18, 8791) The date line is reproduced from The Hindu 8 7 1937.
('72', 4, 0, 1, 8844) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 5
('72', 4, 1, 2, 8887) rough hands on you, I should not blame them.
('72', 4, 1, 3, 8932) They are not pledged to ahimsa.
('72', 4, 1, 4, 8964) Nor is money going to help us much.
('72', 4, 1, 5, 9000) You know, I agreed to preside over the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan at Indore in 1935 on condition that the Reception Committee should collect Rs. 1,00,000 for Hindi prachar in South India in particular and other non Hindi Provinces in general.
('72', 4, 1, 6, 9239) I was loath to accept the invitation, but Jamnalalji stood surety for the Reception Committee.
('72', 4, 1, 7, 9334) The Committee failed to collect the amount, in fact it collected then practically nothing at all.
('72', 4, 1, 8, 9432) But in the year following about Rs. 22,000 were collected.
('72', 4, 1, 9, 9491) Jamnalalji has now contributed Rs. 25,000 from his own pocket, and he has secured a promise of Rs. 75,000 from the charities of the late Kamalapatji of Kanpur.
('72', 4, 1, 10, 9651) There is thus no lack of money.
('72', 4, 1, 11, 9683) But what can money do?
('72', 4, 1, 12, 9706) Wardha was just a cotton centre with a few ginning factories.
('72', 4, 1, 13, 9768) It is Jamnalalji’s ambiton to turn it into a cultural centre and a centre of national activities.
('72', 4, 1, 14, 9866) He has, therefore, helped in bringing into being Mahila Ashram, a high school, Hindi Prachar Samiti, the present training school, the weaving school, the Village Workers’ Training School, a tannery and so on.
('72', 4, 1, 15, 10075) But more than these institutions, more than money, we want character.
('72', 4, 1, 16, 10145) That is what I have come this morning to ask you to contribute to this work.
('72', 4, 1, 17, 10222) Harijan, 17 7 1937
('72', 4, 2, 18, 10241) 5. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU” 1
('72', 4, 3, 19, 10271) July 8, 1937
('72', 4, 4, 20, 10284) GANDHIJI: You have come to waylay me, you highway man!
('72', 4, 5, 21, 10339) CORRESPONDENT: Are you giving any message to the Congress on the morrow
('72', 4, 6, 22, 10411) of the inauguration of the new policy of trying office?
('72', 4, 7, 23, 10467) G. The Congress Working Committee’s resolution is comprehensive.
('72', 4, 7, 24, 10532) It contains the message and programme to be followed by the Congressmen and the country.
('72', 4, 8, 25, 10621) Asked how he, the author of the demand for assurance, reconciled the stand taken in Delhi with the decision reached yesterday, Gandhiji again said: The resolution has dealt with it.
('72', 4, 8, 26, 10803) I have nothing to add to it.
('72', 4, 9, 27, 10832) 1 The correspondent had reported that he met Gandhiji “early in the morning, at 5.30, half way down from Segaon to Wardha.”
('72', 5, 0, 1, 10956) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 6
('72', 5, 1, 2, 10996) When I drew his attention to the fact that he was completing his year of seclusion in the village, Gandhiji said: Segaon has an irresistible attraction for me and I feel inclined to stay there indefinitely.
('72', 5, 2, 3, 11203) I referred to the European situation, the armament race and the war menace and asked whether he, the apostle of non violence, would not come out of his retirement in the village and spread the message of non violence over the world and thus do a service to humanity.
('72', 5, 2, 4, 11470) It is all so soothing to hear but I am not big enough for that task.
('72', 5, 2, 5, 11539) You are taking me beyond my depth.
('72', 5, 3, 6, 11574) The rest of the walk was devoted to talk about fast walking.
('72', 5, 3, 7, 11635) Gandhiji remarked on the ease and facility with which the everage villagers covered the long distances in fair weather or foul.
('72', 5, 3, 8, 11763) The Hindu, 8 7 1937
('72', 5, 4, 9, 11783) 6. MEANING OF THE CONSTITUTIONAL OATH
('72', 5, 5, 10, 11821) Shri Kishorelal Mashruwala writes:
('72', 5, 6, 11, 11856) I am afraid that Gandhiji's position 1 with regard to the constitutional oath has not been properly understood.
('72', 5, 6, 12, 11968) of course, one ought not to make a distinction between a legal oath and a moral oath.
('72', 5, 6, 13, 12054) But there can be a distinction between a legal oath and a religious oath.
('72', 5, 6, 14, 12128) By the latter, Gandhiji appears to mean an oath taken in the name of God and framed by [the taker] himself or by his religious teachers or scriptures.
('72', 5, 6, 15, 12279) If it is framed by himself, he knows the exact implications of that oath, and he is bound by his own interpretation of it only, and not of anyone else.
('72', 5, 6, 16, 12431) Whether he has fulfilled it or not is a question between himself and his conscience or God.
('72', 5, 6, 17, 12523) If it has been framed by his religious teachers or scriptures, he is expected to have accepted their interpretation of its implications and is fully discharged if they exonerate him.
('72', 5, 6, 18, 12706) If a person who does not accept those teachers or scriptures avers on a mere reading of the language of the oath that the oath has been broken, his opinion does not count.
('72', 5, 7, 19, 12878) A legal oath is one which is framed not by himself but by the Legislature to which he is, de facto, subject.
('72', 5, 7, 20, 12987) The exact implication of that oath is no more than what the Legislature has decided to give it.
('72', 5, 7, 21, 13083) In case of doubt as to its exact meaning, the proper authorities to adjudicate upon the meaning are the Legislature itself, the Court of Law having jurisdiction in
('72', 5, 8, 22, 13247) 1Vide “Are There Different Oaths”,26 6 1937
('72', 6, 0, 1, 13291) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 7
('72', 6, 1, 2, 13334) the matter, and subject to appeal to them eminent lawyers.
('72', 6, 1, 3, 13393) A person who perfectly fulfils the oath in the light of such interpretation is discharged not only legally but also morally.
('72', 6, 2, 4, 13518) A good deal of confusion seems to have arisen by importing into the oath of allegiance implications assigned to it not by the framers or their authorized interpreters but by the layman.
('72', 6, 2, 5, 13704) Perhaps the layman's interpretation is not without its history.
('72', 6, 2, 6, 13768) Nevertheless it cannot be accepted as authoritative.
('72', 6, 2, 7, 13821) The layman's meaning of the oath of allegiance appears to be an attitude of devotional attachment to the person of the King to such a high pitch that the pledger would be willing to die for him.
('72', 6, 2, 8, 14016) He seems also to hold that the oath once taken becomes binding upon him for life.
('72', 6, 2, 9, 14098) According to eminent constitutional lawyers, I am given to understand, both these assumptions are wrong.
('72', 6, 2, 10, 14203) According to them the oath simply means that as long as the pledger is subject to the oath (i.e., is a member of the institution which has framed the oath), he shall not rise in arms against the King, or be a party to his death, except through constitutional process.
('72', 6, 2, 11, 14471) Through constitutional process, even that is allowable.
('72', 6, 2, 12, 14527) Through constitutional process, it is open to the proper Legislagure to amend or repeal the oath altogether; it is possible to dethrone the King and even to order his execution.
('72', 6, 2, 13, 14705) But if the Legislature does not agree to it, no legislator who has taken the oath can resort to violence against the King, except after ceasing to be a member of that body.
('72', 6, 3, 14, 14878) A person pledged to Truth and Non violence (as a member of the Gandhi Seva Sangh) is assumed not to harbour any violent intention to the King under any circumstances.
('72', 6, 3, 15, 15045) There is, therefore, no moral difficulty in his case to take the oath of allegiance as interpreted above.
('72', 6, 3, 16, 15151) There is nothing to prevent him from aiming at complete independence, if he means to achieve it– as long as he is in the Legislature–through constitutional means and, in case he means to resort to other means, to do so after resigning his seat.
('72', 6, 3, 17, 15396) His oath is not intended to bind him to it when he ceases to be a member.
('72', 6, 3, 18, 15470) There is nothing again, according to lawyers, requiring a member not to harbour intentions of bringing about a constitutional revolution, even violent, if the Legislature will agree.
('72', 6, 3, 19, 15653) These means are not open to the members of the Sangh, not because they are members of the Legislature but because of their membership of the Sangh.
('72', 6, 3, 20, 15801) Thus there is no conflict between the legal and the moral aspect as assumed.
('72', 6, 3, 21, 15878) I heartily endorse this presentation of my meaning of the distinction drawn by me between legal and religious oaths.
('72', 6, 3, 22, 15995) But a friend who saw the foregoing note is not yet satisfied.
('72', 6, 3, 23, 16057) He says,
('72', 7, 0, 1, 16066) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 8
('72', 7, 1, 2, 16106) whatever be the meaning the authors of an oath may give to it, the taker of it should be the final judge of its meaning, and must therefore be at liberty to take or not to take the oath.
('72', 7, 1, 3, 16293) Whilst he is at liberty to do what he likes, the arbitrary meaning he may give contrary to the meaning given to it by its very author will be held utterly indefensible.
('72', 7, 2, 4, 16462) Harijan, 10 7 1937
('72', 7, 3, 5, 16481) 7. INSTRUCTIVE FIGURES
('72', 7, 4, 6, 16504) In the course of a conversation with Dr. Syed Mahmud I happened to mention that the All India Spinners’ Association had on its register a large number of Muslim spinners, weavers and carders.
('72', 7, 4, 7, 16696) I was speaking from a general knowledge of the working of the Association.
('72', 7, 4, 8, 16771) This was a few months ago.
('72', 7, 4, 9, 16798) But as there never was any intention to keep a communal register or even to find out the caste or religion of those engaged in the different processes regarding manufacutre of khadi, figures took some time to prepare.
('72', 7, 4, 10, 17016) The actual figures generaly correspond to the impression I gave to Dr. Mahmud.
('72', 7, 4, 11, 17095) They will be found published on p.
('72', 7, 4, 12, 17130) 171 in this issue.
('72', 7, 5, 13, 17149) This is what I call living contact with the masses irrespective of caste or creed.
('72', 7, 5, 14, 17232) If the workers are true to their salt, the contact must be of an abiding nature.
('72', 7, 5, 15, 17313) It should result also in an indissoluble bond between Hindus and Mussalmans of the villages of India.
('72', 7, 5, 16, 17415) Hitherto they have not worked knowingly and voluntarily under the aegis of one agency and for a common purpose.
('72', 7, 5, 17, 17527) There is every possibility of a conscious union of hearts between them being achieved.
('72', 7, 5, 18, 17614) It should be much easier under the new scheme in which the interest of the artisans is held to be predominant.
('72', 7, 5, 19, 17725) Since the new orientation the contact has become far more real than it ever was.
('72', 7, 5, 20, 17806) For the spinners–and they are by far the largest majority among the artisans served by the Associations–are regularly instructed.
('72', 7, 5, 21, 17936) Every individual spinner receives personal attention and is taught to use better tools in a better manner.
('72', 7, 5, 22, 18043) Their wages are in many cases trebled, even quadrupled.
('72', 7, 5, 23, 18099) It is difficult to forecast the result of this new scheme, both to the individual workers and the nation at large.
('72', 7, 5, 24, 18214) One result is obvious.
('72', 7, 5, 25, 18237) These artisans have ceased to be the exploited class.
('72', 7, 5, 26, 18291) Presently they will be conscious controllers of the A.I.S.A. as they are today its prime, though unconscious, shareholders.
('72', 7, 5, 27, 18415) Harijan, 10 7 1937
('72', 7, 6, 28, 18434) 1 The figures are not reproduced here.

('72', 8, 3, 4, 18570) MY DEAR IDIOT, I have apparently neglected you these few days.
('72', 8, 3, 5, 18633) I hope you had my wire 1. I wonder whether the news preceded the wire.
('72', 8, 3, 6, 18704) For you it should be enough that I did not forget it.
('72', 8, 3, 7, 18758) Jawaharlal was more than good throughout.
('72', 8, 3, 8, 18800) His innate nobility asserted itself every time a difficulty cropped up.
('72', 8, 3, 9, 18872) He is truly a warrior, sans peur et sans reproche.
('72', 8, 3, 10, 18923) The more I see him, the more I love him.
('72', 8, 3, 11, 18964) I had long chats with him and the Maulana.
('72', 8, 3, 12, 19007) It will be most difficult to replace him next year.

('72', 8, 3, 14, 19132) She occupies Jamnalal's guest house.
('72', 8, 3, 15, 19169) No more today.

('72', 9, 6, 16, 20746) 11. LETTER TO NIRMLA GANDHI
('72', 9, 7, 17, 20774) SEGAON, WARDHA, July 10, 1937
('72', 9, 8, 18, 20804) NIMU, Ramdas must have left 2. You have done well to ask him to go.
('72', 9, 8, 19, 20872) As for the result, it is in God’s hands alone.
('72', 9, 8, 20, 20919) From the letter I have from him, it appears that you wish to settle dawn there only.
('72', 9, 8, 21, 21004) He also says in his letter that Navanit will not be willing to bear the expenses of your living there.
('72', 9, 8, 22, 21107) So let me know how much I will have to send you every month.

('72', 9, 8, 24, 21206) If you wish

('72', 10, 1, 2, 21936) to come over here, that can certainly be done, or if you wish to settle down somewhere else, that also can be arranged.
('72', 10, 1, 3, 22056) Ramdas worries about your health, too.
('72', 10, 1, 4, 22095) What can I do to help him from this distance?

('72', 24, 2, 3, 43235) July 15, 1937
('72', 24, 3, 4, 43249) MY DEAR NARIMAN, You have sent me an extraordinary letter 1. Either you are in a state of confusion, or your friends are.
('72', 24, 3, 5, 43371) So far as I can recollect, you accepted the Working Committee's decision as final regarding the telegram.
('72', 24, 3, 6, 43477) As to your other charges you had no evidence then in your possession.
('72', 24, 3, 7, 43547) Your letters showed no evidence and therefore the Working Committee could neither decide for itself except to decide against you nor could give you a committee.
('72', 24, 3, 8, 43708) How can you say you closed the matter though in your letter you reserved to yourself the right to ask for a committee when you had framed your charge sheet?
('72', 24, 3, 9, 43865) So far as I can see the matter can only be closed by leading against Sardar Vallabhbhai all the evidence you have in your possession or by making a clear admission that you have nothing against him.
('72', 24, 3, 10, 44064) Can you not see that the Working Committee's decision so far as it goes is wholly against you?
('72', 24, 3, 11, 44159) If you regard its verdict as final, then can you sit still when unbounded vilification of the Sardar is going on in front of you, and to which, in your letters, you have allowed yourself to be a party up to a certain extent?
('72', 24, 3, 12, 44384) You will be committing no breach of faith with me if you were to publish the whole of the conversation between you and me, if you will let me have beforehand what you will publish.
('72', 24, 3, 13, 44565) There are other inaccuracies in your letter which I need not go into.
('72', 24, 3, 14, 44635) Let me be however clear about one point.
('72', 24, 3, 15, 44676) So long as you feel that the Sardar has dealt with you unfairly in any shape or form, or that he has done anything ungentlemanly, it is your bounden duty to accept his offer.
('72', 24, 3, 16, 44851) You owe it to yourself and to a colleague, who emphatically maintains that he has never done or meant any harm to
('72', 24, 4, 17, 44965) 1 Dated July 14, which read: "I am being charged for defying and attempting to circumvent the Working Committee Resolution at Delhi and Wardha by demanding an independent tribunal.

('72', 30, 1, 2, 53897) Your first sentence suggests excessive respect while what you really feel is helplessness.

('72', 31, 1, 2, 55813) 44. LETTER TO N. R. MALKANI
('72', 31, 2, 3, 55841) SEGON (WARDHA), July 16, 1937
('72', 31, 3, 4, 55871) MY DEAR MALKANI, Why don’t you steal in a note in The Hindustan Times advertising your wares or write to The Hindustan Times a letter to be published in the correspondents’ column, complaining of public apathy and telling the public what attactive things can be had there?
('72', 31, 3, 5, 56144) 1 Secondly, Why don’t you have a list of the things you have for sale and post the same to likely addresses in Delhi?
('72', 31, 3, 6, 56262) You are bound to get some orders.
('72', 31, 3, 7, 56296) Thirdly, you can engage a hawker who can hawk about your things on commission.
('72', 31, 3, 8, 56375) Fourthly, sometimes you can pay visits to friends yourself and get their orders.
('72', 31, 3, 9, 56456) If you just learn enough of the tailoring and shoemaking technique, you can take measurements yourself.
('72', 31, 3, 10, 56560) Shrimati Rameshwari Nehru is sporting a pair of slippers or some such thing from your colony.
('72', 31, 3, 11, 56654) They have given her blisters all over.
('72', 31, 3, 12, 56693) Now, your department has to turn out first class articles if you are to command a large custom.
('72', 31, 3, 13, 56789) Then you mention the trouble about getting workers in the Provinces to interest themselves more than they are doing.
('72', 31, 3, 14, 56906) Of course this is a universal complaint.
('72', 31, 3, 15, 56947) We are not slaves without deserving our slavery.
('72', 31, 3, 16, 56996) Then, about the boys themselves, why should you not so arrange your departments as to absorb all the boys in the colony.
('72', 31, 3, 17, 57117) Then they would be earning a decent livelihood and you will produce master tailors, master shoemakers, etc.
('72', 31, 3, 18, 57225) I am surprised that you, as a teacher, can feel lazy and say, you have’t enough to do.
('72', 31, 3, 19, 57312) With eighteen children for whose welfare you are wholly responsible and to whom you are both father and mother, I should have thought that you had more than you could manage.
('72', 31, 3, 20, 57487) Can you imagine a widowed father having eighteen children to care for feeling lazy and with time hanging heavy over him?
('72', 31, 3, 21, 57608) That sentence in your letter is a disturbing sentence.
('72', 31, 3, 22, 57663) You know what I mean.

('72', 32, 1, 2, 57892) 45. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('72', 32, 2, 3, 57915) July 16, 1937 You are hard on poor Sen.
('72', 32, 2, 4, 57955) Surely there are meat eaters who are as good brahmacharis and as abstemious as any vegetarians.
('72', 32, 2, 5, 58051) The physical effect of milk is the same almost as of flesh [or] meat.
('72', 32, 2, 6, 58121) Hundreds, perhaps thousands, of Roman Catholic monks and nuns are not to be beaten in their self restraint in everything.
('72', 32, 2, 7, 58243) Purity of personal life is not a monopoly of vegetarians not kindness.
('72', 32, 2, 8, 58314) Do you know vegetarians who know not what self restraint is, no kindness to human or sub human life?
('72', 32, 2, 9, 58415) Who can be more cruel to man and beast than some vegetarian husbands, fathers and cattleowners?
('72', 32, 2, 10, 58511) We must not make a fetish of our vegetarianism and be intolerant.
('72', 32, 2, 11, 58577) Let us not attribute more virtue to vegetarianism than it can carry.
('72', 32, 2, 12, 58646) And so long as we must take milk, it is wrong to call ourselves vegetarians or non flesh eaters.
('72', 32, 2, 13, 58743) Distinction there is, but ir is not the restriction which you seem to think there is.
('72', 32, 2, 14, 58829) It is only real godliness that alters the whole course of life.

('72', 34, 4, 16, 62058) 49. CONGRESS MINISTRIES
('72', 34, 5, 17, 62082) Since the Working Committee and other Congressmen have allowed themselves to be influenced by my opinion on the office issue, it is perhaps due to the public for me to explain my conception of office acceptance and what is possible to do in terms of the Congress election menifesto.
('72', 34, 5, 18, 62365) I need offer no apology for crossing the self imposed limit in the conduct of Harijan.
('72', 34, 5, 19, 62452) The reason is obvious.
('72', 34, 5, 20, 62475) The Government of India Act is universally regarded as wholly unsatisfactory for achieving India’s freedom.
('72', 34, 5, 21, 62583) But it is possible to consture it as an attempt, however limited and feeble, to replace the rule of the sword by the rule of the majority.
('72', 34, 5, 22, 62722) The creation of the big electorate of three crores of men and women and the placing of wide powers in their hands cannot be described by any other name.
('72', 34, 5, 23, 62875) Underlying it is the hope that what has been imposed upon us we shall get to like, i.e., we shall really regard our exploitation as a blessing in the end.
('72', 34, 5, 24, 63030) The hope may be frustrated if the representatives of the thirty million voters have a faith of their own and are intelligent enough to use the powers (including the holding of offices) placed in their hands for the purpose of thwarting the assumed intention of the framers of the Act.
('72', 34, 5, 25, 63315) And this can be easily done by lawfully using the Act in a manner not expected by them and by refraining from using it in the way intended by them.
('72', 34, 5, 26, 63463) Thus the Ministries may enforce immediate prohibition by making education self supporting instead of paying for it from the liquor revenue.
('72', 34, 5, 27, 63603) This may appear a startling proposition, but I hold it
('72', 35, 0, 1, 63658) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 36
('72', 35, 1, 2, 63699) perfectly feasible and eminently reasonable.
('72', 35, 1, 3, 63744) The jails may be turnecd into reformatories and workshops.
('72', 35, 1, 4, 63803) They should be self supporting and educational instead of being spending and punitive departments.
('72', 35, 1, 5, 63902) In accordance with the Irwin Gandhi Pact, of which only the Salt Clause remains still alive, salt should be free for the poor man, but it is not; it can now be free in Congress Provinces at least.
('72', 35, 1, 6, 64099) All purchases of cloth should be in khadi.
('72', 35, 1, 7, 64142) The attention should now be devoted more to the villages and the peasantry than to the cities.
('72', 35, 1, 8, 64237) These are but illustrations taken at random.
('72', 35, 1, 9, 64282) They are perfectly lawful, and yet not one of them has as yet even been attempted.
('72', 35, 1, 10, 64365) Then the personal behaviour of Ministers.
('72', 35, 1, 11, 64407) How will Congress Ministers discharge themselves?
('72', 35, 1, 12, 64457) Their Chief, the Presidentt of the Congress, travels third class.
('72', 35, 1, 13, 64523) Will they travel first?
('72', 35, 1, 14, 64547) The President is satisfied with a coarse khadi dhoti, Kurta and waistcoat.
('72', 35, 1, 15, 64622) Will the Ministers require the Western style and expenditure on Western scale?
('72', 35, 1, 16, 64701) Congressmen have for the past seventeen years disciplined themselves in rigorous simplicity.
('72', 35, 1, 17, 64794) The nation will expect the Ministers to introduce simplicity in the administration of their Provinces.
('72', 35, 1, 18, 64897) They will not be ashamed of it, they will be proud of it.
('72', 35, 1, 19, 64955) We are the poorest nation on earth, many millions living in semi srarvation.
('72', 35, 1, 20, 65032) Its representatives dare not live in a style and manner out of all correspondence with their electors.
('72', 35, 1, 21, 65135) The Englishmen coming as conquerors and rulers set up a standard of living which took no account whatsoever of the helpless conquered.
('72', 35, 1, 22, 65270) If the Ministers will simply refrain from copying the Governors and the secured Civil Service, they will have shown the marked contrast that exists between the Congress mentality and theirs.
('72', 35, 1, 23, 65461) Truly there can be no partnership between them and us even as there can be none between a gaint and a dwarf.
('72', 35, 1, 24, 65570) Lest Congressmen should think that they have a monopoly of simplicity and that they erred in 1920 in doing away with the trousers and the chair, let me cite the examples of Aboobaker and Omar.
('72', 35, 1, 25, 65763) Rama and Krishna are prehistoric names.
('72', 35, 1, 26, 65803) I may not use these names as examples.
('72', 35, 1, 27, 65842) History tells us of Pratap and Shivaji living in uttermost simplicity.
('72', 35, 1, 28, 65913) But opinion may be divided as to what they did when they had power.
('72', 35, 1, 29, 65981) There is no division of opinion about the Prophet, Aboobaker and Omar.
('72', 35, 1, 30, 66052) They had the riches of the world at their feet.
('72', 35, 1, 31, 66100) It will be difficult to find a historical parallel to match their rigorous
('72', 36, 0, 1, 66175) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 37
('72', 36, 1, 2, 66219) Omar would not brook the idea of his lieutenants in distant provinces using anything but coarse cloth and coarse flour.
('72', 36, 1, 3, 66339) The Congress Ministers, if they will retain the simplicity and economy they have inherited since 1920, will save thousands of rupees, will give hope to the poor and probably change the tone of the Services.
('72', 36, 1, 4, 66546) It is hardly necessary for me to point out that simplicity does not mean shoddiness.
('72', 36, 1, 5, 66631) There is a beauty and an art in simplicity which he who runs may see.
('72', 36, 1, 6, 66701) It does not require money to be neat, clean and dignified.
('72', 36, 1, 7, 66760) Pomp and pageantry are often synonymous with vulgarity.
('72', 36, 1, 8, 66816) This unostentatious work must be the prelude to demonstrating the utter insufficiency of the Act to meet the wishes of the people and the determination to end it.
('72', 36, 1, 9, 66979) The English Press has been at pains to divide India into Hindu and Muslim.
('72', 36, 1, 10, 67054) The Congress majority Provinces have been dubbed Hindu, the other five Muslim.
('72', 36, 1, 11, 67133) That this is demonstrably false has not worried them.
('72', 36, 1, 12, 67187) My great hope is that the Ministers in the six Provinces will so manage them as to disarm all suspicion.
('72', 36, 1, 13, 67292) They will show their Muslim colleagues that they know no distinction between Hindu, Muslim, Christian or Sikh or Parsi.
('72', 36, 1, 14, 67412) Nor will they know any distinction between high caste and low caste Hindus.
('72', 36, 1, 15, 67488) They will demonstrate in every action of theirs that with them all are the sons of the soil among whom there is no one low and no one high.
('72', 36, 1, 16, 67628) Poverty and climate are common to all without distinction.
('72', 36, 1, 17, 67687) The major problems are identical for all of them.
('72', 36, 1, 18, 67737) And whilst, so far as we can judge from actions, the goal of the English system is wholly different from ours, the men and women representing the two goals belong to the same human family.
('72', 36, 1, 19, 67926) They will now be thrown together as they never have been before.
('72', 36, 1, 20, 67991) If the human reading that I have given to the Act is correct, the two parties meet together, each with its own history, background and goal, to convert one another.
('72', 36, 1, 21, 68156) Corporations are wooden and soulless but not those who work them or use them.
('72', 36, 1, 22, 68234) If the Englishmen or Anglicized Indians can but see the Indian which is the Congress viewpoint, the battle is won by the Congress and complete independence will come to us without shedding a drop of blood.
('72', 36, 1, 23, 68440) This is what I call the non violent approach.
('72', 36, 1, 24, 68486) It may be foolish, visionary, imprectical; never theless it is best that Congressmen, other Indians and Englishmen should know it.
('72', 36, 1, 25, 68617) This office acceptance is not intended to work the Act anyhow.
('72', 36, 1, 26, 68680) In the prosecution by the Congress of its goal of complete independence, it is a serious attempt on the one hand to avoid a
('72', 37, 0, 1, 68804) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 38
('72', 37, 1, 2, 68845) bloody revolution and on the other to avoid mass civil disobedience on a scale hitherto not attempted.
('72', 37, 1, 3, 68948) May God bless it.
('72', 37, 1, 4, 68966) Harijan, 17 7 1937
('72', 37, 2, 5, 68985) 50. NOTE ON RENTIA JAYANTI CELEBRATION 1

('72', 37, 7, 15, 69569) July 17, 1937
('72', 37, 8, 16, 69583) One answer to all your doubts and questions is this.
('72', 37, 8, 17, 69636) One is said to fall, i.e., completely rely, on Ramanama when one does so through the heart.
('72', 37, 8, 18, 69728) If you think that you have not attained success, the only inference is that your prayer does not come from the heart, it comes only from the lips.
('72', 37, 8, 19, 69875) That does not mean that you are not sincere but it does mean that your prayer has some connection with the result that you want to attain and since as a good Hindu you believe in prayer, you think you are complying with all the requirements when you utter the prayer with your lips.
('72', 37, 8, 20, 70158) Utterance with the lips is no doubt necessary, but in order to perceive the efficacy of prayer it has to find its place in the heart.
('72', 37, 8, 21, 70292) The only way to test the question whether it has permeated the heart is by finding whether there is real peace of mind.
('72', 37, 8, 22, 70412) For answer to prayer does not mean that you should get what you

('72', 38, 1, 2, 70843) want but it means that you become free from all anxiety and become indifferent as to whether you get the thing prayed for or not.
('72', 38, 1, 3, 70973) The illustration that I can give from life is that whenever I have been assailed in difficult situations by anxiety or doubts they have been dispelled by prayer, and peace has taken the place of depression.

('72', 40, 1, 2, 73604) 56. LETTER TO K. F. NARIMAN
('72', 40, 2, 3, 73632) July 17, 1937
('72', 40, 3, 4, 73646) MY DEAR NARIMAN, Sir Govindrao 1 has sent me a copy of his letter to you.
('72', 40, 3, 5, 73720) In the covering letter he gives me an extract from your letter to him.
('72', 40, 3, 6, 73791) From you letters to the Working Committee and from your letter to Sir Govindrao I see that, in your excitement, which has become chronic with you, you have lost even your legal acumen.
('72', 40, 3, 7, 73976) The more I think of this wretched quarrel, the clearer I am becoming that your grievance is wholly imaginary and that, by allowing the agitation to continue, you are harming yourself and the public interest.
('72', 40, 3, 8, 74184) I would strongly advise you to take legal advice, and frame your indictment in a proper manner which anybody can understand.
('72', 40, 3, 9, 74309) I wholly endorse Sir Govindrao’s remark that your charge is too vague for any lawyer or judge to understand or decide upon.
('72', 40, 3, 10, 74433) In your reference, you are bound to refer to the charge of Sardar Vaallabhbhai having secretly poisoned the minds of the voters directly or indirectly in connection with the election of the leader of the Congress Parliamentary Party.
('72', 40, 3, 11, 74667) How I wish that you could see that you have made mountain out of a molehill.
('72', 40, 3, 12, 74744) Assuming that you were utterly innocent of the defeat of the Congress candidate at the Bombay election of 1934, and yet the Sardar persisted in believing that you were not innocent, and actuated the voters against you, how can you make that a cause of serious grievance?
('72', 40, 3, 13, 75015) These things will happen in public life.
('72', 40, 3, 14, 75056) Do we not often suspect the bona fides even of our companions and act upon those suspicions?
('72', 40, 3, 15, 75149) In your letter to Sir Govindrao, you say that your claims were defeated because of the allegations against you.
('72', 40, 3, 16, 75261) Has a public worker any claim to anything?
('72', 40, 3, 17, 75304) Had Jawaharlal any claim to the Presidentship of the Congress?
('72', 40, 3, 18, 75367) He may even try his level best to get elected, but why should he brood over his defeat?
('72', 40, 3, 19, 75455) Would he be justified in making that a cause of grievance against those who were responsible for his defeat?
('72', 40, 3, 20, 75564) And yet is it not this that you are doing, or is there anything more?
('72', 40, 3, 21, 75634) But Sardar Vallabhabahi has generously come forward to submit to an inquiry into your charge.
('72', 40, 3, 22, 75728) You resent this offer and make that an additional grievance.
('72', 40, 3, 23, 75789) What he believes about you he has
('72', 40, 4, 24, 75823) 1 Justice Govindrao Madgaonkar of Bombay High court
('72', 41, 0, 1, 75875) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 42
('72', 41, 1, 2, 75916) frankly told you and he undertakes to give the grounds of his belief to any impartial judge.
('72', 41, 1, 3, 76009) He tells you and the public that he never asked anyone to vote against you, and challenges you to prove the contrary.
('72', 41, 1, 4, 76127) What more can he do?
('72', 41, 1, 5, 76148) That you have failed to be elected is surely nobody’s fault, not even yours.
('72', 41, 1, 6, 76225) Bombay is not the Bombay Presidency.
('72', 41, 1, 7, 76262) If you have the ambition of leading Maharashtra, Karnataka and Gujarat, the field is still open to you.
('72', 41, 1, 8, 76366) The golden way is through utterly selfless service, surely, not through a baseless and hysterical agitation for which you must be held responsible.
('72', 41, 1, 9, 76514) The target of this agitation remains unharmed.
('72', 41, 1, 10, 76561) The Sardar has no parliamentary ambition.
('72', 41, 1, 11, 76603) He has no ambition for leadership either.
('72', 41, 1, 12, 76645) Nature has endowed him with certain qualities and he uses them.
('72', 41, 1, 13, 76709) You won’t find him going to the Press and complaining if he loses hold on the populace.
('72', 41, 1, 14, 76797) Therefore, why won’t you see and realize that in the end you will be the only loser?
('72', 41, 1, 15, 76882) Therefore, take the inquiry and let the judge or judges go into the whole matter, and if you do not want it, then bravely and hounourably declare that you had not weighed and valued things properly, and that now you see quite clearly that Sardar Vallabhbhai had nothing to do with your defeat.
('72', 41, 1, 16, 77176) For, that is so far as I can see, the whole of your allegation.
('72', 41, 1, 17, 77240) I think I told you in the course of our conversation that if you convince me that Sardar had poisoned the minds of the voters against you, I for one would cease to have the intimate public connection that I have with him.
('72', 41, 1, 18, 77462) He has told me repeatedly what he has said in his statement 1 which, as I say, was made at my instance.
('72', 41, 1, 19, 77566) You will regard this letter as coming from a friend who wishes well to you.
('72', 41, 2, 20, 77642) Yours sincerely,

('72', 46, 4, 7, 83801) 65. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('72', 46, 5, 8, 83827) July 18, 1937
('72', 46, 6, 9, 83841) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, I read all your letters with good care.
('72', 46, 6, 10, 83900) I had no time to write nor had I any inclination.
('72', 46, 6, 11, 83950) What could I write?
('72', 46, 6, 12, 83970) The situation was changing and developing every moment.
('72', 46, 6, 13, 84026) It did not seem proper to write anything in such circumstances.
('72', 46, 6, 14, 84090) It was imperative to write to others so that their replies could weigh with me as far as possible.
('72', 46, 6, 15, 84189) I cannot specify the impression your letters made on me.
('72', 46, 6, 16, 84246) But I can assert that the letters received from there did not influence me as much as happenings here.
('72', 46, 6, 17, 84349) It may be said that my condition was like that of a woman in labour.
('72', 46, 6, 18, 84418) She cannot give expression to all the turmoil taking place within her.
('72', 46, 6, 19, 84489) Now we know all that happened.
('72', 46, 6, 20, 84520) Let me state this much that whatever Jawaharlal said and did in the Working Committee was marvellous.
('72', 46, 6, 21, 84622) Even otherwise he held a high place in my esteem but now he has risen still higher.
('72', 46, 6, 22, 84706) The beauty of it is that it is so in spite of our continuing difference of opinion.
('72', 46, 6, 23, 84790) The real difficulty starts now.
('72', 46, 6, 24, 84822) It is good that the future depends upon our strength, truth, courage, firmness, hard work and duty.
('72', 46, 6, 25, 84922) What you are doing is right.
('72', 46, 6, 26, 84951) Let the authorities there understand that there is no ‘padding’ in the decision of the Working Committee.
('72', 46, 6, 27, 85057) Every word is significant and everything will be acted upon.
('72', 46, 6, 28, 85118) After all, what has been done has been done in the name of God, with the utmost faith in Him.
('72', 46, 6, 29, 85212) I hope you are well.
('72', 46, 6, 30, 85233) Remain so.

('72', 49, 1, 2, 88245) 70. LETTER TO SHANKERRAO DEO
('72', 49, 2, 3, 88274) July 20, 1937
('72', 49, 3, 4, 88288) MY DEAR DEO, I have now heard from Shri Kelkar.
('72', 49, 3, 5, 88336) He has forgotten to return the cutting which I had sent him.
('72', 49, 3, 6, 88397) 1 I, therefore send my reply from memory.
('72', 49, 3, 7, 88439) About Shri Savarkar, I did refuse to sign the memorial for, as I told those who came to me, it was wholly unnecessary as Shri Savarkar was bound to be released after the coming into force of the new Act, no matter who the Ministers were.
('72', 49, 3, 8, 88677) And that is what has happened.
('72', 49, 3, 9, 88708) The Savarkar Brothers, at least, know that whatever the differences between us as to certain fundamentals, I could never contemplate with equanimity their incarceration.
('72', 49, 3, 10, 88878) Perhaps, Dr. Savarkar 2 will bear me out when I say that I did whaever was in my power after my own way to secure their release.
('72', 49, 3, 11, 89007) And the barrister will perhaps recall the pleasant relations that existed between us when we met for the first time in London and how, when nobody was forthcoming, I presided at the meeting that was held in his honour in London.
('72', 49, 3, 12, 89236) As to my relations with the late Lokamanya Tilak, our defferences were well known and yet we were on the friendliest terms.
('72', 49, 3, 13, 89360) After all, you, Gangadharrao Deshpande and others who know me would perhaps testify that I yield to no one in my regard to Lokamanya for his burning patriotism, his fearlessness, his magnetic personality and his great learning.
('72', 49, 3, 14, 89588) As to office acceptance, I have not retraced my steps.
('72', 49, 3, 15, 89643) I have no repentance for the advice I gave in 1920 to boycott the Legislatures.
('72', 49, 3, 16, 89723) I have not a shadow of doubt that the abstention of the Congress deprived them of the false halo of glory which they had acquired.
('72', 49, 3, 17, 89854) In now strongly advising the Congress to send its representatives to the Legislatures and even to accept office I have responded to the wholly new circumstances that have since come into being.
('72', 49, 3, 18, 90048) I have never made a fetish of foolish consistency.
('72', 49, 4, 19, 90099) 1 Vide “Letter to Shankarrao Deo”, 15 7 1937 2 Brother of V. D. Savarkar
('72', 50, 0, 1, 90172) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 51
('72', 50, 1, 2, 90216) Whilst you are at liberty to publish this letter, my personal inclination is that I should suffer in silence the cruel misinterpretation that Shri Kelkar has given of my motives and attitude.
('72', 50, 1, 3, 90408) The Bombay Chronicle.

('72', 54, 1, 2, 95256) 79. LETTER TO KANTILAL GANDHI
('72', 54, 2, 3, 95286) SEGAON, WARDHA, July 21, 1937
('72', 54, 3, 4, 95316) KANTI, I read both your letters.
('72', 54, 3, 5, 95349) You were keeping in touch with Amtul Salaam even in Bombay.
('72', 54, 3, 6, 95409) I have seen in your letters, too, that you are still clinging to her.
('72', 54, 3, 7, 95479) But I don’t think there is anything wrong in that.
('72', 54, 3, 8, 95530) In the beginning, of course, you made a mistake in showering thoughtless love on her, but there was no impurity even in that.
('72', 54, 3, 9, 95656) You shouldn’t, therefoe, completely break off your relation with her.
('72', 54, 3, 10, 95726) But there is no need at all for you to let her come to Bangalore, not even by way of atonement.
('72', 54, 3, 11, 95822) There is a no need for any atonement.
('72', 54, 3, 12, 95860) You are right in saying that she is a child.
('72', 54, 3, 13, 95905) My advice now is that you yourself should write directly to her and tell her that I had asked your opinion; and that it was foolishness on your part to have shown such excessive love.
('72', 54, 3, 14, 96089) You may tell her that her coming to Bangalore would not benefit either of you in any way, that on the contrary it would upset you, etc.
('72', 54, 3, 15, 96225) Write a fairly long and affectionate letter.
('72', 54, 3, 16, 96270) I will manage the rest.
('72', 54, 3, 17, 96294) Don’t worry about her being hurt.
('72', 54, 3, 18, 96328) Keep writing to her, but only postcards.
('72', 54, 3, 19, 96369) Don’t mind expense on a postcard every week.
('72', 54, 3, 20, 96414) She has asked me to send her your letters to me.
('72', 54, 3, 21, 96463) I will not send to the one about her, but will send the other one in which you have described your discussion with the Christian.
('72', 54, 3, 22, 96593) I will use my discretion every time.
('72', 54, 3, 23, 96630) I will thus satisfy her.
('72', 54, 3, 24, 96655) Try to bear with her having gone to Trivandrum.
('72', 54, 3, 25, 96703) Your admiration for her had its root in a beautiful sentiment.
('72', 54, 3, 26, 96766) Her sacrifice is beyond description.
('72', 54, 3, 27, 96803) Poor girl, she lacks intelligence and has bad health.
('72', 54, 3, 28, 96857) If her health improves and she gets strong, I hope to take much work from her.
('72', 54, 3, 29, 96936) Don’t cut her off completely, but don’t think from this, either, that deep in my heart I want you to permit her to go to Bangalore.
('72', 54, 3, 30, 97068) I fully endorse your decision on that point.
('72', 54, 3, 31, 97113) I am sending this reply by return of post.
('72', 54, 4, 32, 97156) Blessings from BAPU
('72', 54, 5, 33, 97176) From a photostat of the Gujarati: C.W. 7327. Courtesy: Kantilal Gandhi

('72', 59, 3, 4, 103532) SARASWATI, I have your letter.
('72', 59, 3, 5, 103563) Yes, you may certainly come over here if Ramachandran, Paparamma, Father and Kanti approve of it.
('72', 59, 3, 6, 103661) On my part, I shall love to have you here 1.
('72', 59, 4, 7, 103706) Blessings from BAPU
('72', 59, 5, 8, 103726) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 6162. Also C.W. 3435. Courtesy: Kantilal Gandhi
('72', 59, 6, 9, 103810) 89. THE FUNDAMENTAL DIFFERENCE
('72', 59, 7, 10, 103841) It is necessary to contemplate for a moment the fundamental difference between the old and the new order.
('72', 59, 7, 11, 103947) In order fully to realize it we must try to forget for the moment the crushing limitations of the Act.
('72', 59, 7, 12, 104050) Seeing that the Congress has gone to the farthest limit and has accepted office, let every Congressman note the power it has taken.
('72', 59, 7, 13, 104182) Whereas formerly the Ministers were amenable to the control of the Governors, now they are under the control of the Congress.
('72', 59, 7, 14, 104308) They are responsible to the Congress.
('72', 59, 7, 15, 104346) They owe their status to the Congress.
('72', 59, 7, 16, 104385) The Governors and the Civil Service though irremovable are yet answerable to the Ministers.
('72', 59, 7, 17, 104477) The Ministers have effective control over them up to a point.
('72', 59, 7, 18, 104539) That point enables them to consolidate the power of the Congress, i.e., the people.
('72', 59, 7, 19, 104623) The Ministers have the whip hand so long as they act within the four corners of the Act, no matter how distasteful their actions may be to the Governors.
('72', 59, 7, 20, 104777) It will be found upon examination that so long as the people remain non violent, the Congress Ministers have enough freedom of action for national growth.
('72', 59, 7, 21, 104932) For effective use of this power, the people have to give hearty co operation to the Congress and their Ministers.
('72', 59, 7, 22, 105046) If the latter do wrong or they neglect their duty, it is open to any person to complain to the Secretary of the A.I.C.C. and seek redress.
('72', 59, 7, 23, 105185) But no one may take the law into his own hands.
('72', 59, 8, 24, 105233) 1 Vide also “Letter to Amtussalaam”, 23 7 1937
('72', 60, 0, 1, 105280) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 61
('72', 60, 1, 2, 105324) Congressmen should also realize that there is no other political party in the field to question the authority of the Congress.
('72', 60, 1, 3, 105451) For the other parties have never penetrated the villages.
('72', 60, 1, 4, 105509) And that is not a work which can be done in a day.
('72', 60, 1, 5, 105560) So far therefore, as I can see a vast opportunity is at the disposal of the Ministers in terms of the Congress objective of Complete Independence, if only they are honest, selfless, industrious, vigilant and solicitous for the true welfare of the starving millions.
('72', 60, 1, 6, 105826) No doubt, there is great validity in the argument that the Act has left the Ministers no money to spend for the nation building departments.
('72', 60, 1, 7, 105967) But this is largely an illusion.
('72', 60, 1, 8, 106000) I believe with Sir Daniel Hamilton that labour, and not metal, is real money.
('72', 60, 1, 9, 106078) Paper backed by labour is as good as, if not better than, paper backed by gold.
('72', 60, 1, 10, 106158) Here are the sentiments of an English financier 1 who has held high office in India:
('72', 60, 2, 11, 106243) The worst legacy we have left to India is a high grade Service.
('72', 60, 2, 12, 106307) What has been done cannot be undone.
('72', 60, 2, 13, 106344) I should now start something independent.
('72', 60, 2, 14, 106386) Whatever is being done today with ‘money motive’ should in future be based on ‘service motive’.
('72', 60, 2, 15, 106482) Why should teachers and doctors be paid high salaries?
('72', 60, 2, 16, 106537) Why cannot most of the work be done on a co operative basis?
('72', 60, 2, 17, 106598) Why should you worry about capital when there are seven hundred million hands to toil?
('72', 60, 2, 18, 106685) If things are done on a co operative basis, which in other words is modified socialism, money would not be needed, at least not in large quantity.
('72', 60, 2, 19, 106832) I find this verified in little Segaon.
('72', 60, 2, 20, 106871) The four hundred adults of Segaon can easily put ten thousand rupees annually into their pockets if only they would work as I ask them.
('72', 60, 2, 21, 107007) But they won’t.
('72', 60, 2, 22, 107023) They lack co operation, they do not know the art of intelligent labour, they refuse to learn anything new.
('72', 60, 2, 23, 107130) Untouchability blocks the way.
('72', 60, 2, 24, 107161) If someone presented them with one lakh of rupees, they would not turn it to account.
('72', 60, 2, 25, 107247) They are not responsible for this state of affairs.
('72', 60, 2, 26, 107299) We the middle class are.
('72', 60, 2, 27, 107324) What is true of Segaon is true of other villages.
('72', 60, 2, 28, 107374) They will respond by patient effort as they are responding in Segaon though ever so slowly.
('72', 60, 2, 29, 107466) The State, however, can do much in this direction with out having to spend a single pie extra.
('72', 60, 2, 30, 107561) The State officials can be utilized for serving the people instead of harassing them.
('72', 60, 2, 31, 107647) The villagers may not be coerced into doing anything.
('72', 60, 2, 32, 107701) They can be educated to do things which enrich them morally, mentally, physically and economically.
('72', 60, 2, 33, 107801) Harijan, 24 7 1937
('72', 60, 3, 34, 107820) 1 Sir George Schuster
('72', 61, 0, 1, 107842) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 62
('72', 61, 1, 2, 107883) 90. A KHADI JOURNAL
('72', 61, 2, 3, 107903) For the past four years monthly journal has been issued in Wardha called Maharashtra Khadi Patrika.
('72', 61, 2, 4, 108003) It has from month to month registered the progress of khadi in Maharashtra.
('72', 61, 2, 5, 108079) It has hitherto been issued in Marathi.
('72', 61, 2, 6, 108119) But its usefulness and the inclusion of Mahakoshal in the sphere of the Maharashtra Branch of the A.I.S.A. have necessitated conversion of the journal into Hindi.
('72', 61, 2, 7, 108282) The first number is before me.
('72', 61, 2, 8, 108313) The journal is a record of the great progress khadi has made under the very able guidance of Shri Jajuji assisted as he is by a devoted band of workers.
('72', 61, 2, 9, 108466) The price of the journal is only Re.
('72', 61, 2, 10, 108503) 1 per year, a single copy being 11/2 as.
('72', 61, 2, 11, 108544) It has no advertisements.
('72', 61, 2, 12, 108570) It has no padding.
('72', 61, 2, 13, 108589) It contains an unvarnished and faithful account of the progress of khadi within the jurisdiction of the Maharashtra Branch.
('72', 61, 2, 14, 108713) The work touches the social and economic life of the people who are engaged in it.
('72', 61, 2, 15, 108796) For the week, I wish to draw attention to a great experiment the branch is making in enabling spinning to yield a wage equal to any in the villages.
('72', 61, 2, 16, 108945) Three annas per day was the minimum accepted provisionally and in the transition stage instead of eight annas minimum I have aimed at.
('72', 61, 2, 17, 109080) If the buying public were to give intelligent and patriotic help, the objective can be achieved sooner than expected.
('72', 61, 2, 18, 109198) The present experiment is one of increasing wages by inducing the spinners to do their own carding.
('72', 61, 2, 19, 109298) The result has been most gratifying.
('72', 61, 2, 20, 109335) Sixteen workers spun for two weeks slivers carded for them and after being taught carding for one month they spun their own slivers.
('72', 61, 2, 21, 109468) The result was that in the place of 161 chhatanks 1, they spun in the same period 198, the average count increased from 14 to 18, the test from 55 to 59, their earnings from Rs. 12 4 0 to Rs. 24 0 3. This is a striking example of how with intelligence and application earnings can even be doubled.
('72', 61, 3, 22, 109766) Harijan, 24 7 1937
('72', 61, 4, 23, 109785) 1 One sixteenth of a seer
('72', 62, 0, 1, 109811) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 63

('72', 69, 1, 2, 120795) 102. LETTER TO SAMPURNANAND
('72', 69, 2, 3, 120823) July 27, 1937
('72', 69, 3, 4, 120837) BHAI SAMPURNANAND, I had taken your book 1 to Tithal, and had started reading it there.
('72', 69, 3, 5, 120925) I finished it last Saturday, i.e., on July 24. I used to read it whenever I had a few minutes to spare.
('72', 69, 3, 6, 121029) I have read it carefully from cover to cover.
('72', 69, 3, 7, 121075) I liked the book, the language is sweet but it might also be regarded a bit difficult for those totally unacquainted with Sanskrit.
('72', 69, 3, 8, 121207) The glossary of English Hindi and Hindi English equivalents given at the end is useful for the student.
('72', 69, 3, 9, 121311) It is laudable that arguments in favour of socialism have been put forward without any disparagement of others.
('72', 69, 3, 10, 121423) I have no difficulty in accepting almost all the principles of socialism propounded in the book.
('72', 69, 3, 11, 121520) I have also read with care the book 2 by Jayaprakash.
('72', 69, 3, 12, 121574) Can there possibly be any difference between his interpretation and yours?
('72', 69, 3, 13, 121649) Neither in your book nor in his do I find a clear idea how the ultimate revolution in India will be brought about.
('72', 69, 3, 14, 121764) This I could not understand even after discussing it with many others.
('72', 69, 3, 15, 121835) Only the day before yesterday a report of Meherally’s Madras speech came into my hands and I went through it 3 .
('72', 69, 3, 16, 121948) It explains fully what the socialists are doing.
('72', 69, 3, 17, 121997) The object is to start a revolt in every sphere.
('72', 69, 3, 18, 122046) But a revolt has never been possible without violence.
('72', 69, 3, 19, 122101) In your book, however, I find nothing of the kind.
('72', 69, 3, 20, 122152) Have we or have not we acquired strength through peaceful ways such as the civil disobedience or non violent non co operation carried on since 1920?
('72', 69, 3, 21, 122301) You say that the principles of socialism cannot be fully implemented until we have State power.
('72', 69, 3, 22, 122397) Supposing, you ask, a powerful land owner turned a complete socialist, could he well and truly act upon his principles?
('72', 69, 3, 23, 122517) Assuming that he had no punitive power, could an Indian raja who was a socialist be able to implement socialism?
('72', 69, 3, 24, 122630) I recollect your having written that socialism cannot be practised in its entirety until the whole world turns socialist.
('72', 69, 3, 25, 122752) Does this imply that even if we gain complete independence socialism will not
('72', 69, 4, 26, 122830) 1 Samajvad.
('72', 69, 4, 27, 122842) 2 Why Socialism?
('72', 69, 4, 28, 122859) 3 Vide also “Letter to Mahadev Desai”, 27 7 1937., and “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 30 7 1937
('72', 70, 0, 1, 122954) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 71
('72', 70, 1, 2, 122998) be fully or almost fully implemented?
('72', 70, 1, 3, 123036) I hope you have understood my point.
('72', 70, 1, 4, 123073) The purpose behind this question is only to ascertain how far it would be possible for me to accept the socialist principles and the means of their implementation.
('72', 70, 1, 5, 123237) You may reply to this letter at your leisure.
('72', 70, 1, 6, 123283) I am in no hurry.
('72', 70, 2, 7, 123301) Yours, M. K. GANDHI
('72', 70, 3, 8, 123321) From Hindi: C.W. 9940. Courtesy: Kashi Vidyapith.

('72', 70, 6, 14, 123514) What more can I do?

('72', 71, 1, 2, 124588) 105. LETTER TO K. F. NARIMAN
('72', 71, 2, 3, 124617) SEGAON, WARDHA, July 29, 1937
('72', 71, 3, 4, 124647) MY DEAR NARIMAN, I have just seen your letter to the Press.
('72', 71, 3, 5, 124707) 1 You are strange.
('72', 71, 3, 6, 124726) You won’t wait even whilst you are in correspondence with me.
('72', 71, 3, 7, 124788) Your letter compels a public statement from me.
('72', 71, 3, 8, 124836) I want to avoid it if I can.
('72', 71, 3, 9, 124865) The Working Committee has never refused to give you a tribunal.
('72', 71, 3, 10, 124929) It has told you to frame your charge sheet before it can decide whether to give it or not.
('72', 71, 3, 11, 125020) But, if you like, I am willing to ask the President to give you a tribunal even before you have framed your charge sheet.
('72', 71, 3, 12, 125142) If you do not want me to do so, shall I make a statement of my impressions that have been made upon me throughout this sad episode?
('72', 71, 3, 13, 125274) Please wire your reply 2 .
('72', 71, 3, 14, 125301) I may state that Sardar is here.
('72', 71, 3, 15, 125334) He is quite willing to join me in asking the President to give you an independent tribunal.
('72', 71, 4, 16, 125426) Yours sincerely,

('72', 73, 1, 2, 128120) 108. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('72', 73, 2, 3, 128152) SEGAON, WARDHA, July 30, 1937
('72', 73, 3, 4, 128182) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, I hope Mahadev told you yesterday in addition to acknowledging your essay on Hindi 1 that the Viceroy had invited me to Delhi on the 4th for no special reason but merely to have the pleasure of meeting him.
('72', 73, 3, 5, 128409) I replied 2 saying that he had anticipated me for I wanted to seek an interview with him about the ban on Khan Saheb and my desire to visit the Frontier.
('72', 73, 3, 6, 128563) I am accordingly reaching Delhi on the 4th.
('72', 73, 3, 7, 128607) The appointment is for 11.30. Therefore, I hope to be able to leave the same day, returning to Segaon on the 5th.
('72', 73, 3, 8, 128721) But this letter is to send you a copy of Zakir's letter in reply to my letter giving my reaction to the recent riot in Bombay and the wretched Hindi Urdu controversy.
('72', 73, 3, 9, 128888) I thought that I should share with you this considered letter.
('72', 73, 3, 10, 128951) I do not regard the Jhansi election as a rout.
('72', 73, 3, 11, 128998) It is an honourable defeat, giving rise to the hope that if we plod away we can effectively take the Congress message to the Mussalmans.
('72', 73, 3, 12, 129135) But I still abide by my opinion that the mere taking of the message unaccompanied by substantial work in the villages won't answer our purpose in the end.
('72', 73, 3, 13, 129290) But it all depends upon the way in which we want to generate power.
('72', 73, 3, 14, 129358) Meherally's speech in Madras is an eye opener for me.
('72', 73, 3, 15, 129412) I wonder how far he represents the general socialistic view.
('72', 73, 3, 16, 129473) Rajaji has sent me a cutting containing his speech.
('72', 73, 3, 17, 129525) I hope he has sent a copy to you also.
('72', 73, 3, 18, 129564) I call it a bad speech of which you should take notice.
('72', 73, 3, 19, 129620) This is going contrary to the Congress policy as I read it.
('72', 73, 3, 20, 129680) There is also Roy's speech at Madras.
('72', 73, 3, 21, 129718) I take it, you get all such cuttings.
('72', 73, 3, 22, 129756) Nevertheless, for ready reference I enclose the cuttings which Pyarelal has made for me.
('72', 73, 3, 23, 129845) Roy has been writing to me, too.
('72', 73, 3, 24, 129878) You should see his latest letter.
('72', 73, 3, 25, 129912) It will go with this if I have not destroyed it.
('72', 73, 3, 26, 129961) What is your reaction to his attitude?
('72', 73, 3, 27, 130000) As I have already told you I find it difficult to understand him.
('72', 73, 4, 28, 130066) 1 Vide footnote 1, “Letter to Mirabehn”, 10 7 1937 2 Vide “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 27 7 1937 3 Vide also "Letter to M.N. Roy", 27 7 1937
('72', 74, 0, 1, 130207) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 75
('72', 74, 1, 2, 130251) Your calling khadi 'livery of freedom' 1 will live as long as we speak the English language in India.
('72', 74, 1, 3, 130353) It needs a first class poet to translate into Hindi the whole of the thought behind that enchanting phrase.
('72', 74, 1, 4, 130461) For me it is not merely poetry but it enunciates a great truth whose full significance we have yet to grasp.
('72', 74, 2, 5, 130570) BAPU [PS.] Though the paragraph about Roy's speech follows the one about Meherally's it is not to suggest that it is on a par with M's.
