('72', 75, 4, 8, 132009) 111. CRITICISM ANSWERED
('72', 75, 5, 9, 132033) My article 1 on Congress Ministries has attracted attention and evoked criticism.
('72', 75, 5, 10, 132115) The latter demands an answer.
('72', 75, 5, 11, 132145) How can total prohibition be brought about immediately if at all?
('72', 75, 5, 12, 132211) By 'immediately' I mean an immediate planned declaration bringing about total prohibition not later than three years from 14th July 1937, the date of the taking of office by the first Congress Ministry.
('72', 75, 5, 13, 132414) I imagine that it is quite possible to bring it about in two years.
('72', 75, 5, 14, 132482) But not being aware of administrative difficulties I put down three years.
('72', 75, 5, 15, 132557) I count loss of this revenue as of no account whatsoever.
('72', 75, 5, 16, 132615) Prohibition will remain a far cry, if the Congress is to count the cost in a matter of first class national importance.
('72', 75, 5, 17, 132735) Let it be remembered that this drink and drugs revenue is a form of extremely degrading taxation.
('72', 75, 5, 18, 132833) All taxation to be healthy must return tenfold to the tax payer in the form of necessary services.
('72', 75, 5, 19, 132932) Excise makes people pay for their own corruption–moral, mental and physical.
('72', 75, 5, 20, 133009) If falls like a dead weight on those who are least able to bear it.
('72', 75, 5, 21, 133077) The revenue is largely derived, I believe, from industrial labour which together with field labour the Congress almost exclusively represents.
('72', 75, 5, 22, 133220) The loss of revenue is only apparent.
('72', 75, 5, 23, 133258) Removal of this degrading tax enables the drinkers, i.e., the tax payer to earn and spend better.
('72', 75, 5, 24, 133356) Apart, therefore, from the tremendous gain, it means a substantial economic gain to the nation.
('72', 75, 5, 25, 133452) I put this prohibition in the forefront because its result is immediate; Congressmen and especially women have bled for it; national prestige will rise in a manner it cannot by any single act that I can conceive, and the other five Provinces are highly likely to follow
('72', 75, 6, 26, 133722) 1Vide “Congress Ministries”, 17 7 1937
('72', 76, 0, 1, 133761) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 77
('72', 76, 1, 2, 133805) the six.
('72', 76, 1, 3, 133814) The Mussalman non Congress Prime Ministers are equally interested in seeing India sober rather than drunk.
('72', 76, 1, 4, 133921) The cry of great expenditure in preventing illicit distillation is thoughtless where it is not hypocritical.
('72', 76, 1, 5, 134030) India is not America.
('72', 76, 1, 6, 134052) The American example is a hindrance rather than a help to us.
('72', 76, 1, 7, 134114) In America drinking carries no shame with it.
('72', 76, 1, 8, 134160) It is the fashion there to drink.
('72', 76, 1, 9, 134194) It reflects the greatest credit on the determined minority in America that by sheer force of its moral weight it was able to carry through the prohibition measure however shortlived it was.
('72', 76, 1, 10, 134384) I do not regard that experiment to have been a failure.
('72', 76, 1, 11, 134440) I do not despair of America once more returning to it with still greater fervour and better experience in dealing with it.
('72', 76, 1, 12, 134563) It may be that if India carries out prohibition it will hasten the advent of prohibition in America.
('72', 76, 1, 13, 134664) In no part of the world is prohibition as easy to carry out as in India for with us it is only a minority that drinks.
('72', 76, 1, 14, 134783) Drinking is generally considered disrespectable.
('72', 76, 1, 15, 134832) And there are millions, I believe, who have never known what drink is.
('72', 76, 1, 16, 134903) But why should prevention of illicit distillation cost any more than prevention of other crimes?
('72', 76, 1, 17, 135000) I should make illicit distillation heavily punishable and think no more about it.
('72', 76, 1, 18, 135082) Some of it will go on perhaps till doomsday as thieving will.
('72', 76, 1, 19, 135144) I would not set up a special agency to pry into illicit distilleries.
('72', 76, 1, 20, 135214) But I would punish anyone found drunk though not disorderly (in the legal sense) in streets or other public places with a substantial fine or alternatively with indeterminate imprisonment to end when the erring one has earned his or her keep.
('72', 76, 1, 21, 135457) This however, is the negative part.
('72', 76, 1, 22, 135493) Voluntary organizations especially manned by women will work in the labour areas.
('72', 76, 1, 23, 135575) They will visit those who are addicted to drink and try to wean them from the habit.
('72', 76, 1, 24, 135660) Employers of labour will be expected by law to provide cheap,healthy refreshment, reading and entertainment rooms where the working men can go and find shelter, knowledge, health giving food and drink and innocent fun.
('72', 76, 1, 25, 135879) Thus prohibition means a type of adult education of the nation and not merely a closing down of grog shops.
('72', 76, 1, 26, 135987) Prohibition should begin by preventing any new shop from being licensed and closing some that are in danger of becoming a nuisance to the public.
('72', 76, 1, 27, 136133) How far the latter is possible without having to pay heavy compensation I do not know.
('72', 76, 1, 28, 136220) In any case, generally, licences that lapse should not be renewed.
('72', 76, 1, 29, 136287) No new shops should be opened on any account.
('72', 76, 1, 30, 136333) Whatever immediately is possible in law
('72', 77, 0, 1, 136373) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 78
('72', 77, 1, 2, 136414) should be done without a moment's thought so far as the revenue is concerned.
('72', 77, 1, 3, 136492) But what is the meaning or extent of total prohibition?
('72', 77, 1, 4, 136548) Total prohibition is prohibition against sales of intoxicating drinks and drugs, except under medical prescription by a practitioner licensed for the purpose and to be purchasable only at Government depots maintained therefor.
('72', 77, 1, 5, 136775) Foreign liquors in prescribed quantity may be imported for the use of Europeans who cannot or will not do without their drink.
('72', 77, 1, 6, 136902) These will also be sold in bottles in select areas and under authorized certificates.
('72', 77, 1, 7, 136988) Hotels and restaurants will cease to sell intoxicating drinks.
('72', 77, 1, 8, 137051) But what about relief to the peasantry which is oppressed by excessive taxation, rack renting, illegal exactions, indebtedness which can never be fully discharged, illiteracy, superstition and disease, peculiarly due to pauperism?
('72', 77, 1, 9, 137282) Of course it comes first in terms of numbers and economic distress.
('72', 77, 1, 10, 137350) But the relief of the peasantry is an elaborate programme and does not admit of wholesale treatment.
('72', 77, 1, 11, 137451) And no Congress Ministry that does not handle this universal problem can exist for ten days.
('72', 77, 1, 12, 137544) Every Congressman is instinctively interested, if largely academically, in this problem.
('72', 77, 1, 13, 137633) He has inherited the legacy from the birth of the Congress.
('72', 77, 1, 14, 137693) The distress of the peasantry may be said to be the raison d'etre of the Congress.
('72', 77, 1, 15, 137776) There was and is no fear of this subject being neglected.
('72', 77, 1, 16, 137834) I fear the same cannot be said of prohibition.
('72', 77, 1, 17, 137881) It became an integral part of the Congress programme only in 1920. In my opinion, the Congress,, now that it is in power, will put itself morally right only by once for all courageously and drastically dealing with this devastating evil.
('72', 77, 1, 18, 138119) How to solve the problem of education is the problem unfortunately mixed up with the disapperance of the drink revenues.
('72', 77, 1, 19, 138240) No doubt there are ways and means of raising fresh taxation.
('72', 77, 1, 20, 138301) Professors Shah and Khambhatta have shown that even this poor country is capable of raising fresh taxation.
('72', 77, 1, 21, 138409) Riches have not yet been sufficiently taxed.
('72', 77, 1, 22, 138454) In this of all countries in the world possession of inordinate wealth by individuals should be held as a crime against Indian humanity.
('72', 77, 1, 23, 138590) Therefore the maximum limit of taxation of riches beyond a certain margin can never be reached.
('72', 77, 1, 24, 138686) In England, I understand, they have already gone as far as 70% of the earnings beyond a prescribed figure.
('72', 77, 1, 25, 138793) There is no reason why India should not go to a much higher figure.
('72', 77, 1, 26, 138861) Why should there not be death duties?
('72', 78, 0, 1, 138899) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 79
('72', 78, 1, 2, 138943) Those sons of millionaires who are of age and yet inherit their parents' wealth, are losers for the very inheritance.
('72', 78, 1, 3, 139061) The nation thus becomes a double loser.
('72', 78, 1, 4, 139101) For the inheritance should rightly belong to the nation.
('72', 78, 1, 5, 139158) And the nation loses again in that the full faculties of the heirs are not drawn out, being crushed under the load of riches.
('72', 78, 1, 6, 139284) That death duties cannot be imposed by provincial Governments does not affect my argument.
('72', 78, 1, 7, 139375) But as a nation we are so backward in education that we cannot hope to fulfil our obligations to the nation in this respect in a given time during this generation, if the programme is to depend on money.
('72', 78, 1, 8, 139579) I have therefore made bold, even at the risk of losing all reputation for constructive ability, to suggest that education should be self supporting.
('72', 78, 1, 9, 139728) By education I mean an all round drawing out of the best in child and man–body, mind and spirit.
('72', 78, 1, 10, 139825) Literacy is not the end of education nor even the beginning.
('72', 78, 1, 11, 139886) It is only one of the means whereby man and woman can be educated.
('72', 78, 1, 12, 139953) Literacy in itself is no education.
('72', 78, 1, 13, 139989) I would therefore begin the child's education by teaching it a useful handicraft and enabling it to produce from the moment it begins its training.
('72', 78, 1, 14, 140137) Thus every school can be made self supporting, the condition being that the State takes over the manufactures of these schools.
('72', 78, 1, 15, 140265) I hold that the highest development of the mind and the soul is possible under such a system of education.
('72', 78, 1, 16, 140372) Only every handicraft has to be taught not merely mechanically as is done today but scientifically, i.e., the child should know the why and the wherefore of every process.
('72', 78, 1, 17, 140544) I am not writing this without some confidence, because it has the backing of experience.
('72', 78, 1, 18, 140633) This method is being adopted more or less completely wherever spinning is being taught to workers.
('72', 78, 1, 19, 140732) I have myself taught sandal making and even spinning on these lines with good results.
('72', 78, 1, 20, 140819) This method does not exclude a knowledge of history and such general information by word of mouth.
('72', 78, 1, 21, 140918) One imparts ten times as much in this manner as by reading and writing.
('72', 78, 1, 22, 140990) The signs of the alphabet may be taught later when the pupil has learnt to distinguish wheat from chaff and when he has somewhat developed his or her tastes.
('72', 78, 1, 23, 141148) This is a revolutionary proposal but it saves immense labour and enables a student to acquire in one year what he may take much longer learn.
('72', 78, 1, 24, 141290) This means all round economy.
('72', 78, 1, 25, 141320) Of course the pupil learns mathematics whilst he is learning his handicraft.
('72', 79, 0, 1, 141397) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 80
('72', 79, 1, 2, 141438) I attach the greatest importance to primary education which according to my conception should be equal to the present matriculation less English.
('72', 79, 1, 3, 141584) If all the collegians were all of a sudden to forget their knowledge, the loss sustained by the sudden lapse of the memory of say a few lacs of collegians would be as nothing compared to the loss that the nation has sustained and is sustaining through the ocean of darkness that surrounds three hundred millions.
('72', 79, 1, 4, 141897) The measure of illiteracy is no adequate measure of the prevailing ignorance among the millions of villagers.
('72', 79, 1, 5, 142007) I would revolutionize college education and relate it to national necessities.
('72', 79, 1, 6, 142086) There would be degrees for mechanical and other engineers.
('72', 79, 1, 7, 142145) They would be attached to the different industries which should pay for the training of the graduates they need.
('72', 79, 1, 8, 142258) Thus the Tatas would be expected to run a college for training engineers under the supervision of the State, the mill associations would run among them a college for training graduates whom they need.
('72', 79, 1, 9, 142459) Similarly for the other industries that may be named.
('72', 79, 1, 10, 142513) Commerce will have its college.
('72', 79, 1, 11, 142545) There remain arts, medicine and agriculture.
('72', 79, 1, 12, 142590) Several private arts colleges are today self supporting.
('72', 79, 1, 13, 142647) The State would, therefore, cease to run its own.
('72', 79, 1, 14, 142697) Mecical colleges would be attached to certified hospitals.
('72', 79, 1, 15, 142756) As they are popular among monied men they may be expected by voluntary contributions to support medical colleges.
('72', 79, 1, 16, 142870) And agricultural colleges to be worthy of the name must be self supporting.
('72', 79, 1, 17, 142946) I have a painful experience of some agricultural graduates.
('72', 79, 1, 18, 143006) Their knowledge is superficial.
('72', 79, 1, 19, 143038) They lack practical experience.
('72', 79, 1, 20, 143070) But if they had their apprenticeship on farms which are self sustained and answer the requirements of the country, they would not have to gain experience after getting their degrees and at the expense of their employers.
('72', 79, 1, 21, 143291) This is not a fanciful picture.
('72', 79, 1, 22, 143323) If we would but shed our mental laziness, it would appear to be an eminently reasonable and practical solution of the problem of education that faces the Congress Ministers and therefore the Congress.
('72', 79, 1, 23, 143524) If the declarations recently made on behalf of the British Government mean what they sound to the ear, the Ministers have the organizing and organized ability of the Civil Service at their disposal to execute their policy.
('72', 79, 1, 24, 143747) The Services have learnt the art of reducing to practice the policies laid down for them even by capricious Governors and Viceroys.
('72', 79, 1, 25, 143879) Let the Ministers lay down a well conceived but determined policy, and let the Services redeem the promise made on their behalf and prove worthy of the salt they eat.
('72', 80, 0, 1, 144046) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY, 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 81
('72', 80, 1, 2, 144090) There remains the question of teachers.
('72', 80, 1, 3, 144130) I like Prof.
('72', 80, 1, 4, 144143) K.T. Shah's idea expressed in his article elsewhere of conscription being applied to men and women of learning.
('72', 80, 1, 5, 144255) 1 The may be conscripted to give a number of years, say, five, to the teaching for which they may be qualified, on a salary not exceeding their maintenance on a scale in keeping with the economic level of the country.
('72', 80, 1, 6, 144473) The very high salaries that the teachers and professors in the higher branches demand must go.
('72', 80, 1, 7, 144568) The village teacher has to be replaced by more competent ones.
('72', 80, 1, 8, 144631) My Suggestion to turn jails into reformatories to make them self supporting has not excited much criticism.
('72', 80, 1, 9, 144739) Only one remark I have noticed.
('72', 80, 1, 10, 144771) If they turn out marketable goods, I am told, they will unfairly compete with the open market.
('72', 80, 1, 11, 144866) There is no substance in the remark.
('72', 80, 1, 12, 144903) But I anticipated it in 1922 when I was a prisoner in Yeravda.
('72', 80, 1, 13, 144966) I discussed my plan with the then Home Member, the then Inspector General of Prisons, and two Superintendents who were in charge of the prison in succession.
('72', 80, 1, 14, 145124) Not one of them cavilled at my suggestion.
('72', 80, 1, 15, 145167) The then Home Member was even enthusiastic about it and wanted me to put my scheme in writing, if he could obtain the permission from the Governor.
('72', 80, 1, 16, 145315) But His Excellency would not hear of a prisoner making suggestions regarding jail administration!
('72', 80, 1, 17, 145413) And so my scheme never saw the light of day.
('72', 80, 1, 18, 145458) But the author believes in its soundness today just as much as when he first made it.
('72', 80, 1, 19, 145544) This was the plan: All industries that were not paying should be stopped.
('72', 80, 1, 20, 145618) All the jails should be turned into hand spinning and hand weaving institutions.
('72', 80, 1, 21, 145699) They should include (wherever possible) cotton growing to producing the finest cloth.
('72', 80, 1, 22, 145785) I suggest that almost every facility for this purpose already exists in the prison.
('72', 80, 1, 23, 145869) Only the will has to be there.
('72', 80, 1, 24, 145900) Prisoners must be treated as defectives, not criminals to be looked down upon.
('72', 80, 1, 25, 145979) Warders should cease to be terrors of the prisoners, but the jail officials should be their friends and instructors”.
('72', 80, 1, 26, 146097) The only one indispensable condition is that the State should buy all the khadi that may be turned out by the prisons at cost price.
('72', 80, 1, 27, 146230) And if there is a surplus, the public may get it at a trifling higher price to cover the expense of running a sales depot.
('72', 80, 1, 28, 146353) If my suggestion is adopted, the jails will be linked to the villages and they will spread to them the message of khadi and discharged prisoners may become model citizens of the State.
('72', 80, 2, 29, 146538) 1 Vide also the following item.
('72', 81, 0, 1, 146570) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 82
('72', 81, 1, 2, 146611) I am reminded that salt being a Central subject, the poor Ministers cannot do anything.
('72', 81, 1, 3, 146699) I should be painfully surprised if they cannot.
('72', 81, 1, 4, 146747) The Central Government has to operate in provincial territories.
('72', 81, 1, 5, 146812) Provincial Governments are bound to protect people within their jurisdiction against being dealt with unjustly even by the Centre.
('72', 81, 1, 6, 146943) And the Governors are bound to back the protests of their Ministers against unjust dealings with the people of their respective Provinces.
('72', 81, 1, 7, 147082) If the Ministers are on the alert, there should be no difficulty in the poor villagers helping themselves to the salt without undue interference on behalf of the Central authority.
('72', 81, 1, 8, 147263) I have no fear of such undue interference.
('72', 81, 1, 9, 147306) In conclusion, I should like to add that whatever I have said about prohibition, education and jails is presented merely for the consideration of Congress Ministers and the interested public.
('72', 81, 1, 10, 147498) I may not withhold from the public the views which–however strange, visionary or unpractical they may appear to critics–I have held tenaciously for long.
('72', 81, 2, 11, 147652) Harijan, 31 7 1937

('72', 83, 9, 10, 149525) Your attitude is most bewildering.
('72', 83, 9, 11, 149560) Before I issue my statement I make this offer.
('72', 83, 9, 12, 149607) I am prepared to go through the whole of your charges and if I feel convinced that you have been unjustly dealt with by the Sardar, I shall unhesitatingly say so and do everything humanly possible to undo the mischief.
('72', 83, 9, 13, 149826) If, on the other hand, I find against you and you are not satisfied with my findings, I shall request Bahadurji or Sir Govindrao Madgaonkar to go through the recorded evidence and review my findings.
('72', 83, 9, 14, 150026) All these proceedings need not be public so far as I am concerned.
('72', 83, 9, 15, 150093) If the findings are against you, you should have an opportunity of tendering an apology and making a full and frank confession of your weakness and the wrong done to the public, the Sardar and other colleagues.
('72', 83, 9, 16, 150304) But if you want the proceedings to be public, I do not mind.
('72', 83, 9, 17, 150365) You need not even know what is being done.
('72', 83, 9, 18, 150408) I had no desire to be in this affair at all.
('72', 83, 9, 19, 150453) But you wanted me to intercede.
('72', 83, 9, 20, 150485) Many friends, including Mr. Bharucha, have been pressing me to do likewise.
('72', 83, 9, 21, 150561) I may not now sit still.
('72', 83, 9, 22, 150586) I hope you will understand my anxiety to see that full justice is done to you and avoid everything that may possibly harm you without cause.
('72', 83, 9, 23, 150727) If you desire an enquiry by me, please send me your charge sheet and a precis of your evidence.
('72', 83, 9, 24, 150823) I would send it to the Sardar and any other colleagues against whom you have any grievance and after having had his and their reply, I shall call for such evidence as may be required, if any.

('72', 89, 5, 7, 158616) 125. FOREWORD TO “THE QUESTION OF LANGUAGES”
('72', 89, 6, 8, 158661) August 3, 1937 I have very carefully gone through Jawaharlal Nehru’s essay 3 on the Hindi Urdu question.
('72', 89, 6, 9, 158766) The question has latterly become an unfor tunate controversy.
('72', 89, 6, 10, 158828) There is no valid reason for the ugly turn it has taken.
('72', 89, 6, 11, 158885) Be that as it may, Jawaharlal’s essay is a valuable contribution to a proper elucidation of the whole subject considered from the national and purely educational point of view.
('72', 89, 6, 12, 159062) His constructive suggestions, if they are widely accepted by persons concerned, should put an end to the controversy which has taken a communal turn.
('72', 89, 6, 13, 159212) The suggestions are exhaustive and eminently reasonable.

('72', 89, 10, 18, 159449) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, I am writing this on the train taking us to Delhi.
('72', 89, 10, 19, 159520) Herewith is my Foreword or whatever it may be called.
('72', 89, 10, 20, 159574) I could not give you anything elaborate.
('72', 89, 10, 21, 159615) You have “perhaps” 5 before Pushtu and Punjabi.
('72', 89, 10, 22, 159663) I suggest your removing the adverb.
('72', 89, 10, 23, 159699) Khan Saheb for instance will never give up
('72', 89, 11, 24, 159742) 1 G. Ramachandran’s sister’s daughter, Kanti Gandhi’s fiancee 2 G. Ramachandran’s sister 3 For the suggestions made therein, vide” The Question Of Languages”, 21 8 1937 ; also “Hindi Urdu”, 21 8 1937. 4 Vide also the following item.

('72', 90, 0, 1, 160065) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 91
('72', 90, 1, 2, 160108) Pushtu.
('72', 90, 1, 3, 160116) I believe it is written in some script, I forget which.
('72', 90, 1, 4, 160172) And Punjabi?
('72', 90, 1, 5, 160185) The Sikhs will die for Punjabi written in Gurmukhi.
('72', 90, 1, 6, 160237) There is no elegance about that script.
('72', 90, 1, 7, 160277) But I understand that it was specially invented like Sindhi to isolate the Sikhs from the other Hindus.
('72', 90, 1, 8, 160381) Whether such was the case or not, it seems to me impossible at present to persuade the Sikhs to give up Gurmukhi.
('72', 90, 1, 9, 160495) You have suggested a common script to be evolved out of the four Southern languages.
('72', 90, 1, 10, 160580) It seems to me to be as easy for them to substitute Devanagari as a mixture of the four.
('72', 90, 1, 11, 160669) From a practical standpoint, the four do not admit of an invented mixture.
('72', 90, 1, 12, 160744) I would, therefore, suggest your confining yourself to the general recommendation that wherever possible the provincial languages which have vital connection with Sanskrit, if they are not off shoots from it, should adopt revised Devanagari.
('72', 90, 1, 13, 160986) You may know that this propaganda is going on.
('72', 90, 1, 14, 161033) Then, if you think like me, you should not hesitate to express the hope that as Hindus and Muslims are one day bound to be one at heart, they will also, who speak Hindustani, adopt one script, i.
('72', 90, 1, 15, 161229) e., Devanagari, because of its being more scientific and being akin to the great provincial scripts of the languages descended from Sanskrit.
('72', 90, 1, 16, 161371) If you adopt my suggestions in part or in toto you will have no difficulty in laying your finger on the spots requiring the necessary changes.
('72', 90, 1, 17, 161514) I had intended to do so myself in order to save your time.
('72', 90, 1, 18, 161573) But I must not put that strain on my system just now.
('72', 90, 1, 19, 161627) I take it that my endorsement of your suggestions does not mean that I must ask the Hindi Sammelan to give up the use of the word Hindi.
('72', 90, 1, 20, 161764) I am sure, that cannot be your meaning.
('72', 90, 1, 21, 161804) I have taken it to the farthest limit possible as far as I can think.
('72', 90, 1, 22, 161874) If you cannot accept my suggestions, it would be better for the sake of accuracy to add the following sentence to the ‘Foreword’: ‘At any rate I have no hesitation in heartily endorsing them in a general way.’ I hope Indu’s 1 operation will go off well.

('72', 97, 1, 2, 172096) 135. ITS DEEPER MEANING
('72', 97, 2, 3, 172120) The thought world of khadi workers had undergone a revolu tion since the objective of khadi became the steady improvement of the artisans engaged in its production rather than its supply at as cheap rates as possible.
('72', 97, 2, 4, 172338) The fact that the increase in the wages has not much, if at all, affected the public has given a confidence to the workers which they had not when the policy was revolutionized.
('72', 97, 2, 5, 172516) The workers are beginning to realize that they have to touch every department of the lives of the artisans and try to bringabout an all round improvement in their lot.
('72', 97, 2, 6, 172684) Thus one reads with joy the following in the Maharashtra khadi Patrika noticed the other day in these columns: 1
('72', 97, 3, 7, 172797) In Korutala khadi workers are using the paper prepared by the local paper makers and are inducing local artisans to make twine from flax which is locally grown.
('72', 97, 3, 8, 172958) Many artisans have the bad habit of spitting fairly often just where they are sitting.
('72', 97, 3, 9, 173045) Eighty two such have been supplied with small earthen spittoons for use.
('72', 97, 3, 10, 173118) The manager of a zamindar in Metpally has been induced to stop begar.
('72', 97, 3, 11, 173188) In Tendur the weavers have been induced to adopt measures to prevent incurring debts.
('72', 97, 3, 12, 173274) Thus they have reduced marriage expenses to Rs. 30 as the maximum, stopped feasts at the time of the first shave, stopped drinking on ceremonial occasions, caste dinners on deaths.
('72', 97, 3, 13, 173455) Measures have been adopted to induce the womenfolk to use khadi saris (cheap patterns have been devised for the purpose), to save the increase in the artisans’ income against a rainy day.
('72', 97, 3, 14, 173643) In Savli a substantial rise has been given to those who will not incur debts and will card and spin one seer of not less than twenty counts of yarn of eighty per cent strength in one month.
('72', 97, 3, 15, 173833) Thus the following speaks for itself:
('72', 97, 4, 16, 173871) COUNT CURRENT RATE INCREASED RATE Rs. As.
('72', 97, 4, 17, 173913) Rs. As.
('72', 97, 4, 18, 173921) 22 2 8 0 3 4 0 24 2 14 0 3 12 0
('72', 97, 5, 19, 173953) 1 Vide “A Khadi Journal”, 24 7 1937
('72', 98, 0, 1, 173989) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 99
('72', 98, 1, 2, 174032) 26 3 4 0 4 4 0 28 3 10 0 4 12 0 30 4 0 0 5 4 0 32 4 8 0 6 0 0 This new rate enables the workers to make four annas per day of eight hours.
('72', 98, 1, 3, 174171) In Sindevahi they have agreed to open a co operative store.
('72', 98, 1, 4, 174231) I have given but a condensation of the original in Hindi which I commend to the diligent student of the working of the new objective.
('72', 98, 2, 5, 174365) Harijan, 7 8 1937
('72', 98, 3, 6, 174383) 136. NOT A PRIZE
('72', 98, 4, 7, 174400) I have been receiving several letters from different provinces protesting against the exclusion of their or their friends’ names from ministerships and asking me to intervene.
('72', 98, 4, 8, 174576) I do not think there is a single province from which such complaints have not been received.
('72', 98, 4, 9, 174669) In some such letters dire results including communal riots have been threatened, if the excluded person’s claims are not considered.
('72', 98, 4, 10, 174802) In the first instance let me say that I have not intervened in any single case in the selection of ministers.
('72', 98, 4, 11, 174912) I have no right, having completely withdrawn from the Congress, to intervene in such matters, even if I had the wish which I have not.
('72', 98, 4, 12, 175047) My participation in Congress affairs is confined to tendering advice on the issues involved in office acceptance and on the policies to be pursued in the prosecution of our march to the goal of Complete Independence.
('72', 98, 4, 13, 175264) But it seems to me that my numerous correspondents who have been writing voluminously think that ministerships are prizes for past services and that certain Congressmen can demand their inclusion.
('72', 98, 4, 14, 175461) I venture to suggest to them that ministerships are avenues to service which those who are called to it should render cheerfully and to the best of their ability.
('72', 98, 4, 15, 175624) There can therefore never be a scramble for these offices.
('72', 98, 4, 16, 175683) It would be decidedly wrong to create ministerships for the sake of conciliating interests.
('72', 98, 4, 17, 175775) If I were a Prime Minister and I was pestered with such claims, I should tell my electors to choose another leader.
('72', 98, 4, 18, 175891) These offices have to be held lightly, not tightly.
('72', 98, 4, 19, 175943) They are or should be crowns of thorns never of renown.
('72', 98, 4, 20, 175999) Offices have been taken in order to see if they enable us to quicken the pace at which we are
('72', 99, 0, 1, 176093) 100 THE COOLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 99, 1, 2, 176135) moving towards our goal.
('72', 99, 1, 3, 176160) It would be tragic if self seekers or misguided zealots were allowed to impede the progress by imposing themselves on Prime Ministers.
('72', 99, 1, 4, 176295) If it was necessary to have assurances from those who have ultimately to clothe ministers with authority, it is doubly necessary to have assurances of understanding, of loyalty beyond suspicion and of willing obedience to discipline.
('72', 99, 1, 5, 176529) The grim fight in which the country is engaged cannot be won if Congressmen do not show in their conduct a sufficient measure of selflessness, discipline and faith in the means enunciated by the Congress for the attainment of the goal.
('72', 99, 1, 6, 176765) Thanks to the Karachi resolution 1, ministerships under the Congress aegis have no pecuniary attraction.
('72', 99, 1, 7, 176870) I must say in parenthesis that considering Rs. 500 as if it was the minimum instead of the maximum was a mistake.
('72', 99, 1, 8, 176984) Rs. 500 was the last limit.
('72', 99, 1, 9, 177012) Had we not got used to the excessive scale of salaries imposed upon the country, we would have regarded Rs. 500 to be excessive.
('72', 99, 1, 10, 177141) The Congress scale has been generally, for the past seventeen years at least, Rs. 75 per month.
('72', 99, 1, 11, 177237) In its three great constructive all India departments, national education, khadi and village industries, the authorized scale has been Rs. 75. These departments contain men who are good enough, so far as ability is concerned, any day to be ministers.
('72', 99, 1, 12, 177488) They have distingu ished educationists, lawyers, chemists and merchants, who if they were so minded, could easily command over Rs. 500 per month.
('72', 99, 1, 13, 177634) Why should the fact of becoming a minister make the great difference we see?
('72', 99, 1, 14, 177711) But the die is perhaps cast.
('72', 99, 1, 15, 177740) My remarks represent my personal opinion.
('72', 99, 1, 16, 177782) I have too high a regard for the Prime Ministers to question their judgment and wisdom.
('72', 99, 1, 17, 177870) No doubt they thought that this was the best in the circumstances facing them.
('72', 99, 1, 18, 177949) The point I wish to make, in answer to my correspondents, is that these offices have not been taken in view of the emoluments they offer.
('72', 99, 1, 19, 178087) And then they have to be given to those only in the party who are best able to discharge the duty to which they are called.
('72', 99, 1, 20, 178211) And, lastly, the acid test is that the choice must commend itself to the members of the party to whom the Prime Ministers owe their nomination.
('72', 99, 1, 21, 178355) No Prime Minister can for one moment impose a man or woman of his choice on the party.
('72', 99, 1, 22, 178442) He is Chief because he enjoys the full confidence of his party as to ability, knowledge of persons, and the other qualities that mark out one for leadership.
('72', 99, 1, 23, 178600) Harijan, 7 8 1937

('72', 100, 2, 3, 178765) The A. I. V. I. A. has issued its first bulletin.
('72', 100, 2, 4, 178815) After describing the various activities conducted in Maganwadi, the Headquarters at Wardha, it ends: 1
('72', 100, 3, 5, 178918) There is a great deal of slackness on the part of members and agents in submitting their reports.
('72', 100, 3, 6, 179016) Members are reminded that according toour rules no report is received from a member for three consecutive quarters, his membership will lapse.
('72', 100, 3, 7, 179159) We regret to say that in accordance with this rule the membership of several has lapsed.
('72', 100, 3, 8, 179248) The reason for such slackness is probably that members think that it is not worthwhile reporting unless there is something noteworthy to mention.
('72', 100, 3, 9, 179394) Their work is in the nature of routine, and once they have reported they think that so long as they have not done anything new they need not report.
('72', 100, 3, 10, 179543) This again is a mistake.
('72', 100, 3, 11, 179568) It is quite essential for the proper working of the Association and for exchange of experiences through the medium of this bulletin that members and agents should carry on their work in close touch with the Central Office and keep it duly informed of their activities by means of full and regular reports.

('72', 102, 12, 20, 183158) 143. WORKERS OF KATHIAWAR
('72', 102, 13, 21, 183184) A gathering of some workers of Kathiawar was held some time ago in Bhavnagar.
('72', 102, 13, 22, 183262) After a great deal of discussion, a resolution was passed, at the instance of Shri Nanabhai, that they should do social work under my guidance and be governed by the restrictions imposed by me.
('72', 102, 13, 23, 183456) Some of these gentlemen were to come to me to discuss the
('72', 102, 14, 24, 183514) 1 Vide the following item.
('72', 103, 0, 1, 183541) 104 THE COOLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 103, 1, 2, 183583) matter.
('72', 103, 1, 3, 183591) On receiving their letter, I tried to prevent their coming by writing to them that their journey would perhaps be in vain as they would get from me advice only on what I regard as constructive work.
('72', 103, 1, 4, 183790) However, this failed to convince them and, Shri Jagjivandas, Balwan trai 1, Fulchand 2, Dhebarbhai 3 and Vajubhai 4 came over.
('72', 103, 1, 5, 183917) At the end of a discussion lasting two hours it was decided that I should write the substance of my advice in Harijanbandhu.
('72', 103, 1, 6, 184042) I agreed to comply with this request.
('72', 103, 1, 7, 184080) The first discussion was about the letter 5 I had written to Shri Dani.
('72', 103, 1, 8, 184152) I had been told that in that letter I had done grave injustice to the workers of Kathiawar by calling them useless, selfish, or unprincipled or all this at the same time.
('72', 103, 1, 9, 184323) In my reply I had stated that I was not in the habit of writing such crude letters and I asked for a copy of my letter.
('72', 103, 1, 10, 184443) In reply to this letter the above gentlemen came in person and produced the original letter 6, which runs as follows.
('72', 103, 1, 11, 184561) I said that those who took this letter to be censorious could be regarded as ignorant of Gujarati.
('72', 103, 1, 12, 184660) Its meaning is clear.
('72', 103, 1, 13, 184682) If public life in Kathiawar is actually in such a mess as described by Shri Dani, public servants must be guilty of one of the three or all the three shortcomings.
('72', 103, 1, 14, 184846) These gentlemen agreed that my letter could not be construed in any other way.
('72', 103, 1, 15, 184925) With reference to this they inquired whether anyone had sent me names of persons who had acted in a manner not befitting Kathiawaris?
('72', 103, 1, 16, 185059) I replied that I had published the names which had been sent to me and regarding whom I believed the allegations to be true.
('72', 103, 1, 17, 185184) The following points were then discussed: 1.Gandhiji to guide 2.[Kathiawar] Political Conference 3.The Prajamandal and the Conference 4.The restrictions and the injustices in the States 5.Organizing labour to improve their conditions 6.Constructive work like khadi, service of Harijans, etc.
('72', 103, 1, 18, 185476) 7.Whether these activities should be carried on indepen dently or under one organization.

('72', 104, 1, 2, 185730) Regarding my guidance, I declared that I could not shoulder the burden.
('72', 104, 1, 3, 185802) I have neither the capacity nor the inclination to guide anyone from a distance, hence they should write off my name.
('72', 104, 1, 4, 185920) If my advice is sought in a particular matter, I have always been giving it, and I regard it as my dharma to do so.
('72', 104, 1, 5, 186036) In my opinion, Kathiawaris should appoint a leader from amongst persons living there and, such a leader should be reappointed every year.
('72', 104, 1, 6, 186174) This would give them self confidence and make them self reliant.
('72', 104, 1, 7, 186239) The belief, whether true or otherwise, that Kathiawaris cannot accept for long any leader selected from amongst themselves, will also be dispelled.
('72', 104, 1, 8, 186387) While discussing other activities, I gave the opinion that if I had my way, I would engage everyone in khadi work, service of Harijans and village industries.
('72', 104, 1, 9, 186546) Even if everyone was to be engaged in this manner, many more workers would be needed than are at present available.
('72', 104, 1, 10, 186662) But those who do not find that kind of service congenial should select whatever field they preferred and put their heart and soul into it.
('72', 104, 1, 11, 186801) Having once made the choice one should not go on changing one’s field of work.
('72', 104, 1, 12, 186880) If a session of the Political Conference must be called, it should be called keeping in view the restrictions imposed by me in Bhavnagar and in accordance with the practice established in Porbandar.
('72', 104, 1, 13, 187079) It must not be held outside the boundaries of Indian States.
('72', 104, 1, 14, 187140) If permission is granted only in a single State it could be held there year after year.
('72', 104, 1, 15, 187228) It could be held in Amreli 1, but it would be preferable to hold it in a State in Kathiawar.
('72', 104, 1, 16, 187321) There should be a Prajamandal in each State.
('72', 104, 1, 17, 187366) Everyone should render to the best of his ability whatever service he can to these bodies.
('72', 104, 1, 18, 187457) Within the limits imposed by me, the Political Conference cannot freely discuss such questions as injustices practised in different States, etc.
('72', 104, 1, 19, 187602) This does not imply that these cannot bediscussed anywhere.
('72', 104, 1, 20, 187662) The people of a particular State may certainly discuss those questions, they should try and get justice in those particular matters, for it is their dharma to do so.
('72', 104, 1, 21, 187828) Thus, in whichever States restrictive orders are issued or injustices perpetrated, they could be freely discussed there.
('72', 104, 1, 22, 187949) Only truth and non violence should be the restraining principles in these cases.
('72', 104, 1, 23, 188030) Whatever is said should be hundred per cent true; it should be free from exaggeration and discourtesy.
('72', 104, 1, 24, 188133) We should not hold out threats about anything which we are not capable of doing.
('72', 104, 1, 25, 188214) We have to tolerate many things in this world because we are
('72', 104, 2, 26, 188275) 1 A town in Kathiawar which however formed part of the Baroda State
('72', 105, 0, 1, 188343) 106 THE COOLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 105, 1, 2, 188385) powerless In order to improve its condition labour must get organized.
('72', 105, 1, 3, 188456) Everyone knows that I prefer the policy which has been adopted by Shrimati Anasuyabehn 1 in Ahmedabad.
('72', 105, 1, 4, 188559) I have not adopted the principle of organizing labour for political purposes.
('72', 105, 1, 5, 188637) They may take interest in politics as all citizens should.
('72', 105, 1, 6, 188696) But politics should not be the motive in forming an organization.
('72', 105, 1, 7, 188762) People should form organizations having regard to their vocations and their special circumstances.
('72', 105, 1, 8, 188861) We already have in the Congress an organization to deal with political issues and to train men for the work.
('72', 105, 1, 9, 188970) It has to protect the political rights of labourers in the same way as it has to protect those of others.
('72', 105, 1, 10, 189076) As a matter of fact, the political rights of labourers are not and should not be opposed to those of others.
('72', 105, 1, 11, 189185) This means that the work of the Congress safeguards [the interests of] and represents all.
('72', 105, 1, 12, 189276) It is my experience that if labour unions are politically motivated, there is an unnecessary rivalry between [political] workers, labourers become pawns in their game and, as a result, labourers have to suffer and the unions get a bad name.
('72', 105, 1, 13, 189517) Labour may also perhaps eye with suspicion those who come claiming to be their friends.
('72', 105, 1, 14, 189605) Those who form labour unions in order to improve their conditions should also be adept in the art of doing so.
('72', 105, 1, 15, 189716) If anyone without ability tries to form a union because he wants to, it cannot be done.
('72', 105, 1, 16, 189804) Amongst all these activities, I would give the highest place to khadi, eradication of untouchability, service of Harijans, village industries and prohibition.
('72', 105, 1, 17, 189963) If this cannot be done, I believe that other activities are not worthwhile.
('72', 105, 1, 18, 190039) The belief that constructive work can be carried on only if supported by other activities is, in my opinion, born out of ignorance.
('72', 105, 1, 19, 190171) It is my opinion that the strength that can be generated by firm and determined adherence to constructive activity is far superior to the strength gained by any other type of work.
('72', 105, 1, 20, 190352) I know that ordinarily no one is interested in these constructive activities.
('72', 105, 1, 21, 190430) I can think of two reasons for this.
('72', 105, 1, 22, 190467) One reason is that these activities bring one into contact with the villages.
('72', 105, 1, 23, 190545) Our workers have been brought up in cities, they have been educated in English schools and colleges, hence they have little interest in the life of rural people.
('72', 105, 1, 24, 190707) They do not regard themselves as fit only for living in villages and are ignorant of the art of mixing with the villagers.
('72', 105, 1, 25, 190830) The other reason is our idleness and the ignorance born of it.
('72', 105, 1, 26, 190893) Khadi and such other constructive work demand constant vigilance, effort, study and
('72', 105, 2, 27, 190977) 1 Anasuyabehn Sarabhai
('72', 106, 0, 1, 191000) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 107
('72', 106, 1, 2, 191044) diligence.
('72', 106, 1, 3, 191055) We are not prepared to render these; and later, when we cannot create interest in these great tasks, rather than blame ourselves we conclude that such work is dull.
('72', 106, 1, 4, 191220) I regard this as a serious shortcoming and have, therefore, come to the conclusion that so long as we do not do credit to these tasks, our other tasks will not be wholly successful.
('72', 106, 1, 5, 191402) And it is for this reason that, even after so many years, I give the utmost importance to these tasks.
('72', 106, 1, 6, 191505) Now the last question.
('72', 106, 1, 7, 191528) If all the activities are being managed by the same body, this may well continue.
('72', 106, 1, 8, 191610) I see no harm in each activity being carried on wholly independently.
('72', 106, 1, 9, 191680) Even if these are being carried on under the same authority, each should become self sufficient, and people should be allowed to be absorbed in the particular sphere which they have chosen.

('72', 108, 1, 2, 194106) 147. LETTER TO KANTILAL GANDHI
('72', 108, 2, 3, 194137) SEGAON, August 8, 1937
('72', 108, 3, 4, 194160) KANTI, I am not wrong in calling you a tyrant.
('72', 108, 3, 5, 194207) You were a tyrant to Amtul Salaam when you idolized her.
('72', 108, 3, 6, 194264) Now that that idolization has changed into a kind of repulsion, you are again being a tyrant to her.
('72', 108, 3, 7, 194365) Ramachandran had been pressing her—so were Paparamma and Saraswati—and he had sent a wire.
('72', 108, 3, 8, 194456) That is why she went.
('72', 108, 3, 9, 194478) She is having some peace there.
('72', 108, 3, 10, 194510) Now you wish that I should call her away from there.
('72', 108, 3, 11, 194563) I, therefore, wrote a letter 1 to her asking her to return and even sent a wire 2. I haven’t told her that it was at your instance that I asked her to come away.
('72', 108, 3, 12, 194725) I have given no reason at all.
('72', 108, 3, 13, 194756) If necessary, I will tell her when she comes.

('72', 109, 7, 16, 196295) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 9, 1937
('72', 109, 8, 17, 196326) MIRA, I have your disturbing letter.
('72', 109, 8, 18, 196363) You need not stop there even till 24th if your mind is not there.
('72', 109, 8, 19, 196429) It is distinctly harmful for you to be there, if you can’t be happy there but will stay there because it is a duty imposed from without.
('72', 109, 8, 20, 196566) You have tried that again and again and failed each time.
('72', 109, 8, 21, 196624) Therefore you must follow your will no matter where it leads you to.
('72', 109, 8, 22, 196693) You will learn only by making mistakes, if mistakes there must be through following your will.
('72', 109, 8, 23, 196788) To paraphrase the alcoholic saying, I would rather find you always in error than find you correct only under compulsion.
('72', 109, 8, 24, 196909) You can grow through error, never through compulsion.

('72', 112, 1, 2, 199532) 154. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('72', 112, 2, 3, 199564) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 10, 1937
('72', 112, 3, 4, 199596) CHHAGANLAL, I got your long letter.
('72', 112, 3, 5, 199632) I will see how the problem can be solved.
('72', 112, 3, 6, 199674) When we lack either time or space, we have to leave some things aside even though they may be important.
('72', 112, 3, 7, 199779) Please tell Vimu 1 that in her letter to me she was unwilling to promise 25,000 rounds in the spinning yajna and had asked my advice.
('72', 112, 3, 8, 199913) But in the printed list of names with me, I see 51,000 against her name.
('72', 112, 3, 9, 199986) Is 51 a misprint for 15?
('72', 112, 3, 10, 200011) If it is not, how did she get the courage to raise 25,000 to twice as much, or to treble the 17,000 which she had intended?
('72', 112, 3, 11, 200135) If she had the courage to do that, why couldn’t she quadruple 17,000 and make it 68,000?
('72', 112, 3, 12, 200224) If “scoffer friends” then looked upon her as an idolator, she should pay no attention to them.
('72', 112, 3, 13, 200319) On the contrary, she should welcome their blessings.
('72', 112, 3, 14, 200372) Spinning 68,000 rounds in 68 days would be no great achievement for a girl like Vimu.
('72', 112, 3, 15, 200458) According to the calculations here, 1000 rounds a day would require less than three hours, for the average speed is taken to be 400 rounds an hour.
('72', 112, 3, 16, 200606) Even if, however, the work takes four hours, I wouldn’t regard that as too strenuous for her.
('72', 112, 3, 17, 200700) Moreover, anyone who does this job with zest and enthusiasm would learn to get absorbed in the work on hand and automatically acquire the ability to do a great many other things.
('72', 112, 3, 18, 200879) Narandas is hesitating to undertake the preparation of the manual [of the science of khadi] though there is not the slightest reason for such hesitation.
('72', 112, 3, 19, 201033) If, however, you join him in preparing the booklet, I think it can immediately be done.
('72', 112, 3, 20, 201121) Anyone who has complete mastery of most of the processes will find it easy to give a methodical description of them and of the equipment required.
('72', 112, 3, 21, 201268) If you have not read any literature on the history of the subject, you should read it up.
('72', 112, 3, 22, 201358) If at least one booklet, covering all aspects of the subject, is brought out systematically, it would be easy to do further work in the field in future.
('72', 112, 3, 23, 201511) Think over this .

('72', 113, 6, 11, 202207) NARANDAS, I got your letter.
('72', 113, 6, 12, 202236) There can be no cause at all for worrying about Kanaiyo.
('72', 113, 6, 13, 202293) What is necessary is to take care of him, to guide him, to understand the thousands of fancies that catch his mind, and to pacify him.
('72', 113, 6, 14, 202428) Besides this, nothing more is necessary, for his mind is not devious.
('72', 113, 6, 15, 202498) He is not secretive, doesn’t wish to conceal anything and has faith in those whom he regards as his elders.

('72', 113, 6, 17, 202659) One thing, of course, is true.
('72', 113, 6, 18, 202690) If he is not given work which he can do and if nobody takes interest in him, he does feel lost.
('72', 113, 6, 19, 202786) At present I have heaps of work to do.
('72', 113, 6, 20, 202825) There is so much typing to be done that it leaves him exhausted and so many copies to be made that his fingers get cramps.
('72', 113, 6, 21, 202948) And this is apart from spinning.

('72', 113, 6, 23, 203079) He gets his fill listening to the sweet music of Nanavati and, as he does so, tries to pick up as much as he can.

('72', 114, 6, 15, 204666) August 10, 1937
('72', 114, 7, 16, 204682) NARANDAS, I got your letter.
('72', 114, 7, 17, 204711) If you find it impossible to write the Khadishastra Praveshika, you may give up the idea.
('72', 114, 7, 18, 204801) But the fact that your brain doesn’t work on this subject may perhaps be indicative of some deficiency in you.
('72', 114, 7, 19, 204912) I was not satisfied with the few lines that Jayantilal wrote.
('72', 114, 7, 20, 204974) I got the impression that he had forced himself to write.
('72', 114, 7, 21, 205032) The discussion with you doesn’t seem to have given him a new light.
('72', 114, 7, 22, 205100) That is, [he believes that] spinning and the other activities are conducted not as a means of intellectual development but only as training in crafts side by side with intellectual training.
('72', 114, 7, 23, 205291) I hope you understand the difference between the two.
('72', 114, 7, 24, 205345) If a carpenter teaches me his craft and I learn it mechanically, my hand will be able to use the carpenter’s tools but there will hardly be
('72', 114, 8, 25, 205485) 1 A student of the national school at Rajkot who died of typhoid.
('72', 114, 8, 26, 205551) He had resolved to spin one lakh rounds of yarn.
('72', 114, 8, 27, 205600) 2 On Rentia Baras celebrations in National School, Rajkot, published in Harijanbandhu, 15 8 1937
('72', 115, 0, 1, 205697) 116 THE COOLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 115, 1, 2, 205739) any intellectual development.
('72', 115, 1, 3, 205769) If, however, an expert on carpentry teaches me the craft, my intellect also will develop fully in the process.
('72', 115, 1, 4, 205880) That is, I shall not only be a good carpenter but will also become an engineer, for while teaching me carpentry the teacher will have improved and embellished my language.
('72', 115, 1, 5, 206052) He will have taught me the history of wood and, while explaining where and how wood is grown, will have taught me geography.
('72', 115, 1, 6, 206177) He will also have taught me a little about agriculture and will have likewise taught me to make illustra tions of my tools.
('72', 115, 1, 7, 206301) While teaching me the economics of carpentry, he will have taught me arithmetic and geometry.
('72', 115, 1, 8, 206395) All this will make up a course of some seven years.
('72', 115, 1, 9, 206447) Maybe you do not link up spinning and the other crafts which you are teaching with intellectual development.
('72', 115, 1, 10, 206556) Perhaps you consider knowledge of the alphabet and reading as the only means of such development.
('72', 115, 1, 11, 206654) If this is not so, the writing of the Praveshika should be an easy job for you.
('72', 115, 1, 12, 206734) I know that I have not previously explained these thoughts in the manner in which I have explained them in this letter.
('72', 115, 1, 13, 206854) But I have been explaining in Harijan the ideas which are coming to me these days, and this idea is the first and foremost of them all.
('72', 115, 1, 14, 206990) I have hitherto also said that there should be training in crafts along with training of the intellect and that such training should occupy the primary place in a scheme of national education.
('72', 115, 1, 15, 207183) What I am now saying is that an important means of intellectual training should be craft training.
('72', 115, 1, 16, 207282) I feel that talents are being wasted and the fact that thousands of young people who leave schools are good for nothing except clerkships is indicative not of intellectual development but of intellectual waste.
('72', 115, 1, 17, 207493) True education is that which trains all the three abilities, spiritual, intellectual and economic, simultaneously.
('72', 115, 1, 18, 207608) No boy on leaving school should have to ask himself: “What shall I do now?” His education should be a kind of insurance guaranteeing him a livelihood.
('72', 115, 1, 19, 207759) I have dictated all this for you to think over.
('72', 115, 1, 20, 207807) If you have followed what I have said, you will have to examine the art of spinning from a new point of view and also devise a new method of teaching it.
('72', 115, 1, 21, 207961) Please read again from this point of view my recent articles 1 in Harijan.
('72', 115, 1, 22, 208036) Shankaran’s is a painful case.
('72', 115, 1, 23, 208067) I am of course writing to him.
('72', 115, 2, 24, 208098) 1 Vide “A Great Experiment”, 3 7 1937 and “Criticism Answered”, 31 7 1937

('72', 119, 1, 2, 211431) 162. DISCUSSION WITH D. K. MEHTA 1 AND P. B. GOLE
('72', 119, 2, 3, 211481) SEGAON, August 11/12, 1937
('72', 119, 3, 4, 211508) It is understood that the discussions centred round land revenue and excise policies.
('72', 119, 3, 5, 211594) It was pointed out to Gandhiji that the policy of flat reduction in land revenue was undesirable, inasmuch as there were areas which had been heavily assessed and needed immediate help, while in some areas the land revenue was so low that it would not be advisable to reduce it any further.
('72', 119, 4, 6, 211885) As regards the excise policy, it is understood that Gandhiji impressed on the Ministers that in all the six Congress Provinces the policy in this matter should be uniform and total prohibition should be the goal of the Congress Ministries.
('72', 119, 4, 7, 212125) This goal should have to be achieved within the lifetimes of the present Ministries.
('72', 119, 4, 8, 212210) The loss in revenue would be made good by drastic retrenchments, and, if need be, the Congress Ministers should be prepared to face fresh taxation measures.
('72', 119, 5, 9, 212367) The Hitavada, 13 8 1937
('72', 119, 6, 10, 212391) 163. STATEMENT ON INTERVIEW WITH THE VICEROY 2
('72', 119, 7, 11, 212438) August 12, 1937 I have read what are described as startling disclosures of the Delhi interview in The Bombay Sentinel 3. It is from beginning to end a figment of imagination, pure and simple.
('72', 119, 7, 12, 212630) The interview, as stated in the Viceroy’s letter, was without any purpose beyond that of establishing courteous contact on his part.
('72', 119, 7, 13, 212763) Therefore, I studiously refrained from referring to any matter outside of lifting the ban on Khan Saheb’s entry into his own Province, and an understanding of Government’s wishes regarding my desire to visit that Province.
('72', 119, 7, 14, 212986) [The] other conversation was more or less of a general character.
('72', 119, 7, 15, 213052) The word ‘Federation’ was not even mentioned at the interview.
('72', 119, 8, 16, 213115) The Hindu, 13 8 1937
('72', 119, 9, 17, 213136) 1 Minister for Finance, C. P. 2 Gandhiji had met the Viceroy on August 4; vide “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 4 8 1937 3 Dated 10 8 1937

('72', 121, 9, 12, 215674) 167. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('72', 121, 10, 13, 215702) WARDHA, August 13, 1937 I have seen what seems to be a distorted version of the part I have played in the Nariman episode.
('72', 121, 10, 14, 215825) The virulent agitation that has gathered round it has caused me deep distress.
('72', 121, 10, 15, 215904) I cannot do better than quote from my letter, dated August 1, to Mr. Nariman: 3 Since that date, further correspondence between him and me has taken place.
('72', 121, 11, 16, 216060) 1 A communist labour leader, who had written “drawing Mr. Gandhi’s attention to the non release of all politicals and the necessity for labour legislation and the creation of deadlocks after some time.” 2 The letter appeared under the date line “Bombay, August 13” 3 The extract is not reproduced here; for the full text of the letter, vide “Letter to K. F. Nariman”,
('72', 122, 0, 1, 216428) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 123
('72', 122, 1, 2, 216472) telegram received from him today tells me that he will be ready with his evidence in both cases in five days.
('72', 122, 1, 3, 216582) I shall lose no time whatsoever in applying myself to the task I have undertaken.
('72', 122, 1, 4, 216664) I have not as yet worried Bahadurji in this matter, but if my findings are adverse to Mr. Nariman and he is not satisfied with them, I shall immediately request Bahadurji to review the evidence produced before me and my findings.
('72', 122, 1, 5, 216894) It has been suggested that what I have done now might have been done when the unfortunate controversy first burst forth.
('72', 122, 1, 6, 217015) I am not free at this stage to publish the whole of the correspondence that has taken place between him and me.
('72', 122, 1, 7, 217127) But I can say I have been always willing, as he has admitted himself, that he should have an independent inquiry if he desired it.
('72', 122, 1, 8, 217258) Therefore, whatever has taken place, has not been due to my indifference or unwillingness to help.
('72', 122, 1, 9, 217357) If I have been hitherto silent, my silence has been solely in the interest of Mr. Nariman as could be amply borne out by the correspondence referred to above.
('72', 122, 1, 10, 217516) I would appeal to the Bombay Press to stop the agitation altogether and ask the public to suspend judgment till the findings are in their possession.

('72', 123, 4, 12, 219739) 169. LETTER TO DR.
('72', 123, 4, 13, 219758) FRITZ MICHAELIS
('72', 123, 5, 14, 219774) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 13, 1937
('72', 123, 6, 15, 219806) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter.
('72', 123, 6, 16, 219848) Here are answers to your questions of which, I hope, you have kept a copy.
('72', 123, 6, 17, 219923) Handicraft experts would be expected to live with us like ourselves and work side by side with us giving us the benefit of their labour and their experience.
('72', 123, 6, 18, 220081) We would adopt such European methods and tools which we need, consistently with our poverty.
('72', 123, 6, 19, 220174) There is no question of independent workshops being established.
('72', 123, 6, 20, 220239) We are villagers.
('72', 123, 6, 21, 220257) A village containing not more than 1000 souls all told.
('72', 123, 6, 22, 220313) No experts are required who cannot work without capital.
('72', 123, 6, 23, 220370) India’s villages require to be revivified.
('72', 123, 6, 24, 220413) Land is parcelled out in holdings, often even less than one acre.
('72', 123, 6, 25, 220479) The idea, therefore, is to turn
('72', 123, 7, 26, 220511) 1 Gosibehn Captain, Dadabhoy Naoroji’s granddaughter
('72', 124, 0, 1, 220564) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 125
('72', 124, 1, 2, 220608) waste into wealth.
('72', 124, 1, 3, 220627) Hence talent that is expensive or that can only express itself in bignesses will not serve my purpose.
('72', 124, 1, 4, 220730) I want the use of that talent which can see the universe in an atom and, therefore, relates itself to and is rooted in the earth from which we have sprung, on which we are living, to which we have to return.
('72', 124, 1, 5, 220938) Anyone, therefore, who comes from the West has got to be capable of living the life of the poor.
('72', 124, 1, 6, 221035) Therefore he must [be] able bodied and be prepared to live the life of the poorest in the land.

('72', 125, 5, 8, 221887) 172. LETTER TO MARIA SEVENICH
('72', 125, 6, 9, 221917) SAGAON WARDHA [August 13, 1937] 1
('72', 125, 7, 10, 221951) DEAR FRIEND, I have Margaret’s translation of your letter.
('72', 125, 7, 11, 222010) It is good that you have written so freely.
('72', 125, 7, 12, 222054) Let me correct one opinion in it.
('72', 125, 7, 13, 222088) You say I have had the experience of being not successful and that I had retired for some time from political work.
('72', 125, 7, 14, 222204) In the dictionary of a seeker of truth there is no such thing as being “not successful”.
('72', 125, 7, 15, 222293) He is or should be an irrepressible optimist because of his immovable faith in the ultimate victory of Truth which is God.
('72', 125, 7, 16, 222416) And, I have not retired, temporarily or permanently, from political work for I recognize no watertight compartments.
('72', 125, 7, 17, 222533) What I have done is to retire from the Congress and Congress politics—and that I have done to serve the Congress and the politics of the country better than before.
('72', 125, 7, 18, 222698) For the rest I await your promised letter.
('72', 125, 7, 19, 222741) BAPU M. K. GANDHI From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('72', 128, 0, 1, 225081) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 129
('72', 128, 1, 2, 225125) 177. NOTES
('72', 128, 2, 3, 225136) UNSEEMLINESS IS INDISCIPLINE The Daily Press reports that at the opening of the C. P. Assembly session the gallery which was packed to overflowing made an unseemly demonstration against Shri Raghavendra Rao 1. Those who packed the gallery were presumably Congressmen or those who sympathized with the Congress.
('72', 128, 2, 4, 225447) I suppose there will be parties even after we have Complete Independence of our make.
('72', 128, 2, 5, 225533) It will go hard with us if the parties will not tolerate one another or show towards one another ordinary courtesy.
('72', 128, 2, 6, 225649) And the Congress which claims to represent the whole nation can ill afford to be intolerant towards its political opponents or others.
('72', 128, 2, 7, 225784) If it is, and it is, the only all India body, it represents all interests.
('72', 128, 2, 8, 225859) It represents even Shri Raghavendra Rao who was at one time a respected member of the Congress organization.
('72', 128, 2, 9, 225968) It may be that the votes in the constituency for which he stood were tampered with.
('72', 128, 2, 10, 226052) If they were, the law would look after it.
('72', 128, 2, 11, 226095) But he must be presumed to be honest till he is proved guilty.
('72', 128, 2, 12, 226158) And even if he is proved guilty, the guilt will be no warrant for unseemly demonstration against him.
('72', 128, 2, 13, 226260) Intolerance, discourtesy, harshness are not only against Congress discipline and code of honour, they are taboo in all good society and are surely contrary to the spirit of democracy.
('72', 128, 3, 14, 226444) Harijan, 14 8 1937
('72', 128, 4, 15, 226463) 178. AGAINST AHIMSA AND TRUTH?
('72', 128, 5, 16, 226494) A friend writes: 2
('72', 128, 6, 17, 226513) The following sentence in your article 3 “Criticism Answered” (31st July) seems to me to offend against the spirit of truth and non violence as also against good logic.
('72', 128, 7, 18, 226682) “Foreign liquors in prescribed quantity may be imported for the use of Europeans who cannot or will not do without their drink.”
('72', 128, 8, 19, 226811) The Congress Govemments must feel as much concerned for the welfare of the European community within their provinces as for the Indian
('72', 128, 9, 20, 226946) 1 The ex Premier 2 Only extracts from the letter are reproduced here.
('72', 128, 9, 21, 227016) 3 Vide “Criticism Abswered”, 31 7 1937
('72', 129, 0, 1, 227055) 130 THE COOLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 129, 1, 2, 227097) communities.
('72', 129, 1, 3, 227110) I assume that the Congressmen, as prohibitionists, are agreed that drink is as bad for the European as for the Indian.
('72', 129, 1, 4, 227229) In that case the mere whim of the drinker cannot count.
('72', 129, 1, 5, 227285) If drink is to be allowed to the European— although it is bad for him—because he “cannot or will not do without it”, the Japanese, the Americans and several other foreigners in India may seek the same permission; and if they are to be allowed to continue their evil habit on that ground, why should an Indian in his own country be not allowed to ruin himself in the same way?.
('72', 129, 2, 6, 227662) If anyone is to be permitted to take (not take to) alcohol, it must be entirely on medical or some other universally applicable ground.
('72', 129, 2, 7, 227798) There cannot be under the Congress regime a discriminatory legislation for or against a community.
('72', 129, 3, 8, 227897) A foreigner residing in India for a period only ought not to be exempt
('72', 129, 4, 9, 227968) from the same obligation.
('72', 129, 4, 10, 227994) Thus, even for those who feel that total abstinence
('72', 129, 5, 11, 228046) is not absolutely necessary, it must be obligatory to give up drink during their
('72', 129, 6, 12, 228127) stay in India if the nation has declared itself against it.
('72', 129, 6, 13, 228187) They must be deemed to
('72', 129, 7, 14, 228210) reside in India on the understanding that they will respect the laws, customs
('72', 129, 8, 15, 228288) and rules of decent conduct of the people amongst whom they have come to
('72', 129, 9, 16, 228361) reside.
('72', 129, 9, 17, 228369) I have no difficulty generally in following and often adopting this writer’s criticism.
('72', 129, 9, 18, 228457) But I must confess that though I have read the letter three times, I have failed to understand the argument.
('72', 129, 9, 19, 228566) Why is the proposed exemption against the spirit of ahimsa or truth?
('72', 129, 9, 20, 228635) I fail to see even the bad logic the writer sees in it.
('72', 129, 9, 21, 228691) In dealing with living entities, the dry syllogistic method leads not only to bad logic but sometimes to fatal logic.
('72', 129, 9, 22, 228809) For if you miss even a tiny factor— and you never have control over all the factors that enter into dealings with human beings—your conclusion is likely to be wrong.
('72', 129, 9, 23, 228975) Therefore you never reach the final truth, you only reach an approximation, and that too if you are extra careful in your dealings.
('72', 129, 9, 24, 229107) Indeed it was my regard for ahimsa and truth that made me think of exempting Europeans.
('72', 129, 9, 25, 229195) For I am unable to lay down a universal law for all human beings and for all climes that drink is an evil.
('72', 129, 9, 26, 229302) I can well regard it as a necessity in the frigid zone.
('72', 129, 9, 27, 229358) I would therefore be chary of imposing prohibition against Europeans who not only do not regard measured quantities of alcohol at each meal an evil but consider it a necessity.
('72', 129, 9, 28, 229535) Drink is not regarded as a vice in European society as it is generally in India.
('72', 129, 9, 29, 229616) I would therefore, even from the point of view of courtesy (a phase of ahimsa), leave it to their honour to respect the usage of the
('72', 130, 0, 1, 229749) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 131
('72', 130, 1, 2, 229793) country of their adoption.
('72', 130, 1, 3, 229820) I would gladly accept the logic of allowing other nationals, if the necessity is proved, the modified freedom the Europeans will enjoy.
('72', 130, 1, 4, 229956) Indeed it might be necessary to bring in a large number of Indians too under the medical certificate clause.
('72', 130, 1, 5, 230065) For me the drink question is one of dealing with a growing social evil against which the State is bound to provide whilst it has got the opportunity.
('72', 130, 1, 6, 230215) The aim is patent.
('72', 130, 1, 7, 230234) We want to wean the labouring population and the Harijans from the curse.
('72', 130, 1, 8, 230308) It is a gigantic problem, and the best resources of all social workers, especially women, will be taxed to the utmost before the drink habit goes.
('72', 130, 1, 9, 230455) The prohibition I have adumbrated is but the beginning (undoubtedly indispensable) of the reform.
('72', 130, 1, 10, 230553) We cannot reach the drinker so long as he has the drink shop near his door to tempt him.
('72', 130, 1, 11, 230642) One might not as well prevent an ailing child, nay man, from touching sweets so long as he does not remove the open box in front of them.
('72', 130, 1, 12, 230780) Whilst on this question, I would like to answer an argument advanced in one of the newspaper cuttings which good friends send me that Shri C. Rajagopalachari in his zeal for this reform has brushed aside the question of the unemployment of the tappers who will be thrown out of work.
('72', 130, 1, 13, 231064) I do not know what he has in mindfor them.
('72', 130, 1, 14, 231107) Shri Gajanan, who is becoming an expert in making palm gur 1, tells me that in the Southern Presidency there are tappers engaged in the nefarious trade.
('72', 130, 1, 15, 231260) He further suggests that the tapping need not stop at all.
('72', 130, 1, 16, 231319) Only what they will tap under the prohibition regime will be sweet toddy which will be converted into gur instead of fiery liquid.
('72', 130, 1, 17, 231450) Indeed I learn that in Andhradesh the tappers do not sell the palm juice they extract, but they convert it into gur which they sell to the arrack manufacturers who make arrack out of this gur.
('72', 130, 1, 18, 231643) In such cases nothing need be done except for the State to take over this gur at a reasonable agreed price.
('72', 130, 1, 19, 231751) From what I know of the tappers, they are not likely to lose anything by the impending prohibition, and the poor will get a rich but cheap food in the shape of good pure gur instead of a liquid which harms both body and soul.
('72', 130, 1, 20, 231977) Harijan, 14 8 1937
('72', 130, 2, 21, 231996) 1 Jaggery

('72', 131, 7, 12, 232594) 180. RENTIA BARAS
('72', 131, 8, 13, 232612) I feel—and I should feel—hesitant to write about my own birthday.
('72', 131, 8, 14, 232678) Readers should know that I would have forgotten it altogether if people in India had not kept reminding me of it.
('72', 131, 8, 15, 232792) I had to recollect my date of birth only on my joining the school and again when I went to become a barrister.
('72', 131, 8, 16, 232903) However, I do not recall my parents having customarily celebrated either my birthday or that of any of my brothers.
('72', 131, 8, 17, 233019) I have not celebrated the birthday of my parents or my sons.
('72', 131, 8, 18, 233080) At one time, I used to keep a record of their birthdays but even that record was lost when like the [proverbial] cat we changed houses more than seven times.
('72', 131, 8, 19, 233238) I do not know why I have never been interested in birthdays.
('72', 131, 8, 20, 233299) But ever since my birthday was first celebrated with pomp in India, I made it known as Rentia Baras.

('72', 132, 1, 2, 233929) very small sum in my opinion.
('72', 132, 1, 3, 233959) I would regard no amount big enough where khadi propaganda and Harijan work are concerned.
('72', 132, 1, 4, 234050) Propag ation of khadi means a clear increase in national wealth.
('72', 132, 1, 5, 234115) With an insignificant capital, the Spinners’ Association has to date distributed three crore rupees amongst the poor, that is to say that khadi worth a minimum of rupees four crores was produced and, of these three crores found their way to the villages.
('72', 132, 1, 6, 234370) Similarly, Harijan service should also be regarded as charity which earns immediate merit for the donor, as it is a form of atonement.
('72', 132, 1, 7, 234505) And charity thus given yields immeasurable fruit.

('72', 132, 1, 13, 234978) It has been found that the routine programme which has been in operation for three years has been steadily expanding.
('72', 132, 1, 14, 235096) Hence, I can unreservedly request devotees of khadi and Harijans to contribute their utmost to this fund.
('72', 132, 1, 15, 235202) Those who contribute to this fund should realize that persons contributing to the yajna in the form of yarn are certainly giving more than those who pay money, as the former pay with wealth produced by their own labour.
('72', 132, 1, 16, 235422) Those who give money only transfer it to the charity box, they do not produce new wealth, though of course they help to produce more.

('72', 140, 8, 17, 246902) I have also remonstrated 3 a bit with him.

('72', 140, 8, 19, 246986) In fact I consider it a fault.
('72', 140, 8, 20, 247017) How long can anyone carry on in this fashion?
('72', 140, 8, 21, 247063) How will he manage if he himself falls ill?
('72', 140, 8, 22, 247107) To create all the conditions for illness, yet hope to escape it is to expect the impossible.
('72', 140, 8, 23, 247200) Therefore I expect that you, your brothers and sisters will all collectively stop him and will not allow him at any cost to overwork like this.
('72', 140, 8, 24, 247344) If all of you, brothers and sisters, make up your mind, you will surely succeed.

('72', 141, 1, 2, 247644) 195. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('72', 141, 2, 3, 247672) WARDHA, August 20, 1937 Mr. K. F. Nariman has sent me a statement containing his case against Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and others.
('72', 141, 2, 4, 247803) In it he wants me to invite witnesses and give them certain assurances.
('72', 141, 2, 5, 247875) 1 This I gladly do hereby.
('72', 141, 2, 6, 247902) I would like all those members of the Assembly and the Council who took part in the election of the leader for the Congress Party and those who were influencing votes to send me their statements of what they know, especially whether they voted in the manner they did at the instigation of Sardar Vallabhbhai directly or indirectly, and also their reasons for voting.
('72', 141, 2, 7, 248269) It is said that the election being unanimous there was no voting.
('72', 141, 2, 8, 248335) Even so, I would like members who were present at the election to write to me, if they will, as to why they did not express their dissent.
('72', 141, 2, 9, 248474) I would also like those who took part in influencing the decisions of the electors to write to me whether they acted at the instigation or advice of the Sardar and whether, as a matter of fact, they used his name in speaking to the electors and, if they did, whether they did so with his knowledge and consent.
('72', 141, 2, 10, 248785) There is another class of witnesses as to the part Mr. Nariman played in 1934 at the election of members from Bombay for the Central Assembly.
('72', 141, 2, 11, 248928) I would ask those who can to throw light on the charge of betrayal of trust or improper conduct brought against Mr. Nariman.
('72', 141, 2, 12, 249053) It has been stated to me that the truth might be stifled for fear of victimization by the Sardar.
('72', 141, 2, 13, 249151) I do not visualize how the Sardar can victimize.
('72', 141, 2, 14, 249200) But I can give this assurance that in the event of the Sardar being found guilty of such conduct I should cut off the intimate contact I enjoy with him.
('72', 141, 2, 15, 249353) If there are witnesses who wish to write to me in confidence I shall respect their confidence, but they should know that if their statements are such as need corroboration or
('72', 141, 3, 16, 249528) 1 In Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Narahari Parikh explains: “Nariman .
('72', 141, 3, 17, 249596) issued a statement on the 17th of August.
('72', 141, 3, 18, 249638) In this he stated that he was not prepared to apologize and that an assurance of protection should be given to all the witnesses.
('72', 141, 3, 19, 249768) He followed up the public statement by a letter to Gandhiji urging that as the President of the Parliamentary Committee, Sardar Patel enjoyed large and arbitrary powers and many witnesses who were members of the Legislature were afraid of incurring his displeasure.
('72', 141, 3, 20, 250034) It was essential, therefore, and in the interest of truth, that assurance of complete protection should be given to the witnesses.”
('72', 142, 0, 1, 250166) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 143
('72', 142, 1, 2, 250210) contradiction by the Sardar or parties whom they may mention, their statements will have no weight with me if I could not show them—not necessarily the names—to the parties concerned.
('72', 142, 1, 3, 250394) Any evidence that any party may wish to give in the two matters mentioned above should reach me not later than the 31st instant addressed Maganwadi, Wardha, and marked “Confidential: about Shri Nariman”.
