('72', 144, 1, 2, 253223) 200. DISCUSSION ON PROHIBITION 1
('72', 144, 2, 3, 253256) [Before August 21, 1937]
('72', 144, 3, 4, 253281) GANDHIJI: The cruellest irony of the new reforms lies in the fact that we are left with nothing but the liquor revenue to fall back upon in order to give our children education.
('72', 144, 3, 5, 253459) That is the educational puzzle but it should not baffle us.
('72', 144, 3, 6, 253519) We have to solve it and the solution must not involve the compromise of our ideal of prohibition, cost whatever else it may.
('72', 144, 3, 7, 253644) It must be shameful and humiliating to think that unless we got the drink revenue, our children would be starved of their education.
('72', 144, 3, 8, 253777) But if it comes to it, we should prefer it as a lesser evil.
('72', 144, 3, 9, 253838) If only we will refuse to be obsessed by the figures and by the supposed necessity of giving our children the exact kind of education that they get today, the problem should not baffle us.
('72', 144, 4, 10, 254027) QUESTION: Then would you really abolish what is called secondary education and give the whole education up to matriculation in the village schools?
('72', 144, 5, 11, 254175) A. Certainly.
('72', 144, 5, 12, 254189) What is your secondary education but compelling the poor boys to learn in a foreign language in seven years what they should learn in the course of a couple of years in their own mother tongue?
('72', 144, 5, 13, 254383) If you can but make up your minds to free the children from the incubus of learning their subjects in a foreign tongue, and if you teach them to use their hands and feet profitably, the educational puzzle is solved.
('72', 144, 5, 14, 254599) You can sacrifice without compunction the whole of the drink revenue.
('72', 144, 5, 15, 254669) But you must resolve to sacrifice this revenue first, and think of the ways and means about education later.
('72', 144, 5, 16, 254778) Make the beginning by taking the big step.
('72', 144, 6, 17, 254821) Q. But would just the mere declaration of prohibition mean prohibition?
('72', 144, 6, 18, 254893) May it not be that we may sacrifice the revenue without touching the curse of drink, not to talk of abolishing it?
('72', 144, 7, 19, 255008) A. The declaration does not mean that you will thereafter sit still.
('72', 144, 7, 20, 255077) You will impress everyone into your service.
('72', 144, 7, 21, 255122) In fact the whole staff is there—the staff of excise inspectors, their superior officers, and the whole of their subordinate staff.
('72', 144, 7, 22, 255254) You will tell them that they will serve on no other terms but those of working for total abolition of drink.
('72', 144, 7, 23, 255363) You will convert every grog shop into a recreation centre.
('72', 144, 7, 24, 255422) You will
('72', 144, 8, 25, 255431) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “The Education Puzzle”
('72', 145, 0, 1, 255487) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 145, 1, 2, 255529) concentrate on places where opportunities for getting drunk are greatest.
('72', 145, 1, 3, 255603) You will ask the mill owners and factory owners to provide light refreshment stalls, you will provide there refreshing drinks for them like sugar cane juice, games for them, lantern shows for them, and make them feel that they are like you.
('72', 145, 1, 4, 255844) Impress everyone, without exception, into your service.
('72', 145, 1, 5, 255900) The village school master and the other official should be all prohibition workers.
('72', 145, 2, 6, 255984) Q. Very good.
('72', 145, 2, 7, 255998) But in many places you will find the village Patel and others joining the drinking folk in their drunken revels.
('72', 145, 2, 8, 256111) What about them?
('72', 145, 3, 9, 256128) A. Every one of your school children will be a prohibition worker.
('72', 145, 3, 10, 256195) Ministers will be going up and down the country visiting the grog shops turned recreation centres, have their cup of refreshing dirnk with the common folk and make these houses fashionable.
('72', 145, 3, 11, 256385) Don’t be deterred by the thought that prohibition failed in America.
('72', 145, 3, 12, 256454) Remember that the stupendous experiment was tried there, where drinking is not looked upon as a vice, where millions usually drink.
('72', 145, 3, 13, 256586) Here drink is held reprehensible by all religions, and it is not the millions who drink but individuals who drink.
('72', 145, 4, 14, 256701) Harijan, 21 8 1937

('72', 146, 0, 1, 257283) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 147
('72', 146, 1, 2, 257327) 202. NOTES
('72', 146, 2, 3, 257338) NOT INSTRUMENT OF INSTRUCTIONS What I have been recently writing in connection with the constructive programme before the Congress Ministries has been described by some newspapers as “Instrument of Instructions”.
('72', 146, 2, 4, 257551) No one but the President of the Congress and the Working Committee has any power to issue instructions to the Congress Ministries.
('72', 146, 2, 5, 257682) Mine is a very humble note.
('72', 146, 2, 6, 257710) I can only advise on matters about which I may claim special Knowledge or experience.
('72', 146, 2, 7, 257796) My articles have a value only to the extent that they appeal to the reason of those to whom they are addressed.
('72', 146, 2, 8, 257908) Though I enjoy the confidence of the Working Committee, the views I may express here need not be taken to represent its views or even those of any of its groups.
('72', 146, 2, 9, 258070) Indeed the public should know that in several matters I do not represent the views of many individual members.
('72', 146, 2, 10, 258181) Therefore, whatever I may say in these columns should be taken to be purely personal to me and in no way representative of the Working Committee.
('72', 146, 2, 11, 258327) But in matters relating to the struggle for swaraj through non violent action.
('72', 146, 2, 12, 258406) I do claim special qualifications.
('72', 146, 2, 13, 258441) For me office acceptance has a special meaning even in terms of the Congress manifesto and resolutions.
('72', 146, 2, 14, 258545) It would be wrong if I did not put before the Ministers and the public my meaning of office acceptance.
('72', 146, 2, 15, 258649) But it may not always be the official Congress view, it may not be the view of Congressmen in general.
('72', 146, 2, 16, 258752) My position and limitations being made clear, there need be no embarrassment to the Ministers or me.
('72', 146, 2, 17, 258853) I should feel cramped if my writings were presumed to bear the imprimatur of the official or even the non official Congress view.
('72', 146, 3, 18, 258983) Harijan, 21 8 1937
('72', 146, 4, 19, 259002) 203. THE IMPLICATIONS
('72', 146, 5, 20, 259024) I have not hesitated to express my opinion that the salaries that the Congress Ministers have voted for themselves are much too high for the standard that govern us in this the poorest country in the would.
('72', 146, 5, 21, 259231) In the hurried note that Prof.
('72', 146, 5, 22, 259262) K. T. Shah has sent me and which the reader will find elsewhere, India’s average annual per capita income will be found to be £4 against £50 of Great Britain.
('72', 146, 5, 23, 259421) Unfortunately for us we have to bear yet a while the burden of the
('72', 147, 0, 1, 259488) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 147, 1, 2, 259530) British inheritance, and in spite of the best effort we fail to achieve the ideal standard.
('72', 147, 1, 3, 259622) The salaries and the allowances are now a settled fact.
('72', 147, 1, 4, 259678) The question now is, will the Ministers, their secretaries and the Members work so hard as to deserve the emoluments they will receive?
('72', 147, 1, 5, 259814) Will the Members become whole time workers for the nation and give a faithful account of the services they may render?
('72', 147, 1, 6, 259933) Let us not make the mistake of imagining that the things are what we wish them to be or what they should be.
('72', 147, 1, 7, 260042) And it is not enough that the Ministers live simply and work hard.
('72', 147, 1, 8, 260109) They have to see to it that the departments they control also respond.
('72', 147, 1, 9, 260180) Thus justice should become cheap and expeditious.
('72', 147, 1, 10, 260230) Today it is the luxury of the rich and the joy of the gambler.
('72', 147, 1, 11, 260293) The police should be friends of the people instead of being their dread.
('72', 147, 1, 12, 260366) Education should be so revolutionized as to answer the wants of the poorest villager instead of answering those of an imperial exploiter.
('72', 147, 1, 13, 260504) All those who were imprisoned for political offences even of a violent nature will shortly find themselves free if the Ministers can give them the freedom.
('72', 147, 1, 14, 260660) This is a phenomenon not to be looked at lightly.
('72', 147, 1, 15, 260710) Does it mean passport to violence?
('72', 147, 1, 16, 260745) Certainly not in terms of the Congress creed of non violence.
('72', 147, 1, 17, 260807) The Congress abhors individual violence in a far more real sense than the Government it replaces.
('72', 147, 1, 18, 260905) It seeks to meet the violence of individuals not with the organized violence called punishment but with non violence in the shape of friendly approach to the erring individuals and through the cultivation of sound public opinion against any form of violence.
('72', 147, 1, 19, 261164) Its methods are preventive, not punitive.
('72', 147, 1, 20, 261206) In other words, the Congress will rule not through the police backed by the military but through its moral authority based upon the greatest goodwill of the people.
('72', 147, 1, 21, 261371) It will rule not in virtue of authority derived from a superior armed power but in virtue of the service of the people whom it seeks to represent in every one of its actions.
('72', 147, 1, 22, 261546) Ban on all prohibited literature is being removed.
('72', 147, 1, 23, 261597) Now some of the books banned will be found, I suppose, to inculcate violence and spread obscenity, or hatred among different classes or sects.
('72', 147, 1, 24, 261740) The Congress rule does not mean licence to violence or obscenity or fomenting of hatred.
('72', 147, 1, 25, 261829) Again the Congress will rely upon the unstinted support of enlightened public opinion in dealing with objectionable literature.
('72', 147, 1, 26, 261957) The Ministers who may find violence, hatred or obscenity spreading in their provinces will look to the Congress organizations and ultimately the Working Committee for active and efficient help before they resort to the processes of the criminal law and all it means.
('72', 147, 1, 27, 262224) Indeed the triumph of the Congress will be measured
('72', 148, 0, 1, 262276) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 149
('72', 148, 1, 2, 262320) by the success it achieves in rendering the police and the military practically idle.
('72', 148, 1, 3, 262406) And it will fail utterly if it has to face crises that render the use of the police and the military inevitable.
('72', 148, 1, 4, 262519) The best and the only effective way to wreck the existing Constitution is for the Congress to prove conclusively that it can rule without the aid of the military and with the least possible assistance of the police who may well have some new and friendly designation given to them as a correspondent suggests.
('72', 148, 1, 5, 262829) Harijan, 21 8 1937

('72', 150, 8, 16, 266279) 208. LETTER TO MULSHANKER NAUTAMLAL
('72', 150, 9, 17, 266315) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 23, 1937
('72', 150, 10, 18, 266347) MULSHANKER, I do not seem to have received your letter of the 19th March.
('72', 150, 10, 19, 266421) It is certainly good that you are doing the work with your whole heart in it.
('72', 150, 10, 20, 266499) Please keep it up.This is what I believe to be dharma regarding marriage.
('72', 150, 10, 21, 266573) Parents cannot force their children to marry, or to marry a particular person.
('72', 150, 10, 22, 266652) While making their choice, the son or the daughter should listen with the utmost respect to their parents’ advice, but need not marry anybody whom their heart does not accept.
('72', 150, 10, 23, 266828) At the same time they should not form an alliance which would displease their parents.
('72', 150, 10, 24, 266915) I see no harm in restraining the desire for marriage as long as one can preserve self control.
('72', 150, 10, 25, 267010) But one must not deceive oneself in any way.
('72', 150, 10, 26, 267055) When the time for courting imprisonment comes again, those who have in them a strong spirit of self sacrifice will have a right to do so.
('72', 150, 10, 27, 267193) In this one should try to obtain the blessings of one’s elders.

('72', 153, 1, 2, 269692) 212. LETTER TO G. CUNNINGHAM
('72', 153, 2, 3, 269721) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 24, 1937
('72', 153, 3, 4, 269753) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter 1 of the 17th instant.
('72', 153, 3, 5, 269817) Evidently I did not quite understand what H. E. the Viceroy said to me about trans Frontier.
('72', 153, 3, 6, 269910) I understood him to mean that he could not think of permitting me to cross the border.
('72', 153, 3, 7, 269997) And I accepted what I understood to be the Viceroy’s decision adding that I did not lose the hope that, when I have inspired sufficient confidence as to my integrity and ability, I could safely be permitted to cross the Frontier.
('72', 153, 3, 8, 270227) But that is irrelevant to this letter.
('72', 153, 3, 9, 270266) I would like to know the implication of “leaving all affairs connected with the tribes severely alone” during my visit.
('72', 153, 3, 10, 270386) Not that I have the slightest desire to meddle in trans Frontier affairs.
('72', 153, 3, 11, 270460) My intention is, as it was when I first broached the subject to Lord Irwin 2, as Lord Halifax then was, to know the Frontier Pathan in his own home, to make the acquaintance of Khudai Khidmatgars, to ascertain for myself how far their claim to be utterly non violent could be sustained and how I could promote the general welfare of the Pathans which is dear to the heart of Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan.
('72', 153, 3, 12, 270866) He puts implicit reliance upon my judgment as I put on his transparency and trustworthiness.
('72', 153, 3, 13, 270959) But I suppose it is inevitable that people will come to me to talk about trans Frontier affairs.
('72', 153, 3, 14, 271056) Am I not to listen to their narratives and even give my opinion if I were asked toexpress it and could form one on what they might tell me?
('72', 153, 3, 15, 271196) If I succeed in visiting the Frontier Province, I should certainly feel sorry if I had to leave it without having the pleasure of renewing the acquaintance we made during the time you were at Delhi.
('72', 153, 3, 16, 271395) I await your further letter about the Khan Saheb’s question.
('72', 153, 4, 17, 271456) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI [PS.] I just read in the papers the ban has been lifted.
('72', 153, 4, 18, 271543) I am grateful.
('72', 153, 5, 19, 271558) H. E. THE GOVERNOR N.W.F.P. From a copy: C.W. 7991. Courtesy: G. D. Birla
('72', 153, 6, 20, 271632) 1 Vide “Letter from G. Cunnigham”, 17 8 1937 2 In March 1931; vide “Letter to Dr. William H. Tandy”, 20 10 1937

('72', 154, 7, 11, 272369) 214. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('72', 154, 8, 12, 272401) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 25, 1937
('72', 154, 9, 13, 272433) PREMA, You must have heard about my ill health.
('72', 154, 9, 14, 272481) I have been ordered minimum mental exertion and maximum rest.
('72', 154, 9, 15, 272543) Since both the brain and the right hand demand complete rest, I will content myself with writing what you want immediately.I did tie your raksha 2 which I received in time.
('72', 154, 9, 16, 272716) I have completely re written the reply to your question.
('72', 154, 9, 17, 272773) 3 The old replies are not incorrect, but being incomplete they may lend themselves to misinterpretation.
('72', 154, 9, 18, 272878) I am returning them.
('72', 154, 9, 19, 272899) Cancel them.
('72', 154, 9, 20, 272912) See that they are not published at all.
('72', 154, 9, 21, 272952) If the new reply is useful, you may publish it.
('72', 154, 9, 22, 273000) I have preserved your letters and will reply to
('72', 154, 10, 23, 273048) 1 The third stage in one’s life when one retired to the forest leaving behind all worldly connections 2 A thread tied on Shravana Shukla 15 by a sister to the wrist of her brother or a person regarded as such implying that he would protect her 3 The addressee had written a novel based on a discussion Gandhiji had with a friend about the case of a married professor aspiring to observe brahmacharya.
('72', 154, 10, 24, 273449) The addressee included Gandhiji’s answer in her novel, a Gujarati translation of which appeared under the title Kama ane Kamini.
('72', 155, 0, 1, 273578) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 155, 1, 2, 273620) them when I am all right.
('72', 155, 1, 3, 273646) You may even receive my reply sooner if I am permitted to dictate.
('72', 155, 1, 4, 273713) There is no cause for worry about me.
('72', 155, 1, 5, 273751) However, I have to be extremely careful.
('72', 155, 2, 6, 273792) Blessings from
('72', 155, 4, 7, 273807) QUESTLON: A professor who is married wants to observe brahmacharya.
('72', 155, 4, 8, 273875) The wife doesn’t agree.
('72', 155, 4, 9, 273899) What is the professor friend’s dharma in these circumstances?
('72', 155, 5, 10, 273961) ANSWER: This question could have arisen only if the idea of observing brahmacharya came to the husband after marriage.
('72', 155, 5, 11, 274080) What I mean by marriage as a part of dharma is that intercourse between husband and wife is resorted to only when they desire children, and never for sex gratification.
('72', 155, 5, 12, 274249) Those who do not look upon marriage as a holy bond will of course respect each other’s wishes.
('72', 155, 5, 13, 274344) Intercourse without the consent of the other party is nothing but rape.
('72', 155, 5, 14, 274416) Let us now deal with the above mentioned question.
('72', 155, 5, 15, 274467) In a case in which it is only the husband who wishes to observe brahmacharya but the wife does not, if the husband has become completely free from passion, that is, has, in the language of the Gita, Ch. II, v.
('72', 155, 5, 16, 274677) 59, realized the Supreme, intercourse will be physically impossible.
('72', 155, 5, 17, 274746) The wife will realize the husband’s condition and her passion will subside.
('72', 155, 5, 18, 274822) But the question refers to a man’s striving for brahmacharya.
('72', 155, 5, 19, 274884) A husband or wife can strive for any aim which was not present in the minds of both at the time of marriage, only with the consent of the other partner.
('72', 155, 5, 20, 275037) In other words, a husband cannot take the vow of brahmacharya without the consent of his wife.
('72', 155, 5, 21, 275132) Of course everybody should try to practise ordinary self control.
('72', 155, 5, 22, 275198) When either party is aroused, generally the other party also is agreeable or becomes so after a little persuasion.
('72', 155, 5, 23, 275313) When this does not happen, bitterness results.
('72', 155, 5, 24, 275360) I have, therefore, come to the conclusion, from the experiences of many people and after careful reflection over them, that practice of self control depends on mutual consent.
('72', 155, 5, 25, 275536) I should therefore say that the question is defective.
('72', 155, 5, 26, 275591) Where brahmacharya has become a natural condition, the question does not arise.
('72', 155, 5, 27, 275671) And it has no room when passion is present and the person only wants to strive for brahmacharya.
('72', 155, 6, 28, 275768) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 10393. Also C.W. 6832. Courtesy: Premabehn Kantak
('72', 156, 0, 1, 275857) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 157
('72', 156, 1, 2, 275901) 215. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('72', 156, 2, 3, 275928) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 25, 1937
('72', 156, 3, 4, 275960) BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, What can I write?
('72', 156, 3, 5, 275997) My mind can work in one direction only.
('72', 156, 3, 6, 276037) I do not know how I can be of help.
('72', 156, 3, 7, 276073) What opinion can I form on a matter I know nothing about?
('72', 156, 3, 8, 276131) Hence I would only suggest that you do what is in the interest of India irrespective of the opinion of Congressmen.
('72', 156, 3, 9, 276247) Rest assured that the Congress will have to accept what is for the country’s good.
('72', 156, 3, 10, 276330) And its prestige will suffer in rejecting it.
('72', 156, 3, 11, 276376) The Con gress has no other capital except its prestige which in turn depends upon the following of the poor millions.
('72', 156, 3, 12, 276494) Thus the welfare of India means simply the economic, intellectual and moral welfare of its millions.
('72', 156, 3, 13, 276595) I have said nothing new but at times such pronouncements of principle are most effective when made by a friend.
('72', 156, 3, 14, 276707) One can say my health is quite good.
('72', 156, 3, 15, 276744) A little weakness is there but it will disappear.
('72', 156, 3, 16, 276794) There is no need for a change.
('72', 156, 3, 17, 276825) But it will automatically be brought about if the trip to the Frontier Province materializes.
('72', 156, 3, 18, 276919) For one thing the climate there is good and fruit, etc., are available in plenty.
('72', 156, 3, 19, 277001) You must be building up your health.
('72', 156, 3, 20, 277038) The operation must have been of considerable help.

('72', 157, 5, 6, 277837) 217. LETTER TO EDITH HUNTER
('72', 157, 6, 7, 277865) SEGAON, WARDHA, C. P., August 26, 1937
('72', 157, 7, 8, 277904) DEAR SISTER, Here is my message.
('72', 157, 7, 9, 277937) You can do with it what you like.
('72', 157, 7, 10, 277971) Attainment of world peace is impossible except for greater scientific precision, greater travail of the soul, greater patience and greater resources than required for the invention and consolidation of the means of mutual slaughter.
('72', 157, 7, 11, 278204) It cannot be attained by a mere muster roll signed by millions of mankind desiring peace.
('72', 157, 7, 12, 278294) But it can, if there is a science of peace, as I hold there is, by a few devoting themselves to the discovery of the means.
('72', 157, 7, 13, 278418) Their effort being from within will not be showy but then it will not need a single farthing.
('72', 157, 8, 14, 278512) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI MRS.
('72', 157, 8, 15, 278547) EDITH HUNTER SECRETARY, FRIENDS OF INDIA SOCIETY 47 VICTORIA STREET LONDON S.W. 1

('72', 160, 5, 7, 282668) 221. LETTER TO R. GANGADHARAN
('72', 160, 6, 8, 282698) SEGAON, WARDHA, August 27, 1937
('72', 160, 7, 9, 282730) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter of the 10th inst.
('72', 160, 7, 10, 282789) Marriage is not an affair in which one person can dispose of his girls or boys against their will.
('72', 160, 7, 11, 282888) My boy married Shri Rajagopala chari’s daughter because they fell in love with each other in perfectly honourable manner and the couple had our blessings.
('72', 160, 7, 12, 283043) I would be glad to think that you could also be similarly matched.
('72', 160, 7, 13, 283110) I have absolutely no prejudices, but no third party can bring about such matches.
('72', 160, 7, 14, 283192) I see nothing unhygienic in a person carrying a moustache or a shikha or both.
('72', 160, 7, 15, 283271) I cannot give any reason for this age long custom but I do not believe in setting aside customs for which I can give no valid reason but which are not repugnant to my moral or sanitary sense.
('72', 160, 8, 16, 283463) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI R. GANGADHARAN THOPPIKAVILAKOM VAKKOM, P. O. ANJUTENGU, TRAVANCORE

('72', 163, 5, 18, 287578) 227. DISCUSSION ON PROHIBITION 3
('72', 163, 6, 19, 287611) [Before August 28, 1937]
('72', 163, 7, 20, 287636) GANDHIJI: If we can achieve prohibition within the next three years, and if we can demonstrate to the world that we can do without the military in the provinces, we shall have raised India’s name to a height that it had never reached before and to which no nation has yet reached.
('72', 163, 7, 21, 287917) The task of making people sober is a task of the most vital importance and no amount of energy devoted to it is likely to be wasted.
('72', 163, 7, 22, 288050) It will at once be a kind of true adult education and [a means] of improving the taxable capacity of the citizen.
('72', 163, 8, 23, 288164) [QUESTION:] What are the most effective agencies for the creation of a sober India?
('72', 163, 9, 24, 288248) G. I have said already that the existing excise force may be used to advantage.
('72', 163, 9, 25, 288328) Up to now they had no belief in the Government’s bona
('72', 163, 10, 26, 288382) 1 The architect in charge of construction work at the Haripura Congress; vide “Letter to Vallabbhbhai Patel”, 26 9 1937. 2 Some words are illegible in the source.
('72', 163, 10, 27, 288545) 3 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “A Stupendous Task”, under “Notes”
('72', 164, 0, 1, 288613) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 165
('72', 164, 1, 2, 288657) fides to achieve prohibition at even a distant date.
('72', 164, 1, 3, 288710) They now know well enough that the Congress will not rest in peace and will not let others rest in peace until it has achieved prohibition, and they will gladly fall into line with the new policy and programme.
('72', 164, 1, 4, 288921) But the voluntary agencies will be more effective.
('72', 164, 1, 5, 288972) There are our professors and teachers, and students of colleges.
('72', 164, 1, 6, 289037) They may well be called upon to devote a couple of hours each day to the task.
('72', 164, 1, 7, 289116) They should go to the areas frequented by the drinkers, associate with them, speak to them and reason with them and do peaceful picketing of an educative character.
('72', 164, 1, 8, 289281) I look to the medical profession to put their heads together to find out why people drink, how they can be weaned from drink, find out effective, wholesome and healthful substitutes of drink.
('72', 164, 1, 9, 289473) Then there are our sisters.
('72', 164, 1, 10, 289501) They did great work during the non co operation days.
('72', 164, 1, 11, 289555) They should be organized again to revive the work under better auspices now.
('72', 164, 1, 12, 289632) Whilst their presence will be a sure deterrent, they will have few difficulties in the way.

('72', 164, 1, 14, 289818) Now, women can count on their help in their holy crusade.

('72', 164, 1, 16, 289920) Most of them have been up to now inert and inactive.
('72', 164, 1, 17, 289973) We should now ask them to pull themselves together and engage actively in the crusade.
('72', 164, 1, 18, 290060) We might well have a Prohibition League under which all these agencies may work in a regular and systematic manner.
('72', 164, 1, 19, 290176) The revenue drawn from excise may rightly be used for the prohibition campaign.
('72', 164, 1, 20, 290256) That will be no forbidden use of tainted money, but something like turning a channel of foul water into the holy Ganges and making it pure.
('72', 164, 1, 21, 290396) Above all, find out the plague spots., concentrate your forces on them.
('72', 164, 1, 22, 290468) Have meetings of the liquor contractors and liquor dealers, teach them how to turn an honest penny by converting their liquor booths into recreation centres.
('72', 164, 1, 23, 290626) I have already described 1 how these places may be turned into centres of harmless recreation and even of educative amusement.

('72', 165, 0, 1, 290818) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 165, 1, 2, 290860) 228. NOTES
('72', 165, 2, 3, 290871) DANGEROUS EVEN IN FRIGID ZONE Apropos of my remark 1 that alcohol might be required in a frigid zone, a friend sends me the following interesting paragraph from Liquor Control by G. E. G. Catlin who while discussing the apparent warming effect of alcohol says:
('72', 165, 3, 4, 291132) A simple mechanical consideration should, however, warn us against a misinterpretation of these results.
('72', 165, 3, 5, 291237) The body temperature has not been changed but the warmer blood has been sent to the surface where, if it is chilled, it returns to reduce the temperature of the whole system.
('72', 165, 3, 6, 291412) In cases where there is serious need of protection against cold, alcohol is not only useless but dangerous.
('72', 165, 3, 7, 291520) Fridtjof Nansen 2 stated that ‘my experience leads me to take a decided stand against the use of stimulants and narcotics of all sorts’ in Arctic journeys—in the case of alcohol owing to the increased risk of death by freezing.
('72', 165, 3, 8, 291748) We in India, however, do not need such testimony.
('72', 165, 3, 9, 291798) We have no excuse apparent or real for taking alcoholic drinks in our temperate zone where the sun gives us all the warmth we need.
('72', 165, 3, 10, 291930) NEEDLESS FEAR A Liberal friend 3 after highly appreciating the Congress programme of prohibition within three years thus expresses his fear about education:
('72', 165, 4, 11, 292087) The educational programme of the Congress seems to be causing some uneasiness.
('72', 165, 4, 12, 292166) There is a fear that it may result in blocking the progress of higher education.
('72', 165, 4, 13, 292247) I hope that till a well considered scheme is adumbrated and sufficient notice given of the changes proposed, no precipitate step should be taken, at any rate without giving an opportunity to the public to discuss the Congress proposals fully.
('72', 165, 4, 14, 292490) The fear is wholly needless.
('72', 165, 4, 15, 292519) The Working Committee has laid down no general policy.
('72', 165, 4, 16, 292574) The Congress, except for being responsible for the existence of many national educational institutions, e.g., the Kashi Vidyapith, Jamia Millia, Tilak Vidyapith, Bihar Vidyapith, Gujarat Vidyapith and the like, has made no general announcement.
('72', 165, 4, 17, 292819) What I have written is my personal contribution to the discussion.
('72', 165, 5, 18, 292886) 1 Vide “Against Ahimsa and Truth”, 14 8 1937 2 (1861 1930); Norwegian Polar explorer, who was awarded Nobel Prize in 1922 3 G. A. Natesan; vide “Letter to G. A. Natesan”, 24 8 1937
('72', 166, 0, 1, 293067) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 167
('72', 166, 1, 2, 293111) Indeed I feel most strongly about the vast injury that the existing system of education has done to the youth of the country and to the languages and general culture of India.
('72', 166, 1, 3, 293287) I hold my views strongly.
('72', 166, 1, 4, 293313) But I do not claim to have converted Congressmen in general.
('72', 166, 1, 5, 293374) What then can be said of those educationists who are outside even the Congress atmosphere and who dominate the Universities of India?
('72', 166, 1, 6, 293508) It is no easy task to convert them.
('72', 166, 1, 7, 293544) My friend and those who share his fear may rest assured that the advice given by Shri Shastriar will be taken to heart by those concerned and no serious step will be taken without due consideration and consultation with the persons whose advice is of value in matters educational.
('72', 166, 1, 8, 293825) I may add that I am already in correspondence with many educationists and am already receiving valuable opinions which I am happy to be able to say are in general agreement with my scheme.
('72', 166, 2, 9, 294014) WHAT ABOUT LITERACY?
('72', 166, 2, 10, 294035) I have received many opinions on the ideas I have been propounding in these columns on education.
('72', 166, 2, 11, 294133) I may be able to reproduce the most important of them in these columns.
('72', 166, 2, 12, 294205) For the moment I wish to answer a grievance a learned correspondent has made of the neglect of literacy of which he imagines I have been guilty.
('72', 166, 2, 13, 294350) There is nothing in what I have written to warrant such a belief.
('72', 166, 2, 14, 294416) For have I not contended that the children in the schools of my conception will receive every instruction through the handicrafts they may be taught?
('72', 166, 2, 15, 294566) That includes literacy.
('72', 166, 2, 16, 294590) In my scheme of things the hand will handle tools before it draws or traces the writing.
('72', 166, 2, 17, 294679) The eyes will read the pictures of letters and words as they will know other things in life, the ears will catch the names and meanings of things and sentences.
('72', 166, 2, 18, 294840) The whole training will be natural, responsive, and therefore the quickest and the cheapest in the land.
('72', 166, 2, 19, 294945) The children of my school will therefore read much more quickly than they will write.
('72', 166, 2, 20, 295031) And when they write they will not produce daubs as I do even now (thanks to my teachers), but they will trace correct letters even as they will trace correct figures of the objects they may see.
('72', 166, 2, 21, 295226) If the schools of my conception ever come into being, I make bold to say that they will vie with the most advanced schools in quickness, so far as reading is concerned, and even writing if it is common ground that the writing must be correct and not incorrect as now is in the vast majority of cases.
('72', 166, 2, 22, 295527) The children of the Segaon school may be said to be writing in accordance with the orthodox standard; they spoil slate and paper according to my standard.
('72', 166, 2, 23, 295682) Harijan, 28 8 1937
('72', 167, 0, 1, 295701) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 167, 1, 2, 295743) 229. THE GREATEST ACT
('72', 167, 2, 3, 295765) In as much as prohibition has been one of the chief planks of the Congress since the inauguration of the non cooperation movement in 1920, and thousands of men and women have had to suffer imprisonment and physical injury in furtherance of this cause, the Working Committee is of opinion that it is incumbent upon the Congress Ministries to work for this end.
('72', 167, 2, 4, 296125) The Committee expects them to bring about total prohibition in their respective provinces within three years.
('72', 167, 2, 5, 296235) The Working Committee appeals to the Ministries in other provinces, and to the Indian States also, to adopt this programme of moral and social uplift of the people.
('72', 167, 2, 6, 296400) I regard this resolution as the greatest act of the Working Com mittee 1 at any time of its chequered career.
('72', 167, 2, 7, 296510) The cry of prohibition has been always fashionable.
('72', 167, 2, 8, 296562) In 1920 it became one of the chief constructive items of the Congress.
('72', 167, 2, 9, 296633) The Congress, therefore, could not but go in for total prohibition immediately it came into power in any part of India.
('72', 167, 2, 10, 296753) The Ministers had to have the courage to sacrifice nearly Rs. eleven crores of revenue in the six provinces.
('72', 167, 2, 11, 296862) The Working Committee has taken the risk for the sake of redeeming its pledge and conserving the moral and the material welfare of those who are addicted to intoxicants and narcotics.
('72', 167, 2, 12, 297046) It is my fervent hope that the five provinces which have non Congress majorities will not hesitate to follow the example of the six provinces.
('72', 167, 2, 13, 297189) It is less difficult for them than for the six provinces to achieve prohibition.
('72', 167, 2, 14, 297270) And is it too much to expect the States to fall in with British India?
('72', 167, 2, 15, 297341) I know that many are sceptical about prohibition being achieved.
('72', 167, 2, 16, 297406) They think that the financial lure will be too strong for them to resist.
('72', 167, 2, 17, 297480) They argue that the addicts will procure their drinks and drugs anyhow, and that when the Ministers discover that prohibition means mere loss of revenue without any appreciable diminution in the consumption, though illicit, of drinks and drugs, they will revert to the tainted revenue and the then state will be worse than the present.
('72', 167, 2, 18, 297816) I do not share any such fear.
('72', 167, 2, 19, 297846) I believe there is the requisite moral momentum in the nation to achieve the noble end.
('72', 167, 2, 20, 297934) If prohibition is to be a reality, we shall begin to see the end not with the end of the three years but inside of six months.
('72', 167, 2, 21, 298061) And when the reality dawns upon India, those provinces or States that have lagged behind
('72', 167, 3, 22, 298150) 1 Which met at Wardha from August 14 to 17, 1937
('72', 168, 0, 1, 298199) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 169
('72', 168, 1, 2, 298243) are bound to bow to the inevitable.
('72', 168, 1, 3, 298279) We have the right, therefore, to expect the sympathy and support not only of all the parties in India including the Europeans but the best mind of the whole world in this, perhaps the greatest moral movement of the century.
('72', 168, 1, 4, 298503) If, then, prohibition is to mean a great moral awakening in India, the closing of liquor shops should merely mean the indispensable beginning of the movement ending in the complete weaning from drink and narcotics of those poor people and some rich people whom the habit has ruined, body and soul.
('72', 168, 1, 5, 298801) Such a consummation cannot be brought about by mere State effort.
('72', 168, 1, 6, 298867) At the risk of repetition of what is stated by Mahadev Desai in his notes, let me summarize what should, in my opinion, be the comprehensive programme: (1) A drink drug map showing the locality of liquor and opium shops in each province.
('72', 168, 1, 7, 299105) (2) Closing them as liquor shops on the expiry of the licences.
('72', 168, 1, 8, 299169) (3) Immediate earmarking of liquor revenue, whilst it is still being received, exclusively for the purpose of prohibition.
('72', 168, 1, 9, 299292) (4) Conversion, wherever possible, of the liquor shops into refreshment and recreation rooms in the hope that the original visitors will continue to use them, liquor contractors being themselves persuaded to conduct them if they will.
('72', 168, 1, 10, 299527) (5) Employment of the existing excise staff for detection of illicit distillation and drinking.
('72', 168, 1, 11, 299623) (6) Appeal to the educational institutions to devote a part of the time of teachers and students to temperance work.
('72', 168, 1, 12, 299740) (7) Appeal to the women to organize visits to the persons given to the drink and opium habits.
('72', 168, 1, 13, 299835) (8) Negotiation with the neighbouring States to undertake simultaneous prohibition.
('72', 168, 1, 14, 299919) (9) Engaging the voluntary or, if necessary, paid assistance of the medical profession for suggesting non alcoholic drinks and other substitutes for intoxicants and methods of weaning the addicts from their habit.
('72', 168, 1, 15, 300133) (10) Revival of the activities of temperance associations in support of the campaign against drink.
('72', 168, 1, 16, 300233) (11) Requiring employers of labour to open and maintain,
('72', 169, 0, 1, 300290) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 169, 1, 2, 300332) under first class management, refreshment, recreation and educational rooms for the use of their employees.
('72', 169, 1, 3, 300440) (12) Toddy tappers to be used for drawing sweet toddy for sale, as such, or conversion into gur.
('72', 169, 1, 4, 300537) I understand that the process of collecting sweet toddy for drinking, as such, or for making gur is different from the one for fermenting toddy.
('72', 169, 1, 5, 300682) So much for the campaign against drink and drugs.
('72', 169, 1, 6, 300732) Now as to how to make up for the loss of revenue in some provinces to the extent of one third.
('72', 169, 1, 7, 300827) I have unhesitatingly suggested cutting out the educational budget for which purpose mainly the excise revenue is used.
('72', 169, 1, 8, 300947) I still maintain that education can be made self supporting.
('72', 169, 1, 9, 301008) With this I must deal elsewhere.
('72', 169, 1, 10, 301041) 1 It cannot be made so in a day even if the possibility of its being made self supporting is accepted.
('72', 169, 1, 11, 301144) Existing obligations have to be met.
('72', 169, 1, 12, 301181) Therefore, fresh sources of revenue have to be tapped.
('72', 169, 1, 13, 301236) Death duties, tax on tobacco including bidis, have already been given as some suggestions.
('72', 169, 1, 14, 301327) If these are considered impossible of immediate accomplishment, short term loans may be devised to tide over the deficit; and if even that fails, the Central Government should be approached to curtail the military budget and give the provinces the proportionate grant.
('72', 169, 1, 15, 301596) The demand would be irresistible especially if it is demonstrated by the Provincial Governments that they do not need the military, at any rate for their internal peace and tranquillity.
('72', 169, 1, 16, 301783) Harijan, 28 8 1937
('72', 169, 2, 17, 301802) 230. “SUFFICIENTLY ACQUAINTED”
('72', 169, 3, 18, 301833) A professor writes:
('72', 169, 4, 19, 301853) You have suggested that even if an M. L. A. can express himself in English it is open to him to declare that he is not ‘sufficiently’ acquainted with it and thus enable the Speaker, who is of course not expected to question his bona fides, to allow him to speak in Hindustani.
('72', 169, 4, 20, 302130) I have read your remarks 2 with the greatest care but have not been able to see how a person having a scrupulous regard for truth can take this course, much less how you can suggest it.
('72', 169, 4, 21, 302316) Section 85 obviously refers to persons who find themselves unable to express their meaning in English well enough to make it intelligible to those who know English and not to those who do not know it.
('72', 169, 4, 22, 302517) There can be no
('72', 169, 5, 23, 302533) 1 Vide “Self supporting Education”, 11 9 1937 2 The reference is to Mahadev Desai’s interpretation of Section 85 of the Government of India Act of 1935; vide Appendix V.
('72', 170, 0, 1, 302703) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 171
('72', 170, 1, 2, 302747) question of ‘sufficient’ acquaintance with English for making oneself intelligible to the latter.
('72', 170, 1, 3, 302845) The wording is too clear to permit any other interpretation, and in face of it for anybody to declare himself insufficiently acquainted with English simply because there arc some fellow Members who do not understand English, looks like mere casuistry.
('72', 170, 1, 4, 303097) In U.P. they have got out of the difficulty by interpreting the words, ‘unacquainted or not sufficiently acquainted with the English language’ to mean less acquainted with the English language than with Hindi.
('72', 170, 1, 5, 303307) But I think the question of comparative acquaintance is also ruled out by the context.
('72', 170, 1, 6, 303394) I agree that the Section is highly obnoxious and must go.
('72', 170, 1, 7, 303452) If you suggested that it should be deliberately disobeyed, it would be a perfectly straightforward course and there could be no objection at least of the conscientious type.
('72', 170, 1, 8, 303626) As it is, however, you must have some justification for the course you have suggested, which I have been unable to see.
('72', 170, 1, 9, 303746) There must be others in the same position and we shall all benefit if you elucidate the point in the Harijan.
('72', 170, 1, 10, 303856) “Sufficient” can only have a relative meaning, not absolute.
('72', 170, 1, 11, 303917) Even an M. A. may not have “sufficient acquaintance” with English for the purpose before him.
('72', 170, 1, 12, 304011) Thus an M. A. from U. P. will surely not have sufficient knowledge of English to make himself understood by Hindustani speaking matriculates.
('72', 170, 1, 13, 304153) My teachers had often to speak in Gujarati in order to make themselves understood to the class they were teaching.
('72', 170, 1, 14, 304268) The reason was that they, most of them graduates, had to struggle through their English to make themselves intelligible to their class.
('72', 170, 1, 15, 304404) Speaking in Gujarati they became fluent, and our eyes sparkled as we drank in the wisdom they distilled into us.
('72', 170, 1, 16, 304517) If I was Speaker of an Assembly, I would certainly allow a most polished speaker in English to speak in Hindustani if he believed that he did not know sufficient English for the audience before him.
('72', 170, 1, 17, 304716) It is not a question of grammar or fluency.
('72', 170, 1, 18, 304760) It is a question of intelligibility.
('72', 170, 1, 19, 304797) To give any other mean ing to the Section would be to frustrate its very object.
('72', 170, 1, 20, 304878) An ungram matical English speech would amount to sufficient acquaintance with English if the audience could only understand English and no other language.
('72', 170, 1, 21, 305033) Such things have often happened during my numerous tours in India.
('72', 170, 1, 22, 305100) The meaning given in these columns is an honest atte mpt to deal with a difficult situation.
('72', 170, 1, 23, 305193) My well known partiality for the Indian languages for India had nothing to do with the inter pretation.
('72', 170, 1, 24, 305297) If I could not have honestly subscribed to the interpretation which Mahadev Desai’s ingenious brain conceived, I would certainly not have allowed it to go in and would have gladly advised a battle with the Government for a just and workable interpretation of the phrase “sufficiently acquianted”.
('72', 170, 1, 25, 305594) No doubt the proper course is to have the Section amended as the Punjab Premier has already suggested.
('72', 170, 1, 26, 305697) Harijan, 28 8 1937
('72', 171, 0, 1, 305716) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('72', 171, 3, 4, 305813) MY DEAR KU., I wonder if Rao has left Maganwadi.

('72', 173, 1, 2, 309104) 234. UNDER SHADOW OF LYNCH LAW 1
('72', 173, 2, 3, 309137) The following is a free translation of a letter 2 of Shri Narahari Parikh on the conditions of Harijans in Kheda District.
('72', 173, 2, 4, 309260) If this is a correct picture of the actual state of things, it should not be beyond the power of the Kheda District Congress Committee to cope with it.
('72', 173, 2, 5, 309412) Harijan, 4 9 1937
('72', 173, 3, 6, 309430) 235. A SUPERSTITION
('72', 173, 4, 7, 309450) There is no limit to superstitions in Kathiawar.
('72', 173, 4, 8, 309499) One such superstition concerns the taboo on the castration of calves.
('72', 173, 4, 9, 309569) It is found particularly in Kathiawar.
('72', 173, 4, 10, 309608) Peasants cannot earn their livelihood without oxen.
('72', 173, 4, 11, 309660) Hence they would buy oxen, allowing their own calves to wander about or die or let them be led to the slaughter house, and consider this as their dharma.
('72', 173, 4, 12, 309814) Such superstitions can be wiped out only when the rulers and the intelligent section of the public work against them whole heartedly.
('72', 173, 4, 13, 309948) A policy of punishment is perhaps pardonable in such instances.
('72', 173, 4, 14, 310012) Such a policy, when aimed at public welfare and not meant as punishment for its own sake, should be carefully devised.
('72', 173, 4, 15, 310131) Depriving the owners of their calves if they refuse to get them castrated may be the best punishment, and it may be accompanied by the condition that the owner could have his calf back provided he pays the charge of castrating it and the cost of keeping it.
('72', 173, 4, 16, 310389) If the fees for castration and the daily expense are fixed in advance, the public would not be handicapped and even a superstitious man would feel satisfied that the sin of castration is committed not by him but by the State.
('72', 173, 4, 17, 310615) The State must have a team of workers who would do the necessary propaganda about it, and it should be their job to remove such superstitions.
('72', 173, 4, 18, 310758) I would consider such a thing part of education, for, what value can knowledge have if it is not used for ending wrong practices among people?
('72', 173, 5, 19, 310901) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 29 8 1937
('72', 173, 6, 20, 310942) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu.
('72', 173, 6, 21, 311001) 29 8 1937. 2 Not reproduced here.
('72', 173, 6, 22, 311035) Narahari Parikh had written about the Harijans of Kheda District who could not get their children admitted to pubilc schools

('72', 175, 9, 15, 313089) 239. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('72', 175, 10, 16, 313117) [August 31, 1937] 2
('72', 175, 11, 17, 313137) I gladly release the messages 3 that passed between the Andamans prisoners and me.
('72', 175, 11, 18, 313220) In view of the prisoners’ noble response to my appeal for a declaration of their present attitude on terrorist methods, let us hope that all of them will be unconditionally discharged.
('72', 175, 11, 19, 313405) I have appealed to the proper quarters for relief, in which I am sure the whole country will join.
('72', 175, 12, 20, 313504) The Hindu, 1 9 1937
('72', 175, 13, 21, 313524) 1 At 7 p.m.
('72', 175, 13, 22, 313536) on the same day, Gandhiii received the following reply from the prisoners: “Touched by nationwide appeal and your message.
('72', 175, 13, 23, 313659) We supend hunger strike on assurance that the whole country has taken up our demands and because we are confidently hoping that within a reasonable period of time you will succeed in getting all our demands fulfilled.
('72', 175, 13, 24, 313877) We are glad you have given us the opportunity to express our firm opinion on terrorism.
('72', 175, 13, 25, 313965) We feel honoured to inform you and through you the nation that those of us who ever believed terrorism do not hold to it any more and are convinced of its futility as a political weapon or creed.
('72', 175, 13, 26, 314161) We declare that it definitely retards rather than advances the cause of our county.” 2 Mahadev Desai released the correspondence to the Press on this date.

('72', 178, 5, 9, 317300) 244. LETTER TO P. G. MATHEW
('72', 178, 6, 10, 317328) SEGAON, WARDHA, September 1, 1937
('72', 178, 7, 11, 317362) MY DEAR MATHEW, Whether I write “love” or do not makes no difference in my attitude towards you.
('72', 178, 7, 12, 317459) It all depends under what pressure I write letters.
('72', 178, 7, 13, 317511) There is no royal road to becoming moral.
('72', 178, 7, 14, 317553) You do so by prayer and penance and by living for the service of humanity.
('72', 178, 7, 15, 317628) When you do that you have no time to become immoral.
('72', 178, 7, 16, 317681) Of course, marriage is the ordinary thing for all.
('72', 178, 7, 17, 317732) I overcame the impulse to the extent I have done simply because the impulse for service was greater than the sexual impulse.
('72', 178, 7, 18, 317857) I do not know how many people who are associated with me are pure—nor have I any desire to pry into their lives.
('72', 178, 7, 19, 317970) I assume their purity until their impurity obtrudes itself upon my gaze.
('72', 178, 7, 20, 318043) A celibate is wedded to his work with which he has fallen in love.

('72', 180, 7, 13, 320304) 247. A SILENT CO WORKER GONE 1
('72', 180, 8, 14, 320335) [September 1, 1937] The inmates of the Satyagraha Ashram of Sabarmati are today a scattered family, joined together only by their common vow of silent service.
('72', 180, 8, 15, 320495) No one, perhaps, with the exception of the late Shri Maganlal Gandhi, personified so nearly this self effacing ideal as Shri Chhotelal Jain whose death, through suicide, has just stunned me.
('72', 180, 8, 16, 320686) I have not adequate language to describe his insatiable capacity for silent service.
('72', 180, 8, 17, 320771) He dreaded publicity and loved to live and serve unknown.
('72', 180, 8, 18, 320829) In fact it may be said of him that his right hand did not know what his left hand was doing.
('72', 180, 8, 19, 320922) I do not remember his ever visting his relations or being visited by them.
('72', 180, 8, 20, 320997) He never even mentioned them to anyone.
('72', 180, 8, 21, 321037) At the time of writing I do not even know their names or whereabouts.
('72', 180, 8, 22, 321107) I have the good luck to have a band of co workers who are to me as my hands and feet.
('72', 180, 8, 23, 321193) Without their willing and loyal cooperation I should feel utterly helpless.
('72', 180, 8, 24, 321269) Prominent among these was Chhotelal.
('72', 180, 9, 25, 321306) 1 The original in Gujarati of which this is an adaptation by Pyarelal appeared in Harijanbandhu, 5 9 1937.
('72', 181, 0, 1, 321413) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 181, 1, 2, 321455) He had a versatile and powerful intelligence which shirked no task however difficult.
('72', 181, 1, 3, 321541) He was a born linguist.
('72', 181, 1, 4, 321565) Rajputana being his home, Hindi was his mother tongue, but he knew Gujarati, Marathi, Bengali, Tamil, Sanskrit and English as well.
('72', 181, 1, 5, 321697) He knew the Urdu script.
('72', 181, 1, 6, 321722) I have seldom seen anybody with such aptitude for quickly mastering a new language or a new task.
('72', 181, 1, 7, 321820) He was one of the foundation members of the Sabarmati Ashram.
('72', 181, 1, 8, 321882) He went through the whole range of Ashram activities with natural ease, and hardly touched anything that he did not adorn.
('72', 181, 1, 9, 322005) Thus he felt equally at home whether he was engaged in kitchen work, conservancy, spinning or weaving, accounts, or translation work, or correspondence.
('72', 181, 1, 10, 322158) He had an equal share with the late Maganlal in the writing of Vanatshastra 1. The riskier a job the more it was welcomed by Chhotelal, and once he took it up, he knew no rest till he had seen it through.
('72', 181, 1, 11, 322363) He threw himself, with the indefatigable energy which was his characteristic, into any task that he took up, and at the end of it he would still be fresh and ready for the next.
('72', 181, 1, 12, 322541) The words weariness and fatigue were not in his dictionary.
('72', 181, 1, 13, 322601) To render service only, never to receive any, was the passion of his life.
('72', 181, 1, 14, 322676) When the All India Village Industries Association was started at Wardha, it was Chhotelal who first learnt and then introduced the art of ghani 2 in Maganwadi.
('72', 181, 1, 15, 322836) It was he who introduced the wooden hand mill for rice husking.
('72', 181, 1, 16, 322900) Again, it was he who started bee culture there.
('72', 181, 1, 17, 322948) Today I feel disconsolate and crippled by his loss.
('72', 181, 1, 18, 323000) And I am sure, if we could only know it, the same must be the feeling of the bees whom he had gathered and was looking after with a mother’s care.
('72', 181, 1, 19, 323147) I do not know who else will look after them with the loving care of Chhotelal.
('72', 181, 1, 20, 323226) For, Chhotelal had literally become apiculture mad.
('72', 181, 1, 21, 323278) In the course of his quest he had contracted paratyphoid fever which had a fatal ending.
('72', 181, 1, 22, 323367) He had been bed ridden for hardly six or seven days, but the very thought of being a helpless charge upon others evidently ate into him, and on Tuesday night, the 31st of August, leaving everybody asleep, he put an end to his life by throwing himself into the Maganwadi well.
('72', 181, 1, 23, 323643) The corpse was recovered from the well today, Wednesday, at 4 p.
('72', 181, 1, 24, 323708) and even as I pen these lines at Segaon, at 8 p.
('72', 181, 1, 25, 323757) m., his body is being cremated at Wardha.
('72', 181, 1, 26, 323799) I have not the heart to rebuke Chhotelal for his suicide.
('72', 181, 1, 27, 323857) He was no coward.
('72', 181, 1, 28, 323875) He was guilty of no unworthy deed.
('72', 181, 1, 29, 323910) He could laugh at
('72', 181, 2, 30, 323928) 1 A Gujarati treatise on the science of weaving 2 Oil press
('72', 182, 0, 1, 323988) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 183
('72', 182, 1, 2, 324032) suffering.
('72', 182, 1, 3, 324043) I cannot account for this self immolation except on the supposition that he could no longer brook to be nursed.
('72', 182, 1, 4, 324155) No doubt that is a sign of subtle pride.
('72', 182, 1, 5, 324196) But there it was.
('72', 182, 1, 6, 324214) He was not conscious of it.
('72', 182, 1, 7, 324242) His name figured in the Delhi Conspiracy Case of 1915. He was acquitted.
('72', 182, 1, 8, 324315) He had told me he did not desire acquittal.
('72', 182, 1, 9, 324359) A casual reading of some of my writings gave a new turn to his life and outlook.
('72', 182, 1, 10, 324440) He studied my activities in South Africa, and from a violent revolutionary became a votary of ahimsa.
('72', 182, 1, 11, 324542) He shed his cult of violence as completely and naturally as a snake does its outworn skin, but he could never completely control the proneness to anger and pride that were deeply ingrained in his nature.
('72', 182, 1, 12, 324746) Did he expiate with his life for these?
('72', 182, 1, 13, 324786) By his death (he was 42 1) he has left me heavily in his debt.
('72', 182, 1, 14, 324849) I had entertained high hopes of him.
('72', 182, 1, 15, 324886) I could not tolerate any imperfection in him and so he had often to bear the brunt of my impatience as, perhaps, only one or two besides him have borne.
('72', 182, 1, 16, 325039) But he never complained, never even winced.
('72', 182, 1, 17, 325083) Had I any right to put him through this fire as I used to?
('72', 182, 1, 18, 325142) I had hoped one day to discharge my debt towards him by offering him as a sacrifice at the altar of Hindu Muslim unity, untouchability or cow protection.
('72', 182, 1, 19, 325296) To my mind these are some of the altars in the great yajna of the swaraj of my dream.
('72', 182, 1, 20, 325382) And Chhotelal was in the front rank of the few who, to my knowledge, had the strength and capacity to claim this privilege.
('72', 182, 1, 21, 325506) The country needs an army of silent warriors like him.
('72', 182, 1, 22, 325561) The achievement of swaraj, which to me is synonymous with Ramaraj, is no joke.
('72', 182, 1, 23, 325640) Let these few glimpses of Chhotelal’s life serve as an inspiration in our striving for India’s freedom.
('72', 182, 1, 24, 325744) Harijan, 11 9 1937

('72', 186, 7, 10, 331382) 253. NOTES
('72', 186, 8, 11, 331393) APPEAL TO DISCHARGED PRISONERS My congratulations to the Congress Ministries who are discharging prisoners who had been condemned for proved violence done from political motives, and also the discharged prisoners.
('72', 186, 8, 12, 331607) Personally I draw no distinction between violence done from a private motive or from a political motive.
('72', 186, 8, 13, 331712) The effect on the sufferers does not vary with the motive of the authors of violence.
('72', 186, 8, 14, 331798) But as an out and out believer in non violence I do not believe in the system of punishments for crimes, whether private or public.
('72', 186, 8, 15, 331930) Therefore, I should welcome an extension of the principle which guides the Ministers in discharging prisoners; but I am aware that they do not share my extreme views on non violence.
('72', 186, 8, 16, 332113) Their reason, therefore, for discharging the prisoners condemned for violence is not the same as I would apply.
('72', 186, 8, 17, 332225) They have been guided, naturally and rightly, by the purely political motive, viz., to establish contact with those who have hitherto believed in the efficacy of a species of violence for the attainment of India’s freedom.
('72', 186, 8, 18, 332448) They want to wean these men from violence and harness their energy for the Congress method of non violence.
('72', 186, 8, 19, 332556) If my reading of the Congress method is correct, the large public demonstration that took place on the discharge of Kakori prisoners was, to say the least, a political mistake.
('72', 186, 8, 20, 332733) Did the thousands of demonstrators approve of the
('72', 187, 0, 1, 332783) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 187, 1, 2, 332825) acts said to have been committed by these prisoners, let me hope, in mistaken zeal?
('72', 187, 1, 3, 332909) If they did, they have evidently not understood the Congress method; what is more, they have embarrassed the Ministry and made more difficult the task of giving the fullest liberty to the people in their Provinces.
('72', 187, 1, 4, 333124) We ought to learn to take such ministerial acts as in the natural course and, therefore, with calmness.
('72', 187, 1, 5, 333228) Kakori prisoners are no fools.
('72', 187, 1, 6, 333259) They are able, intelligent men, with unyielding love of their country.
('72', 187, 1, 7, 333330) They and all such prisoners will pave the way for the liberty of others, if they use their liberty to help Congress Ministers by their exemplary conduct and by proving themselves true Congressmen, taking their full share in strengthening the Congress organization by silent and selfless service.
('72', 187, 1, 8, 333626) For they should know that Congress Ministers seem to be having their own way in many matters because they have inspired the respective Governors with confidence in their ability to handle efficiently all the departments under their charge, especially that of law and order, without the intervention of the police and military.
('72', 187, 1, 9, 333953) The moment they lose their credit in this respect and are obliged to fall back on these two so called limbs of the law, the confidence will be weakened and their authority all but gone.
('72', 187, 1, 10, 334139) Whilst power, superimposed, always needs the help of police and military, power generated from within should have little or no use for them.
('72', 187, 1, 11, 334280) GAMBLING AND VICE
('72', 187, 2, 12, 334298) In the provinces where the Congress has a majority, all kinds of hopes have been raised.
('72', 187, 2, 13, 334387) Some are legitimate and will, no doubt, be fulfilled.
('72', 187, 2, 14, 334441) Some others cannot be.
('72', 187, 2, 15, 334464) Thus the people who indulge in gambling, which unfortunately is ever on the increase in the Bombay Presidency, think that gambling will be legalized and surreptitious dens that cover Bombay will be no longer required.
('72', 187, 2, 16, 334682) I am not quite sure that even if gambling is legalized on a universal scale, as it is already in a restricted manner, there will be no illegal dens.
('72', 187, 2, 17, 334831) Thus it has been suggested that the Turf Club, which has the monopoly of gambling on the racecourse, should be allowed to open an additional entrance to make it easier for poor people to gamble.
('72', 187, 2, 18, 335026) The bait offered is a larger revenue.
('72', 187, 2, 19, 335064) A similar suggestion has been made for the regulation and licensing of brothels.
('72', 187, 2, 20, 335145) The argument advanced, as in all such cases, is that the vice will continue whether it is legalized or not and, therefore, it is better to legalize it and make it safe for those who visit the brothels.
('72', 187, 2, 21, 335347) Let me hope that the Ministers will not fall into this
('72', 188, 0, 1, 335402) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 189
('72', 188, 1, 2, 335446) The proper method of dealing with brothels is for the women to carry on a double propaganda, (a) amongst women who sell their honour for a livelihood and (b) amongst men whom they must shame into behaving better towards their sisters whom they ignorantly or insolently call the weaker sex.
('72', 188, 1, 3, 335736) I remember years and years ago in the early nineties when the brave Salvation Army people, at the risk of their own lives, used to carry on picketing at the corners of notorious streets of Bombay which were filled with houses of ill fame.
('72', 188, 1, 4, 335975) There is no reason why some such thing should not be organized on a large scale.
('72', 188, 1, 5, 336056) As for gambling on the racecourse, it is, so far as I am aware, an importation, like many other importations, from the West, and if I had my way [I] would withdraw the protection of the law that gambling on the racecourse enjoys even to the extent it does.
('72', 188, 1, 6, 336313) The Congress programme being one of self purification, as is stated in so many words in the resolution 1 of 1920, the Congress can have nothing to do with income derived from any vice.
('72', 188, 1, 7, 336498) The Ministers will, therefore, use the authority that they have obtained for educating public opinion in the right direction and for stopping gambling in high quarters.
('72', 188, 1, 8, 336667) It is useless to hope that the unwary public will not copy the bad manners of the so called high placed people.
('72', 188, 1, 9, 336779) I have heard it argued that horse racing is necessary for breeding good horses.
('72', 188, 1, 10, 336859) There may be truth in this.
('72', 188, 1, 11, 336887) Is it not possible to have horse racing without gambling, or is gambling also an aid to the good breeding of horses?
('72', 188, 1, 12, 337004) Harijan, 4 9 1937
('72', 188, 2, 13, 337022) 254. MY MEANING OF OFFICE ACCEPTANCE
('72', 188, 3, 14, 337059) Shri Shankerrao Deo 2 writes:
('72', 188, 4, 15, 337089) In your note “Not Instrument of Instructions” 3 in the last Harijan, you say in the second paragraph, “For me office acceptance has a special meaning even in the terms of the Congress manifesto and resolutions.
('72', 188, 4, 16, 337300) It would be wrong if I did not put before the Ministers and the public my meaning of office acceptance.” As I have understood you, you arefor office acceptance for serving the masses and consolidating the Congress position through constructive programme.
('72', 188, 4, 17, 337555) But I think you should explain in greater detail your meaning of office acceptance.
('72', 188, 5, 18, 337639) 1 Vide “ Congress Resolution on Non Co Operation” 2 President, Maharashtra Provincial Congress Committee 3 Vide “Notes”, sub title”Not Instrument of Instructions”
('72', 189, 0, 1, 337802) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 189, 1, 2, 337844) Rightly or wrongly, since 1920 the Congress minded millions have firmly held the view that the British domination of India has been on the whole a curse.
('72', 189, 1, 3, 337998) It has been as much sustained by British arms as it has been through the legislatures, distribution of titles, the law courts, the educational institutions, the financial policy and the like.
('72', 189, 1, 4, 338190) The Congress came to the conclusion that the guns should not be feared, but that the organized violence of which the British guns were a naked emblem should be met by the organized non violence of the people, and the legislatures and the rest by non co operating with them.
('72', 189, 1, 5, 338464) There was a strong and effective, positive side to the foregoing plan of non co operation, which became known as the constructive programme.
('72', 189, 1, 6, 338605) The nation succeeded to the exact extent of its success in the programme of action laid down in 1920. Now this policy has never changed; not even the terms have been revoked by the Congress.
('72', 189, 1, 7, 338796) In my opinion all the resolutions since passed by the Congress are not a repudiation but a fulfilment of the original, so long as the mentality behind all of them remains the same as in 1920. The corner stone of the policy of 1920 was organized national non violence.
('72', 189, 1, 8, 339064) The British system was wooden, even Satanic; not so the men and women behind the system.
('72', 189, 1, 9, 339153) Our non violence, therefore, meant that we were out to convert the administrators of the system, not to destroy them; the conversion may or may not be willing.
('72', 189, 1, 10, 339313) If, notwithstanding their desire to the contrary, they saw that their guns and everything they had created for the consolidation of their authority were useless because of our non use of them, they could not do otherwise than bow to the inevitable and either retire from the scene, or remain on our terms, i.
('72', 189, 1, 11, 339622) e., as friends to co operate with us, not as rulers to impose their will upon us.
('72', 189, 1, 12, 339704) If Congressmen have entered the legislatures and have accepted office with that mentality, and if the British administrators tolerate Congress Ministries indefinitely, the Congress will be on a fair way to wreck the Act 1 and to achieve complete independence.
('72', 189, 1, 13, 339964) For an indefinite prolongation of the Ministries on the terms mentioned by me means an ever increasing power of the Congress till it becomes irresistible and is able to have its way all along the line.
('72', 189, 1, 14, 340166) The first indispensable condition of the attainment of such a consummation
('72', 189, 2, 15, 340241) 1 Government of India Act of 1935
('72', 190, 0, 1, 340275) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 191
('72', 190, 1, 2, 340319) means willing exercise of non violence by the whole mass of the people.
('72', 190, 1, 3, 340391) That means perfect communal co operation and friendship, the eradication of untouchability, willing restraint of the addicts to the drink and opium habits, the social enfranchisement of women, the progressive amelioration of the toiling millions in the villages, free and compulsory primary education—not in name as it is today, but in reality, as I have ventured to adumbrate—the gradual eradication of superstitions of proved harmfulness through adult mass education, a complete overhauling of the system of higher education so as to answer the wants of the millions instead of the few middle class people, a radical change in the legal machinery so as to make justice pure and inexpensive, conversion of jails into reformatories in which detention would be not a course of punishment but a complete course of the education of those miscalled convicts but who are in fact temporarily deranged.
('72', 190, 1, 4, 341287) This is not conceived as a terribly long plan of action.
('72', 190, 1, 5, 341344) Every one of the items suggested by me can be put into motion today, without let or hindrance, if we have the will.
('72', 190, 1, 6, 341460) I had not studied the Act when I advised office acceptance.
('72', 190, 1, 7, 341520) I have since been studying Provincial Autonomy by Prof.
('72', 190, 1, 8, 341576) K. T. Shah.
('72', 190, 1, 9, 341588) It is an energetic but true indictment of the Act from the orthodox standpoint.
('72', 190, 1, 10, 341668) But the three months’ self denial of the Congress has changed the atmosphere.
('72', 190, 1, 11, 341746) I see nothing in the Act to prevent the Congress Ministers from undertaking the programme suggested by me.
('72', 190, 1, 12, 341853) The special powers and safeguards come into play only when there is violence in the country, or a clash between minorities and the so called majority community, which is another word for violence.
('72', 190, 1, 13, 342050) I detect in the Act a profound distrust of the nation’s capacity to rule itself running through every Section and an inevitable desire to perpetuate British rule, but at the same time a bold experiment of wooing the masses to the British side, and, failing that, a resignation to their will to reject British domination.
('72', 190, 1, 14, 342371) The Congress has gone in to convert these missionaries.
('72', 190, 1, 15, 342427) And I have not a shadow of doubt that if the Congress is true to the spirit of non violence, non co operation and self purification, it will succeed in its mission.
('72', 190, 1, 16, 342592) Harijan, 4 9 1937
('72', 191, 0, 1, 342610) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 191, 1, 2, 342652) 255. THE NATIONAL TRICOLOUR 1
('72', 191, 2, 3, 342682) A friend writes: 2
('72', 191, 3, 4, 342701) In accordance with President Jawaharlal’s instructions Cawnpore
('72', 191, 4, 5, 342765) observed the 1st of August as a National Flag Day and national flags were
('72', 191, 5, 6, 342839) flown from all parts of the city.
('72', 191, 5, 7, 342873) But these flags were manufactured anyhow by
('72', 191, 6, 8, 342917) the individuals concerned according to their whims without any regard .
('72', 191, 7, 9, 342989) uniformity of size, shape or colour.
('72', 191, 7, 10, 343026) Some of the flags had the figure of the
('72', 191, 8, 11, 343066) spinning wheel printed on them; in others it was conspicuous by its absence.
('72', 191, 9, 12, 343143) Today, after the lapse of a fortnight, most of these flags present a sorry
('72', 191, 10, 13, 343218) spectacle.
('72', 191, 10, 14, 343229) I would, therefore, suggest that arrangements should be made to
('72', 191, 11, 15, 343293) see that only flags of standard sizes, shape and colour are manufactured.
('72', 191, 12, 16, 343367) It seems to me that this can be effectively done only by bringing the
('72', 191, 13, 17, 343437) manufacture and sale of national flags under a centralized control.
('72', 191, 13, 18, 343505) If the facts are as described by my correspondent, it calls for serious thought.
('72', 191, 13, 19, 343586) We have been using this flag for the last seventeen years.
('72', 191, 13, 20, 343645) 3 A national flag would lose all its value if it did not strictly conform to the standard laid down.
('72', 191, 13, 21, 343746) Even in the matter of ordinary articles we like to satisfy ourselves as to their size, shape, colour, etc., before we go in for them.
('72', 191, 13, 22, 343880) How much more so must it be, then, with our national flag for which we are pledged to live and die?
('72', 191, 13, 23, 343980) The national flag symbolizes a nation’s self respect and dignity its ideals and aspirations.
('72', 191, 13, 24, 344073) It must, therefore, be capable of easy identification like coins.
('72', 191, 13, 25, 344139) Only the strictest conformity to the standard specifications can invest it with the desired sanctity.
('72', 191, 13, 26, 344241) It should hurt our sense of national pride and self respect to use a flag that is slipshod or slovenly made.
('72', 191, 13, 27, 344350) How can a flag that is a mere clout and is dyed anyhow evoke the feelings of deep reverence that one associates with a national flag?
('72', 191, 13, 28, 344484) I am, therefore, in entire agreement with my correspondent that our national flag should be strictly standardized.
('72', 191, 13, 29, 344599) And this can be best done by having its manufacture centralized as coins are in mint.
('72', 191, 13, 30, 344685) In my opinion the All India Spinners’ Association, working under theguidance of the All India Congress Committee, would be the fittest
('72', 191, 14, 31, 344820) 1 The Hindi original appeared in Harijan Sevak, 11 9 1937. 2 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('72', 191, 14, 32, 344916) 3 This sentence is from Harijan Sevak.
('72', 192, 0, 1, 344955) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 193
('72', 192, 1, 2, 344999) agency for this purpose.
('72', 192, 1, 3, 345024) The collaboration of the two bodies would provide the surest guarantee of strict conformity to the standard specifications as to its size, shape, colour, etc.
('72', 192, 2, 4, 345183) Harijan, 4 9 1937, and Harijan Sevak, 11 9 1937

('72', 194, 2, 7, 348440) 260. LETTER TO GLADYS OWEN
('72', 194, 3, 8, 348467) SEGAON, WARDHA, September 5, 1937
('72', 194, 4, 9, 348501) MY DEAR GLADYS, I like your idea of throwing yourself heart and soul into the Chinese movement.
('72', 194, 4, 10, 348597) But I do not know how I can give the lead.
('72', 194, 4, 11, 348640) No external power can guide you.
('72', 194, 4, 12, 348673) The direction and the strength have to come from within.
('72', 194, 4, 13, 348730) I have just heard from Muriel 1. She too wants me to do something for China.
('72', 194, 4, 14, 348807) I must confess that I am fairly groping.
('72', 194, 4, 15, 348848) China wants to give battle to Japan on her own ground.
('72', 194, 4, 16, 348903) And in this kind of business I am totally at sea.
('72', 194, 4, 17, 348953) I do not know how the message of non violence can be delivered to China as I do not know how it can be delivered to Spain.
('72', 194, 4, 18, 349076) My theatre of action is, therefore, only India.
('72', 194, 4, 19, 349124) If India imbibes the message through and through, then there is hope for whole world.
('72', 194, 4, 20, 349210) If India does not, so far as I can see, a world catastrophe cannot be prevented.
('72', 194, 5, 21, 349291) Yours sincerely, BAPU
('72', 194, 6, 22, 349313) From a photostat: G.N. 10571
('72', 194, 7, 23, 349342) 1 Muriel Lester

('72', 197, 7, 13, 352768) The incompleteness you see in the prisoners’ reply 2 to my request had not escaped me, but I was very much struck by the frank and unequivocal manner in which they gave me satisfaction so far as terrorist methods are concerned.

('72', 204, 9, 32, 364765) They wanted to understand from Gandhiji his idea of the revolution he intended to bring about in the system of education.
