('72', 206, 1, 2, 367066) 280. ARE CHRISTIANS AGAINST PROHIBITION?
('72', 206, 2, 3, 367107) Having received protests from Christian correspondents against prohibition, I asked Mahadev Desai to write to a few representative Christian friends to ascertain their views on the question.
('72', 206, 2, 4, 367298) Here are two answers.
('72', 206, 2, 5, 367320) Shri P. O. Phillip, Indian Secretary of the National Christian Council of India, writes: 1
('72', 206, 3, 6, 367411) I am not surprised to hear that a number of Christian friends are writing to you to say that ‘the policy of prohibition trenches upon their privilege to drink’.
('72', 206, 3, 7, 367572) I may not be far wrong in thinking that most of the correspondents who write to you in that strain are Roman Catholics or those brought up in Anglo Catholic traditions.
('72', 206, 3, 8, 367741) There is .
('72', 206, 3, 9, 367752) no social or religious disapproval among Roman Catholics in India in regard to drinking in moderation as there is among Muslims and higher caste Hindus.
('72', 206, 3, 10, 367905) Among Protestant Christians the attitude toward drink is different.
('72', 206, 4, 11, 367973) The use of alcoholic drink even in moderation is looked upon with social and religious disapprobation among Protestant Christian communities.
('72', 206, 5, 12, 368115) Among Roman Catholics also there is awakening to the evils of drink.
('72', 206, 5, 13, 368184) While the authorities of the Catholic Church may officially maintain that there is nothing wrong in drinking in moderation, they cannot shut their eyes to the moral and economic ruin that drink is causing among their people.
('72', 206, 5, 14, 368409) As a Christian Indian I rejoice that the Congress Ministries have placed prohibition in the very forefront of their programme.
('72', 206, 5, 15, 368536) In the past, few British and American missionaries lent support to the anti drink campaign of the Congress, under the mistaken notion that it was adopted only to harass the British Government and not from a genuine desire for reform.
('72', 206, 5, 16, 368770) Unfortunately Indian Christians also took their cue from the missionaries and generally kept aloof from the movement.
('72', 206, 5, 17, 368888) But the sincerity of the leaders of the Congress in advocating prohibition is beyond question.
('72', 206, 6, 18, 368983) The poorer classes in the villages, including Christians, need protection more than any other group of people from the temptations of drink now placed before them.
('72', 206, 6, 19, 369147) Indian villages will have new life and prosperity when drink is abolished.
('72', 206, 6, 20, 369222) The Christian Indian community along with other communities stands to gain immensely by this measure.
('72', 206, 7, 21, 369324) Christian Indians who love India and care for the real welfare of the
('72', 206, 8, 22, 369394) 1 Only extracts from the letter are reproduced here.

('72', 207, 3, 13, 370836) 281. NOTES
('72', 207, 4, 14, 370847) A WELCOME MOVE The joint statement issued by Moulvi Abdul Haq Saheb and Shri Rajendra Prasad over the Hindi Urdu controversy leads one to hope that the controversy will now end and those who are interested in the evolution of an inter provincial speech will be able to discuss the question on its merits and discover a plan of joint action.
('72', 207, 4, 15, 371188) Here is the statement:
('72', 207, 5, 16, 371211) We had an opportunity, on the occasion of the meeting of the Bihar Urdu Committee at Patna on 28 8 37, to discuss the problem of the Hindustani language with each other and with some other friends.
('72', 207, 5, 17, 371409) We were anxious to
('72', 207, 6, 18, 371428) 1 Congress Ministries were formed in Bombay, Madras, the United Provinces, Bihar, the Central Provinces and Orissa.
('72', 207, 6, 19, 371544) 2 Vide “Against Ahimsa and Truth?”,.
('72', 207, 6, 20, 371581) Also “Citicism Answered”
('72', 208, 0, 1, 371606) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 209
('72', 208, 1, 2, 371650) remove the misunderstandings which have been unfortunately created in connection with the Urdu Hindi Hindustani controversy.
('72', 208, 1, 3, 371775) We are glad to be able to say that as a result of our discussions ranging over various aspects of this problem, we found ourselves in substantial agreement about various points raised.
('72', 208, 1, 4, 371960) We are agreed that Hindustani should be the common language of India and should be written in both the Urdu and [the] Nagari characters which should be recognized for all official and educational purposes.
('72', 208, 1, 5, 372166) By ‘Hindustani’ we mean the largest common factor of the languages spoken in Northern India, and we believe that common usage should be the criterion for the selection and inclusion of words in its vocabulary.
('72', 208, 1, 6, 372376) We are further of opinion that the fullest opportunities for development should be vouchsafed both to Urdu and Hindi and [the] literary languages.
('72', 208, 1, 7, 372523) We suggest that an attempt should be made to compile, through the co operation of Urdu and Hindi scholars, a basic vocabulary of Hindustani words.
('72', 208, 2, 8, 372670) In order to devise practical measures for the compilation of such a vocabulary as well as for settling various outstanding problems like the selection of technical terms, we suggest that a small representative committee, consisting of influential advocates of Urdu and Hindi who believe in the desirability of bringing the two languages nearer and of promoting the development of the Hindustani language and thereby creating goodwill amongst the speakers of the two languages, should be convened at an early date.
('72', 208, 2, 9, 373184) Let us hope that the authors of the statement will take prompt steps to have the basic vocabulary of Hindustani words acceptable to all parties, and that the small committee they have in view will be set up forthwith for this work and for “settling various outstanding problems”.
('72', 208, 2, 10, 373464) I would put emphasis on the smallness of the committee if promptness is to be ensured.

('72', 210, 2, 6, 377239) 282. SELF SUPPORTING EDUCATION
('72', 210, 3, 7, 377270) Dr. A. Lakshmipathi writes:
('72', 210, 4, 8, 377298) I have seen some institutions conducted by missionaries, where the schools are worked only in the mornings, the evenings being spent either in agricultural operations or in some handicraft work for which the students are paid some wages according to the quality and quantity of work done by them.
('72', 210, 4, 9, 377595) In this way, the institution is made more or less self supporting, and the students do not feel like fish out of water when they leave the school, as they have learnt to do some work enabling them to earn at least their livelihood.
('72', 210, 4, 10, 377827) I have noticed that the atmosphere in which such schools are conducted is quite different from the dull routine of the stereotyped schools of the Education Department.
('72', 210, 4, 11, 377995) The boys look more healthy and happy in the idea that they have turned out some useful work, and are physically of a better build.
('72', 210, 4, 12, 378126) These schools are closed for a short period in the agricultural seasons when all their energy is required for field work.
('72', 210, 4, 13, 378248) Even in cities, such of the boys as have an aptitude may be employed in trades and professions, thereby enabling them to find a diversion.
('72', 210, 4, 14, 378387) One meal may also be provided at school for those boys who are in need, or for all who wish to partake of the same in an interval of half an hour during the morning classes.
('72', 210, 4, 15, 378561) Poor boys may thus be persuaded to run to the school with pleasure and their parents may also encourage them to go to school regularly.
('72', 210, 5, 16, 378697) If this scheme of half day school be adopted, the services of some of these teachers may be utilized for promoting adult education in the villages without any extra payment for such services.
('72', 210, 5, 17, 378889) The building and other apparatus may also be useful in the same way.
('72', 210, 6, 18, 378958) I have seen the Minister for Education, Madras, and presented a letter stating that the deterioration of health of the present generation is mainly due to unsuitable hours of education at schools.
('72', 210, 6, 19, 379155) I am of opinion that all schools and colleges should work only in the morning, i.
('72', 210, 6, 20, 379237) e., between 6 and 11 a.

('72', 211, 1, 2, 379303) study of four hours at school must be quite enough.
('72', 211, 1, 3, 379355) The afternoon should be spent at home, and the evening should be devoted to games and physical development.
('72', 211, 1, 4, 379463) Some of the boys may employ themselves in earning their livelihood, and some may help their parents in their business.
('72', 211, 1, 5, 379582) The students will be more in touch with their parents, which is essential for development of any vocational calling and hereditary aptitude.
('72', 211, 2, 6, 379723) If we realize that body building is nation building, the proposed change, though apparently revolutionary, is according to Indian customs and climate, and it would be welcome to most people.
('72', 211, 2, 7, 379914) Of Dr. Lakshmipathi’s suggestion for restricting school hours to mornings, I do not wish to say much save to commend it to the educational authorities.
('72', 211, 2, 8, 380066) As to the more or less self supporting institutions, they could not do anything else if they were to pay their way partly or wholly and make something of their pupils.
('72', 211, 2, 9, 380234) Yet my suggestion has shocked some educationists because they have known no other method.
('72', 211, 2, 10, 380324) The very idea of education being self supporting seems to them to rob education of all value.
('72', 211, 2, 11, 380418) They see in the suggestion a mercenary motive.
('72', 211, 2, 12, 380465) I have, however, just been reading a monograph on a Jewish effort in matters educational.
('72', 211, 2, 13, 380555) In it the writer speaks thus of the vocational training imparted in the Jewish schools:
('72', 211, 3, 14, 380643) So they find the labour of their hands to be worthy in itself.
('72', 211, 3, 15, 380706) It is made lighter by intellectual activity, it is ennobled by the patriotic ideal which it serves.
('72', 211, 3, 16, 380806) Given the right kind of teachers, our children will be taught the dignity of labour and learn to regard it as an integral part and a means of their intellectual growth, and to realize that it is patriotic to pay for their training through their labour.
('72', 211, 3, 17, 381059) The core of my suggestion is that handicrafts are to be taught, not merely for productive work, but for developing the intellect of the pupils.
('72', 211, 3, 18, 381203) Surely, if the State takes charge of the children between seven and fourteen, and trains their bodies and minds through productive labour, the public schools must be frauds and teachers idiots if they cannot become self supporting.
('72', 211, 3, 19, 381435) Supposing that every boy and girl works, not as a machine but as an intelligent unit, taking interest in the corporate work done under expert guidance, the corporate labour should be, say, after the first year of the course, worth one anna per hour.
('72', 211, 3, 20, 381685) Thus for twenty six working days of four hours per day, each child will have earned Rs. 6 8 0 per month.
('72', 211, 3, 21, 381790) The only question is whether millions of children can be so profitably employed.
('72', 211, 3, 22, 381871) We should be intellectual bankrupts if
('72', 212, 0, 1, 381910) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 213
('72', 212, 1, 2, 381954) we cannot direct the energy of our children so as to get from them, after a year’s training, one anna worth of marketable labour per hour.
('72', 212, 1, 3, 382093) I know that nowhere in India do villagers earn so much as one anna per hour in the villages.
('72', 212, 1, 4, 382186) That is because we have reconciled ourselves to the intense disparity between the haves and the have nots, and because the city people have, perhaps unwittingly, joined in the British exploitation of the village.

('72', 213, 5, 8, 384012) 285. LETTER TO KANTILAL GANDHI
('72', 213, 6, 9, 384043) SEGAON, WARDHA,
('72', 213, 7, 10, 384059) September 12, 1937
('72', 213, 8, 11, 384078) KANTI, Just now I am not able to write to you myself.
('72', 213, 8, 12, 384132) What is this you are doing?
('72', 213, 8, 13, 384160) You are making yourself needlessly unhappy.
('72', 213, 8, 14, 384204) I can’t understand anything.
('72', 213, 8, 15, 384233) Amtul Salaam would never have gone to Trivandrum if you had forbidden her.
('72', 213, 8, 16, 384308) No sooner did you ask me to call her back than I acted.
('72', 213, 8, 17, 384364) But I was not ready to call her back at the risk of displeasing everybody, Ramachandran 2, Saraswati and Papara mma, and interrupting the improvement in her health.
('72', 213, 8, 18, 384529) Had I known— which I now do—how sensitive you are even now, I would have incurred all these risks and called her back.
('72', 213, 8, 19, 384648) But how was I to know that you, who show yourself off as a very brave person, are in fact so weak hearted that you would fall ill to the point of being bed ridden merely by imagining things?
('72', 213, 8, 20, 384839) When I talked to her under some pretext, she immediately agreed that not only would she never write to you but she would not write to Saraswati or anybody else and would never in future even so much as talk of going to Trivandrum.
('72', 213, 8, 21, 385070) What more can she do?
('72', 213, 8, 22, 385092) Why so much hatred?
('72', 213, 8, 23, 385112) I see no blemish in her.
('72', 213, 8, 24, 385137) She doesn’t ask for anybody’s service but goes on silently serving others.
('72', 213, 8, 25, 385212) Why then do you hate her so much?
('72', 213, 8, 26, 385246) Wake up, pull yourself together, leave this profound darkness and come out into the light.
('72', 213, 8, 27, 385337) How can one cure suffering that has no basis at all?
('72', 213, 8, 28, 385390) I have already sent you a wire and am awaiting a reply.

('72', 215, 8, 16, 387360) [Before September 13, 1937]
('72', 215, 9, 17, 387388) Motioning to a varnished box about half the size of an orange crate six feet in front of him, Gandhiji said: You’d better sit over there.
('72', 215, 10, 18, 387526) I ask him some questions about Indian politics, about the victorious Congress party’s policies.
('72', 215, 10, 19, 387622) This isn’t the time for such questions.
('72', 215, 10, 20, 387662) I have work to do here, I can’t take myself from it to answer them.
('72', 215, 10, 21, 387730) You should ask these questions of the political leaders.
('72', 215, 10, 22, 387787) Of course, I wouldn’t say that I don’t know anything about politics.
('72', 215, 10, 23, 387856) But I have no time for such questions now.
('72', 215, 10, 24, 387899) Many feel that any form of co operation is a mistake.
('72', 215, 10, 25, 387953) Others disagree, feeling that perhaps our objectives can best be achieved by giving ground now and then.
('72', 215, 10, 26, 388058) Both groups are sincere.
('72', 215, 10, 27, 388083) We have just won a great victory and this brings us a big responsibility.
('72', 215, 10, 28, 388157) We had literally no opposition.
('72', 215, 10, 29, 388189) This is what counts.
('72', 215, 10, 30, 388210) This result didn’t surprise me, but it is a fine thing for others to see.
('72', 215, 10, 31, 388284) It shows the world our strength.

('72', 216, 1, 2, 388414) We talk then about American public opinion, its attitude toward India.
('72', 216, 1, 3, 388485) American opinion is of great importance to us and by our deeds we hope to win it.
('72', 216, 2, 4, 388567) Gandhiji agreed that British foreign policy is often influenced by American opinion.
('72', 216, 2, 5, 388652) He is aware that England tries in many devious ways to mould it.

('72', 216, 2, 7, 388794) We do not try, our methods must be different methods.
('72', 216, 2, 8, 388848) We make no conscious effort to influence American opinion.
('72', 216, 2, 9, 388907) I believe that the American is emotionally sympathetic to our cause, but he is profoundly ignorant of the real facts and of our real problem.

('72', 219, 1, 2, 392888) 293. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('72', 219, 2, 3, 392916) September 15, 1937 I held back these telegrams 1 in the hope of being able to announce the cheerful news that seven prisoners had broken the fast on my acceptance of their meeting of the word ‘relief’.
('72', 219, 2, 4, 393118) I am sorry that I have failed in my attempt.
('72', 219, 2, 5, 393163) I can only hope that those who may be special friends of these prisoners will persuade them to break the fast which alone can give the public time to consolidate its effort to secure the very relief for which they are giving up their precious lives.
('72', 219, 2, 6, 393413) I would also appeal to the authorities, whoever they may be, to relent and discharge the prisoners, if they will not give up their fast, even as I was discharged and left to my own resources when I would not give up my fast in 1933. 2
('72', 219, 3, 7, 393648) The Bombay Chronicle, 16 9 1937

('72', 221, 5, 9, 396560) 296. LETTER TO CHANDRASHANKAR
('72', 221, 6, 10, 396590) September 15, 1937
('72', 221, 7, 11, 396609) BHAI CHANDRASHANKAR, Certainly I too lay stress on spinning and especially on the takli.
('72', 221, 7, 12, 396698) My experience confirms my belief that in India there is nothing so small, so cheap, so artistic, so useful and so beautiful [as the takli] 2. It is also my claim that except for the English language, all other subjects being taught in India today can be taught through craft within the same amount of time.
('72', 221, 7, 13, 397005) In spite of all the assurances you may be able to give, if the parents start at the very mention of the word ‘craft’, if they [shudder] 3 to hear the word takli and will not send their children if you pay them a stipend of eight annas or four annas instead of a rupee and a half, I should, if I were you, close down the school and follow some other vocation.
('72', 221, 7, 14, 397364) A true teacher would teach on his own terms, not on the terms laid down by parents [who] 4 under stand nothing in the matter of education.

('72', 222, 1, 2, 397667) 297. LETTER TO NARASINHBHAI
('72', 222, 2, 3, 397695) September 15, 1937
('72', 222, 3, 4, 397714) BHAI NARASINHBHAI, Very little money has been received for the Kamala Memorial Fund.
('72', 222, 3, 5, 397799) The largest amount was collected in the course of Jawaharlal’s tour.
('72', 222, 3, 6, 397868) But that did not come in the name of poor Kamala.
('72', 222, 3, 7, 397918) We might as well say that it came in the name of her husband.
('72', 222, 3, 8, 397980) What has happened to Kamala is something that happens to saintly women who pass into the last sleep without being a burden to others.
('72', 222, 3, 9, 398114) This is how the idea of the Kamala Memorial originated.
('72', 222, 3, 10, 398170) She had taken over the case of the Prayag Congress Hospital.
('72', 222, 3, 11, 398231) She collected funds for the hospital till her death.
('72', 222, 3, 12, 398284) The hospital could be maintained only because of her efforts.
('72', 222, 3, 13, 398346) After her death it was about to be closed down.
('72', 222, 3, 14, 398394) And so, a few persons like me who knew her well decided that the hospital should be kept going.
('72', 222, 3, 15, 398490) The easiest way to do it was to make it the Kamala Memorial.
('72', 222, 3, 16, 398551) Jawaharlal donated half of his small estate for the purpose.
('72', 222, 3, 17, 398612) Now how can this amount of some 2_ lakhs be spent without a violation of morality?
('72', 222, 3, 18, 398695) Moreover, those who have given the money have done it knowing this.
('72', 222, 3, 19, 398763) Hence we should regard it as our duty to use the money only for the hospital at Prayag.
('72', 222, 3, 20, 398851) And, if we cannot see that what the women of Prayag gain is gained by all of us does it not mean that we do not belong to India but only to our own province?
('72', 222, 3, 21, 399009) Let us follow the words of the Gita that whatever is dedicated to God in a spirit of service reaches God.
('72', 222, 3, 22, 399115) And this dedication is for the sake of India, through the Kamala Memorial.
('72', 222, 3, 23, 399190) Hence, remove every other thought from your mind.
('72', 222, 4, 24, 399240) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('72', 222, 4, 25, 399286) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('72', 225, 0, 1, 402313) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 225, 1, 2, 402355) 303. DISCUSSION WITH AN EDUCATIONIST 1
('72', 225, 2, 3, 402394) [Before September 18, 1937]
('72', 225, 3, 4, 402422) [GANDHIJI] sounded a warning against the assumption that the idea of self supporting education sprang from the necessity of achieving total prohibition as soon as possible.
('72', 225, 3, 5, 402595) Both are independent necessities.
('72', 225, 3, 6, 402629) You have to start with the conviction that total prohibition has to be achieved, revenue or no revenue, education or no education.
('72', 225, 3, 7, 402760) Similarly, you have to start with the conviction that looking to the needs of the villages of India our rural education ought to be made self supporting if it is to be compulsory.
('72', 225, 4, 8, 402940) [THE EDUCATIONIST:] I have the first conviction deep down in me.
('72', 225, 4, 9, 403005) Prohibition to me is an end in itself, and I regard it as a great education in itself.
('72', 225, 4, 10, 403092) I should, there fore, sacrifice education altogether to make prohibition a success.
('72', 225, 4, 11, 403176) But the other conviction is lacking.
('72', 225, 4, 12, 403213) I cannot yet believe that education can be made self suppor ting.
('72', 225, 4, 13, 403279) There, too, I want you to start with the conviction.
('72', 225, 4, 14, 403332) The ways and means will come as you begin to work it out.
('72', 225, 4, 15, 403390) I regret that I woke up to the necessity of this at this very late age.
('72', 225, 4, 16, 403462) Otherwise I should have made the experiment myself.
('72', 225, 4, 17, 403514) Even now, God willing, I shall do what I can to show that it can be self supporting.
('72', 225, 4, 18, 403599) But my time has been taken up by other things all these years, equally important perhaps, but it is this stay in Segaon that brought the conviction home to me.
('72', 225, 4, 19, 403759) We have up to now concentrated on stuffing children’s minds with all kinds of information, without ever thinking of stimulating and developing them.
('72', 225, 4, 20, 403908) Let us now cry a halt and concentrate on educating the child properly through manual work, not as a side activity, but as the prime means of intellectual training.
('72', 225, 5, 21, 404072) I see that too.
('72', 225, 5, 22, 404088) But why should it also support the school?
('72', 225, 5, 23, 404131) That will be the test of its value.
('72', 225, 5, 24, 404167) The child at the age of 14, that is after finishing a seven years’ course, should be discharged as an earning unit.
('72', 225, 5, 25, 404283) Even now the poor people’s children automatically lend a helping hand to their parents—the feeling at the back of their minds being, what shall my parents eat and what should they give me to eat if I do not also work with them?
('72', 225, 5, 26, 404511) That is an education in itself.
('72', 225, 5, 27, 404543) Even so the State takes charge of the child at seven and returns it to the family as an earning unit.
('72', 225, 5, 28, 404645) You impart education and simultaneously cut at
('72', 225, 6, 29, 404692) 1 Reproduced from Mahadev Desai’s “Talks on Self supporting Education”
('72', 226, 0, 1, 404763) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 227
('72', 226, 1, 2, 404807) the root of unemployment.
('72', 226, 1, 3, 404833) You have to train the boys in one occupation or another.
('72', 226, 1, 4, 404890) Round this special occupation you will train up his mind, his body, his handwriting, his artistic sense, and so on.
('72', 226, 1, 5, 405006) He will be master of the craft he learns.
('72', 226, 2, 6, 405048) But supposing a boy takes up the art and science of making khadi.
('72', 226, 2, 7, 405114) Do you think it must occupy him all the seven years to master the craft?
('72', 226, 2, 8, 405187) It must, if he will not learn it mechanically.
('72', 226, 2, 9, 405234) Why do we give years to the study of history or to the study of languages?
('72', 226, 2, 10, 405309) Is a craft any the less important than these subjects which have been up to now given an artificial importance?
('72', 226, 3, 11, 405421) But as you have been mainly thinking of spinning and weaving, evidently you are thinking of making of these schools so many weaving schools.
('72', 226, 3, 12, 405562) A child may have no aptitude for weaving and may have it for something else.
('72', 226, 3, 13, 405639) Quite so.
('72', 226, 3, 14, 405649) Then we will teach him some other craft.
('72', 226, 3, 15, 405690) But you must know that one school will not teach many crafts.
('72', 226, 3, 16, 405752) The idea is that we should have one teacher for twenty five boys, and you may have as many classes or schools of twenty five boys as you have teachers available, and have each of these schools specializing in a separate craft—carpentry, smithy, tanning or shoe making.
('72', 226, 3, 17, 406021) Only you must bear in mind the fact that you develop the child’s mind through each of these crafts.
('72', 226, 3, 18, 406121) And I would emphasize one more thing.
('72', 226, 3, 19, 406159) You must forget the cities and concentrate on the villages.
('72', 226, 3, 20, 406219) They are an ocean.
('72', 226, 3, 21, 406238) The cities are a mere drop in the ocean.
('72', 226, 3, 22, 406279) That is why you cannot think of subjects like brick making.
('72', 226, 3, 23, 406339) If they must be civil and mechanical engineers, they will after the seven years’ course go to the special colleges meant for these higher and specialized courses.
('72', 226, 3, 24, 406502) And let me emphasize one more fact.
('72', 226, 3, 25, 406538) We are apt to think lightly of the village crafts because we have divorced educational from manual training.
('72', 226, 3, 26, 406647) Manual work has been regarded as something inferior, and owing to the wretched distortion of the varna we came to regard spinners and weavers and carpenters and shoe makers as belonging to the inferior castes and the proletariat.
('72', 226, 3, 27, 406877) We have had no Cromptons 1 and Hargreaves 2 because of this vicious system of considering the crafts as something inferior divorced from the skilled.
('72', 226, 3, 28, 407027) If they had been regarded as callings having an independent status of their own equal
('72', 226, 4, 29, 407113) 1 Samuel Crompton, inventor of the spinning mule, and William Crompton and his son George Crompton, inventors of improved weaving loom 2 James Hargreaves, inventor of the spinning jenny
('72', 227, 0, 1, 407299) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 227, 1, 2, 407341) to the status that learning enjoyed, we should have had great inventors from among our craftsmen.
('72', 227, 1, 3, 407439) Of course the ‘spinning jenny’ led on to the discovery of water power and other things which made the mill displace the labour of thousands of people.
('72', 227, 1, 4, 407590) That was, in my view, a monstrosity.
('72', 227, 1, 5, 407627) We will by concentrating on the villages see that the inventive skill that an intensive learning of the craft will stimulate will subserve the needs of the villager as a whole.
('72', 227, 1, 6, 407804) Harijan, 18 9 1937
('72', 227, 2, 7, 407823) 304. FOR MONKEYS
('72', 227, 3, 8, 407840) I have before me nearly fifty letters from America asking me to do what I can to prevent the export of Macacus Rhesus monkeys from India to America for purposes of vivisection.
('72', 227, 3, 9, 408017) Some of these letters are from humanitarian and anti vivisection societies.
('72', 227, 3, 10, 408093) They send interes ting literature containing harrowing details and pictures of vivisection and opinions of eminent medical men against the utility of the cruel practice.
('72', 227, 3, 11, 408263) A typical letter enclosed a picture of St. Francis of Assisi for whom birds and beasts were as brothers and sisters.
('72', 227, 3, 12, 408380) The reader will appreciate the following prayer of the saint:
('72', 227, 4, 13, 408442) Lord, make me an instrument of your peace; where there is hatred, let me sow love; where there is injury, pardon; where there is doubt, faith; where there is despair, hope; where there is darkness, light; and where there is sadness, joy.
('72', 227, 5, 14, 408680) O Divine Master, grant that I may not so much seek to be consoled as to console; to be understood, as to understand; to be loved, as to love; for it is in giving that we receive; it is in pardoning that we are pardoned, and it is in dying that we art born to eternal life.
('72', 227, 5, 15, 408953) My sympathies are wholly with my correspondents.
('72', 227, 5, 16, 409002) If I had the power I would not send a single monkey abroad for vivisection or slaughter.
('72', 227, 5, 17, 409091) My advice to my correspondents is that they should promote representations to the Government of India which, if they are well supported are, bound to be listened to by them.
('72', 227, 5, 18, 409265) The other way obviously is a strong public agitation in India against the practice of sending monkeys abroad.
('72', 227, 5, 19, 409375) Of this, so far as I can see, there is not much prospect.
('72', 227, 5, 20, 409433) The public hardly know that there is any export of monkeys.
('72', 227, 5, 21, 409493) And I do not know how to prevent private persons from carrying on what must be to them a lucrative trade.
('72', 227, 5, 22, 409599) All, therefore, that I can do is to express the pious wish that India will be no party to what
('72', 228, 0, 1, 409694) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 229
('72', 228, 1, 2, 409738) is undoubtedly an inhuman practice.
('72', 228, 1, 3, 409774) It would be wrong to subject the lower creation to living death even if it could be proved that it contributed something to the alleviation of human suffering.
('72', 228, 1, 4, 409934) Surely, it can never be an end in itself justifying adoption of inhumanities involved in vivisection.
('72', 228, 1, 5, 410036) Rather, the end is for the human family not to sacrifice tenderness, even though the practice of that virtue should involve continuation of human suffering or even an increase in it.
('72', 228, 1, 6, 410219) I suggest that tenderness for others and other life itself promotes alleviation in that it makes pain bearable.
('72', 228, 1, 7, 410331) Harijan, 18 9 1937

('72', 230, 0, 1, 414092) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 231
('72', 230, 1, 2, 414136) 307. SELF SUPPORTING SCHOOLS
('72', 230, 2, 3, 414165) The main cause of India’s economic decay is that her workers begin life too early.
('72', 230, 2, 4, 414248) The immature mind put to industrial apprenticeship gets dwarfed and fossilized; and there is no grasp of the economic significance of work.
('72', 230, 2, 5, 414388) Anybody can exploit such a worker.
('72', 230, 2, 6, 414423) When I visited the Ceylon plantations what harrowed me most was the existence of child labour.
('72', 230, 2, 7, 414518) Even in a country like Ceylon where the population is inadequate to exploit natural resources, child labour is indefensible; much more so is it in India where the employment of children may mean the unemployment of adults.
('72', 230, 3, 8, 414741) Let us not delude ourselves into believing that self supporting work shop schools manufacturing and marketing goods will impart education.
('72', 230, 3, 9, 414880) In actual practice it will be nothing but legalized child labour.
('72', 230, 3, 10, 414946) I cannot agree with the editor of the Harijan that mathematics can be studied by calculating how much yarn would be needed for a piece, and science and geography by observing the growth and improvement of strains of cotton.
('72', 230, 3, 11, 415170) The training of the eye, ear and hand is absolutely necessary, and manual labour must be made compulsory in all schools; but we must not forget that what is called the training of the hand is really a training of the brain.
('72', 230, 3, 12, 415394) If a school aims at education, it must give up all ideas of producing standardized goods for sale.
('72', 230, 3, 13, 415493) It must give a variety of raw materials and machines for children to experiment with and spoil.
('72', 230, 3, 14, 415589) Waste is inevitable.
('72', 230, 3, 15, 415610) A careful study of Sjt.
('72', 230, 3, 16, 415634) Parikh’s figures in the current issue of the Harijan shows that even when a school has specialized in one occupation and has trained grown up children, waste is considerable.
('72', 230, 3, 17, 415809) A vocational school, like a college of science, is a place for experimenting and wasting resources.
('72', 230, 3, 18, 415909) A country like India with limited resources must start as few as necessary.
('72', 230, 4, 19, 415985) That we can force the pace and make the boy learn in two years what he now learns in seven is a curious illusion.
('72', 230, 4, 20, 416099) A child cannot, and should not, try to learn at eight what he can learn only at 16. The foreign language is not the cause of delay, nor are we giving as much extra time to it as people imagine.
('72', 230, 5, 21, 416293) Let us not demand that schools should produce not only men but also goods.
('72', 230, 6, 22, 416368) To sum up, it is bad economy to adopt a short sighted policy which will make the schools solvent and the nation bankrupt.
('72', 230, 7, 23, 416490) ‘A PROFESSOR’

('72', 235, 5, 8, 424919) 312. THE USE AND ABUSE OF TODDY 1
('72', 235, 6, 9, 424953) A Parsi correspondent from Ahmedabad has addressed me a long letter of which the following is the gist:
('72', 235, 7, 10, 425057) I am not a liquor dealer myself, nor do I drink, though I have found half an ounce of toddy, taken judiciously in illness, to have wonderfully curative properties.
('72', 235, 7, 11, 425221) But then, it befuddles me and I have to discontinue its use.
('72', 235, 7, 12, 425282) Since 1896 when I became a vegetarian I have not taken meat.
('72', 235, 7, 13, 425343) I am sixty five and therefore can claim to speak with some experience.
('72', 235, 7, 14, 425414) I have not a shadow of doubt that prohibition will add to the health and longevity of the working people as a whole.
('72', 235, 7, 15, 425531) But I am afraid that what will be saved from liquor will be swallowed up by cinemas, theatres and vice, besides encouraging idleness and surreptitious illicit distillation.
('72', 235, 7, 16, 425704) Toddy, on the other hand, has a number of valuable uses which I note below:
('72', 235, 8, 17, 425780) (1) Fresh toddy is a healthy, non intoxicating beverage, though under the heat of the sun it quickly ferments and develops alcoholic properties.
('72', 235, 9, 18, 425925) (2) Taken medicinally it acts as a refrigerant and cures the system of excess of heat.
('72', 235, 10, 19, 426012) (3) Toddy is used as leaven to raise the flour for making bread, biscuits and pastries.
('72', 235, 11, 20, 426100) (4) It cures constipation and promotes bowel action.
('72', 235, 12, 21, 426153) (5) From toddy we get vinegar which is used in pickles and as a
('72', 235, 13, 22, 426217) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 19 9 1937.
('72', 236, 0, 1, 426287) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 237
('72', 236, 1, 2, 426331) condiment.
('72', 236, 2, 3, 426342) Unfortunately it is becoming increasingly difficult to obtain pure, unadulterated toddy.
('72', 236, 2, 4, 426431) What is generally sold is a thin, poisonous mixture adulterated with water, saccharine, opium and other narcotics which act as a slow poison on the system.
('72', 236, 2, 5, 426587) The toddy dealer, who is generally impecunious and harassed by the exactions of the Excise Department, is driven to make both ends meet by defrauding the consumer.
('72', 236, 2, 6, 426751) In my opinion, what is really needed is to exempt toddy from the licensing system, and make it possible to provide pure stuff to the consumer in sealed bottles at the rate of two pice per bottle.
('72', 236, 3, 7, 426947) To enforce prohibition in respect of toddy, while leaving tobacco, ganja, opium and other narcotics free, would be tantamount to favouring Hindu licensees of these narcotics at the expense of Parsi vendors of toddy, and is bound to make a bad impression.
('72', 236, 3, 8, 427202) The evil of juvenile smoking is daily becoming worse in our country.
('72', 236, 3, 9, 427271) The result is a devitalized manhood and a fearful increase in the cases of tuberculosis, etc.
('72', 236, 3, 10, 427365) The economic bill that the nation has to pay annually for this vice of tobacco smoking works out at a staggering figure.
('72', 236, 3, 11, 427486) If we take the cases of tobacco smoking in our country to be one in three, and two pice worth of cigarettes as the average daily consump tion of smoke for each smoker, then twelve crore smokers would, in a year, blow away 138 crores of rupees among them in this pleasant vice!
('72', 236, 3, 12, 427763) By enforcing prohibition against tobacco smoking the whole of this amount could be saved and the problem of financing primary education for the nation be automatically solved; the national health would distinctly gain; and the daily desecration of the Atash deva1 at the hands of millions of smokers be stopped.
('72', 236, 3, 13, 428075) At the same time the abolition of licensed toddy shops in the cities would cause the townspeople to go to the villages for fresh drawn toddy and help to put some money into the pockets of the needy village folk.
('72', 236, 3, 14, 428287) Perhaps you know that in certain parts of the Surat District the date palm is the only stay of the poor as the sub soil water is too brackish to support any other cultivation.
('72', 236, 3, 15, 428463) The necessity of journeying to the villages to obtain toddy will also serve as an automatic check on the consumption of toddy and effectively reduce the evil of drunkenness that is becoming more and more rampant in all the big cities.
('72', 236, 3, 16, 428698) Other Parsi correspondents too have written to me in the same strain.
('72', 236, 3, 17, 428768) I must confess that it did surprise me somewhat at first that all such arguments against prohibition should emanate invariably from
('72', 236, 4, 18, 428900) 1 Fire god of the Zoroastrians
('72', 237, 0, 1, 428931) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 237, 1, 2, 428973) Parsi brains.

('72', 237, 2, 4, 429373) Coming now to the arguments advanced by my correspondent,
('72', 237, 3, 5, 429431) it will be seen that such of them as are valid do not apply to the plan of prohibition that I have adumbrated.
('72', 237, 3, 6, 429542) Prohibition will certainly not affect the sale of toddy for bona fide medicinal purposes.
('72', 237, 3, 7, 429632) Only, as in the case of other drugs so in the case of toddy, the intending purchaser will be required to produce a certificate issued not by the patient concerned to himself, but by a duly qualified doctor.
('72', 237, 3, 8, 429839) My correspondent may feel competent to act as his own physician, but an average patient cannot safely be left to prescribe for himself.
('72', 237, 3, 9, 429975) The proposed restriction in respect of medicinal toddy is thus conceived in the patient’s own interest.
('72', 237, 4, 10, 430079) It is hardly necessary for me here to examine all the claims on
('72', 237, 5, 11, 430143) behalf of toddy advanced by my correspondent.

('72', 237, 5, 14, 430346) My sole objection is to fermented toddy which has alcoholic properties like any other spirituous liquor whether made from sugarcane, grape or apples.
('72', 237, 5, 15, 430496) I have myself freely partaken, and made others partake, of sweet toddy gur1 and its sherbet.
('72', 237, 5, 16, 430589) Nor is there any duty on the tapping of sweet toddy for gur making.
('72', 237, 5, 17, 430657) I am planning to tap 250 palms here at Segaon in the coming season for sweet toddy and, God willing, I hope to get some of the finest gur and sugar from it.
('72', 237, 5, 18, 430814) The deeper I dive into this question of sweet toddy, the more I find that, owing to the disrepute into which it has fallen by its evil association with liquor manufacture, its proper use has never been inculcated upon our people.2 The grapes of the Madeira island in the Atlantic Ocean, which is under Portuguese rule, meet with the same fate.
('72', 237, 5, 19, 431158) There are vines in every courtyard and wine is distilled in every home.
('72', 237, 5, 20, 431230) Hence in this place ‘grape’ means ‘wine’.
('72', 237, 5, 21, 431272) The term has acquired such a noxious connotation that in our language it has become a common expression and we employ the word ‘madira’ 3 to denote liquor.
('72', 237, 5, 22, 431428) Today hassimilarly become accursed.
('72', 237, 5, 23, 431464) I also played no
('72', 237, 6, 24, 431481) 1 Jaggery 2 The rest of the paragraph is translated from the Gujarati in Harijanbandhu.

('72', 238, 1, 2, 431742) small part in condemning it in the last Satyagraha 1. The above mentioned gentleman can rest assured that now I am atoning for it by helping people to a true knowledge of toddy and by keeping the intoxicating principle away from it.
('72', 238, 1, 3, 431975) May I in all sincerity suggest that the Parsi community can render a great service to itself and the Province of Bombay by renouncing the liquor trade and doing its bit for the redemption of the much wronged toddy palm.
('72', 238, 1, 4, 432195) Is it not also a happy augury that the cause of prohibition in the Bombay Presidency has for its helmsman and guide a celebrated Parsi doctor?
('72', 238, 1, 5, 432338) I hope it will now be sufficiently clear to my esteemed correspondent, and others who might be inclined to think like him, that the prohibition move which I am sponsoring is not calculated to injure Parsi interests or for the matter of that any legitimate interests.
('72', 238, 1, 6, 432605) It is directed as much against opium, ganja, charas and every narcotic as it is against liquor drinking and, what is more, as I have already shown, it does not affect the legitimate use of the toddy palm in which the Parsis as a community are especially interested.

('72', 238, 3, 10, 433151) 313. TO NATIONAL TEACHERS
('72', 238, 4, 11, 433177) To the teachers who are conducting national schools I would suggest that if they are convinced by my recent writings 2 on primary education, they should try to put my ideas into practice.
('72', 238, 4, 12, 433365) They should maintain a proper record and keep me informed about their experiences.
('72', 238, 4, 13, 433448) Those who are willing to conduct a school on the lines suggested by me, those who are not engaged for the time being or those who are willing to give up their present vocation and run a school, should write to me.
('72', 238, 4, 14, 433662) It is my belief that a craft which immediately suggests itself for making primary schools self sufficient is spinning and allied processes.
('72', 238, 4, 15, 433802) This includes ail the processes from picking cotton to
('72', 238, 5, 16, 433857) 1 Salt Satyagraha of 1930. 2 Vide “Self Supporting Education”, also “Congress Ministries”, 17 7 1937
('72', 239, 0, 1, 433958) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 239, 1, 2, 434000) weaving intricate designs into khadi.
('72', 239, 1, 3, 434038) The wages should be calculated at a minimum of half an anna per hour.
('72', 239, 1, 4, 434108) Of the five working hours in the school day four hours should be devoted to manual work and one hour to instruction in the science of the craft taught in the school and the teaching of other subjects that cannot be taken up as part of the craft taught.
('72', 239, 1, 5, 434361) While teaching the crafts, subjects like history, geography and arithmetic would be partially or wholly covered.
('72', 239, 1, 6, 434474) Language and grammar as part of it, and also correct pronunciation would be naturally included.
('72', 239, 1, 7, 434570) For the teacher will treat the craft as a vehicle of all such knowledge and will teach the children correct speech and in so doing would incidentally impart knowledge of grammar.
('72', 239, 1, 8, 434749) Children must learn the process of counting right from the beginning.
('72', 239, 1, 9, 434819) Hence, the first beginning will have to be made with arithmetic.
('72', 239, 1, 10, 434884) Neatness would of course not be a separate subject.
('72', 239, 1, 11, 434936) Children ought to be neat in everything they do.
('72', 239, 1, 12, 434985) They will begin it by coming to school neat and tidy.
('72', 239, 1, 13, 435039) Hence, for the present I cannot think of any subject which the children cannot be taught side by side withtheir vocational training.
('72', 239, 1, 14, 435172) It is of course my idea that just as the subjects to be taught have not been considered separately but as interconnected and originating from a single source, I also think that there would be a single teacher.
('72', 239, 1, 15, 435382) There should be no separate teachers for different subjects but only one teacher.
('72', 239, 1, 16, 435464) There could be separate teachers for the different forms.
('72', 239, 1, 17, 435522) That is to say, there would be seven teachers if there are seven forms and one teacher would not have more than 25 children.
('72', 239, 1, 18, 435647) If education is compulsory, I would consider it necessary to have separate classes for boys and girls from the very beginning.
('72', 239, 1, 19, 435774) For ultimately they will not have to be trained in the same vocations.
('72', 239, 1, 20, 435845) Hence, I believe that it would be more convenient to have separate classes from the very start.
('72', 239, 1, 21, 435941) It may be possible to make some modifications in this method and in the working hours, number of teachers and distribution of subjects; but the school of my conception can be conducted only by regarding as inviolable the principles which each school must follow.
('72', 239, 1, 22, 436204) Right now, the pursuit of these principles may not have shown any results; but any minister who wishes to start on such a system of education must have faith in these principles.
('72', 239, 1, 23, 436383) And this faith, based as it is on reason, should not be blind but rational.
('72', 239, 1, 24, 436459) The two principles are: (I) The vehicle of education should be some vocation or craft which would be useful in the village.
('72', 239, 1, 25, 436583) (2) Education, on the whole, should be self supporting.
('72', 239, 1, 26, 436639) It may be not completely self supporting for a year or two in the beginning; but income and expenditure
('72', 240, 0, 1, 436743) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 241
('72', 240, 1, 2, 436787) should be balanced at the end of seven years.
('72', 240, 1, 3, 436833) There is scope for increasing or decreasing these seven years that I have posited for this kind of education.
('72', 240, 2, 4, 436943) [From Gujarati]

('72', 249, 0, 1, 451685) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 249, 1, 2, 451727) 328. HAVOC IN ORISSA
('72', 249, 2, 3, 451748) Floods, famines and pestilences have become part of the natural life of India.
('72', 249, 2, 4, 451827) Famines and floods take place almost all the world over, but their effects are largely overcome in countries which have financial and other resources.
('72', 249, 2, 5, 451978) But in India, where poverty reaches the point of starvation, the effects of floods and famines are not only not overcome but are felt with double force, and pestilences are ever with us through the same cause.
('72', 249, 2, 6, 452188) But the gravest defect of India’s pauperism is that we have come to regard these visitations with resignation which is none the less brutal because it is unconscious.
('72', 249, 2, 7, 452355) To illustrate my point I single out the case of Orissa because of the appeal issued by the Minister of Revenue and Public Works in his capacity as Chairman of the Orissa Flood Relief Committee.
('72', 249, 2, 8, 452549) In him, a member of the Congress Ministry, Government and the Congress combine.
('72', 249, 2, 9, 452629) But in a covering letter he tells me that the response to the appeal has been nothing worth mentioning.
('72', 249, 2, 10, 452733) The Orissa Governor, in his address at the inaugural meeting of the Flood Relief Fund, says: “As it was graphically put to me, on the night of the 6th August 30,000 people in this town, Cuttack, were sleeping or trying to sleep ten feet below the river level.” Cuttack is an insignificant place compared to Bombay.
('72', 249, 2, 11, 453048) It is not one tenth the size of that city.
('72', 249, 2, 12, 453091) Imagine what would happen to Bombay if there was a river passing by it, and floods put three lakhs of people in the predicament in which the people of Cuttack found themselves on the night of the sixth of August!

('72', 250, 2, 11, 455276) 329. NOT IMPRACTICABLE
('72', 250, 3, 12, 455299) Sardar Sir Jogendra Singh is a great social reformer, a man of letters and a politician.
('72', 250, 3, 13, 455388) Whatever, therefore, he writes commands attention.
('72', 250, 3, 14, 455439) He has contributed an article on total prohibition to The Times of India.
('72', 250, 3, 15, 455513) Having read it with the care his writings demand from me, I must confess that I left the article with a sigh.
('72', 250, 3, 16, 455623) How could such a reformer accept defeat on grounds that do not bear examination?
('72', 250, 3, 17, 455704) His only argument seems to be: ‘There is bound to be illicit distillation and secret drinking, therefore do not attempt prohibition.’ In the Punjab there was local option but nobody applied it.
('72', 250, 3, 18, 455898) “Therefore,” he says, “my conclusion is that prohibition by compulsion will fail, and provinces will lose revenue which they need for rural reconstruction.” By linking prohibition to revenue the Sardar has precipitately given up his case and contradicted himself.
('72', 250, 3, 19, 456162) For in the fourth paragraph of his article he says: “I expressly declared that considerations of revenue would not weigh with me in carrying out a policy of controlling drink.” Thank God Congress Ministries have cut their way through the revenue snare by debarring themselves from the use of liquor revenue.
('72', 250, 3, 20, 456470) Once the loophole is left, the temptation to make use of this immoral gain will be too irresistible, for nobody denies the difficulty of making the drunkard sober in a moment.

('72', 250, 3, 22, 456752) But they pleaded inability to forgo the rich revenue received from the traffic.

('72', 252, 1, 2, 459175) 330. FOUR QUESTIONS
('72', 252, 2, 3, 459195) A correspondent asks the following four questions:
('72', 252, 3, 4, 459246) 1. Hindus who once renounced their faith for some reason or other and joined Islam or Christianity sincerely repent and want to come back.
('72', 252, 3, 5, 459385) Should we re convert them or not?

('72', 252, 4, 8, 459575) Some of them, since the Travancore Durbar Declaration2 and the popularity of the Harijan movement, feel it worthwhile to re adopt their ancestral faith.
('72', 252, 4, 9, 459728) What would you advise about them?
('72', 252, 5, 10, 459762) 3. A Hindu was made to join another faith for certain material considerations.
('72', 252, 5, 11, 459841) After some time he feels disillusioned and comes and knocks at our door.
('72', 252, 5, 12, 459914) Shall we welcome him or not?

('72', 252, 6, 14, 460038) At some places Muslims are also making use of their orphanages for this purpose.
('72', 252, 6, 15, 460119) What should we do, when these boys and girls, either alone or with their guardians, approach us for shuddhi?
('72', 252, 6, 16, 460228) These, or such questions, have been asked and answered before now in these columns in some shape or other.
('72', 252, 6, 17, 460335) I do not need to answer each separately.
('72', 252, 6, 18, 460376) In my opinion they are not examples of real heart conversion.
('72', 252, 6, 19, 460438) If a person, through fear, compulsion, starvation or for material gain or consideration, goes over to another faith, it is a misnomer to call it conversion.
('72', 252, 6, 20, 460595) Most cases of mass conversion, of which we have heard so much during the past two years, have been to my mind false coin.
('72', 252, 6, 21, 460717) Real conversion springs from the heart and at the prompting of God, not of a stranger.
('72', 252, 6, 22, 460804) The voice of God can always be distinguished from the voice of man.
('72', 252, 6, 23, 460872) The hypothetical cases coined by my correspondent are, so far as I can see, not cases of conversion.
('72', 252, 6, 24, 460973) I would, therefore, unhesitatingly re admit to the Hindu fold all such repentants without ado, certainly without any shuddhi.
('72', 252, 6, 25, 461099) Shuddhi is not applicable to such cases.
('72', 252, 6, 26, 461140) And, as I believe in the equality of all the great religions of the earth, I regard no man as polluted because he

('72', 255, 5, 20, 466561) 333. PRIMARY EDUCATION IN BOMBAY 2
('72', 255, 6, 21, 466596) In discussing the question of primary education I have hither to deliberately confined myself to the villages, as it is in the villages that the bulk of India’s population resides.
('72', 255, 6, 22, 466777) To tackle successfully the question of the villages is to solve the problem for the cities also.
('72', 255, 6, 23, 466874) But a friend interested in the question of primary education in the city of Bombay puts the following poser:
('72', 255, 7, 24, 466983) The Congress Ministry is just now preoccupied with the question of financing primary education.
('72', 255, 7, 25, 467079) The cry to make primary education self suppor ting is in the air.
('72', 255, 7, 26, 467145) It would, therefore, be worthwhile to examine as to how and to what extent this can be done in the case of a city like Bombay.
('72', 255, 7, 27, 467272) The annual budget of the Bombay Corporation for education is said to be somewhere between 35 and 36 lakhs of rupees.
('72', 255, 7, 28, 467389) But this amount would have to be
('72', 255, 8, 29, 467422) 1 G. Ramachandran 2 The Gujarati original appeared in Harijanbandhu, 26 9 1937.
('72', 256, 0, 1, 467502) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 257
('72', 256, 1, 2, 467546) augmented by several lakhs of rupees before the scheme of introducing compulsory primary education in Bombay can be realized.
('72', 256, 1, 3, 467672) At present over twenty lakhs of rupees are annually spent on teachers’ salaries, while another four lakhs go as rent.
('72', 256, 1, 4, 467790) This gives an average of Rs. 40 to 42 for each student.
('72', 256, 1, 5, 467846) Can a student earn this amount in the course of his vocational training?
('72', 256, 1, 6, 467919) And if not, then, how can primary education be made self supporting?
('72', 256, 1, 7, 467988) I have no doubt in my mind that the city of Bombay and its children would only stand to gain by adopting a vocational basis for primary education.

('72', 256, 1, 19, 469512) This means that no less than 62,000 children of school going age in the city of Bombay are at present going without primary education.
('72', 256, 1, 20, 469647) If we take away 6,000 out of this figure as the number of children who are possibly receiving their education privately in their homes, it would still leave 56,000 children for whom primary education has still got to be provided.
('72', 256, 1, 21, 469877) At the present scale of expenditure this would require a sum of Rs. 22,40,000 which, so far as I can see, is hardly likely to be forthcoming on this side of doomsday.
('72', 256, 2, 22, 470044) 1 The paragraph, except for the last sentence, which is from Harijan, is translated from the Gujarati in Harijanbandhu.
('72', 257, 0, 1, 470164) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 257, 1, 2, 470206) I am a firm believer in the principle of free and compulsory primary education for India.
('72', 257, 1, 3, 470296) I also hold that we shall realize this only by teaching the children a useful vocation and utilizing it as a means for cultivating their mental, physical and spiritual faculties.
('72', 257, 1, 4, 470475) Let no one consider these economic calculations in connection with education as sordid, or out of place.
('72', 257, 1, 5, 470580) There is nothing essentially sordid about economic calculations.
('72', 257, 1, 6, 470645) True economics never militates against the highest ethical standard just as all true ethics to be worth its name must at the same time be also good economics.
('72', 257, 1, 7, 470804) An economics that inculcates mammon worship and enables the strong to amass wealth at the expense of the weak, is a false and dismal science.
('72', 257, 1, 8, 470946) It spells death.
('72', 257, 1, 9, 470963) True economics, on the other hand, stands for social justice, it promotes the good of all equally, including the weakest, and is indispensable for decent life.
('72', 257, 1, 10, 471123) I therefore make bold to suggest that Bombay would be setting a noble example for the whole country to follow if, by teaching its children a useful industry, it can make primary education pay its way.
('72', 257, 1, 11, 471324) Supposing a student works at a vocation for four hours a day, then taking the number of working days in a month to be 25 and the rate of remuneration two pice per hour, he or she would be earning Rs. 3 2 0 per month for the school.
('72', 257, 1, 12, 471556) The vocational exercise will keep the mind of the student fresh and alert while providing at the same time a means for drawing out his or her intellect.
('72', 257, 1, 13, 471709) This does not mean that the child would begin to pay 2 pice per hour from the commencement.
('72', 257, 1, 14, 471801) But he will pay during the whole period of seven years at the rate of 2 pice per hour.
('72', 257, 1, 15, 471888) It is a gross superstition to think that this sort of vocational exercise will make education dull, or cramp the child’s mind.
('72', 257, 1, 16, 472015) Some of my happiest recollections are of the bright and joyful faces of children while they were receiving vocational instruction under competent teachers.
('72', 257, 1, 17, 472171) As against this, I have also known the most fascinating of subjects boring children, when taught in the wrong way by an incompetent instructor.
('72', 257, 1, 18, 472315) But it may be asked where from are we going to get capable instructors of the kind that we require?
('72', 257, 1, 19, 472415) My reply is that necessity is the mother of invention.
('72', 257, 1, 20, 472470) Once we realize the necessity for reorientation of our educational policy, the means for giving effect to it will be found without much difficulty.
('72', 257, 1, 21, 472618) I am sure that, for a fraction of the time and expense incurred on the present educational system and the staff to man it, we could easily train all the manual instructors that we should require for our work.
('72', 257, 1, 22, 472827) It ought to be possible for a committee of educational experts of Bombay, if they
('72', 258, 0, 1, 472909) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 259
('72', 258, 1, 2, 472953) are in earnest, to draw up a scheme of primary education on the lines suggested by me and to put it into operation without loss of time.
('72', 258, 1, 3, 473090) Only they must have a living faith in it as I have.
('72', 258, 1, 4, 473142) Such faith can only grow from within; it cannot be acquired vicariously.
('72', 258, 1, 5, 473215) Nothing great in this world was ever accomplished without a living faith.
('72', 258, 1, 6, 473289) What kinds of vocations are the fittest for being taught to children in urban schools?
('72', 258, 1, 7, 473376) There is no hard and fast rule about it.
('72', 258, 1, 8, 473417) But my reply is clear.
('72', 258, 1, 9, 473440) I want to resuscitate the villages of India.
('72', 258, 1, 10, 473485) Today our villages have become a mere appendage to the cities.
('72', 258, 1, 11, 473548) They exist, as it were, to be exploited by the latter and depend on the latter’s sufference.
('72', 258, 1, 12, 473641) This is unnatural.
('72', 258, 1, 13, 473660) It is only when the cities realize the duty of making an adequate return to the villages for the strength and sustenance which they derive from them, instead of selfishly exploiting them, that a healthy and moral relationship between the two will spring up, and if the city children are to play their part in this great and noble work of social reconstruction, the vocations through which they are to receive their education ought to be directly related to the requirements of the villages.
('72', 258, 1, 14, 474151) So far as I can see, the various processes of cotton manufacture from ginning and cleaning of cotton to the spinning of yarn answer this test as nothing else does.
('72', 258, 1, 15, 474315) Even today cotton is grown in the villages and is ginned and spun and converted into cloth in the cities.
('72', 258, 1, 16, 474421) But the chain of processes which cotton undergoes in the mills from the beginning to the end constitutes a huge tragedy of waste in men, materials and mechanical power.
('72', 258, 1, 17, 474590) My plan to impart primary education through the medium of village handicrafts like spinning and carding, etc., is thus conceived as the spearhead of a silent social revolution fraught with the most far reaching consequence.
('72', 258, 1, 18, 474814) It will provide a healthy and moral basis of relationship between the city and the village and thus go a long way towards eradicating some of the worst evils of the present social insecurity and poisoned relationship between the classes.
('72', 258, 1, 19, 475052) It will check the progressive decay of our villages and lay the foundation of a juster social order in which there is no unnatural division between the ‘haves’ and have nots’ and everybody is assured of a living wage and the right to freedom.
('72', 258, 1, 20, 475295) And all this would be accomplished without the horrors of a bloody class war or a colossal capital expenditure such as would be involved in the mechanization of a vast continent like India.
('72', 258, 1, 21, 475485) Nor would it entail a helpless dependence on foreign imported
('72', 259, 0, 1, 475547) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 259, 1, 2, 475589) machinery or technical skill.
('72', 259, 1, 3, 475619) Lastly, by obviating the necessity for highly specialized talent, it would place the destiny of the masses, as it were, in their own hands.

('72', 259, 1, 5, 475786) Will the city folk listen to me at all?

('72', 260, 1, 2, 477587) 335. LETTER TO V. V. ATITKAR
('72', 260, 2, 3, 477616) SEGAON, WARDHA, September 26, 1937
('72', 260, 3, 4, 477651) DEAR ATITKAR, Morally and legally, in the Congress sense, there is nothing wrong in your asking for and receiving Government grants now, but I quite agree with you that it would be better if you did not.
('72', 260, 3, 5, 477855) From the views I have been recently propounding about education you will deduce that I would not multiply Universities if they are to be a burden on the Government.
('72', 260, 3, 6, 478020) But I would grant a charter for the asking if the Government is called upon to create a separate examining University, for such a body is more than self supporting from the examination fees it charges.
('72', 260, 3, 7, 478222) In any event, those who seek a charter for a new University have to calculate upon the University being self supporting.
('72', 260, 3, 8, 478343) Colleges and even schools, if the latter are also taken under University wings, would naturally have to conform to the syllabus and other regulations framed by the University.
('72', 260, 3, 9, 478519) Thus you will be entitled to have a charter for the Lokamanya University if you can see your way to making the University self supporting—in other words, that is, if you think you can find sufficient students to appear for your examinations.
('72', 260, 3, 10, 478761) Under my conception there will be colleges for every conceivable art and craft, and, therefore, I would not mind any number of Universities on these terms.
('72', 260, 4, 11, 478917) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI SJT.

('72', 270, 1, 2, 494438) 347. LETTER TO SHANKARLAL
('72', 270, 2, 3, 494464) September 29, 1937
('72', 270, 3, 4, 494483) BHAI SHANKARLALBHAI, Your letter contains a question to which you expect an answer from me.
('72', 270, 3, 5, 494575) You ask me how it is possible in practice to be tolerant and continue to bear with faults even when they are quite evident.
('72', 270, 3, 6, 494699) You have yourself said and written that you are able to see countless faults in yourself every day.
('72', 270, 3, 7, 494799) And yet, how very tolerant you are to yourself !
('72', 270, 3, 8, 494848) I see countless faults in me every day and yet there is no limit to my tolerance of myself.
('72', 270, 3, 9, 494940) If I am not tolerant of myself in spite of seeing my faults, I would have to fast every day and think of all sorts of expiations and finally go the way of Chhotelal 1!
('72', 270, 3, 10, 495108) But I do none of these things.
('72', 270, 3, 11, 495139) I believe that my tolerance is not misplaced.
('72', 270, 3, 12, 495185) That is why I learnt to be tolerant of others in spite of seeing their faults.
('72', 270, 3, 13, 495264) But I have not yet attained the ideal state because I must be at least as tolerant of others as I am of myself if not more.
('72', 270, 3, 14, 495388) I have not been able to be so.
('72', 270, 3, 15, 495419) However, I find that I want to proceed in that direction and I know I am doing it.
('72', 270, 3, 16, 495502) But even as I proceed I regard faults as faults indeed.
('72', 270, 3, 17, 495558) With these two things my own strength grows as it should indeed.
('72', 270, 3, 18, 495623) I had my first lesson in this training from my parents.
('72', 270, 3, 19, 495679) They were tolerant of me even when they saw my faults.
('72', 270, 3, 20, 495734) I used to worship my parents.
('72', 270, 3, 21, 495764) But it cannot be said that 1 could not see their faults.
('72', 270, 3, 22, 495821) I was quite tolerant of them because of my devotion to them.
('72', 270, 3, 23, 495882) The same attitude then continued towards my brothers and other relatives.
('72', 270, 3, 24, 495956) My family continued to grow.
('72', 270, 3, 25, 495985) But the attitude remained unchanged.
('72', 270, 3, 26, 496022) So there is always a certain measure of tolerance in me.
('72', 270, 4, 27, 496079) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('72', 270, 4, 28, 496125) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('72', 271, 7, 13, 496832) BHAI GOPI NATH, What you write about the law suit is correct.
('72', 271, 7, 14, 496894) Filing a suit even over a small amount involves considerable expense.
('72', 271, 7, 15, 496964) But today there is no provision under which one could be governed only by the rule of the panchayat.
('72', 271, 7, 16, 497065) Under such circumstances the golden rule is that we should neither lend nor borrow.
('72', 271, 7, 17, 497149) If you do lend it must be with the idea that you are not going to get your money back.
('72', 271, 7, 18, 497236) You just have to do it.
('72', 271, 7, 19, 497260) And if you have to do such a thing you should be clear in your mind that it is charity.
('72', 271, 7, 20, 497348) It should be remembered that out of the millions those who are required to go to the court are very few.
('72', 271, 7, 21, 497453) If we can be out of [debt] 2 and mingle with the masses like drops in the ocean, we would not have to bother with law courts.
('72', 271, 7, 22, 497579) Now for the profession of vaidyas.
('72', 271, 7, 23, 497614) In the ancient times vaidyas gave the benefit of their knowledge without charging fees.
('72', 271, 7, 24, 497702) They did not charge even for the medicines.
('72', 271, 7, 25, 497746) And generally the medicines too used to be quite inexpensive.
('72', 271, 7, 26, 497808) The Rajavaidyas and such others used to make their own patent medicines and put up a great show.
('72', 271, 7, 27, 497905) Today only people of the latter category are left.

('72', 279, 2, 6, 511044) You will have to forget your tomes, and start making use of your hands and feet.
('72', 279, 2, 7, 511125) For this you must set apart part of your busy hours.
('72', 279, 2, 8, 511178) Take up cotton and takli spinning and approach them intellectually.

('72', 279, 2, 12, 511582) Even their crude handiwork will reveal some art; But with your intelligent perception you will be able to find out that there is much scope for improvement in the method of their work, and you will see how these ignorant folks have gone along the beaten track for years without anyone to show them improved ways.
('72', 279, 2, 13, 511895) You will also realize that their ignorance is the result of our middle class ancestors and of you and I having neglected these poor folks, and you will perhaps shed a genuine tear.
('72', 279, 2, 14, 512076) You will then see what I mean by education through handicrafts.

('72', 279, 2, 18, 512417) For my sole purpose is to seek truth by thought, word and deed.
('72', 279, 2, 19, 512481) That is the thing I am mad about, the thing for which I am living and for which I am hoping to die.
('72', 279, 2, 20, 512581) That is why I challenge friends like you and invite them to challenge me.
('72', 279, 2, 21, 512655) If they convince me of the error of my ways, I shall not hesitate to confess my folly.

('72', 280, 1, 2, 513254) 361. LEST WE FORGET
('72', 280, 2, 3, 513274) A Harijan sevak reminds me that nowadays Harijans, for whom this weekly was started, have receded into the background and its columns are devoted to all sorts of subjects.
('72', 280, 2, 4, 513446) He is half right.
('72', 280, 2, 5, 513464) I have begun to discuss questions which have been hitherto deliberately excluded.
('72', 280, 2, 6, 513546) The reason for exclusion no longer exists.
('72', 280, 2, 7, 513589) The contrary is the case now.
('72', 280, 2, 8, 513619) In the greater part of India the Congress is both in office and power.
('72', 280, 2, 9, 513690) It is true that the power is limited.
('72', 280, 2, 10, 513728) But it is limited in terms of Complete Independence, not otherwise.
('72', 280, 2, 11, 513796) India is one vast prison with high walls of suppression choking her mind and body.
('72', 280, 2, 12, 513879) But its Superintendent has seen fit to give a large part of the prisoners the power to appoint from among themselves the governing officials with full powers of administration, at any rate enough for growing strong, so long as they recognize that they are still prisoners.
('72', 280, 2, 13, 514152) Well, they have chosen to take advantage of this freedom in the hope that by never requiring the assistance of his admitted physical superiority they will convince the Superintendent that he is no longer wanted.
('72', 280, 2, 14, 514364) Anyway, that being my interpretation of the Government of India Act and the office acceptance, I must strive to show to the co workers, who have become Ministers, how in my opinion they can achieve the end.
('72', 280, 2, 15, 514571) And if I succeed in so doing, the battle against untouchability is almost won.
('72', 280, 2, 16, 514650) But I need hardly say that removal of untouchability from the Hindu heart is, like communal unity, an indispensable condition of success through the non violent action that is implicit in office acceptance.
('72', 280, 2, 17, 514857) Therefore Harijan sevaks have to redouble their efforts to touch the caste Hindu heart as well as the Harijan heart.
('72', 280, 2, 18, 514974) We must constantly remind Hindu orthodoxy of the solemn oath taken at the all India meeting held in Bombay on the 25th September, 1932, under the presidentship of Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya.
('72', 280, 2, 19, 515166) 1 Here is the oath:
('72', 280, 3, 20, 515186) This Conference resolves that henceforth, amongst Hindus, no one shall be regarded as untouchable by reason of his birth, and that those who have been so regarded hitherto shall have the same right as other Hindus in regard to the use of public wells, public schools, public roads and all other public institutions.
('72', 280, 3, 21, 515502) This right shall have statutory recognition at the first opportunity, and shall be one of the earliest acts of the Swaraj Parliament, if it shall not have received such recognition before that time.

('72', 281, 4, 11, 516706) A student cannot be an active politician and pursue his studies at the same time.
