('72', 283, 1, 2, 520121) 363. DOING, NOT IDLE THINKING
('72', 283, 2, 3, 520151) Dr. G. S. Arundale sends me an advance copy of an article he has written for the Orient Illustrated Weekly with the following covering letter:
('72', 283, 3, 4, 520294) You have expressed a wish that education should now begin to be real in this country and not artificial as it has been for so many years.
('72', 283, 3, 5, 520432) As one who has been active in education in India for more than thirty years, I send you an article which is appearing in the Orient Illustrated Weekly.
('72', 283, 3, 6, 520584) Maybe it represents in some degree your own views.
('72', 283, 3, 7, 520635) I do feel that there should be a national scheme of education which every National Minister will do his best to express in his particular Province.
('72', 283, 3, 8, 520783) There has been a good deal of independent tinkering.
('72', 283, 3, 9, 520836) I feel it is urgent that the note of the great principles should be sounded without delay so that there may be a common bond and a common effort in which public and Government alike shall join.
('72', 283, 3, 10, 521030) I take from the article the most important and relevant extracts.
('72', 283, 3, 11, 521096) After dealing with the question of how to proceed, he says:
('72', 283, 4, 12, 521156) I have no space here to suggest the nature of the principles which should underlie national education.
('72', 283, 4, 13, 521259) But at least so far as both boys and girls are concerned in the school sphere—I hope we shall gradually eliminate the absurd distinctions of ‘school’ and ‘college’—the note throughout must be that of Doing.
('72', 283, 5, 14, 521466) However much thought may be stimulated, it is valueless save as it mellows into Doing.
('72', 283, 5, 15, 521553) The same may be said as regards the emotions and feelings, so dangerously neglected in most modern systems of education.
('72', 283, 5, 16, 521674) India needs her youth to be workers—workers whose character is such—developed through education—that it naturally becomes translated into work, into practical capacity, into service.
('72', 283, 5, 17, 521857) India needs young citizens who can do well in whatever department of life to which they may be called by environment and by heredity.
('72', 283, 5, 18, 521991) Every subject of the curriculum is to the end of right living.
('72', 283, 5, 19, 522054) Every subject discloses the Law, the Order and the Purpose of Life.
('72', 283, 5, 20, 522122) Teachers must never forget this as they tend to grow submerged in the hardness of so called facts.
('72', 283, 5, 21, 522221) They should remember that in the world of our intelligence there are no facts, but only conventions.
('72', 283, 5, 22, 522322) It was well said by Sir Arthur Eddington1 that science has taken the great step forward of moving from certainty to doubt.
('72', 283, 5, 23, 522445) Our education must, therefore, cause all its ‘facts’ to rest lightly in the minds
('72', 283, 6, 24, 522527) 1 Sir Arthar Stanley Eddington, a British astronomer
('72', 284, 0, 1, 522580) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 285
('72', 284, 1, 2, 522624) of its pupils, and use them beyond all else for the development of that character which is the only safe foundation both for individuals and for nations.
('72', 284, 2, 3, 522778) And once character stirs, the desire to do will intensify, in the directions both of self support and of self sacrifice.
('72', 284, 2, 4, 522899) There will arise the desire to draw as close as possible to the Earth our Mother, to worship her in the ritual of agriculture, and to become as little as may be of a burden to her by simplicity of need and purity of desire.
('72', 284, 2, 5, 523123) Indeed, I hold that no child of Mother Earth should be unable to draw from her some direct sustenance, and I would have as part of all education some measure of direct contact with her, even in town educational institutions.
('72', 284, 3, 6, 523348) We must tear ourselves radically away from those educational conventions which have made education so largely futile today.
('72', 284, 3, 7, 523472) We must begin, under the existing favourable auspices of the national ministries, a system of real education which is not instruction.
('72', 284, 3, 8, 523607) We have become imprisoned in the ruts and grooves of out of date educational forms and fetishes, and I heartily welcome Gandhiji’s adumbration of an education which is self supporting.
('72', 284, 3, 9, 523792) I am not quite sure if we shall be able to go quite as far as he suggests.
('72', 284, 3, 10, 523867) I entirely agree that a young citizen after finishing a seven years’ course “should be discharged as an earning unit”.
('72', 284, 3, 11, 523986) I myself feel that everyone should, partly through education, become conscious of his creative capacity, for he is a god in the becoming and therefore possesses the supreme attribute of God—the power to create, to do.
('72', 284, 3, 12, 524204) If this power be not awakened, of what use education?
('72', 284, 3, 13, 524258) Then indeed is it instruction and not education.
('72', 284, 4, 14, 524307) There is as much brain in the hand as there is in the head.
('72', 284, 4, 15, 524367) For long the intellect in the head has been our God.
('72', 284, 4, 16, 524420) Intellect has been our tyrant, our dictator.
('72', 284, 4, 17, 524465) Under the new dispensation it must be one among our many servants, and we must learn to exalt all that makes for simple living, that draws us near to the beautiful simplicities of nature, all that helps me to live with my hands—manual work of all kinds, of the artist, of the artisan, of the agriculturist.
('72', 284, 5, 18, 524772) I know I should have lived a happier and more effective life had I so been educated.
('72', 284, 5, 19, 524857) What I have been saying as a layman, for the lay reader, Dr. Arundale has said as an educationist, for the educationist, and those who have in their charge the moulding of the youth of the country.
('72', 284, 5, 20, 525055) I am not surprised at the caution with which he approaches the idea of self supporting education.
('72', 284, 5, 21, 525153) For me it is the crux.
('72', 284, 5, 22, 525176) My one regret is that what I have seen through the glass darkly for the past 40 years I have
('72', 285, 0, 1, 525269) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 285, 1, 2, 525311) begun to see no quite clearly under the stress of circumstances.
('72', 285, 1, 3, 525376) Having spoken strongly in 1920 against the present system of education, and having now got the opportunity of influencing, however little it may be, Ministers in seven Provinces, who have been fellow workers and fellow sufferers in the glorious struggle for freedom of the country, I have felt an irresistible call to make good the charge that the present mode of education is radically wrong from bottom to top.
('72', 285, 1, 4, 525789) And what I have been struggling to express in these columns very inadequately has come upon me like a flash, and the truth of it is daily growing upon me.
('72', 285, 1, 5, 525944) I do, therefore, venture to ask the educationists of the country, who have no axes to grind, and who have an open mind, to study the two propositions that I have laid down, without allowing their preconceived and settled notions about the existing mode of education to interfere with the free flow of their reason.
('72', 285, 1, 6, 526259) I would urge them not to allow my utter ignorance of education, in its technical and orthodox sense, to prejudice them against what I have been saying and writing.
('72', 285, 1, 7, 526423) Wisdom, it is said, often comes from the mouths of babes and sucklings.
('72', 285, 1, 8, 526495) It may be a poetic exaggeration, but there is no doubt that sometimes it does come through babes.
('72', 285, 1, 9, 526593) Experts polish it and give it a scientific shape.
('72', 285, 1, 10, 526643) I therefore ask for an examination of my propositions purely on merits.
('72', 285, 1, 11, 526715) Let me restate them here, not as I have previously laid them down in these columns, but in the language that occurs to me as I am dictating these lines: 1. Primary education, extending over a period of 7 years or longer, and covering all the subjects up to the matriculation standard, except English, plus a vocation used as the vehicle for drawing out the minds of boys and girls in all departments of knowledge, should take the place of what passes today under the name of Primary, Middle and High School Education.
('72', 285, 1, 12, 527233) 2. Such education, taken as a whole, can, and must be, self supporting; in fact self support is the acid test of its reality.
('72', 285, 2, 13, 527359) Harijan, 2 10 1937
('72', 286, 0, 1, 527378) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 287
('72', 286, 1, 2, 527422) 364. QUESTIONS BEFORE EDUCATIONAL CONFERENCE
('72', 286, 2, 3, 527467) The Marwari High School, recently renamed Navabharat Vidya laya, is celebrating its Silver Jubilee.
('72', 286, 2, 4, 527567) The management conceived the idea of calling on the occasion a small conference of nationally minded educationists to discuss the plan of education I have been endeavouring to propound in these columns.
('72', 286, 2, 5, 527770) The Secretary, Shri Shrimannarayan Agrawal, consulted me as to the desirability of converting such a conference, and asked me to preside if I approved of the idea.
('72', 286, 2, 6, 527934) I liked both the suggestions.
('72', 286, 2, 7, 527964) So the conference will be held at Wardha on October 22nd and 23rd.
('72', 286, 2, 8, 528031) Only those will attend who are invited thereto.
('72', 286, 2, 9, 528079) If there are any educationists who would like to attend and who have not received invitations, they may apply to the Secretary, giving their names and addresses, and such particulars as would enable the management to decide whether they can afford to issue the invitation.
('72', 286, 2, 10, 528352) Provision is being made only for a limited number who are deeply interested in the problem and can make a useful contribution to the discussion.
('72', 286, 2, 11, 528497) The conference is not intended to be at all spectacular.
('72', 286, 2, 12, 528554) There will be no visitors.
('72', 286, 2, 13, 528581) It will be a purely business meeting.
('72', 286, 2, 14, 528619) A limited number of Press tickets will be issued.
('72', 286, 2, 15, 528669) I advise Pressmen to elect one or two representatives and share the reporting.
('72', 286, 2, 16, 528748) I approach the task in confidence but in all humility, with an open mind, and with the will to learn and to revise and correct my views, whenever necessary.
('72', 286, 2, 17, 528905) The propositions I shall submit to the conference for consideration will be, so far as they occur to me at present, as follows: 1. The present system of education does not meet the requirements of the country in any shape or form.
('72', 286, 2, 18, 529136) English, having been made the medium of instruction in all the higher branches of learning, has created a permanent bar between the highly educated few and the uneducated many.
('72', 286, 2, 19, 529313) It has prevented knowledge from percolating to the masses.
('72', 286, 2, 20, 529372) This excessive importance given to English has cast upon the educated class a burden which has maimed them mentally for life and made them strangers in their own land.
('72', 286, 2, 21, 529540) Absence of vocational training has made the educated class almost unfit for productive work and harmed them physically.
('72', 286, 2, 22, 529660) Money spent on primary education is a waste of expenditure inasmuch as what little is
('72', 287, 0, 1, 529746) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 287, 1, 2, 529788) taught is soon forgotten and has little or no value in terms of the villages or cities.
('72', 287, 1, 3, 529876) Such advantage as is gained by the existing system of education is not gained by the chief taxpayer, his children getting the least.
('72', 287, 1, 4, 530009) 2. The course of primary education should be extended at least to seven years and should include the general knowledge gained up to the matriculation standard less English and plus a substantial vocation.
('72', 287, 1, 5, 530214) 3. For the all round development of boys and girls all training should so far as possible be given through a profit yielding vocation.
('72', 287, 1, 6, 530349) In other words vocations should serve a double purpose—to enable the pupil to pay for his tuition through the products of his labour and at the same time to develop the whole man or woman in him or her through the vocation learnt at school.
('72', 287, 1, 7, 530590) Land, buildings and equipment are not intended to be covered by the proceeds of the pupil’s labour.
('72', 287, 1, 8, 530690) All the processes of cotton, wool and silk, commencing from gathering, cleaning, ginning (in the case of cotton), carding, spinning, dyeing, sizing, warp making, double twisting, designing and weaving, embroidery, tailoring, paper making, cutting, bookbinding, cabinet making, toy making, gur making are undoubtedly occupations that can easily be learnt and handled without much capital outlay.
('72', 287, 1, 9, 531085) This primary education should equip boys and girls to earn their bread, by the State guaranteeing employment in the vocations learnt or by buying their manufactures at prices fixed by the State.
('72', 287, 1, 10, 531280) 4. Higher education should be left to private enterprise and for meeting national requirements whether in the various industries, technical arts, belles lettres or fine arts.
('72', 287, 1, 11, 531455) The State Universities should be purely examining bodies, self supporting through the fees charged for examinations.
('72', 287, 1, 12, 531572) Universities will look after the whole of the field of education and will prepare and approve courses of studies in the various departments of education.
('72', 287, 1, 13, 531726) No private school should be run without the previous sanction of the respective Universities.
('72', 287, 1, 14, 531820) University charters should be given liberally to any body of persons of proved worth and integrity, it being always understood that the Universities will not cost the State anything except that it will bear the cost of running a Central Education Department.
('72', 287, 1, 15, 532079) The foregoing scheme does not absolve the State from running such seminaries as may be required for supplying State needs.
('72', 287, 1, 16, 532202) It is claimed that if the whole scheme is accepted, it will solve the question of the greatest concern to the State—training of its youth, its future makers.
('72', 287, 1, 17, 532360) Harijan, 2 10 1937

('72', 288, 2, 3, 532434) PRAISE FROM THE HIGHEST Thus runs an A. P. message 1 from Calicut:
('72', 288, 3, 4, 532501) In a statement issued today His Holiness Azhvancheri Thampurakkal, who is considered as the highest of the Brahmins in Kerala, says: “The Temple entry Proclamation 2 issued by His Highness the Maharaja of Travan core has resuscitated Hinduism, without in the least deviating from its essential ideals.” His Holiness considers that the Proclamation will shine resplendent through the ages as the most perfect doctrine of varnashrama dharma.
('72', 288, 4, 5, 532941) His Holiness also points out that the Proclamation has rooted out the evils of untouchability, disharmony and inequality among the Hindus, and as such His Holiness welcomes all the principles laid down in the Proclamation.
('72', 288, 4, 6, 533164) His Holiness is of opinion that it in no way contravenes the Vedic injunctions or Shastric ordinances.
('72', 288, 5, 7, 533267) His Holiness Azhvancheri Thampurakkal is the last resort of appeal in caste matters, according to the history of Kerala written by the historian Padmanabha Menon.
('72', 288, 5, 8, 533430) I tender my congratulations to His Holiness on his courageously ranging himself on the side of truth and progress.
('72', 288, 5, 9, 533545) It is to be hoped that if he is “the last resort of appeal in caste matters” his opinion will be respected and adopted by orthodoxy at least in Kerala if not elsewhere.

('72', 290, 1, 2, 535782) 367. ILLITERATES v.
('72', 290, 1, 3, 535802) LITERATES
('72', 290, 2, 4, 535812) A gentleman writes from Bombay:
('72', 290, 3, 5, 535844) The present Government has urged the Corporation to widen its franchise.
('72', 290, 3, 6, 535917) Today it is limited to the adults who pay not less than Rs. 5 rent.
('72', 290, 3, 7, 535985) It has been recommended that it should be extended to all literates.
('72', 290, 3, 8, 536054) The question now is what effect this will have on the proposal to have adult franchise for election to the Constituent Assembly.
('72', 290, 3, 9, 536183) If the Congress members now rest content with literacy franchise, would it not be a violation of the Congress principle?
('72', 290, 3, 10, 536304) There are some like me who think it expedient for the present to accept the literacy franchise.
('72', 290, 3, 11, 536400) What is our duty in the circumstances ?
('72', 290, 3, 12, 536440) In so far as this question is directly related to Congress discipline, I have no right to express an opinion on the subject.
('72', 290, 3, 13, 536565) My interpretation as a journalist I would not consider more authoritative than the interpretation of the questioner.
('72', 290, 3, 14, 536682) The opinion of the Congress President would be sufficient and should be binding in this matter.
('72', 290, 3, 15, 536778) But, let me, as one with long experience, give my opinion too for the sake of the questioner and others like him.
('72', 290, 3, 16, 536892) Anyone who thinks that he lacks the capacity or the time to take all the steps suggested by the Congress, should, I hold, take without hesitation whatever steps he can in the direction laid down by the Congress.
('72', 290, 3, 17, 537104) It is his duty to do this and there is no question of any breach of discipline.
('72', 290, 3, 18, 537184) Considering the merits of the proposal, 1 feel that while extending the franchise, it is not at all proper to confine it to literates.
('72', 290, 3, 19, 537319) It is possible that an educated young man of 21 may not at all be fit to exercise his franchise, whereas, an illiterate man of 50, experienced and sensible, may realize the value of his vote and his vote will have its own significance.
('72', 290, 3, 20, 537555) It has been daily happening that way.
('72', 290, 3, 21, 537593) There are many things taken for granted even in the Congress advocacy of adult franchise.
('72', 290, 3, 22, 537683) I am firmly convinced that the deaf and dumb, known idiots, lunatics, persons indulging in secret crimes and those suffering from incurable diseases cannot enjoy the right to vote even if they have attained the prescribed age.
('72', 290, 3, 23, 537910) Moreover, there is no reason to believe that those who have learnt to read and write have achieved something great.
('72', 290, 3, 24, 538026) I am not prepared to say that those who have not been able so far to get educated are themselves responsible for their ignorance.
('72', 290, 3, 25, 538156) It is indeed the indifference of the middle class people that is responsible for the
('72', 291, 0, 1, 538241) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 291, 1, 2, 538283) ignorance of the masses.
('72', 291, 1, 3, 538308) The number of illiterate people in India has remained so large because these people have not discharged their duty.
('72', 291, 1, 4, 538424) Hence, in my view it is a double crime to give franchise to those who, by the favour of the Government, have become educated and to deny it to those who, because of the Government’s indifference, received no education.
('72', 291, 1, 5, 538643) It becomes the duty of those in power to arrange for early education of those illiterates who are entitled to exercise their votes.
('72', 291, 1, 6, 538775) Thus, on the one hand, it would mean atonement for not giving franchise to those who should have had it from the beginning, and, on the other, it would encourage efforts to educate the electorate so that voters can exercise their franchise intelligently.
('72', 291, 1, 7, 539030) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 3 10 1937

('72', 299, 7, 11, 550362) 383. LETTER TO CHANDAN PAREKH
('72', 299, 8, 12, 550392) October 7, 1937
('72', 299, 9, 13, 550408) CHANDU, I am writing this letter though I have had none from you.
('72', 299, 9, 14, 550474) You are alone there and in a foreign land where everything is strange.
('72', 299, 9, 15, 550545) And moreover you have the burden of the .

('72', 305, 2, 3, 559883) SEGAON, October 8, 1937
('72', 305, 3, 4, 559907) NANAVATI, I told Mirabehn to note down the many things which she felt called for criticism.
('72', 305, 3, 5, 559999) The note is enclosed.
('72', 305, 3, 6, 560021) As a matter of fact, some of them fall within Dahyabhai’s sphere of work and some within Vijaya’s.
('72', 305, 3, 7, 560120) Perhaps there is nothing at all in this for which you are directly responsible.
('72', 305, 3, 8, 560200) But because you are the manager, all this should come to you for implementation at any rate.
('72', 305, 3, 9, 560293) Mirabehn, of course, had suggested that she herself should give it to you.
('72', 305, 3, 10, 560368) But I disapproved of it.
('72', 305, 3, 11, 560393) If she were to be dissatisfied with any explanation given by you, I would have to listen to that again.
('72', 305, 3, 12, 560497) If some of her words hurt you, you might not let them reach my ears but even so the pain would be there.
('72', 305, 3, 13, 560602) I have adopted this course in order to avoid that dilemma.
('72', 305, 3, 14, 560661) Many of Mirabehn’s suggestions are useful and worth considering.
('72', 305, 3, 15, 560726) All of them are indeed good, but there may be an element of exaggeration in some of them for which I would excuse her.
('72', 305, 3, 16, 560845) I intend to encourage Mirabehn to bring such things to my notice.
('72', 305, 3, 17, 560911) But she will talk only to me and, therefore, there will be no possibility of any tension arising.
('72', 305, 3, 18, 561009) I will make whatever suggestion or take whatever steps I wish to on the basis of what she tells me.
('72', 305, 3, 19, 561109) Please discuss this with Dahyabhai.
('72', 305, 3, 20, 561145) Show Vijaya whatever concerns her.

('72', 306, 3, 5, 561810) 393. LETTER TO PURUSHOTTAMDAS TANDON
('72', 306, 4, 6, 561847) SEGAON, October 8, 1937 DEAR TANDONJI, I have gone through all your letters.
('72', 306, 4, 7, 561924) All I had heard was that you had taken a liberal decision with regard to language.
('72', 306, 4, 8, 562007) I had read nothing at all.
('72', 306, 4, 9, 562034) I had also seen the brief Press report of your statement at the time you took your seat as Speaker.
('72', 306, 4, 10, 562134) These days I am able to give hardly five to seven minutes to the newspapers.
('72', 306, 4, 11, 562211) At times I cannot manage even that much.The burden of work has greatly increased since I placed before you my new ideas about education, and the need for rest is always there.
('72', 306, 4, 12, 562387) None the less, when Kaka Saheb left with me the treasure sent by you, it became my duty to read it.
('72', 306, 4, 13, 562487) I liked all of it immensely: your speech as the Speaker, your decision about language and your speech on that subject.
('72', 306, 4, 14, 562606) Both struck me as being original.
('72', 306, 4, 15, 562640) It is all to the good that you accepted the position of Speaker.
('72', 306, 4, 16, 562705) I also received the telegram concerning me.
('72', 306, 4, 17, 562749) I had not seen anything else.
('72', 306, 4, 18, 562779) It was good that you sent the report about it.
('72', 306, 4, 19, 562826) I deliberately did not answer the telegram.
('72', 306, 4, 20, 562870) This year there were so many telegrams from all parts of the world that I was astonished and I considered it grace of God.
('72', 306, 4, 21, 562993) I Sent a brief message of thanks through the Press.
('72', 306, 4, 22, 563045) 1 I decided not to reply to anyone personally.
('72', 306, 4, 23, 563092) And what reply could I have given in words?
('72', 306, 4, 24, 563136) Such abundance of love can only be acknowledged through action.
('72', 306, 4, 25, 563200) Let us see in what way God uses me as His instrument.

('72', 307, 1, 2, 563513) 394. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('72', 307, 2, 3, 563546) SEGAON, WARDHA, [Before October 9, 1937] 1
('72', 307, 3, 4, 563589) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, I don’t see any chance of my meeting Jinnah at present.

('72', 307, 3, 6, 563693) It seems I shall have to go to Calcutta.

('72', 307, 3, 8, 563807) I have had a letter from Subhas, too.
('72', 307, 3, 9, 563845) And if I go, I can see the detenus also.
('72', 307, 3, 10, 563886) We are, therefore, sure to meet during the journey or, if not during the journey, at any rate in Calcutta.
('72', 307, 3, 11, 563993) It will be better if you yourself write to Bahadurji regarding the Nariman case and request him to expedite it.
('72', 307, 3, 12, 564105) If we cannot gain control over the turbulent wind that is blowing, I am afraid the game will be lost completely.
('72', 307, 3, 13, 564218) We should try our best to gain that control.
('72', 307, 3, 14, 564263) If people don’t listen to us, we shall have no option but to leave.
('72', 307, 3, 15, 564331) A few persons having control at a few points in the present set up will not serve our purpose.
('72', 307, 3, 16, 564426) We shall be able to continue to work only if we have control over the whole organization.
('72', 307, 3, 17, 564516) We will try our best to preserve such control.

('72', 308, 0, 1, 565456) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 309
('72', 308, 1, 2, 565500) 395. GIVE MINISTERS A CHANCE
('72', 308, 2, 3, 565529) This is the gist of the conversation of a visitor: You may not know what Ministers have to go through just now.
('72', 308, 2, 4, 565641) Congressmen, having abjured office for seventeen years, suddenly find that their own chosen representatives are in possession of powers which they had voluntarily surrendered before.
('72', 308, 2, 5, 565824) They do not know what to do with these representatives.
('72', 308, 2, 6, 565880) They smother them with addresses and entertainments and, as often as not, they demand interviews with them as a matter of right and present them with all kinds of suggestions and sometimes even ask for petty favours.
('72', 308, 2, 7, 566097) This is the best way to disable the Ministers from doing real service to the country.
('72', 308, 2, 8, 566183) They are new to their work.
('72', 308, 2, 9, 566211) A conscientious Minister has no time for receiving addresses and honours, or for making speeches in return for fulsome or deserved praise.
('72', 308, 2, 10, 566350) Nor have they time for interviewers whom they do not invite, or who they think are not going to help them in their work.
('72', 308, 2, 11, 566471) In theory, a leader of democracy holds himself at the beck and call of the public.
('72', 308, 2, 12, 566554) It is but right that he should do so.
('72', 308, 2, 13, 566592) But he dare not do so at the sacrifice of the duty imposed upon him by the public.
('72', 308, 2, 14, 566675) Ministers will cut a sorry figure if they do not master, or are not allowed by the public to master, the work entrusted to them.
('72', 308, 2, 15, 566804) An Education Minister has to have all his wits about him if he is to evolve a policy in keeping with the requirements of the country.
('72', 308, 2, 16, 566938) An Excise Minister will prove a disastrous failure if he does not attend to the constructive side of prohibition.
('72', 308, 2, 17, 567052) And so will a Finance Minister who, in spite of the handicap created for him by the [Government of] India Act and in spite of the voluntary surrender of the Excise Revenue, will not balance his budget.
('72', 308, 2, 18, 567254) It requires a juggler in figures to be able to do so.
('72', 308, 2, 19, 567308) These are but illustrations.
('72', 308, 2, 20, 567337) Every ministerial office requires almost the same vigilance, care and study as the three I have mentioned.
('72', 308, 2, 21, 567444) It would have been easy for them, if they had simply to read and sign papers put before them by the permanent Service.
('72', 308, 2, 22, 567563) But it is not easy to study every document and think out and originate new policies.
('72', 308, 2, 23, 567648) Their gesture of simplicity, necessary as it was as a preliminary, will avail them nothing if they will not show the requisite industry, ability, integrity, impartiality, and an infinite capacity for mastering details.
('72', 308, 2, 24, 567867) It would be well, therefore, if the public will exercise self restraint in the matter of giving addresses, seeking interviews or writing to them long epistles.
('72', 308, 2, 25, 568027) Harijan, 9 10 1937
('72', 309, 0, 1, 568046) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 309, 1, 2, 568088) 396. CONDITIONS OF SUCCESS
('72', 309, 2, 3, 568115) Bhausaheb Lavate 1 has been honouring me with a visit in the interest of prohibition which is as dear to him as to me.
('72', 309, 2, 4, 568234) We came to the following conclusions: 1. Strict non use from now of all Excise Revenue for any but prohibition purposes.
('72', 309, 2, 5, 568355) 2. Non renewal of all licences on their expiry and immediate closing of all liquor shops, where there is a clear demand for closing on the part of at least 75% of those who have been visiting these shops.
('72', 309, 2, 6, 568560) 3. Liquor, whenever it is necessary to sell it, should be sold only through direct Government agency.
('72', 309, 2, 7, 568662) 4. All existing liquor shops should be, wherever possible, converted into refreshment and recreation rooms.
('72', 309, 2, 8, 568770) 5. Causes of the habit in typical areas should be carefully investigated and dealt with.
('72', 309, 2, 9, 568859) 6. Absolutely peaceful, silent and educative picketing by recognized individuals or groups should be undertaken, the object being to establish intimate personal contact with the addicts so as to help them to give up the habit.
('72', 309, 2, 10, 569086) Personal visits to the addicts in their own homes would be a feature of scientific picketing.
('72', 309, 2, 11, 569180) Voluntary agency for this work should be invited by the Government and encouraged to do this philanthropic work.
('72', 309, 2, 12, 569293) Harijan, 9 10 1937

('72', 312, 1, 2, 573116) 401. TWO ENDORSEMENTS OF EDUCATION THROUGH WORK Even though Vinoha and I are separated by a distance of only five miles, we hardly meet each other as we are both deep in our own work and as neither is in the best of health.
('72', 312, 1, 3, 573340) Hence, we decide many matters by correspondence.
('72', 312, 1, 4, 573389) I have quoted these ideas 1 from one such letter.
('72', 312, 1, 5, 573439) I consider these ideas very significant, because I am not aware of anyone else from among my colleagues who has carried out so many experiments in that direction as Vinoba has.
('72', 312, 1, 6, 573616) The revolutionary increase in the speed of the takli has at its root Vinoba’s inspiration and his untiring labour.
('72', 312, 1, 7, 573731) He has worked on his charkha and takli for eight to ten hours a day even though he has been managing a big organization.
('72', 312, 1, 8, 573852) And, right from the beginning he has given this craft an important place in education.
('72', 312, 1, 9, 573939) Thus, Vinoba is naturally in full agreement with me in making education self supporting through a craft which I consider to be my original discovery.
('72', 312, 1, 10, 574089) This, indeed, is a matter of great encouragement for me.
('72', 312, 1, 11, 574146) I have quoted his opinion here in the hope that it would strengthen the faith of those who know Vinoba and would inspire faith in those who have none now.
('72', 312, 1, 12, 574301) Support from Shri Vinoba is not a matter of surprise for me.
('72', 312, 1, 13, 574362) Nor would it be for readers of Harijanbandhu.
('72', 312, 1, 14, 574408) On the contrary, if I do not get his support, it should set me thinking.
('72', 312, 1, 15, 574481) It would be foolish and certainly impudent to venture to convince the nation about a point if I am not able to convince my oldest colleagues about it.
('72', 312, 1, 16, 574632) I was no doubt pleasantly surprised on receiving Shri Manu Subedar’s letter.
('72', 312, 1, 17, 574709) I have been corresponding with him on issues like education, prohibition, etc.
('72', 312, 1, 18, 574788) As a result I have the following letter 2. The reader will be happy to see it.
('72', 312, 1, 19, 574867) He had sent some suggestions in English along with the letter which I have already published in Harijan 3. [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 10 10 1937
('72', 312, 2, 20, 575016) 1 Not translated here.
('72', 312, 2, 21, 575039) Vinoba Bhave had conveyed his appreciation of Gandhiji’s latest thoughts on education and had further stated that he would not have even the dualistic conception of work and education and he had therefore already started experimenting on the lines of work education.

('72', 313, 0, 1, 575642) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 313, 1, 2, 575684) 402. MY NOTES
('72', 313, 2, 3, 575698) PROHIBITION IN AHMEDABAD The Government of the Bombay Presidency has taken the welcome decision of introducing total prohibition from the 1st of April.
('72', 313, 2, 4, 575850) This is no doubt a correct step.
('72', 313, 2, 5, 575883) As Ahmedabad is one of those fields where this thing has been well tried, this experiment should meet with easy success there.
('72', 313, 2, 6, 576010) The aim of prohibition is that people may stop taking alcohol.
('72', 313, 2, 7, 576073) If people do not give up the habit, illicit distillation will go on and the addicts will persist in drinking, and the prohibition law will have failed.
('72', 313, 2, 8, 576225) Thus, although people cannot be made to give up drinking unless the drinking booths are closed down, the mere closing down of the booths will bring no result unless people are convinced through education of the evils of alcoholism.
('72', 313, 2, 9, 576457) The largest number of alcoholics in Ahmedabad comes from the working class.
('72', 313, 2, 10, 576533) The Majoor Mahajan deserves to be congratulated on having undertaken the responsibility of educating the public and on having passed the necessary resolution.
('72', 313, 2, 11, 576692) If men and women take upon themselves the individual responsibility and carry on this work, it is sure to meet with success.
('72', 313, 2, 12, 576817) If success is achieved in a centre like Ahmedabad, other parts of India will also be encouraged and they will also learn how success can be achieved.
('72', 313, 2, 13, 576967) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 10 10 1937

('72', 321, 12, 23, 588919) MY DEAR REBEL,
('72', 321, 13, 24, 588934) Though there is nothing wrong in Hindus putting emphasis on Devanagari script and a knowledge of Hindi (if it is to be distinguished from highly Persianized Urdu), if you can postpone active work till after the Sammelan it would be wise.
('72', 321, 13, 25, 589172) This is all a matter of experience, and it is so difficult to advise without sensing the
('72', 322, 0, 1, 589261) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 323
('72', 322, 1, 2, 589305) surrounding atmosphere and the local circumstances.
('72', 322, 1, 3, 589357) Both these I like to see for myself whenever I have to decide a delicate question which depends for its solution on a knowledge of the atmosphere and circumstances.
('72', 322, 1, 4, 589522) I hope this will be some sort of guide for you.
('72', 322, 1, 5, 589570) Whatever happens, this is quite clear to me, that every Punjabi should realize that Punjabi and Urdu are his languages; but a Hindu, wherever he is, should know Hindi through the Devanagari script, for the sake of being able to read first class devotional literature, the like of which is not to be found in any other Provincial speech.
('72', 322, 1, 6, 589907) I do not know what the approach of the Hindi Pracharini Sabha is.
('72', 322, 1, 7, 589973) It may be wholly different from mine.
('72', 322, 1, 8, 590011) If that is so the decision as to the propriety of carrying on propaganda will be different from what I have given.

('72', 322, 1, 15, 590449) I wish I could find the time for practising writing with the left hand daily, but I don’t, beyond having the time for tracing my signature to the daily letters.

('72', 326, 3, 6, 596523) He knew that with the advance of years my memory was decaying rapidly, and, trading upon that knowledge he challenged me to guess the writer’s identity.
('72', 326, 3, 7, 596676) I could not till I saw the last sentence, and I asked since when you had become Jaisoorya.
('72', 326, 3, 8, 596767) Then I thought that my memory was gradually coming back, and I said to myself that when you had come to me at Knightsbridge in that Deputation of self styled firebrands, you had sent in your name as Jaisoorya.
('72', 326, 3, 9, 596977) But at that time Mother 1 had prepared me to identify you with the bearded young man with amazing self assurance.
('72', 326, 3, 10, 597091) Your letter shows that you remain the same on the surface, but in spite of your looking down upon old fogies, you have inward regard for them, and know that you can as little do without them as without the very stupid days of your childhood.
('72', 326, 3, 11, 597333) Therefore, in spite of your profound differences with me, in which you glory, I am not going to disregard your outline.
('72', 326, 3, 12, 597453) But I am going to study it carefully, and then give you my opinion.
('72', 326, 3, 13, 597521) But you will be patient with me.
('72', 326, 3, 14, 597554) Meanwhile this comes to you with all the good wishes that you and yours may care to have, or be in need of.

('72', 327, 5, 10, 598247) 426. NOTE ON NARIMAN SARDAR CASE
('72', 327, 6, 11, 598280) [October 14, 1937] 2
('72', 327, 7, 12, 598301) Mr. Bahadurji has brought me his judgment 3 on the Nariman Sardar case which is attached hereto.
('72', 327, 7, 13, 598398) When I asked, not without much hesitation, to associate himself with me in the task I had taken up in the public interest, he readily agreed to do so.
('72', 327, 7, 14, 598549) He had, perhaps, not realized what anxious labour it would cost him to do justice to the task.
('72', 327, 7, 15, 598644) I do not know what I would have’ done without his valuable assistance.
('72', 327, 7, 16, 598715) We read his judgment together and with very slight changes I suggested, and which he readily accepted.
('72', 327, 7, 17, 598818) The judgment is absolutely his own and arrived at without any previous consultation with me.
('72', 327, 7, 18, 598911) I concur with his reasoning and finding.
('72', 327, 7, 19, 598952) The public will see that the finding is purely judicial.
('72', 327, 7, 20, 599009) Parties were given every facility to see the evidence, to take copies and were free to have witnesses orally examined and cross exarnined.
('72', 327, 7, 21, 599148) But they did not want any examination or cross examination nor was it necessary.
('72', 327, 7, 22, 599229) Though there were over eighty witnesses and the evidence was voluminous, a mass of it was wholly irrelevant to the two issues before us.
('72', 327, 7, 23, 599366) The greatest latitude was given to Mr. Nariman to bring before me any evidence he had.
('72', 327, 7, 24, 599453) I sent personal letters to witnesses, whose names he had sent me.
('72', 327, 7, 25, 599519) Most of the Congress legislators have

('72', 327, 10, 28, 599774) 3 In which Bahadurji had arrived at the conclusion that the “charge against K. F. Nariman in respect of the elections in 1934 was proved and the charge made by K. F. Nariman against Vallabhbhai was not proved.”

('72', 328, 1, 2, 600029) sent in their statements in answer to my public appeal for evidence.
('72', 328, 2, 3, 600098) If I had no further duty to discharge, there would be nothing more for me to say.
('72', 328, 2, 4, 600180) But I must not avoid reference to the things that have been brought to light in the course of the evidence sent to me.
('72', 328, 2, 5, 600299) Mr. Nariman has sent to me newspaper cuttings.
('72', 328, 2, 6, 600346) They have made painful reading.
('72', 328, 2, 7, 600378) There is no evidence whatsoever to show that the Sardar was actuated by any communal bias.
('72', 328, 2, 8, 600469) The newspapers, which have made suggestions that there was communal bias behind the rejection of Mr. Nariman, have rendered a great disservice to the Bombay public life and Mr. Nariman, who has himself, I am glad, rejected any such suggestion.
('72', 328, 2, 9, 600713) Indeed, Mr. Nariman’s grievances against the Sardar seem to resolve themselves into this: As the Sardar told him on the 3rd of March, he would not and did not exert himself on his behalf.
('72', 328, 2, 10, 600901) It is plain that when a person of the Sardar’s influence remains passive, his attitude was bound to go against Mr. Nariman, but for that the Sardar could not be held blameworthy.
('72', 328, 2, 11, 601080) It seems to me Mr. Nariman forgot that the City of Bombay is not the Bombay Presidency.
('72', 328, 2, 12, 601168) And if he had really the confidence of Maharashtra and Karnataka, the Sardar’s passivity would have availed nothing.
('72', 328, 2, 13, 601285) Indeed, there is nothing to prevent the legislators even now from inviting Mr. Kher 2 to resign and electing Mr. Nariman in his place.
('72', 328, 2, 14, 601420) The suggestion that the Sardar’s overpowering influence would prevent such a change is thoughtless.
('72', 328, 2, 15, 601520) Ninety men cannot be overawed for a long time by one man, however powerful he may be.
('72', 328, 2, 16, 601606) My analysis of the situation is that Mr. Nariman overestimated his hold on the legislators and felt the keenest disappointment over the defeat.
('72', 328, 2, 17, 601750) His judgment became warped.
('72', 328, 2, 18, 601778) This is evidenced by his own statements before me.
('72', 328, 2, 19, 601829) His advisers and the newspaper propaganda kept up the illusion.
('72', 328, 2, 20, 601893) It is no pleasure to me to have to pen these lines.
('72', 328, 2, 21, 601945) But I pen them in the hope that his eyes may be opened by the opening out of the agonized heart of one who has been his friend and well wisher and who was somewhat responsible for his inclusion in the Congress Cabinet.

('72', 332, 5, 10, 607235) 434. SOME CRITICISM ANSWERED
('72', 332, 6, 11, 607264) A high educational officer who wishes to remain unknown has sent me, through a common friend, an elaborate and considered criticism of my plan of primary education.
('72', 332, 6, 12, 607429) For want of space I may not reproduce the whole argument here.
('72', 332, 6, 13, 607492) Nor is there anything new in it.
('72', 332, 6, 14, 607525) And yet it deserves a reply, if only for the pains the writer has bestowed on his paper.
('72', 332, 6, 15, 607614) This is how my suggestions have been paraphrased by the writer:
('72', 332, 7, 16, 607678) (i) Primary education should start and end with training in crafts and industries, and that whatever may be necessary by way of general information should come in as auxiliaries in the initial stage, and that formal training through the medium of reading and writing in subjects like History, Geography and Arithmetic [should] come right at the end.
('72', 332, 8, 17, 608028) 1 Vide “Are Christians Against Prohibition”
('72', 333, 0, 1, 608072) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 333, 1, 2, 608114) (ii) Primary education should be self supporting from the first, and that this should and could be achieved by the State taking over the finished articles coming from the schools and selling them to the public.
('72', 333, 2, 3, 608325) (iii) Primary education should be fully up to the Matriculation standard— less of course English.
('72', 333, 3, 4, 608423) (iv) Prof.
('72', 333, 3, 5, 608434) K. T. Shah’s idea of conscripting young men and women to teach in the primary schools should be fully examined and, if possible, acted upon.
('72', 333, 4, 6, 608575) The writer at once proceeds to say:
('72', 333, 5, 7, 608611) If we analyse the above programme it seems to us that the underlying ideas are in some cases mediaeval, and in some cases based upon assumptions which would not bear examination.
('72', 333, 5, 8, 608790) Probably No.
('72', 333, 5, 9, 608803) iii is a very high standard.
('72', 333, 5, 10, 608832) It would have been better if, instead of paraphrasing, the writer had quoted my own words.
('72', 333, 5, 11, 608923) For all the statements in the first paraphrase are wide of the truth.
('72', 333, 5, 12, 608993) My point is not that the start should be made with crafts and the rest should come in as auxiliaries.
('72', 333, 5, 13, 609095) On the contrary I have said that the whole of the general education should come through the crafts and simultaneously with their progress.
('72', 333, 5, 14, 609234) This is wholly different from what the writer imputes to me.
('72', 333, 5, 15, 609295) 1 do not know what happened in the Middle Ages.
('72', 333, 5, 16, 609343) But I do know that the aim in the Middle Ages or any age was never to develop the whole man through crafts.
('72', 333, 5, 17, 609451) The idea is original.
('72', 333, 5, 18, 609473) That it may prove to be wrong does not affect the originality.
('72', 333, 5, 19, 609536) And an original idea does not admit of a frontal attack unless it is tried on a sufficiently large scale.
('72', 333, 5, 20, 609642) To say a priori that it is impossible is no argument.
('72', 333, 5, 21, 609696) Nor have I said that the formal training through the medium of reading and writing should come right at the end.
('72', 333, 5, 22, 609809) On the contrary the formal training comes in at the very beginning.
('72', 333, 5, 23, 609877) Indeed it is an integral part of the general equipment.
('72', 333, 5, 24, 609933) I have indeed said, and I repeat here, that reading may come a little later, and writing may come last.
('72', 333, 5, 25, 610037) But the whole process has to be finished within the first year, so that at the end of the first year in the school of my imagination a seven year old child, boy or girl, will have much more than the general information that any boy or girl has in the present primary school during the first year.
('72', 333, 5, 26, 610334) He will read correctly and draw correct letters instead of making the daubs that the children generally do at present.
('72', 333, 5, 27, 610453) The child will also know elementary additions and subtractions and the simple
('72', 333, 6, 28, 610531) 1 K. T. Shah’s article appeared in Harijan, 31 7 1937.
('72', 334, 0, 1, 610586) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 335
('72', 334, 1, 2, 610630) multiplication table.
('72', 334, 1, 3, 610652) He will have learned all this through and while he has learned a productive craft, say spinning, by choice.
('72', 334, 1, 4, 610760) The second paraphrase is just as unhappy as the first.
('72', 334, 1, 5, 610815) For what I have claimed is that education through handicrafts should be self supporting during the sum total of seven years I have assigned for it.
('72', 334, 1, 6, 610963) I have specifically said that during the first two years it may mean a partial loss.
('72', 334, 1, 7, 611048) Mediaeval times may have been bad, but I am not prepared to condemn things simply because they are mediaeval.
('72', 334, 1, 8, 611158) The spinning wheel is undoubtedly mediaeval, but seems to have come to stay.
('72', 334, 1, 9, 611235) Though the article is the same it has become a symbol of freedom and unity as at one time, after the advent of the East India Company, it had become the symbol of slavery.
('72', 334, 1, 10, 611407) Modern India has found in it a deeper and truer meaning than our forefathers had dreamt of.
('72', 334, 1, 11, 611499) Even so, if the handicrafts were once symbols of factory labour, may they now be symbols and vehicles of education in the fullest and truest sense of the term.
('72', 334, 1, 12, 611659) If the Ministers have enough imagination and courage, they will give the idea a trial in spite of the criticism, undoubtedly well meant, of high educational officers and others especially when the criticism is based on imaginary premises.
('72', 334, 1, 13, 611898) Though the writer has been good enough to assume the possibility of Prof.
('72', 334, 1, 14, 611972) K. T. Shah’s scheme of conscription being sound, he later on evidently repents of it.
('72', 334, 1, 15, 612058) For he says:
('72', 334, 2, 16, 612071) The idea of conscripting teachers is to our mind an outrage.
('72', 334, 2, 17, 612132) We should have in schools, where young children assemble, men and women who have voluntarily dedicated their lives to this profession so far as such a dedication is possible in this world, and who will bring sun shine and zeal.
('72', 334, 2, 18, 612360) We have made far too many experiments with our young men and women, but this one bids fair in its results to land us in a ruin from which there will be no escape for at least half a century.
('72', 334, 2, 19, 612551) The whole thing is based on the notion that teaching is one of those arts for which no adequate training is necessary and that everyone is a born teacher.
('72', 334, 2, 20, 612706) How a man of K. T. Shah’s eminence comes to hold it is inexplicable.
('72', 334, 2, 21, 612775) The idea is a freak idea bound to be tragic in results if applied.
('72', 334, 2, 22, 612842) Again, bow can each and everyone train children in handicrafts, etc.?
('72', 334, 2, 23, 612912) Shah is well able to defend his proposition.
('72', 334, 2, 24, 612957) But I would like to remind the writer that the existing teachers are not volunteers.
('72', 334, 2, 25, 613042) They are hirelings (the word is used in its natural sense) working for their bread and butter.
('72', 334, 2, 26, 613137) Shah’s scheme does contemplate possession of patriotism, spirit of sacrifice, a certain amount of culture, and training in a handicraft, before they are taken up.
('72', 334, 2, 27, 613300) His idea is
('72', 335, 0, 1, 613312) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 335, 1, 2, 613354) substantial, quite feasible, and deserves the greatest consideration.
('72', 335, 1, 3, 613424) If we have to wait till we have born teachers, we shall have to wait till the Judgement Day for them.
('72', 335, 1, 4, 613526) I submit that teachers will have to be trained on a wholesale scale during the shortest term possible.
('72', 335, 1, 5, 613629) This cannot be done unless the services of the existing educated young men and women are gently impressed.
('72', 335, 1, 6, 613736) It will not be unless there is a general willing response from that body.
('72', 335, 1, 7, 613810) They responded, however feebly, during the civil disobedience campaign.
('72', 335, 1, 8, 613882) Will they fail to respond to the call for constructive service against maintenance money?
('72', 335, 1, 9, 613972) Then the writer asks:
('72', 335, 2, 10, 613994) (1) Are we not to allow for a great deal of wastage in raw materials when handled by little boys?
('72', 335, 3, 11, 614092) (2) Are the sales to be effected by a central organization?
('72', 335, 3, 12, 614152) What about the cost of this?
('72', 335, 4, 13, 614181) (3) Are the people to be compelled to buy at these stores?
('72', 335, 5, 14, 614240) (4) What about the cases of those communities which are at present manufacturing these?
('72', 335, 5, 15, 614328) What will be the reaction on these?
('72', 335, 5, 16, 614364) My answers are: 1. Of course there will be wastage, but there will be even at the end of the first year some gain by each pupil.
('72', 335, 5, 17, 614493) 2. The State will absorb much of the material for its own requirements.
('72', 335, 5, 18, 614565) 3. Nobody will be compelled to buy the nation’s children’s manufactures, but the nation is expected to buy with pardonable pride and patriotic pleasure what its children make for its needs.
('72', 335, 5, 19, 614755) 4. There is hardly any competition in the products of village handicrafts.
('72', 335, 5, 20, 614830) And care will be taken to manufacture things which do not come into unfair competition with any indigenous manufacturers.
('72', 335, 5, 21, 614952) Thus khadi, village paper, palm gur and the like have no competitors.
('72', 335, 6, 22, 615022) Harijan, 16 10 1937
('72', 336, 0, 1, 615042) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 337
('72', 336, 1, 2, 615086) 435. PROHIBITION AND EDUCATION
('72', 336, 2, 3, 615117) Mr. J. G. Gilson is the Secretary of the Christian High and Technical School, Balasore, and Director of Industrial Arts and Vocational Education for A. B. B. O. Mission.
('72', 336, 2, 4, 615287) In sending some valuable literature on ‘Rural Sewage Disposal and the Natural Sewage Treatment Process’, he writes: 1
('72', 336, 3, 5, 615405) In general I find myself very much in agreement with your conclusions.
('72', 336, 3, 6, 615476) I was especially pleased with your clear exposition of the fact that manual work, properly conducted, is the best means to intellectual development.
('72', 336, 3, 7, 615625) I have found it hard to make teachers believe that anything else than textbooks and lectures and cramming for examination can contribute to this end.
('72', 336, 3, 8, 615775) Your explanation of the point should help to make it clear to everyone.
('72', 336, 3, 9, 615847) I was also pleased to note that you have appreciated the work done by a number of Mission schools in introducing the handwork curriculum in India.
('72', 336, 4, 10, 615994) On the other hand I cannot agree with you that education can, or should, be made self supporting by the work of the students.
('72', 336, 4, 11, 616120) If children are kept at such work for 4 hours per day under competent supervision, they can no doubt pay for their keep and perhaps for the supervision as well.
('72', 336, 4, 12, 616281) But such work has no educational value.
('72', 336, 4, 13, 616321) It may even become as dulling to the intellect as poring over textbooks and listening to lectures.
('72', 336, 5, 14, 616420) In order for the children’s work to have educational value they must be given a variety of work to do, and as soon as they have learned one operation well they must be allowed to go on to something new.
('72', 336, 5, 15, 616623) But the product of their work will not likely be sufficient to support the school.
('72', 336, 5, 16, 616706) It may contribute something toward the costs of the school.
('72', 336, 6, 17, 616766) But I see no reason why schools should be expected to be self supporting.
('72', 336, 6, 18, 616840) The education of the children, and continued education of adults, is a responsibility of the community, and it seems to me that in the present condition of India it should be the first and largest claim upon the public funds.
('72', 336, 7, 19, 617066) It is very unfortunate that prohibition and education should have been linked together in the discussions, and that the American experience with prohibition should have been brought into it in a way which shows a lack of understanding of American conditions.
('72', 336, 7, 20, 617325) If the American example is to be
('72', 336, 8, 21, 617358) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('72', 337, 0, 1, 617395) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 337, 1, 2, 617437) quoted let it be said that in America during the prohibition period there was no shortage of funds for education; indeed the schools were very rapidly improved during the period.
('72', 337, 2, 3, 617616) Prohibition in America was not a failure in accomplishing an improvement in the condition of the common people, with the possible exception of the big cities where the majority of the people are European born and where public opinion would not allow the enforcement of the law.
('72', 337, 2, 4, 617894) The great mass of the American people outside the cities are total abstainers and drinking is looked upon as a social and moral disgrace just as it is in India; or at least it was so until 1933. Already a strong reaction has set in against the excesses of these past four years.
('72', 337, 3, 5, 618173) Prohibition failed politically in America because of the political power of the big cities, and because the brewers and others who stood to gain by the sale of liquor were willing to spend millions of dollars in newspaper propaganda, while the mass of the people were quite indifferent to what had ceased to be, for them, a pressing problem.
('72', 337, 3, 6, 618515) It is the case of the exploitation of the country by the wealthy of the cities.
('72', 337, 3, 7, 618595) The same problem you have to face in making prohibition a success in India.
('72', 337, 3, 8, 618671) I do not wonder at Mr. Gilson’s scepticism about education through an industry being made wholly self supporting, if it is at the same time to develop the mind of the pupil.
('72', 337, 3, 9, 618845) This point is dealt with by me in another column 1. His testimony about American prohibition will be read with interest.
('72', 337, 3, 10, 618966) Harijan, 16 10 1937
('72', 337, 4, 11, 618986) 436. IN SUPPORT
('72', 337, 5, 12, 619002) I completely agree with, nay, even humbly plead for your suggestion of teaching a child a useful handicraft scientifically and culturally and enabling it to produce from the moment it begins its training.
('72', 337, 5, 13, 619207) No doubt it is a revolutionary proposal, but I agree with it completely.
('72', 337, 5, 14, 619280) Its moral, cultural and economic value will be immense to the individual and to the nation.
('72', 337, 5, 15, 619372) Not only will it promote dignity of labour, but self reliance and proper creative values of life.
('72', 337, 5, 16, 619470) Our aim should be to promote a child’s intellectual, physical, moral and vocational needs.
('72', 337, 5, 17, 619561) The last will teach the general principles of all the processes of production and at the same time give the child or youth practical training in the use of the simplest tools of all industries.
('72', 337, 5, 18, 619755) Our ideal
('72', 337, 6, 19, 619765) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('72', 338, 0, 1, 619792) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 339
('72', 338, 1, 2, 619836) should be a combination of instruction with productive work on the part of the young generation.
('72', 338, 1, 3, 619933) This means a linking up of manual work with general instruction, and aims at giving a broad idea of the chief branches of industry with which manual work can be co ordinated.
('72', 338, 1, 4, 620108) Physical labour combined with an intellectual and moral effort should be our educational outlook.
('72', 338, 1, 5, 620206) There should be no cleavage between brain work and manual work.
('72', 338, 2, 6, 620270) We should include in our system of primary or elementary education:
('72', 338, 3, 7, 620338) 1. Mother tongue
('72', 338, 4, 8, 620355) 2. Arithmetic
('72', 338, 5, 9, 620369) 3. Natural science
('72', 338, 6, 10, 620388) 4. Social science
('72', 338, 7, 11, 620406) 5. Geography and history
('72', 338, 8, 12, 620431) 6. Manual or polytechnical work
('72', 338, 9, 13, 620463) 7. Physical culture
('72', 338, 10, 14, 620483) 8. Art and music
('72', 338, 11, 15, 620500) 9. Hindustani
('72', 338, 12, 16, 620514) The only question which, however, arises here is at what age a child’s education should begin.
('72', 338, 12, 17, 620609) If it be at 5 or 6, can it be possible to start a useful handicraft at that age?
('72', 338, 12, 18, 620690) What about the expenses in teaching it?
('72', 338, 12, 19, 620730) It will not be easier and less expensive than spreading literacy.
('72', 338, 12, 20, 620796) I would start a handicraft at the age of 8 or 10, because the use of implements requires a grasp and a steadiness in handling and applying them to the object in view.
('72', 338, 12, 21, 620963) But primary education must at least begin at the age of five or six.
('72', 338, 12, 22, 621032) A child cannot be made to wait longer.
('72', 338, 12, 23, 621071) We must have a ten years’ curricula to take the child to the matriculation standard in addition to the polytechnical training we intend to give it.
('72', 338, 12, 24, 621219) I am, however, doubtful about the economic value of the products of these children especially in their early stages.
('72', 338, 12, 25, 621336) They will not be saleable in a country where free trade and advanced fashions prevail and when the products themselves will not be durable or finished ones.
('72', 338, 12, 26, 621493) If the State were to purchase them or take them in return for the service or aid rendered, what will it do with them?
('72', 338, 12, 27, 621611) It would be better for the State to spend money directly on the education of children than to adopt this process.
('72', 338, 12, 28, 621725) Of course the products of advanced boys, say, between 12 and 16 may be made marketable and therefore become an important item of income.
('72', 338, 13, 29, 621862) I would rather treat the problem of literacy on a different footing and face
('72', 338, 14, 30, 621939) boldly the taxation and expenditure necessary for it.
('72', 338, 15, 31, 621993) The idea of a useful handicraft can be well developed in the advanced
('72', 339, 0, 1, 622063) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 339, 1, 2, 622105) stages of primary (or secondary) education.
('72', 339, 1, 3, 622149) It should be attempted to be made at least partly self supporting, and after experience gained, fully self suppor ting, if possible, on the basis of the value of its products.
('72', 339, 1, 4, 622325) Only one danger will have to be guarded against, that cultural education of the body, mind and spirit does not become subordinated completely to the economic motive and economics of the school.
('72', 339, 2, 5, 622519) I also agree with your further suggestion of primary education being made equal to the present matriculation standard less English, but plus Hindustani (I would add).
('72', 339, 2, 6, 622686) It means you include also secondary education in the system of primary education.
('72', 339, 2, 7, 622768) Your idea is a complete scheme of school education of, say, ten years.
('72', 339, 2, 8, 622839) I would add in this that it must be imparted through the mother tongue and through no other language.
('72', 339, 2, 9, 622941) This will liberate the mind of the child and create in it a living interest in the problems of knowledge and life and give it a creative turn and outlook.
('72', 339, 3, 10, 623096) I admit here that education was largely self supporting in mediaeval times, and could be made so in a general way if our social, economic and political organization and outlook were to remain mediaeval, that is, addicted to the old and narrow values of class and caste economy, society and polity.
('72', 339, 3, 11, 623394) But today in a democratic, national and socialistic conception of life which has pervaded us, it cannot become so.
('72', 339, 3, 12, 623509) The only organized power of the community with sanctions and resources behind it is the State.
('72', 339, 3, 13, 623604) Hence it has to undertake this work.
('72', 339, 3, 14, 623641) The old power groups—caste, class, guild, college, Church—have lost their power, sanction and resources, and do not exist in that larger sense of the old times.
('72', 339, 3, 15, 623802) People also have no faith in them.
('72', 339, 3, 16, 623837) All social power has shifted to the political group which is also the economic and social force even in India.
('72', 339, 3, 17, 623948) Therefore two ideologies, one mediaeval and one modern, one pluralistic and functional, and the other unitary and territorial, cannot work together.
('72', 339, 4, 18, 624097) There was no universal education in the past, no democratic unitary State, no national equalitarian outlook.
('72', 339, 5, 19, 624206) The idea of conscription for educational service is not now a novel one but is worth following.
('72', 339, 5, 20, 624302) Let the Congress and its Provincial Ministers in their official capacity appeal to the intelligentsia of the country and call upon all who have the education of the people at heart to rally to the assistance of new Governments for the spread of literacy, culture and education.
('72', 339, 5, 21, 624580) It will establish a mass contact on a new basis, and not merely on an economic and political basis.
('72', 339, 5, 22, 624680) It will also serve the higher purposes of awakening, consolidation and organization of mass power and intelligence.
('72', 339, 5, 23, 624796) When I first wrote on self supporting primary education thro 
('72', 340, 0, 1, 624858) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 341
('72', 340, 1, 2, 624902) ugh an industry I had invited educationist fellow workers to favour me with their opinions.
('72', 340, 1, 3, 624994) Professor S. V. Puntambekar was among the first, to send me his.
('72', 340, 1, 4, 625059) He sent me a long reasoned reply.
('72', 340, 1, 5, 625093) But for want of space I was unable to deal with it earlier.
('72', 340, 1, 6, 625153) The foregoing is the most relevant portion of his opinion.
('72', 340, 1, 7, 625212) For the sake of abridgement I have cut out portions dealing with literacy and college education.
('72', 340, 1, 8, 625309) For at the forthcoming Conference on the 22nd and 23rd instant the main discussion will centre round self supporting primary education through an industry.

('72', 341, 9, 25, 627499) 441. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('72', 341, 10, 26, 627527) WARDHAGANJ, October 16, 1937 I am glad to be able to place before the public the statement 1
('72', 341, 11, 27, 627620) made by Mr. K. F. Nariman instead of the considered judgment at which D. N. Bahadurji and I had independently arrived in the Nariman Sardar case.
('72', 341, 11, 28, 627766) It was a painful duty that I had undertaken and then at my instance and request, D. N. Bahadurji.
('72', 341, 11, 29, 627864) But for his most valuable assistance and extraordinary labour he put into the work, I might have with the present state of my health broken down under the
('72', 341, 12, 30, 628019) 1 Vide “K. F. Nariman’s Statement”
('72', 342, 0, 1, 628054) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 343
('72', 342, 1, 2, 628098) burden.
('72', 342, 1, 3, 628106) The evidence that was produced before me was voluminous.
('72', 342, 1, 4, 628163) I have read every line of it but Bahadurji to whom I transferred all the papers not only read every line of the bulky papers but took elaborate notes, read the law about the intricate case of the election of 1934 and prepared the said judgment wholly independently of me.
('72', 342, 1, 5, 628435) It occupies 14 foolscap sheets of close and condensed marshalling of facts and reasoning.
('72', 342, 1, 6, 628525) He was good enough to come down to Segaon with that judgment and pass the whole of Thursday with me.
('72', 342, 1, 7, 628626) I then wrote a concurring note.
('72', 342, 1, 8, 628658) 1 I had hoped that Mr. K. F. Nariman would be with us on that day but he was unable to come.
('72', 342, 1, 9, 628751) I then suggested that on his return to Bombay, Bahadurji should send for Mr. Nariman to show him his judgment and my concurring note and that if on reading them Mr. K. F. Nariman could out of conviction accept both the judgment and my note and himself make a public statement, we should simply be satisfied with giving copies of our judgment to the parties but withhold it from the public and let Mr. Nariman’s statement take its place.
('72', 342, 1, 10, 629188) My suggestion commended itself to Bahadurji.
('72', 342, 1, 11, 629233) On Thursday night, I sent Mr. Mahadev Desai to Bombay with my notes to meet Bahadurji and Mr. Nariman.
('72', 342, 1, 12, 629336) Mr. Nariman with his counsel went to Bahadurji’s office and read our judgment and I am exceedingly happy to be able to place his statement before the public in the full hope that they and the Press will forget the past bitter and unseemly controversy that had robbed the public activity in Bombay of its usual zest and joy.
('72', 342, 1, 13, 629660) I congratulate Mr. Nariman upon his thoughtful and wholehearted confession.
('72', 342, 1, 14, 629736) I owe a debt of deep gratitude to Bahadurji for his having shared labours with me from a high sense of public duty and his unvaried affection for me.
('72', 342, 2, 15, 629886) The Hindustan Times, 17 10 1937
('72', 342, 3, 16, 629918) 442. SELF SUPPORTING EDUCATION
('72', 342, 4, 17, 629949) Government means the Congress Governments in the seven Provinces.
('72', 342, 4, 18, 630015) But just because the Congress has formed Governments, there is no reason to believe that the attitude of the Congress minded people would suddenly change.
('72', 342, 4, 19, 630170) Even though the constructive programme of the Congress has gone on since the great change in 1920 it cannot be said that a lively interest has been created among
('72', 342, 5, 20, 630332) 1 Vide “Note on Nariman Sardar Case”,14 10 1937
('72', 343, 0, 1, 630380) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 343, 1, 2, 630422) Congressmen in this matter.
('72', 343, 1, 3, 630450) What then can we say about those who are outside the Congress?
('72', 343, 1, 4, 630513) Even though the constructive programme has not been as popular as the destructive (if one may without impropriety use the adjective “destructive” for a non violent programme) or negative programme, the Congress has kept it up since 1920. The Congress never dropped that programme and quite a few Congressmen have adopted it.
('72', 343, 1, 5, 630838) Hence, whatever could be achieved in this field has been achieved only by Congressmen, and progress too can be expected only where Congress Governments have been formed.
('72', 343, 1, 6, 631008) But just because the Congress has taken up office, those who have faith in the constructive programme should not slaken their efforts.
('72', 343, 1, 7, 631143) Nor should they become complacent.
('72', 343, 1, 8, 631178) Now that the Congress has formed Governments, their duty is to be more alert, more industrious, more studious.
('72', 343, 1, 9, 631289) Only if this happens can the hopes entertained of the Congress Governments be fulfilled.
('72', 343, 1, 10, 631378) Congress Government means a democratic government responsible to the people.
('72', 343, 1, 11, 631455) If the people want, they can throw out such a government.
('72', 343, 1, 12, 631513) It is based on the will and authority of the people.
('72', 343, 1, 13, 631566) Hence, if Congressmen are keen, they can, and unless they are keen they cannot, get the constructive programme accepted and implemented.
('72', 343, 1, 14, 631703) The Government has no independent power, i.
('72', 343, 1, 15, 631747) e., no physical force.
('72', 343, 1, 16, 631770) The Congress has voluntarily given up that power.
('72', 343, 1, 17, 631820) The British Government wields that power.
('72', 343, 1, 18, 631862) When the Congress Government has to resort to the use of the British power, that is, physical force, it should be regarded as the lowering of the tricolour.
('72', 343, 1, 19, 632019) It should be regarded that, from that day the Congress Government has ceased to be.
('72', 343, 1, 20, 632103) But if the people do not follow the Congress, that is, the Congress Governments, or if non violence has not entered their hearts, the Government which today appears glorious will lose its glory tomorrow.
('72', 343, 1, 21, 632307) And so, Congressmen who have faith in the constructive programme should wake up.
('72', 343, 1, 22, 632388) The scheme of education that I have presented is also a substantial part of the constructive programme.
('72', 343, 1, 23, 632492) It is not my intention to suggest that the Congress has adopted the form I am giving it now.
('72', 343, 1, 24, 632585) But I am firmly convinced that what I am writing now was implicit in everything I have said or written since 1920 about national schools, and now that the occasion has arisen, it has found prompt expression.
('72', 343, 1, 25, 632793) Now, if primary education is to be imparted through a craft, that task can be carried out for the present only by the people who have faith in the spinning wheel and other village industries.
('72', 343, 1, 26, 632985) For, on the
('72', 344, 0, 1, 632997) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 345
('72', 344, 1, 2, 633041) subject of the charkha, which occupies a central position in cottage industries, the Spinners’ Association has collected considerable information and on other industries the Village Industries Association has been collecting it.
('72', 344, 1, 3, 633270) Hence, in my view, whatever immediate provisions we can make can only be through the charkha and allied crafts.
('72', 344, 1, 4, 633382) But all those who have faith in the charkha are not teachers.
('72', 344, 1, 5, 633444) Every carpenter is no authority on carpentry.
('72', 344, 1, 6, 633490) One who has no knowledge of the science of the craft cannot impart general education through the craft.
('72', 344, 1, 7, 633594) And so, only those who are interested in the science of education and have faith in the charkha, etc., can introduce the scheme of primary education which I have suggested.
('72', 344, 1, 8, 633767) I am reproducing the letter 1 from Shri Dilkhush Diwanji with the idea that it would be useful to such persons.
('72', 344, 1, 9, 633879) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 17 10 1937

('72', 344, 3, 11, 633971) I had known Manilal Kothari even before the Harijan campaign gathered momentum.
('72', 344, 3, 12, 634051) And from the day I came to know him I had never once noticed in him the faintest trace of a feeling of untouchability.
('72', 344, 3, 13, 634170) He was always prepared to face the risks that are inevitable while trying to help Harijans.
('72', 344, 3, 14, 634262) He had a flair almost unique for collecting funds for noble causes.
('72', 344, 3, 15, 634330) This is no exaggeration.
('72', 344, 3, 16, 634355) He had many capacities; but he will always be remembered for his ability to collect money for benevolent causes.
('72', 344, 3, 17, 634468) He had collected large funds for Harijan work, and had offered to collect as much money as I wanted if he recovered.
('72', 344, 3, 18, 634585) He used to receive requests from all quarters for collecting money.
('72', 344, 3, 19, 634653) Manilal was a very sensitive man.
('72', 344, 3, 20, 634687) Any altruistic work would interest him.
('72', 344, 3, 21, 634727) His eagerness to serve made him plunge into any kind of danger.
('72', 344, 3, 22, 634791) His death will no doubt be a great loss to his family, and also to Harijans.

('72', 347, 1, 2, 638391) 447. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('72', 347, 2, 3, 638419) WARDHA, October 17, 1937 Andamans prisoners may not be forgotten.
('72', 347, 2, 4, 638485) To remind me that I have made promise to them that I would strain every nerve to secure their release, I have received three letters from three provinces telling me that treatment of prisoners who have been brought from the Andamans is worse than there, that there seems to be no prospect of their early release and that if no release was forthcoming they might have to fall back upon the only weapon open to them, that is, hunger strike.
('72', 347, 2, 5, 638924) I hope that they will not resort to hunger strike so long as they know that the public is not supine about their welfare.
('72', 347, 2, 6, 639046) For myself I may assure them that I am not sleeping over the matter.
('72', 347, 2, 7, 639115) And I urge the public and the Press to keep a vigilant eye on this urgent matter.
('72', 347, 2, 8, 639197) I would appeal to Provincial Governments which have received these prisoners to accord to them the treatment which the country expects them to give.
('72', 347, 2, 9, 639346) Provincial Governments which are in such matters now responsible to the people may not disregard the popular wish.

('72', 354, 1, 2, 648600) 459. LETTER TO DR.
('72', 354, 1, 3, 648619) WILLIAM H. TANDY
('72', 354, 2, 4, 648636) SEGAON, WARDHA, October 20, 1937
('72', 354, 3, 5, 648669) DEAR DOCTOR TANDY, With reference to your hospital scheme, which you were good enough to explain to me today, you tell me that you propose to add family quarters for your patients’ families who would desire to supply the patients with food prepared by them.
('72', 354, 3, 6, 648927) My experience, in what little hospital work I have done, has shown me that it is a harmful concession to prejudice.
('72', 354, 3, 7, 649043) For the food cooked by private parties is rarely cooked according to directions.
('72', 354, 3, 8, 649124) Doting relatives disregard restrictions, pamper patients, and retard recovery where their false affection does not prove fatal to the patients.
('72', 354, 3, 9, 649268) I would, therefore, strongly advise you, for the sake of the patients themselves, not to encourage private cooking for patients under your care, even as you would not allow relatives to administer to them drugs of their own choice.
('72', 354, 3, 10, 649500) If the patients bring families, they can see the former only at stated times and under proper restrictions.
('72', 354, 3, 11, 649608) I know that there are, unfortunately, so called higher castes, who observe untouchability as to food.
('72', 354, 3, 12, 649710) In my opinion you cannot afford to pander to such prejudice, especially at a time when untouchability is fast dying.
('72', 354, 3, 13, 649827) What I hope you will do is to run a strictly vegetarian kitchen for those who would not on any account take flesh, meat or fish.
('72', 354, 4, 14, 649956) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('72', 354, 5, 15, 649986) From a photostat: C.W. 4444. Courtesy: Dr. William H. Tandy
('72', 354, 6, 16, 650046) 1 A Hindi translation of this, signed by Gandhiji, was also enclosed as he thought it would be more useful to the addressee for showing it to the patients and their relatives.

('72', 357, 10, 23, 653699) October 22, 1937
('72', 357, 11, 24, 653716) Gandhiji, after thanking all those who had come in response to the invitations, said whether he was there as Chairman or member, he had invited them in order to listen to their opinion and advice on the propositions 2 he had formulated, especially of those who were opposed to them.
('72', 357, 11, 25, 653999) He asked for a free, frank and full discussion, as he regretted his inability to meet the friends outside of the pandal for reasons of health.
('72', 357, 12, 26, 654142) The propositions, he said, referred both to primary education and college
('72', 357, 13, 27, 654216) 1 This and the following item are reproduced from Mahadev Desai’s article “The Primary Question”.
('72', 357, 13, 28, 654314) The Conference was held on the occasion of the Silver Jubilee of Marwari Shiksha Mandal under the presidentship of Gandhiji.
('72', 357, 13, 29, 654439) The morning session was held from 8.30 a.m.
('72', 357, 13, 30, 654483) to 11.30 a.m.
