('72', 358, 0, 1, 654547) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 359
('72', 358, 1, 2, 654591) education, but they would largely have to address themselves to a consideration of primary education.
('72', 358, 1, 3, 654693) He had included secondary in primary education because primary education was the only education so called that was available to a very small fraction of the people in our villages, many of which he had seen during his peregrinations since 1915. He was speaking exclusively about the needs of these rural boys and girls, the bulk of whom were illiterate.
('72', 358, 1, 4, 655047) He had no experience of college education, though he had come in contact with hundreds of college boys, had heart to heart chats and correspondence with them, knew their needs, failings and the disease they suffered from.
('72', 358, 1, 5, 655269) But they might restrict themselves to a consideration of primary education.
('72', 358, 1, 6, 655345) For, the moment that primary question was solved the secondary one of college education would also be solved.
('72', 358, 2, 7, 655455) He was deliberately of opinion that the present system of primary education was not only wasteful but harmful.
('72', 358, 2, 8, 655566) Most of the boys were lost to the parents and to the occupation to which they were born.
('72', 358, 2, 9, 655655) They picked up evil habits, affected urban ways, and got a smattering of something which may be anything else but not education.
('72', 358, 2, 10, 655784) The remedy, he thought, lay in educating them by means of vocational or manual training.
('72', 358, 2, 11, 655873) He had some experience of it having trained his own sons and the children on the Tolstoy Farm in South Africa 1, belonging to all castes and creeds, who were good, bad and indifferent, through some manual training, e.
('72', 358, 2, 12, 656091) g., carpentry or shoe making which he had learnt from Kallenbach who had training in a Trappist monastery.
('72', 358, 2, 13, 656198) His sons and all these children, he was confident, had lost nothing, though he could not give them an education that either satisfied himself or them, as the time at his disposal was limited and his preoccupations numerous.
('72', 358, 3, 14, 656422) The core of his emphasis was not the occupations but education through manual training—all education, of letters, history, geography, mathematics, science, etc., through manual training.
('72', 358, 3, 15, 656609) It might be objected that in the Middle Ages nothing else was taught.
('72', 358, 3, 16, 656679) But the occupational training then was far from serving an educational purpose.
('72', 358, 3, 17, 656759) In this age those born to certain professions had forgotten them, taken to clerical careers, and were lost to the countryside.
('72', 358, 3, 18, 656886) As a result, go wherever we might, it was impossible to find an efficient carpenter or a smith in an average village.
('72', 358, 3, 19, 657004) The handicrafts were nearly lost, and the spinning wheel being neglected was taken to Lancashire where it was developed, thanks to the English genius for developing crafts, to an extent that was to be seen today This he said irrespective of his views on industrialism.
('72', 358, 4, 20, 657273) The remedy lay in imparting the whole art and science of a craft through practical training and therethrough imparting education.
('72', 358, 4, 21, 657403) Teaching of takli spinning, for instance, presupposed imparting of knowledge of various varieties of cotton,
('72', 358, 5, 22, 657512) 1 Vide “An Autobiography”, sub title “As Schoolmaster
('72', 359, 0, 1, 657566) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 359, 1, 2, 657608) different soils in different provinces of India, the history of the ruin of the handicraft, its political reasons which would include the history of the British rule in India, knowledge of arithmetic, and so on.
('72', 359, 1, 3, 657820) He was trying the experiment on his little grandson 1 who scarcely felt that he was being taught, for he all the while played and laughed and sang.
('72', 359, 2, 4, 657968) He was specially mentioning the takli in order that they might put to him questions about it, and as he had much to do with it, and seen its power and its romance; also because the handicraft of making cloth was the only one which could be universally taught and because the takli required no expense.
('72', 359, 2, 5, 658270) It had more than proved its worth.
('72', 359, 2, 6, 658305) The constructive programme, to the extent it had been carried out, had led to the formation of the Congress Ministries in seven provinces, and their success also would depend on the extent to which we carried it out.
('72', 359, 3, 7, 658522) He had contemplated a seven years’ course which so far as the takli was concerned would culminate in practical knowledge of weaving (including dyeing, designing, etc.).
('72', 359, 3, 8, 658691) The custom for all the cloth we could produce was there ready.
('72', 359, 4, 9, 658754) He was very keen on finding the expenses of the teacher through the product of the manual work of his pupils, as he was convinced that there was no other way to carry education to crores of our children.
('72', 359, 4, 10, 658958) We could not wait until we had the necessary revenue, until the Viceroy reduced the military expenditure, and so on.
('72', 359, 4, 11, 659075) He asked them to remember that this primary education would include the elementary principles of sanitation, hygiene, nutrition, of doing their own work, helping parents at home, etc.
('72', 359, 4, 12, 659259) The present generation of boys knew no cleanliness, no self help, and physically were C 3. He would therefore give compulsory physical training through musical drill, etc.
('72', 359, 5, 13, 659431) The speaker had been accused of being opposed to literary training.
('72', 359, 5, 14, 659499) Far from it.
('72', 359, 5, 15, 659512) He simply wanted to show the way in which it should be given.
('72', 359, 5, 16, 659574) The self supporting aspect had also been attacked.
('72', 359, 5, 17, 659625) Whereas, it was said, we should be expending millions on primary education, we were going to exploit the children.
('72', 359, 5, 18, 659740) It was also feared that there would be enormous waste.
('72', 359, 5, 19, 659795) This fear was falsified by experience.
('72', 359, 5, 20, 659834) As for exploiting or burdening the children, he would ask whether it was burdening the child to save him from a disaster.
('72', 359, 5, 21, 659956) Takli was a good enough toy to play with.
('72', 359, 5, 22, 659998) It was no less a toy because it was a productive toy.
('72', 359, 5, 23, 660052) Even today children helped their parents to a certain extent.
('72', 359, 5, 24, 660114) The Segaon children knew the details of agriculture better than he, having worked with their parents on the fields, Whilst the child would be encouraged to spin and help his parents, with agricultural jobs, he would also be made to feel that he did not belong only to his parents, but to the village and to the country and that he must make some return to them.
('72', 359, 5, 25, 660476) That was the only way.
('72', 359, 5, 26, 660499) He would tell the Ministers that they would make children helpless by doling out education to them.
('72', 359, 5, 27, 660599) They would make them self confident and brave by their paying for their own education by their own labour.
('72', 359, 6, 28, 660706) 1 Presumably, Kanam; vide “Letter to Vidya A. Hingorani”, 6 10 1937

('72', 360, 1, 2, 660818) This system was to be common to all—Hindus, Mussalmans, Parsis, Christians.
('72', 360, 1, 3, 660894) Why did he not lay any stress on religious instruction, he was asked.
('72', 360, 1, 4, 660964) Because he was teaching them practical religion, the religion of self help.
('72', 360, 2, 5, 661040) The State, continued Gandhiji, was bound to find employment, if they needed it, for all the pupils thus trained.
('72', 360, 2, 6, 661153) As for teachers, Prof.
('72', 360, 2, 7, 661176) Shah had suggested the method of conscription.
('72', 360, 2, 8, 661223) 1 He had demonstrated its value by citing instances from Italy and other lands.
('72', 360, 2, 9, 661303) If Mussolini could impress the youth of Italy for the service of his country, why should not we?
('72', 360, 2, 10, 661400) Was it fair to label as slavery the compulsory enlistment of service of our youth for a year or longer before they began their career?
('72', 360, 2, 11, 661535) The youths had contributed a lot to the success of the movement for freedom during the past 17 years, and the speaker would call upon them to freely give a year of their lives to the service of the nation.
('72', 360, 2, 12, 661741) Legislation, if it was necessary in this respect, would not be compulsion, as it could not be passed without the consent of the majority of our representatives.
('72', 360, 3, 13, 661902) Gandhiji would therefore ask them to say whether this imparting of education through manual training appealed to them.
('72', 360, 3, 14, 662021) For him to make it self supporting would be a test of its efficiency.
('72', 360, 3, 15, 662091) The children ought at the end of seven years be able to pay for their instruction and be earning units.
('72', 360, 3, 16, 662195) College education was largely an urban proposition.
('72', 360, 3, 17, 662247) He would not say that it was an unmitigated failure, as primary education was, but the results were fairly disappointing.
('72', 360, 3, 18, 662369) Why should anyone of the graduates have to be unemployed?
('72', 360, 4, 19, 662427) Takli he had proposed as a concrete instance because Vinoba had the largest amount of practical experience in it, and he was there to answer their objections, if any.
('72', 360, 4, 20, 662594) Kakasaheb would also be able to tell them something, though his experience was more theoretical than practical.
('72', 360, 4, 21, 662706) He had especially drawn Gandhiji’s attention to Armstrong’s Education for Life, especially the chapter on “Education of the Hand”.
('72', 360, 4, 22, 662837) The late Madhusudan Das was a lawyer, but he was convinced that without the use of our hands and feet our brain would be atrophied, and even if it worked it would be the home of Satan.
('72', 360, 4, 23, 663022) Tolstoy had taught the same lesson through many of his tales.
('72', 360, 4, 24, 663084) Gandhiji concluded by inviting the attention of the audience to the very fundamentals of his plan of self supporting primary education: We have communal quarrels—not that they are peculiar to us.
('72', 360, 4, 25, 663280) England had also its Wars of the Roses, and today British Imperialism is the enemy of the world.
('72', 360, 4, 26, 663377) If we want to eliminate communal strife and international strife, we must start with foundations pure and strong by rearing our younger generation on the education I have adumbrated.
('72', 360, 4, 27, 663560) That plan springs out of non violence.
('72', 360, 4, 28, 663599) I suggested it in connection with the nation’s resolve to effect complete prohibition, but I may tell you that even if there was to be no loss of revenue, and our exchequer was full, this education would be a sine qua non if we did not want to urbanize our boys.
('72', 360, 4, 29, 663862) We have to make them true

('72', 361, 0, 1, 663943) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 361, 1, 2, 663985) representatives of our culture, our civilization, of the true genius of our nation.
('72', 361, 1, 3, 664069) We cannot do so otherwise than by giving them a course of self supporting primary education.
('72', 361, 1, 4, 664162) Europe is no example for us.
('72', 361, 1, 5, 664191) It plans its programmes in terms of violence because it believes in violence.
('72', 361, 1, 6, 664269) I would be the last to minimize the achievement of Russia, but the whole structure is based on force and violence.
('72', 361, 1, 7, 664384) If India has resolved to eschew violence, this system of education becomes an integral part of the discipline she has to go through.
('72', 361, 1, 8, 664517) We are told that England expends millions on education, America also does so but we forget that all that wealth is obtained through exploitation.
('72', 361, 1, 9, 664663) They have reduced the art of exploitation to a science and might well give their boys the costly education they do.
('72', 361, 1, 10, 664779) We cannot, will not, think in terms of exploitation, and we have no alternative but this plan of education which is based on non violence.
('72', 361, 2, 11, 664918) Harijan, 30 10 1937
('72', 361, 3, 12, 664938) 467. SPEECH AT EDUCATIONAL CONFERENCE II
('72', 361, 4, 13, 664979) October 22, 1937
('72', 361, 5, 14, 664996) In the afternoon Gandhiji opened the session 2 with answering some of the criticisms.
('72', 361, 5, 15, 665082) Takli was not the only thing, but that was the only thing which could be universalized.
('72', 361, 5, 16, 665170) There was paper making, gur making from palms, and so on.
('72', 361, 5, 17, 665228) It would be the function of the Ministers to find out what handicraft would suit what school best.
('72', 361, 5, 18, 665327) He would warn those who were enamoured of the machine that there was every danger of men being turned into machines with the emphasis on the machine.
('72', 361, 5, 19, 665477) For those who wanted to live under the machine age his scheme would be useless, but he would also tell them that it would be impossible to keep villagers alive by means of machines.
('72', 361, 5, 20, 665659) Where there were 300 million living machines, it was idle to think of bringing in new dead machinery.
('72', 361, 5, 21, 665761) Dr. Zakir Husain was not right when he said that the scheme was educationally sound, irrespective of the ideological background.
('72', 361, 5, 22, 665890) 3 A lady who knew the project method was visiting Gandhiji the other day, and she said that there was a vast difference between the project method and Gandhiji’s scheme.
('72', 361, 5, 23, 666060) But he would not ask them to accept the scheme without conviction.

('72', 362, 4, 13, 667478) 468. CIVIL LIBERTY
('72', 362, 5, 14, 667497) Gurudev has given the poetry of Civil Liberty.
('72', 362, 5, 15, 667544) 2 It bears reproduction in a weekly journal like Harijan, although the statement has gone round the world.
('72', 362, 5, 16, 667651) The reader will find it in another column.
('72', 362, 5, 17, 667694) It is a paraphrase of “Work out thine own salvation”, 3 or “Man is his own enemy and his own friend.” Civil liberty is not criminal liberty.
('72', 362, 5, 18, 667835) When law and order are under popular control, the Ministers in charge of the Department cannot hold the portfolio for a day if they act against the popular will.
('72', 362, 5, 19, 667997) It is true that the Assemblies are not sufficiently representative of the whole people.
('72', 362, 5, 20, 668085) Nevertheless the suffrage is wide enough to make it representative of the nation in matters of law and order.
('72', 362, 5, 21, 668195) In seven provinces the Congress rules.
('72', 362, 5, 22, 668234) It seems to be assumed by some persons that, in these provinces at least, individuals can say and do what they like.
('72', 362, 5, 23, 668351) But so far as I know the Congress mind, it will not tolerate any such licence.
('72', 362, 5, 24, 668430) Civil liberty means the fullest liberty to say and do what one likes within the ordinary law of the land.
('72', 362, 5, 25, 668536) The word ‘ordinary’ has

('72', 363, 1, 2, 669095) been purposely used here.
('72', 363, 1, 3, 669121) The Penal Code and the Criminal Procedure Code, not to speak of the Special Powers Legislation, contain provisions which the foreign rulers have enacted for their own safety.
('72', 363, 1, 4, 669296) These provisions can be easily identified, and must be ruled out of operation.
('72', 363, 1, 5, 669375) The real test, however, is the interpretation by the Working Committee of the power of the Ministers of Law and Order.
('72', 363, 1, 6, 669494) Subject, therefore, to the general instructions laid down by the Working Committee for the guidance of Congress Ministers, the Statutory Powers, limited in the manner indicated by me, must be exercised by the Ministers against those who, in the name of civil liberty, preach lawlessness in the popular sense of the term.
('72', 363, 1, 7, 669815) It has been suggested that Congress Ministers who are pledged to non violence cannot resort to legal processes involving punish ments.Such is not my view of the non violence accepted by the Congress.
('72', 363, 1, 8, 670015) I have personally, not found a way out of punishments and punitive restrictions in all conceivable cases.
('72', 363, 1, 9, 670121) No doubt punishments have to be non violent, if such an expression is permissible in this connection.
('72', 363, 1, 10, 670223) Just as violence has its own technique, known by the military science, which has invented means of destruction unheard of before, non violence has its own science and technique.
('72', 363, 1, 11, 670401) Non violence in politics is a new weapon in the process of evolution.
('72', 363, 1, 12, 670471) Its vast possibilities are yet unexplored.
('72', 363, 1, 13, 670514) The exploration can take place only if it is practised on a big scale and in various fields.
('72', 363, 1, 14, 670607) Congress Ministers, if they have faith in non violence, will undertake the explorations.
('72', 363, 1, 15, 670696) But whilst they are doing this, or whether they do so or not, there is no doubt that they cannot ignore incitements to violence and manifestly violent speech, even though they may themselves run the risk of being styled violent.
('72', 363, 1, 16, 670925) When they are not wanted, the public will only have to signify its disapproval through its representatives.
('72', 363, 1, 17, 671033) In the absence of definite instructions from the Congress, it would be proper for the Ministers to report, what they consider is violent behaviour of any member of the public, to their own Provincial Congress Committee, or the Working Committee, and seek instructions.
('72', 363, 1, 18, 671302) If the superior authority does not approve of their recommendations, they may offer to resign.
('72', 363, 1, 19, 671397) They may not allow things to drift so far as to have to summon the aid of the Military.
('72', 363, 1, 20, 671485) In my opinion, it would amount to political bankruptcy when any Minister is obliged to fall back on the Military, which does not belong to the people, and which, in any scheme of non violence, must be ruled out of count for the observance of internal peace.
('72', 364, 0, 1, 671743) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 365
('72', 364, 1, 2, 671787) One interpretation I put upon the India Act is that it is an unconscious challenge to Congressmen to demonstrate the virtue of non violence and the sincerity of their conviction about it.
('72', 364, 1, 3, 671975) If the Congress can give such a demonstration, most of the safeguards fall into desuetude, and the Congress can achieve its goal without a violent struggle, and also without civil disobedience.
('72', 364, 1, 4, 672169) If the Congress has not impregnated the people with the non violent spirit, it has to become a minority, and remain in opposition, unless it will alter its creed.
('72', 364, 2, 5, 672332) Harijan, 23 10 1937
('72', 364, 3, 6, 672352) 469. INDIAN INDUSTRY
('72', 364, 4, 7, 672373) The question is often asked: What is an Indian industry?
('72', 364, 4, 8, 672430) It is asked generally regarding Indian exhibitions.
('72', 364, 4, 9, 672482) Formerly it used to be claimed that any industry that was conducted in India was an Indian industry.
('72', 364, 4, 10, 672583) Thus a mill manned by non domiciled Europeans bringing capital, skilled man power and machinery from abroad was considered to be an Indian industry even though it could be proved to be harmful to the masses.
('72', 364, 4, 11, 672791) From that we have travelled a long distance.
('72', 364, 4, 12, 672836) An industry to be Indian must be demonstrably in the interest of the masses; it must be manned by Indians both skilled and unskilled.
('72', 364, 4, 13, 672970) Its capital and machinery should be Indian and the labour employed should have a living wage and be comfortably housed, while the welfare of the children of the labourers should be guaranteed by the employers.
('72', 364, 4, 14, 673180) This is an ideal definition.
('72', 364, 4, 15, 673209) Only the A. I. S. A. and the A.I.V.I.A. can perhaps barely satisfy that definition.
('72', 364, 4, 16, 673293) For even these Associations have much leeway to make up.
('72', 364, 4, 17, 673350) Nevertheless complete conformation to the definition is their immediate goal.
('72', 364, 4, 18, 673428) But between that definition and the one that was the vogue even with the Congress before 1920 there are many shades of definitions.
('72', 364, 4, 19, 673560) The Congress definition has generally been all goods other than mill cloth manufactured in India.
('72', 364, 4, 20, 673658) The great mill industry may generally be claimed to be an Indian industry.
('72', 364, 4, 21, 673733) But, in spite of its ability to compete with Japan and Lancashire, it is an industry that exploits the masses and deepens their poverty in exact proportion to its success over khadi.
('72', 364, 4, 22, 673916) In the modern craze for wholesale industrialization, my presentation has been questioned, if not brushed aside.
('72', 364, 4, 23, 674028) It has been contended that the growing poverty of the masses, due to the progress of industrialization, is inevitable, and should
('72', 365, 0, 1, 674158) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 365, 1, 2, 674200) therefore be suffered.
('72', 365, 1, 3, 674223) I do not consider the evil to be inevitable, let alone to be suffered.
('72', 365, 1, 4, 674294) The A. I. S. A. has successfully demonstrated the possibility of the villages manufacturing the whole of the cloth requirement of India simply by employing the leisure hours of the nation in spinning and the anterior processes.
('72', 365, 1, 5, 674522) The difficulty lies in weaning the nation from the use of mill cloth.
('72', 365, 1, 6, 674592) This is not the place to discuss how it can be done.
('72', 365, 1, 7, 674645) My purpose in this note was to give my definition of Indian industry in terms of the millions of villagers, and my reasons for that definition.
('72', 365, 1, 8, 674789) And it should be plain to everyone that national exhibitions should only be for those industries which need public support in every way, not those which are flourishing without the aid of exhibitions and the like, and which organize their own exhibitions.
('72', 365, 1, 9, 675045) Harijan, 23 10 1937
('72', 365, 2, 10, 675065) 470. LETTER TO PRANJIVAN
('72', 365, 3, 11, 675090) October 23, 1937
('72', 365, 4, 12, 675107) BHAI PRANJIVAN, If every school which has functioned for many years looked at its own history, it would find someone or the other [from among its students] who has ultimately risen to fame.
('72', 365, 4, 13, 675297) So, as far as I am concerned, I would consider such a thing a mere accident.
('72', 365, 4, 14, 675374) For an old school like yours the real occasion to feel elated would be when it takes measures leading to improvement and makes progress in such a way that it has no parallel in the field.
('72', 365, 4, 15, 675562) What is there to be proud about accidental achievement?
('72', 365, 5, 16, 675618) Vandemataram from MOHANDAS GANDHI [NATIONAL] SCHOOL RAJKOT

('72', 367, 4, 7, 677267) 474. SPEECH AT EDUCATIONAL CONFERENCE1
('72', 367, 5, 8, 677306) October 23, 1937
('72', 367, 6, 9, 677323) Gandhiji in winding up the proceedings said he was grateful to all for having come and co operated with him.
('72', 367, 6, 10, 677432) He would look forward to further co operation as the Conference was but the first of the many they would have to have.
('72', 367, 6, 11, 677551) Malaviyaji had sent to him a warning telegram, but he could put him at ease by saying that there was nothing final about the Conference as it was a Conference of seekers, and everyone was invited to offer suggestions and criticisms.
('72', 367, 6, 12, 677784) He had never the idea of carrying through anything by storm.
('72', 367, 6, 13, 677845) The ideas of national education and prohibition were as old as non co operation.
('72', 367, 6, 14, 677926) But the thing in its present shape came to him under the changed circumstances of the country.
('72', 367, 7, 15, 678021) Harijan, 30 10 1937
('72', 367, 8, 16, 678041) 1 Gandhiji placed before the Conference the resolutions prepared by the Com mittee for discussion.
('72', 367, 8, 17, 678140) The following resolutions were passed: (1) That in the opinion of this Conference free and compulsory education be provided for seven years on a nation wide scale.
('72', 367, 8, 18, 678304) (2) That the medium of instruction be the mother tongue.
('72', 367, 8, 19, 678361) (3) That the Conference endorses the proposal made by Mahatma Gandhi that the process of education throughout this period should centre round some form of manual and productive work, and that all the other abilities to be developed or training to be given should, as far as possible, be integrally related to the central handicraft chosen with due regard to the environment of the child.
('72', 367, 8, 20, 678749) (4) That the Conference expects that this system of education will be gradually able to cover the remuneration of the teachers

('72', 371, 2, 5, 684452) 480. SOCIAL SERVICE CONSCRIPTION
('72', 371, 3, 6, 684485) This valuable thesis 2 does not mean that it contains the only scheme of conscription for social service.
('72', 371, 3, 7, 684591) It shows the feasibility of conscription.
('72', 371, 3, 8, 684633) It points the way to it.
('72', 371, 4, 9, 684658) Usually, conscription has hitherto been used in modern individualist communities for purposes of national defence or imperialist aggression.
('72', 371, 4, 10, 684799) In this country, we would adopt conscription universally, for men as well as women, not for destructive, but for productive purposes of national service and social reconstruction.
('72', 371, 5, 11, 684979) In some countries they allow certain exemptions from such compulsory gratuitous public service, and offer certain compensatory advantages to those who have rendered such service.
('72', 371, 5, 12, 685158) In this country, too, we may have to use a similar device.
('72', 371, 5, 13, 685217) To make this new factor in our national economy function effectively and smoothly, we may have to introduce it by stages.
('72', 371, 5, 14, 685339) But the foundation must be laid immediately.
('72', 371, 6, 15, 685384) This Social Service Conscription should commence with educated males of 18 25 years of age.
('72', 371, 6, 16, 685476) Ancillary organizations of boy or girl volunteers comparable to the British Boy Scouts, or the Italian Ballila, might be set up to support the main force of conscript workers.
('72', 371, 6, 17, 685652) The proportion of educated males in India is about 1 in every 5, and that of educated women 1 in 50. At the age, however, at which conscription should commence the proportion may be appreciably higher, say, 1 in every 3 males, and 1 in every 10 women.
('72', 371, 6, 18, 685904) The term ‘educated’ is used in a very liberal, or even charitable sense, since it includes all those who fulfil the merest test of literacy in their own language.
('72', 371, 6, 19, 686067) It may be expedient to limit the number of conscripts to those of secondary school leaving stage.
('72', 371, 6, 20, 686165) Of the 15 lakhs of such young men available in a province like Bombay, barely 250,000 may be found to satisfy the minimum educational qualification, while less than 100,000 may be found to satisfy the higher qualification suggested above.
('72', 371, 7, 21, 686404) We may well begin the experiment with this latter number.
('72', 371, 8, 22, 686462) 1 Also called neera
('72', 371, 9, 23, 686482) 2 By K. T. Shah, of which only extracts are reproduced here
('72', 372, 0, 1, 686542) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 373
('72', 372, 1, 2, 686586) educated young men of 18 and over must regard the service rendered by them as a sort of personal ten per cent tax, paid in kind, those paying only who have the means to do so, and their superior education being treated as evidence of their ability.
('72', 372, 2, 3, 686835) The 100,000 educated young men, with whom the experiment may be commenced in Bombay, for example, would be more than ample for our immediate objective, in the 21,484 villages of that province.
('72', 372, 2, 4, 687028) Nearly 5 educated conscripts would be available for each village.
('72', 372, 2, 5, 687094) There may be in addition about 25,000 young women who may supplement the effort later on.
('72', 372, 3, 6, 687184) The most urgent and immediate task of social service consists in: (a) liquidation of illiteracy and ignorance; (b) spread of elementary knowledge of health and hygiene; (c) aiding and improving village productive organization and occupation.
('72', 372, 4, 7, 687426) One of the most important sections in the Legislation for Conscription would have to define carefully the tasks to be allotted to the workers.
('72', 372, 4, 8, 687569) No scheme of conscription should be put into effect, until a comprehensive plan of the work to be done has been prepared and approved for each Province.
('72', 372, 4, 9, 687722) The social service conscripts, mobilized in India on the plan here advocated, would have to be given special training even more than the military conscripts of Europe, since the latter, in their ordinary elementary schooling, generally receive some element of practical training, too, before they join the colours.
('72', 372, 4, 10, 688037) In India our educational system provides no such advantage for the average youth.
('72', 372, 5, 11, 688119) This training organization must be developed in each province out of the existing schools and colleges.
('72', 372, 5, 12, 688223) The instructors in these institutions, particularly of the higher grade, are by no means overworked, or underpaid.
('72', 372, 5, 13, 688338) From the highest to the lowest, in every faculty and branch of knowledge, this profession should be indented upon at least to the extent of one hour per day.
('72', 372, 5, 14, 688496) Such training should be given intensively for 6 months in the one year of the service.
('72', 372, 5, 15, 688583) Work should be assigned, or distributed, among the conscripts in accordance with the aptitude and previous training of each individual.
('72', 372, 6, 16, 688719) Those conscripted in this manner both during training and during the period actually at work will not be paid anything by way of salary.
('72', 372, 6, 17, 688856) But they must be maintained at public expense, and must be taken from their place of work to their homes, and vice versa, at public expense.
('72', 372, 6, 18, 688997) This ought not, however, to cost the State such an amount as to be an insupportable burden, nor be out of proportion to the value of the service rendered.
('72', 372, 7, 19, 689152) All those who willingly, and without any exemption, render such service, as and when it falls due, must at the time of seeking employment for
('72', 373, 0, 1, 689294) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 373, 1, 2, 689336) life, be preferred by all public bodies, and even by private employers on pain of losing such patronage or countenance from the State as is now becoming increasingly common between the State and Industry.
('72', 373, 1, 3, 689541) The basic legislation for such conscription must clearly provide for such compensation.
('72', 373, 2, 4, 689629) The advantages of conscription need not be detailed at any great length.
('72', 373, 2, 5, 689702) In the first place, it would solve, in a great measure, the question of the cost of the indispensable and urgent social service we need in this country.
('72', 373, 2, 6, 689855) At the same time, it would help to inculcate those habits of disciplined work and of concerted action—the so called team work—which are indispensable in a community intent upon making up the leeway that India is suffering from.
('72', 373, 2, 7, 690083) Finally, thanks to such regimentation—the phrase may be used without any fear of misinterpretation—an increasing section of the community will automatically acquire those habits of personal cleanliness and healthful living which most people when left to themselves ignore, and consequently suffer in health, temper and efficiency
('72', 373, 3, 8, 690413) Harijan, 30 10 1937
('72', 373, 4, 9, 690433) 481. A STEP FORWARD
('72', 373, 5, 10, 690453) A record of the work of the Educational Conference will be found elsewhere.
('72', 373, 5, 11, 690529) 1 It marks an important stage in the presentation of my plan to the public and the Congress Ministers.
('72', 373, 5, 12, 690632) It was a happy augury that so many Ministers attended.
('72', 373, 5, 13, 690687) The objection and criticism centred round the idea of self support even in the narrow sense I have mentioned.
('72', 373, 5, 14, 690797) Therefore the Conference has made the very cautious declaration it has.
('72', 373, 5, 15, 690869) There is no doubt the Conference had to sail on an unchartered sea.
('72', 373, 5, 16, 690937) There was no complete precedent before it.
('72', 373, 5, 17, 690980) If the idea is sound, it will work itself out in practice.
('72', 373, 5, 18, 691039) After all it is for those who have faith in the self support part to demonstrate it by working schools in accordance with the idea.
('72', 373, 5, 19, 691171) There was a remarkable unanimity so far as the question went of imparting full primary education including the secondary course less English through a vocation.
('72', 373, 5, 20, 691332) The fact that the whole person in the boys and girls has to be developed through a vocation automatically saves the schools from degenerating into factories.
('72', 373, 5, 21, 691490) For over and above the required degree of proficiency in the vocation in which they are trained, the boys and girls will have to show equal proficiency in the
('72', 373, 6, 22, 691649) 1 Vide “Speech at Educational conference II”, 22 10 1937
('72', 374, 0, 1, 691706) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 375
('72', 374, 1, 2, 691750) other subjects they will be expected to learn.
('72', 374, 1, 3, 691797) Dr. Zakir Husain’s Committee’s 1 labours will show how the scheme can be worked in practice and what exactly the boys and girls will be expected to know from year to year.
('72', 374, 1, 4, 691969) Objection has been raised that the Conference’s resolutions 2 were a foregone conclusion.
('72', 374, 1, 5, 692059) It has no validity.
('72', 374, 1, 6, 692079) In the nature of things it was impossible to invite educationists at random to pronounce their views all of a sudden on what to them is undoubtedly a revolutionary plan.
('72', 374, 1, 7, 692249) The invitations had therefore to be restricted to those who as teachers had had at least something to do with vocational training.
('72', 374, 1, 8, 692380) I had myself no idea that the co workers in the cause of national education would receive the new idea with sympathy.
('72', 374, 1, 9, 692498) The wider circle of educationists will undou btedly be invited to consider the scheme when it comes before the public in a concrete and fuller form through the Zakir Husain Committee.
('72', 374, 1, 10, 692682) I would request those educationists who may have helpful suggestions to make to send them at once to Shri Aryanayakam, the Convener and Secretary of the Committee at Wardha.
('72', 374, 1, 11, 692856) One of the speakers at the Conference emphasized the fact that education of little boys and girls could be more effectively handled by women than men and by mothers rather than maidens.
('72', 374, 1, 12, 693042) From another standpoint, too, they are in a better position than men to answer Prof.
('72', 374, 1, 13, 693127) Shah’s conscription scheme.
('72', 374, 1, 14, 693155) Here is undoubtedly an opportunity for patriotic women with leisure to offer their services to a cause which ranks amongst the noblest of all causes.
('72', 374, 1, 15, 693305) But if they come forward, they will have to go through a sound preliminary training.
('72', 374, 1, 16, 693390) Needy women in search of a living will serve no useful purpose by thinking of joining the movement as a career.
('72', 374, 1, 17, 693502) If they approach the scheme, they should do so in a spirit of pure service and make it a life mission.
('72', 374, 1, 18, 693605) They will fail and be severely disappointed if they approach it in a selfish spirit.
('72', 374, 1, 19, 693690) If the cultured women of India will make common cause with the villagers, and that too through their children, they will produce a silent and grand revolution in the village life of India.
('72', 374, 1, 20, 693879) Will they respond?
('72', 374, 1, 21, 693898) Harijan, 30 10 1937

('72', 375, 1, 2, 694429) 482. TALK WITH ANDAMANS PRISONERS 1
('72', 375, 2, 3, 694465) [CALCUTTA, October 30, 1937] 2
('72', 375, 3, 4, 694496) When Gandhiji visited the political prisoners in Alipur Jail 3 they were fresh from the Andamans, and were anxious to go back to hunger strike if they were not released, or rather if Gandhiji declared that he had failed in his mission.
('72', 375, 3, 5, 694732) But they promised to do nothing until Gandhiji definitely told them that he had failed.
('72', 375, 3, 6, 694820) What was to be the position now?
('72', 375, 3, 7, 694853) How long were they to wait?
('72', 375, 3, 8, 694881) Gandhiji said to them: There should be no hunger strike on any account.
('72', 375, 3, 9, 694953) Though there are circumstances conceivable in which a hunger strike may be justified, hunger strike in order to secure release or redress of grievances is wrong.
('72', 375, 3, 10, 695115) And if you resort to it whilst I am carrying on negotiations, you will clip my wings.
('72', 375, 3, 11, 695201) But why think of a hunger strike when you have got me as a good substitute for a hunger strike?
('72', 375, 3, 12, 695297) My days are numbered.
('72', 375, 3, 13, 695319) I am not likely to live long, maybe I may live a year or little more and let me tell you that much of that time is going to be given in order to secure your release.
('72', 375, 3, 14, 695485) I want to see you discharged before I die.
('72', 375, 3, 15, 695528) That is the word I am giving to you, and I want you to give me your word that so long as I live to work for you, you will not go on hunger strike.
('72', 375, 3, 16, 695675) I cannot have peace or comfort so long as I have not secured your discharge.
('72', 375, 3, 17, 695752) You have to believe what I say.
('72', 375, 3, 18, 695784) Man believes and lives.
('72', 375, 3, 19, 695808) My function is not that of a lawyer but of a humanitarian and a votary of non violence.
('72', 375, 3, 20, 695896) Non violence will not spread so long as you prisoners are kept in prison, and that is why I have staked my life for the mission.
('72', 375, 3, 21, 696025) No thought, therefore, of hunger strike please.
('72', 375, 4, 22, 696073) Harijan, 23 4 1938

('72', 375, 6, 24, 696143) 2 From The Bombay Chronicle, 1 11 1937

('72', 376, 1, 2, 696238) 483. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('72', 376, 2, 3, 696264) October 31, 1937
('72', 376, 3, 4, 696281) MY DEAR UNTOUCHABLE, Today I took silence at 12.10 to be ready for the W. C. tomorrow.
('72', 376, 3, 5, 696368) As I write this I have your letter of 29th.
('72', 376, 3, 6, 696412) I have not a moment’s rest to even write a word under Mahadev’s letter.
('72', 376, 3, 7, 696484) I have been generally at the W. C. meetings then[sic].
('72', 376, 3, 8, 696539) I have kept as well as possible under the peculiar circumstances.
('72', 376, 3, 9, 696605) Yes, I have seen the prisoners.

('72', 378, 3, 4, 699580) DEAR JAWAHARLAL, Enclosed herewith is the judgement of the inquiry committee about the two issues raised by Shri Nariman in his correspondence with you and me.
('72', 378, 3, 5, 699740) 1 I had thought that Shri Nariman’s acceptance of my recommendation to make a confession 2 which was to take the place of the judgement was a fair ending to an inquiry which gave me many an anxious moment.
('72', 378, 3, 6, 699946) But Shri Nariman’s recantation of the confession which l first saw only in the Press alters the position and reveals the painful state of Shri Nariman’s mind.
('72', 378, 3, 7, 700105) The recantation contains a patent untruth as pointed out by me in my letter 3 to Shri Nariman which you will find in the enclosure.
('72', 378, 3, 8, 700237) I recall the fact that Shri Nariman himself courted the inquiry and deliberately wanted an investigation into the charge made on him by Sardar Vallabhbhai of a grave breach of trust in the matter of the Bombay election in 1934. In his letter addressed to you occurs the following sentence:
('72', 378, 4, 9, 700527) If the verdict of such an independent tribunal and enquiry tends to blame me in the slightest degree, then I will willingly submit to any penalty which you or any other authority chooses to impose, but at the same time hoping and expecting that, if the blame is found elsewhere, similar indiscriminating judgment should follow regardless of personalities or personal considerations.
('72', 378, 4, 10, 700910) In his letters to me (I have not the copies with me), he went further and said that, if he was found guilty of the Sardar’s charge, he would consider himself to be unworthy of holding any office of trust.
('72', 378, 4, 11, 701115) I am of opinion that by his conduct Shri Nariman has proved himself unworthy of holding any position of trust, not only because he has been found guilty of grave breach of trust in 1934 election and has failed to prove the charge brought by him against Sardar Vallab

('72', 380, 4, 19, 704381) 488. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('72', 380, 5, 20, 704409) November 1, 1937 Before leaving Calcutta I should like to tell the public what actually is the position regarding my efforts to secure the relief which I promised the Andamans prisoners I should make with all my heart.
('72', 380, 5, 21, 704628) In pursuance of these efforts and by the kind permission of the Bengal Government, I saw the repatriates from the Andamans on October 30. 2 I had spent nearly two hours with them.
('72', 380, 5, 22, 704808) I am in correspondence with the Government in the matter and I expect to return to Calcutta on the 11th instant, when I hope to see His Excellency the Governor and, if necessary, subject to the Government’s permission, see both the prisoners and the detenus.
('72', 380, 5, 23, 705067) Meanwhile, I trust that the prisoners, wherever they may be, will not make the position difficult by resuming their hunger strike.
('72', 380, 5, 24, 705198) I have information that many prisoners are getting restive over the delay I can only give them the assurance that, so far as I am concerned, there shall be no remissness on my part in the effort.
('72', 380, 5, 25, 705394) So far as the public are concerned, they should know that the public agitation for securing relief continues unabated.

('72', 385, 4, 12, 711935) 498. A NOTE ON PROHIBITION
('72', 385, 5, 13, 711962) This 1 is a valuable contribution to the discussion on prohibition.
('72', 385, 5, 14, 712030) Whilst there are things which cannot be accepted, there are suggestions which are worthy of consideration.
('72', 385, 5, 15, 712137) The writer adopts the slippery road of gradualness for the sake of revenue.
('72', 385, 5, 16, 712213) That way lies utter failure.
('72', 385, 5, 17, 712242) But the suggestion about State monopoly of manufacture and sale of intoxicants and about unfermented toddy is perfectly sound.
('72', 385, 6, 18, 712369) Harijan, 13 11 1937
('72', 385, 7, 19, 712389) 499. THE A. I. C. C.
('72', 385, 8, 20, 712410) Congress Ministers have a fourfold responsibility.
('72', 385, 8, 21, 712461) As an individual a Minister is primarily responsible to his constituents.
('72', 385, 8, 22, 712535) If he is satisfied that he no longer enjoys their confidence or that he has changed the views for which he was elected, he resigns.
('72', 385, 8, 23, 712667) Collectively the Ministers are responsible to the majority of the legislators who, by a no confidence vote or similar means, may any moment drive them out of office.
('72', 385, 8, 24, 712833) But a Congress Minister owes his position and responsi bility to his Provincial Congress Committee and the A. I. C. C. also.
('72', 385, 9, 25, 712958) 1 An article by a “medical friend” which is not reproduced here
('72', 386, 0, 1, 713022) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 387
('72', 386, 1, 2, 713066) So long as all these four bodies act in co ordination, Ministers have smooth sailing in the discharge of their duty.
('72', 386, 1, 3, 713183) The recent meeting of the A. I. C. C. 1 showed, however, that some of its members were not at all in accord with the Congress Ministries, specially that of C. Rajagopalachari, the Prime Minister of Madras.
('72', 386, 1, 4, 713389) Healthy, well informed, balanced criticism is the ozone of public life.
('72', 386, 1, 5, 713461) A most democratic Minister is likely to go wrong without ceaseless watch from the public.
('72', 386, 1, 6, 713551) But the resolution moved in the.
('72', 386, 1, 7, 713584) A. I. C. C. criticizing the Congress Ministries, and still more the speeches, were wide of the mark.

('72', 392, 2, 8, 725005) 506. LETTER TO NIRMALA GANDHI
('72', 392, 3, 9, 725035) ON THE TRAIN TO WARDHA, November 18, 1937
('72', 392, 4, 10, 725077) NIMU, I cannot write myself, and hence I am dictating this letter.
('72', 392, 4, 11, 725144) I read your letter just now in the train.
('72', 392, 4, 12, 725186) A student’s dharma is difficult to perform.
('72', 392, 4, 13, 725230) Even if it seemed selfish at first sight, if the.
('72', 392, 4, 14, 725280) aim was altruistic it could be shown to be not selfish.
('72', 392, 4, 15, 725336) The student’s case is like that of a brave warrior who may not turn back from the battle field in the face of any obstacle, or a businessman who having gone to a distant land for earning wealth cannot return even though his family might be facing ruin.
('72', 392, 4, 16, 725589) Here, circumstances are favourable for you to suspend your study.
('72', 392, 4, 17, 725655) But credit lies in not being tempted by them.
('72', 392, 4, 18, 725701) This is dharma.
('72', 392, 4, 19, 725717) Whether or not you should follow it will depend on your strength.
('72', 392, 4, 20, 725783) If you have understood this dharma and if you have the strength to follow it, forget the outside world and remain where you are.
('72', 392, 4, 21, 725912) God is the Protector of us all.
('72', 392, 4, 22, 725944) He takes care of everybody.
('72', 392, 4, 23, 725972) I, therefore, see no reason for you to yield to moha 2. Even if Sarita 3 invites you, I would advise you to decline to go.
('72', 392, 4, 24, 726095) But please do not treat my advice as an order.
('72', 392, 4, 25, 726142) I am only explaining to you what I consider to be dharma in such circumstances.
('72', 392, 4, 26, 726222) But I don’t insist that you too should regard that as the only true dharma.
('72', 392, 4, 27, 726298) I don’t know where my ship is drifting.
('72', 392, 4, 28, 726338) It is sailing on.
('72', 392, 4, 29, 726356) The Captain is God.
('72', 392, 4, 30, 726376) Why, then should I worry where it is going?
('72', 392, 4, 31, 726420) And I am not worrying.
('72', 392, 4, 32, 726443) It is bound to disappear some day.
('72', 392, 4, 33, 726478) If so, why keep count of the days?
('72', 392, 4, 34, 726513) BAPU [From Gujarati]

('72', 393, 1, 2, 726724) 507. TEMPLE ENTRY
('72', 393, 2, 3, 726742) The Executive Committee of the Harijan Sevak Sangh has passed the following resolution:
('72', 393, 3, 4, 726830) The Executive Committee of the All India Harijan Sevak Sangh notes with satisfaction the progress of the temple entry campaign in Malabar district and Cochin State and the growing volume of public support in these places for temple entry for Harijans, and gives full support to this work.
('72', 393, 3, 5, 727119) This Committee further requests the Government of Madras and the Government of Cochin to help the rapid emancipation of Harijans by facilitating the declaration of all Hindu temples within their jurisdiction open to the Harijans.
('72', 393, 3, 6, 727349) It is hardly right to bracket the two Governments together.
('72', 393, 3, 7, 727409) The Government of Cochin is a personal Government under a Hindu Prince who owns the temples of Cochin or who is the spiritual head of most of them.
('72', 393, 3, 8, 727557) It is, therefore, within his right and, in my opinion, it is his duty to open the temples within his jurisdiction to the Harijans precisely as they are open to the so called savarna Hindus.
('72', 393, 3, 9, 727747) The appeal addressed to the Cochin Maharaja is, therefore, quite the proper thing.
('72', 393, 3, 10, 727830) But the Madras Government is a government responsible to the people of Madras which include all classes and creeds.
('72', 393, 3, 11, 727946) It cannot, therefore, with any propriety pass legislation like the Cochin Durbar opening to Harijans all the temples within its jurisdiction.
('72', 393, 3, 12, 728088) The temples can only be opened to Harijans either by the trustees of their own motion or at the instance of the savarna visitors who are in the habit of visiting particular temples.
('72', 393, 3, 13, 728270) But the Madras Government can and ought to bring in enabling legislation.
('72', 393, 3, 14, 728344) It has been contended that some judgment of a court of law prevents temples from being opened to Harijans even if all the savarna trustees desire it.
('72', 393, 3, 15, 728494) At the time of the Guruvayur Temple agitation 1 I had discussed this judgment and expressed my doubt as to its validity and meaning.
('72', 393, 3, 16, 728627) But it will be remembered that in order to remove any doubts an attempt was made in the Central Legislative Assembly to bring in an enabling bill.
('72', 393, 3, 17, 728774) The attempt was unsuccessful.
('72', 393, 3, 18, 728804) 2 But I apprehend that under the new Constitution the Provincial Legislatures have the power to bring in and
('72', 393, 4, 19, 728913) 1 In 1932 33
('72', 393, 5, 20, 728926) 2 Vide “Statement on Viceroys Decision”, 24 1 1933
('72', 394, 0, 1, 728977) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 395
('72', 394, 1, 2, 729021) pass enabling legislation.
('72', 394, 1, 3, 729048) The Congress Ministries are pledged to remove untouchability in every shape and form.
('72', 394, 1, 4, 729134) Savarna Hindus were pledged at the time of the Yeravda Pact among many other things to fling open temples to Harijans.
('72', 394, 1, 5, 729253) 1 At the very first opportunity, therefore, Congress Ministries have to bring in legislation, if it is legally within their power, to abolish untouchability in law and to enable trustees or temple goers to open the temples to Harijans and thus put an end to the age long curse of untouchability.
('72', 394, 1, 6, 729549) The Provi ncial Harijan Sevak Sangh can certainly mobilize savarna Hindu opinion in favour of the step.
('72', 394, 1, 7, 729653) I observe that Harijans are already moving in the matter and rightly pressing for the opening of temples.
('72', 394, 1, 8, 729759) I see too that Rao Bahadur M. C. Rajah has a Bill to his credit.
('72', 394, 1, 9, 729824) I hope that he will keep himself in touch with the Ministers and act in accordance with their advice.
('72', 394, 1, 10, 729926) For he and they have a common cause to pursue.
('72', 394, 2, 11, 729973) Harijan, 20 11 1937
('72', 394, 3, 12, 729993) 508. STORM SIGNALS
('72', 394, 4, 13, 730012) The Sholapur affair and the labour unrest in Cawnpore and Ahmedabad show how uncertain is the Congress control over forces of disorder.
('72', 394, 4, 14, 730148) Tribes called criminal cannot be dealt with radically differently from the past practice without ascertaining how they will behave.
('72', 394, 4, 15, 730280) One difference certainly be made at once.
('72', 394, 4, 16, 730322) They may not be treated as criminals to be dreaded and shunned, but efforts should be made to brother them and bring them under the national influence.
('72', 394, 4, 17, 730474) It is said that the red flag men (Communists) have been at work among the men in the Sholapur settlement.
('72', 394, 4, 18, 730580) Are they Congressmen?
('72', 394, 4, 19, 730602) If they are, why are they not found by the side of the Congressmen who are Ministers at the wish of the Congress?
('72', 394, 4, 20, 730716) If they are not Congressmen, do they seek to destroy the Congress influence and prestige?
('72', 394, 4, 21, 730806) If they are not Congressmen and do seek to destroy the Congress prestige, why have Congressmen been unable to reach these tribes and make them proof against the blandishments of those who would exploit their traditional violent tendencies, so called or real?
('72', 394, 5, 22, 731065) 1 Vide “Lest we Forget” ; also “Resolution at the Hindu Leaders” Conference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932
('72', 395, 0, 1, 731161) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 395, 1, 2, 731203) Why are we living in Ahmedabad and Cawnpore in perpetual dread of lightning or unauthorized strikes?
('72', 395, 1, 3, 731304) Is the Congress unable to influence organized labour in the right direction?
('72', 395, 1, 4, 731381) We may not distrust Government notices issued in the provinces administered by Congress Ministers.
('72', 395, 1, 5, 731480) It will not do to belittle their notices as we used to treat the irresponsible Government’s notices.
('72', 395, 1, 6, 731581) If we distrust Congress Ministers or are dissatisfied with them, they can be dismissed without ceremony.
('72', 395, 1, 7, 731686) But while they are permitted to remain in office, their notices and appeals should receive the full hearted support of all Congressmen.
('72', 395, 1, 8, 731822) On no other condition can the holding of offices by Congres smen be justified.
('72', 395, 1, 9, 731901) If in spite of honest effort by Congressmen, forces of disorder cannot be brought under control without the assistance of the police and the military, in my opinion acceptance by the Congress of the burden of office loses all force and meaning, and the sooner the Ministers are withdrawn the better it would be for the Congress and its struggle to achieve complete independence.
('72', 395, 1, 10, 732280) My hope is that the outbreak in the Sholapur settlement and the labour unrest in Ahmedabad and Cawnpore are symptoms of the exaggerated expectations of radical betterment of the condition of labour and even of the so called criminal tribes.
('72', 395, 1, 11, 732521) Then the Congress should have no difficulty in checking disorders.
('72', 395, 1, 12, 732588) If, on the contrary, they are signs of weakness of Congress control, the whole situation arising out of acceptance of office by Congressmen requires reviewing.
('72', 395, 1, 13, 732748) One thing is certain.
('72', 395, 1, 14, 732770) The Congress organization needs streng thening and purging.
('72', 395, 1, 15, 732830) On the Congress register there should be, not merely a few lacs of men and women, but every adult male or female above the age of 18, no matter to what faith they belong.
('72', 395, 1, 16, 733001) And these should be on the register in order to receive a proper training or education in the practice of truth and non violence in terms of the national struggle.
('72', 395, 1, 17, 733165) I have always conceived the Congress to be the greatest school of political education for the whole nation.
('72', 395, 1, 18, 733273) But the Congress is far off from the realization of the ideal.
('72', 395, 1, 19, 733336) One hears of manipulations of Congress registers, and of bogus names being put in for the purpose of showing numbers.
('72', 395, 1, 20, 733454) When the registers have been honestly prepared there is no attempt to keep in close touch with the voters.
('72', 395, 1, 21, 733561) The question naturally arises: Do we really believe in truth and non violence, in sustained work and discipline, in the efficacy of the
('72', 396, 0, 1, 733697) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 397
('72', 396, 1, 2, 733741) fourfold constructive programme?
('72', 396, 1, 3, 733774) If we do, sufficient has been achieved to show, during the working of the Congress Ministries for the past few months, that complete independence is much nearer than when offices were accepted.
('72', 396, 1, 4, 733968) If, however, we are not sure of our own chosen aims, we need not wonder if one fine morning we discover that we had committed a grave blunder in embarking upon office acceptance.
('72', 396, 1, 5, 734147) My conscience as a or the prime mover in the direction of office acceptance is quite clear.
('72', 396, 1, 6, 734239) I advised it on the supposition that the Congressmen as a whole were sound not only on the goal but also on the truthful and non violent means.
('72', 396, 1, 7, 734383) If we lack that political faith in the means, office acceptance may prove to be a trap.
('72', 396, 1, 8, 734471) Harijan, 20 11 1937
('72', 396, 2, 9, 734491) 509. NOTES
('72', 396, 3, 10, 734502) PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENTS AND HARIJANS Thakkar Bapa sends the following for publication:
('72', 396, 4, 11, 734588) (a) The Executive Committee of the Harijan Sevak Sangh urges upon the Congress Provincial Governments to issue declarations of their policies regarding the removal of untouchability of Harijans at an early date.
('72', 396, 4, 12, 734800) (b) This Committee further requests Provincial Governments to create special departments and appoint special officers, where they do not already exist, to look after the uplift work of the Harijans in general and particularly to the removal of disabilities with regard to the use of common schools, public wells, tanks and water taps, and help the Harijans in the enjoyment of their civic rights.
('72', 396, 4, 13, 735197) (c) Further, this Committee requests the Provincial Governments to draw the attention of Municipal and other local bodies towards the deplorable living and service conditions of sweepers and scavengers employed by them and asks them to give the latter better amenities of life by providing them with better housing, water and lighting facilities and a decent and adequate pay and making their service permanent.
('72', 396, 4, 14, 735609) (d) This Committee further draws the attention of the Provincial Governments to clause 9 of the Yeravda Pact of September 1932 which is as follows, and requests them to give effect to the same: “9. In every province out of the educational grant an adequate sum shall be earmarked for providing educational facilities to members of the Depressed Classes.” Why should the Committee only urge in (a) the Congress Provincial Governments to do their duty?
('72', 396, 4, 15, 736060) I think the resolution of the Executive Committee of the Harijan Sevak Sangh applies to all the Governments.
('72', 396, 4, 16, 736169) And where the Governments are supine or indifferent the Opposition should wake them to a sense of their duty.
('72', 396, 4, 17, 736279) Harijan, 20 11 1937

('72', 397, 7, 9, 736575) 511. STATEMENT ON BENGAL GOVERNMENT’S COMMUNIQUE
('72', 397, 8, 10, 736624) WARDHA, November 21, 1937 The Government of Bengal deserve congratulations for the decision they have arrived at on the question of detenus.
('72', 397, 8, 11, 736765) Congressmen will be wrong if they judge the communique 1 by Congress measures.
('72', 397, 8, 12, 736844) The Bengal Ministry are not bound by the Congress election manifesto, nor do they share Congress ideology.
('72', 397, 8, 13, 736951) Nevertheless, they have travelled along Congress lines to a considerable extent.
('72', 397, 8, 14, 737032) It would be wrong not to make this admission.
('72', 397, 8, 15, 737078) Even a political opponent is entitled to credit when this is due.
('72', 397, 8, 16, 737144) In my opinion the Bengal Cabinet have responded to public opinion in a measure, though not to the extent I had expected.
('72', 397, 8, 17, 737265) I would be unfair if I did not mention the fact that H. E. the Governor was helpful in the matter.
('72', 397, 8, 18, 737364) The Ministers could hardly have carried out their wishes but for the Governor’s co operation.
('72', 397, 8, 19, 737458) I regard the communique as an earnest of much more to come.
('72', 397, 8, 20, 737518) I share the opinion, expressed in the communique, that much willdepend upon reaction to the Government’s decision by the public and the 1,100 detenus who have been, or will be, released from all restraint.
('72', 397, 8, 21, 737724) The requirement of supplying change of addresses to the police robs the release order of some of its grace.
('72', 397, 8, 22, 737832) It betokens a timidity I wish the Government of Bengal had not betrayed.
('72', 397, 8, 23, 737905) But much need not be made of what, I hope, is mere formality.
('72', 397, 9, 24, 737967) 1Vide “Bengal Government’s Communique”, 18 11 1937
('72', 398, 0, 1, 738018) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 399
('72', 398, 1, 2, 738062) I am sure that a full measure of relief will be forthcoming, if the atmosphere of non violence is not disturbed, by the step taken by the Government.
('72', 398, 1, 3, 738212) Even Congress insists on observance of non violence; indeed, it is its political creed.
('72', 398, 1, 4, 738300) Congress Ministers know that their existence, as such, depends solely on the observance of non violence.
('72', 398, 1, 5, 738405) I hope that the released detenus will so act as to materially help the creation and consolidation of a non violent atmosphere, on which Mr. Subhas Chandra Bose has justly laid stress in his message on the eve of his departure for Europe for his health.
('72', 398, 1, 6, 738658) I hope that the released detenus will be no party to any public demonstration on their behalf and that the public, too, will exercise necessary restraint.
('72', 398, 1, 7, 738813) I would urge the released men to quietly undertake some public service.
('72', 398, 1, 8, 738885) The great business houses will, I doubt not, help those who may be in need of employment.
('72', 398, 1, 9, 738975) Most of the men I met in the jails of Calcutta told me that their sole object in desiring release was to serve the public cause in the manner indicated by the Congress.
('72', 398, 1, 10, 739144) They, one and all, warned me against entering into any bargain with the Government for securing their discharge.
('72', 398, 1, 11, 739257) They would not give any undertaking to the Government.
('72', 398, 1, 12, 739312) The assurance given by them to me should, they said, be regarded as sufficient test of their bona fides.
('72', 398, 1, 13, 739417) I told them that I would not be guilty of selling their honour or self respect for the purchase of their liberty.
('72', 398, 1, 14, 739531) The public will recall that, at the very outset of my negotiations, I ascertained from the Andamans prisoners whether I could work on the assumption of their renunciation of violent methods for the attainment of independence.
('72', 398, 1, 15, 739757) 1 I could not see my way to asking for relief without the ability to give such an assurance, 2 provided of course, that it represented the correct mentality of the prisoners.
('72', 398, 1, 16, 739932) I was not able to finish my work in Bengal.
('72', 398, 1, 17, 739976) It was not possible for me to do more during my time there.
('72', 398, 1, 18, 740036) I am grateful to the Government of Bengal for the facilities they gave me to see the prisoners and detenus as often as I liked without the presence there of officials.
('72', 398, 1, 19, 740204) My talks are not yet finished.
('72', 398, 1, 20, 740235) My Hijli (jail) friends wanted to have two or three days’ talk with me instead of the two hours only which I was able to give them; but then, they saw from my face that I
('72', 398, 2, 21, 740406) 1 Vide ‘‘Telegram to Viceroy”, 27 8 1937 2 The rest of the sentence is from Harijan, 27 11 1937.
('72', 399, 0, 1, 740503) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 399, 1, 2, 740545) was ill able to bear the strain of animated discussions.
('72', 399, 1, 3, 740602) They were most considerate to me.
('72', 399, 1, 4, 740636) I knew that I took them at a disadvantage for they could not talk to me with the freedom they would have, had I been well.
('72', 399, 1, 5, 740759) I hope, as soon as my health permits me, to go back to Bengal to see each one of the unreleased detenus and prisoners.
('72', 399, 1, 6, 740878) The communique is silent on the question of the Andamans prisoners.
('72', 399, 1, 7, 740946) I know that the Government draw a broad distinction between convicted prisoners and persons detained without trial.
('72', 399, 1, 8, 741062) The distinction is right.
('72', 399, 1, 9, 741088) There are undoubtedly difficulties in the way.
('72', 399, 1, 10, 741135) But at this stage I can only say that I have every hope, if all goes well and the public—especially the Bengal public—continues to help me as it has done hitherto, to secure these men’s discharge also.
('72', 399, 1, 11, 741337) One statement in the communique is disturbing.
('72', 399, 1, 12, 741384) It says that the success of the Government’s policy “must, however, depend on the co operation of the public and the leaders of public opinion in maintaining an atmosphere in which subversive movements will find no encouragement.” If by “subversive movements” they mean only violent activities, no difficulty arises and no difference of opinion exists.
('72', 399, 1, 13, 741737) But, if in the phrase they include non violent activities such as the Congress stands for, including even civil disobedience, the releases already made are a mistake and further releases will become an impossibility.
('72', 399, 1, 14, 741954) Throughout my conversations with the Ministers I made it quite plain that I could only help in maintaining non violence.
('72', 399, 1, 15, 742075) Non violence is the only proper and honourable common ground between the Government and the people.
('72', 399, 1, 16, 742175) Democracy must remain a dream in India without that bed rock.
('72', 399, 1, 17, 742237) I hope and believe that by “subversive movements” the Government mean no more than activities which are either themselves violent or which are intended to further violence.
('72', 399, 1, 18, 742410) The Statesman, 22 11 1937

('72', 402, 9, 16, 746288) 517. A FOREWORD 2
('72', 402, 10, 17, 746306) SEGAON, WARDHA, November 27, 1937 One can at once perceive in Acharya Kripalani’s way of thinking and writing a quality of uniqueness.
('72', 402, 10, 18, 746441) Anyone who has known him will recognize at once any piece of writing as his and his alone.
('72', 402, 10, 19, 746532) This is the impression I had while reading this collection.
('72', 402, 10, 20, 746592) At a time when all kinds of new ideas are spreading in the country, this collection is likely to be of considerable help to those who want to study them.
('72', 402, 10, 21, 746746) Acharya Kripalani has shown very convincingly that the programme the Congress adopted in 1920 is as useful now for attaining freedom as it was in 1920.
('72', 402, 11, 22, 746898) 1 This is a postscript to Mirabehn’s letter to the addressee.
('72', 402, 11, 23, 746960) 2 To Acharya Kripalanina Lekho
('72', 403, 0, 1, 746991) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 403, 1, 2, 747033) Acharya Kripalani is quite correct in saying that there is no such thing as Gandhism.
('72', 403, 1, 3, 747119) Insistence on truth is an eternal principle.
('72', 403, 1, 4, 747164) While contemplating on it the jewel of non violence was discovered and as a result of the experiments in non violence emerged the programme of 1920. Trying to attain independence without it is as good as pounding chaff.
('72', 403, 1, 5, 747384) M. K. GANDHI [From Gujarati] Acharya Kripalanina Lekho

('72', 415, 4, 5, 764493) 545. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('72', 415, 5, 6, 764522) December 21, 1937 I have your letter.
('72', 415, 5, 7, 764560) Don’t believe newspaper reports unless you get a cable from me.
('72', 415, 5, 8, 764624) If there is anything serious a cable will of course be sent.
('72', 415, 5, 9, 764685) What you think about me is not correct.
('72', 415, 5, 10, 764725) I believe that I am more vigilant than any other leader.
('72', 415, 5, 11, 764782) This is, as I understand, the straight and simple cause of my blood pressure.
('72', 415, 5, 12, 764860) My non attachment is less than what is meant by the Gita; I am full of feeling.
('72', 415, 5, 13, 764940) I am always pained by anybody’s suffering.
('72', 415, 5, 14, 764983) This is as it ought to be.
('72', 415, 5, 15, 765010) And still I must remain non attached.
('72', 415, 5, 16, 765048) I have not yet mastered that art.
('72', 415, 5, 17, 765082) It will not be non attachment if I am not affected by others’ sufferings.
('72', 415, 5, 18, 765156) The Gita asks us to endure cold and heat, joy and sorrow.
('72', 415, 5, 19, 765214) It doesn’t say [in so many words] that a non attached person never feels them.
('72', 415, 5, 20, 765293) If, therefore, you said to me, ‘Bapu, you are not obeying the teaching of Mother Gita’, your charge would be tenable.
('72', 415, 5, 21, 765411) But, as for physical rest, such as the pampering of the body, etc., I have been taking more than enough.
('72', 415, 5, 22, 765516) Know that my coming to Juhu is nothing but pampering.
('72', 415, 5, 23, 765570) There are so many things to be done but I have forsaken them.
('72', 415, 5, 24, 765632) My reasoning is clear, but I am not exercising it.
('72', 415, 5, 25, 765683) You should, therefore, stop worrying about me.

('72', 421, 6, 19, 773803) 557. DISCUSSION WITH AN ITALIAN PROFESSOR 2
('72', 421, 8, 20, 773847) PROFESSOR: If we had in the world a people who practised ahimsa, could they keep themselves free from being slaves of others?
('72', 421, 9, 21, 773973) GANDHIJI: If one person can, surely a nation can.
('72', 421, 9, 22, 774023) No man or group of men can hold any other man or group of other men slaves against their will.
('72', 421, 9, 23, 774118) The slave driver will say ‘Do this’ and they will refuse.
('72', 421, 9, 24, 774176) It is possible to imagine that some day all nations will become sufficiently intelligent to act, even in the mass, as individuals do today.
('72', 421, 10, 25, 774316) Gandhiji then drew a vivid picture of the violent road for India, how she might murder and fight, and suffer reprisals, till out of 30 crores only one crore would be left.
('72', 421, 11, 26, 774488) 1 As placed in the source 2 This report by Mirabehn appeared under the title “The way of God or the Way of the Devil” with the following introductory note: “Readers of Harijan will like to share with me the following dialogue between Gandhiji and an Italian Professor which took place in Segaon in 1937. I found it in my notebook as I was turning over old papers.
('72', 421, 11, 27, 774852) It gives a fuller meaning to his Press message on the world situation.” Vide, “Statement to the Press”, On or before 27 8 1939.
('72', 422, 0, 1, 774980) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 423
('72', 422, 1, 2, 775024) But I decided that that was not the road for me.
('72', 422, 1, 3, 775073) I rehearsed all these things in my mind, but I said to myself, ‘This is the way of the Devil, not the way of God.’ The thought of those twenty nine crores of lives sacrificed would ever haunt me.
('72', 422, 1, 4, 775269) The fact of the one crore of giants, trained in violence, who would have the whole of India to spread themselves in, would give me no satisfaction.
('72', 422, 1, 5, 775417) I said to myself, ‘I must take the way of non violence, and take with me even the lepers and the lunatics.’ For, after all, are we not all more or less lepers and more or less mad?
('72', 422, 1, 6, 775598) If we were all sane, we should be like gods.
('72', 422, 1, 7, 775643) It is because we have a screw loose that we cannot succeed in being one with God.
('72', 422, 1, 8, 775725) Harijan, 9 9 1939
('72', 422, 2, 9, 775743) 558. TALK WITH DOCTORS 1
('72', 422, 3, 10, 775768) [On or before January 7, 1938] 2
('72', 422, 4, 11, 775801) The doctors wanted Gandhiji to continue the stay until the end of January, but a month out of Segaon was the most Gandhiji could give himself.
('72', 422, 4, 12, 775944) Not that he has regained a condition of health enabling him to resume his normal activities.
('72', 422, 4, 13, 776037) But as he put it to the doctors in his own unanswerable way: If I cannot get well out of Segaon, I should prefer to face death in Segaon in the process of giving there to the country the work I think I am specially gifted to give.

('72', 423, 5, 11, 777629) 560. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 2
('72', 423, 6, 12, 777659) BOMBAY, January 7, 1938
('72', 423, 7, 13, 777683) When asked whether he could stand the Segaon cold in his present delicate state of health, Gandhiji said in his clear silver voice that he was hopeful that Segaon would suit him.
('72', 423, 7, 14, 777862) Gandhiji admitted that his 32 days’ stay in Juhu had contributed much to his improvement.
('72', 423, 7, 15, 777952) Let me get back to Segaon and try that village.
('72', 423, 7, 16, 778000) If I go down again, I will return to Juhu.
('72', 423, 8, 17, 778043) Asked why he could not continue the stay in Juhu for a few more weeks, instead of running a risk in Segaon, the Mahatma nodded his head, raised his hands and said: Let me see what God has in store for me.
('72', 423, 9, 18, 778248) Mahatma Gandhi had a word of appreciation for the Press who had co operated with him in carrying out the doctors’ instruction regarding complete rest.
('72', 423, 10, 19, 778399) Asked to give a message about the Bengal detenus, Mahatma Gandhi said: No messages, please.

('72', 424, 7, 28, 779900) January 9, 1938
('72', 424, 8, 29, 779916) “But you now know that you cannot put up with more than a certain amount of strain.
('72', 424, 8, 30, 780000) Why should you invite that strain and let all the people feel that Segaon does not suit you?” said Jamnalalji, on Sunday, the day after our return to Segaon.

('72', 425, 0, 1, 780480) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 425, 1, 2, 780522) But you have often assured us that you are making a conscious effort to live.
('72', 425, 1, 3, 780600) I have.
('72', 425, 1, 4, 780608) But if someone were to tell me, in order to avoid death, to retire to the Himalayas until the end of this year, I should not do so.
('72', 425, 1, 5, 780740) For I know that death is inevitable, no matter what precautions man deludes himself with.
('72', 425, 1, 6, 780830) I would like you to appreciate that I am one of the very few among the public men in India who know how to preserve their health.

('72', 427, 1, 2, 784390) 566. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('72', 427, 2, 3, 784419) January 10, 1938 Don’t worry for me.
('72', 427, 2, 4, 784456) There is One who worries for you, me, and everybody.
('72', 427, 2, 5, 784509) Why, then, should we worry at all?
('72', 427, 2, 6, 784544) And now I am improving, even though slowly.
('72', 427, 2, 7, 784588) Do not trust the newspapers—except If you can live there peacefully, your health will improve even there.
('72', 427, 2, 8, 784694) In any case, however, you will be able to earn a plain loaf of bread anywhere.
('72', 427, 2, 9, 784773) If you become calm you will improve your health even there.
('72', 427, 2, 10, 784833) Here you would feel embarrassed to eat as much as you wish while there everybody does and can do so.
('72', 427, 2, 11, 784934) Such is the power of psychological atmosphere.
('72', 427, 2, 12, 784981) How can one eat one’s fill without a sense of guilt in this poverty stricken country?
('72', 427, 2, 13, 785067) There you are far away.
('72', 427, 2, 14, 785091) In a distant land one should forget things back home and adjust oneself to the surrounding atmosphere.
('72', 427, 2, 15, 785194) I have not come across any human being who remains unaffected by his surroundings.
('72', 427, 2, 16, 785277) I for one think there can be no such person.
('72', 427, 2, 17, 785322) If there is any such person in a million, he must be a vatapi, that is, one who lives only on air.
('72', 427, 2, 18, 785421) How can such a one permit himself to eat anything else?
('72', 427, 2, 19, 785477) Does God eat?
('72', 427, 2, 20, 785491) With what mouth and with what body can He eat?
('72', 427, 2, 21, 785538) I will write no more, otherwise the doctors will complain.
('72', 427, 2, 22, 785597) Do not be anxious about Nimu and Kanam.
('72', 427, 2, 23, 785637) Please have faith that everything possible is being done for everyone.
('72', 427, 2, 24, 785708) If more is possible, I would certainly do it.
('72', 427, 2, 25, 785754) But if we attempt anything beyond our capacity, we might violate our dharma and break under the strain.
('72', 427, 2, 26, 785858) [From Gujarati]
('72', 427, 3, 27, 785874) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('72', 432, 5, 14, 796378) 570. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('72', 432, 6, 15, 796406) January 14, 1938 I have read the telegraphic summary of the prisoners’ message 2
('72', 432, 7, 16, 796487) I have no difficulty in appreciating their reasoning, but my plea for patience is based on a personal but peremptory cause.
('72', 432, 7, 17, 796611) If, going out of my way, I begin to move actively and undertake even long journeys, the common end may be defeated by my collapse which medical friends regard as a certainty.
('72', 432, 7, 18, 796786) Therefore, I appeal to the hunger strikers to suspend their strike and to give the country and especially me a chance to make an effort in the common direction.
('72', 432, 7, 19, 796947) Let it not be said of them that they were foolhardy or obstinate.
