('72', 433, 0, 1, 797198) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 433, 1, 2, 797240) 571. DISCUSSION WITH EDUCATIONISTS 1
('72', 433, 2, 3, 797277) [Before January 15, 1938]
('72', 433, 3, 4, 797303) ZILLIACUS:] I had been wishing all these years that leaders of opinion ought to turn their attention to education which alone can reconstruct society, and I cannot tell you how grateful I was when I found that you had turned your attention to education.
('72', 433, 3, 5, 797557) We have studied your scheme and we must assure you of our heartfelt sympathy for its success.
('72', 433, 3, 6, 797651) [GANDHIJI:] I am grateful that so many educationists have blessed the scheme.
('72', 433, 3, 7, 797729) There have been critics also, but when I launched the scheme I did not know that it would appeal to anyone beyond the circle of my co workers.
('72', 433, 3, 8, 797872) When I consider the masses of India and the masses situated as they are, I could not think of any other type of education.
('72', 433, 3, 9, 797995) With them work must precede anything else, and the concern of the educationist is to make that work educative.
('72', 433, 3, 10, 798106) Let every child feel that he creates something for use and also expands his mind and heart therethrough.
('72', 433, 4, 11, 798211) I agree.
('72', 433, 4, 12, 798220) The great psychologist Dr. Adler, who could not express himself well in English, said: “All that education should do is to put the child on the useful side.”
('72', 433, 5, 13, 798378) Harijan, 15 1 1938
('72', 433, 6, 14, 798397) 572. TALK WITH A FRIEND
('72', 433, 7, 15, 798421) [Before January 15, 1938]
('72', 433, 8, 16, 798447) [GANDHIJI:] My idea is not merely to teach a particular profession or occupation to the children, but to develop the full man through teaching that occupation.
('72', 433, 8, 17, 798607) He will not only learn weaving, for instance, but learn why he should weave in a particular fashion and not any other, why he should handle yarn in a particular fashion and no other, why he should himself know spinning and insist on a particular count for a particular kind of weaving.
('72', 433, 8, 18, 798893) All these things the weaver boy does not learn at home.
('72', 433, 8, 19, 798949) The spinning wheel is to him just what it was a thousand years ago.
('72', 433, 8, 20, 799017) We make him learn the art of making a most efficient wheel and a loom, not so as to displace other labour but so as to make them more efficient than the existing
('72', 433, 9, 21, 799179) 1 Dr. Zilliacus, Prof.
('72', 433, 9, 22, 799202) Bovet and Prof.
('72', 433, 9, 23, 799218) Davies, members of the New Education Fellowship Delegation, had called on Gandhiji.
('72', 434, 0, 1, 799302) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 435
('72', 434, 1, 2, 799346) models.
('72', 434, 1, 3, 799354) Your suggestion for different schools for different classes— weavers, spinners, carpenters and so on—would not answer my purpose.
('72', 434, 1, 4, 799484) For I want to bring about an equalization of status.
('72', 434, 1, 5, 799537) The working classes have all these centuries been isolated and relegated to a lower status.
('72', 434, 1, 6, 799629) They have been Shudras, and the word has been interpreted to mean an inferior status.
('72', 434, 1, 7, 799715) I want to allow no differentiation between the sons of a weaver, of an agriculturist and of a schoolmaster.
('72', 434, 2, 8, 799823) [THE FRIEND:] But should we not have different time tables for different boys—I mean seasonal time tables?
('72', 434, 2, 9, 799930) No, we need not have even different hours.
('72', 434, 2, 10, 799973) The village is a composite whole.
('72', 434, 2, 11, 800007) The vast majority of the rural population is agricultural.
('72', 434, 2, 12, 800066) I need not conduct a separate type of school for the ten per cent of the non agricultural population in India.
('72', 434, 2, 13, 800177) I do not want to make every one of the boys and girls in the villages of India spinners or weavers, but I want to make of them whole men through whatever occupation they will learn.
('72', 434, 2, 14, 800359) The village school will be turned into an educative workshop in as economical and efficient a manner as possible.
('72', 434, 2, 15, 800473) Therefore the school will not be a glorified workshop producing more or less the conditions of the present day workshops.
('72', 434, 2, 16, 800595) The workshop will not teach the children to produce anything and everything of conceivable use.
('72', 434, 2, 17, 800691) Tobacco, for instance, is a commodity very largely in use throughout the world, it is cultivated in India as a money crop.
('72', 434, 2, 18, 800814) But its harm to man’s physical and moral fibre is patent.
('72', 434, 2, 19, 800872) I should not teach in our school workshop bidi making.
('72', 434, 2, 20, 800927) It is in this respect that our schools will, 1 hope, differ radically from schools abroad which claim to give a sort of practical education.
('72', 434, 2, 21, 801068) I read the other day about a school in England which trains boys to be efficient shop keepers.
('72', 434, 2, 22, 801163) England accepts no prohibition and does not look forward to its introduction in the near or distant future.
('72', 434, 2, 23, 801271) English boys, therefore, have to be trained as workers in liquor shops too.
('72', 434, 2, 24, 801347) The English school in question has, therefore, applied for a liquor licence in order to be able to teach its pupils how to handle liquor for its consumers.
('72', 434, 2, 25, 801503) In the event of a war England may turn its schools into ammunition factories.
('72', 434, 2, 26, 801581) In a nation with ahimsa for its national policy such a thing should be inconceivable.
('72', 434, 2, 27, 801667) Our schools will be turned into workshops, but workshops where they will learn things that are necessary for healthy living in accordance with the national ideal.
('72', 434, 2, 28, 801830) Harijan, 15 1 1938
('72', 435, 0, 1, 801849) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('72', 436, 1, 2, 802937) 575. DISCUSSION WITH LORD LOTHIAN 1
('72', 436, 2, 3, 802973) [January 20, 1938] 2
('72', 436, 3, 4, 802994) During his talk on the last day Lord Lothian mentioned Christian Science and asked for Gandhiji’s opinion thereon:
('72', 436, 4, 5, 803109) Since man is inseparably related to God in proportion as he recognizes the indissoluble relationship to God he is free from sin and from disease.
('72', 436, 4, 6, 803255) That is how faith heals.
('72', 436, 4, 7, 803280) God is Truth and Health and Love.
('72', 436, 5, 8, 803314) GANDHIJI: And He is Physician too.
('72', 436, 5, 9, 803349) I have no quarrel with Christian Science.
('72', 436, 5, 10, 803391) I said many years ago in Johannesburg that I accept the doctrine in toto, but I do not believe in many Christian Scientists.
('72', 436, 5, 11, 803516) It is one thing to have an intellectual belief and another thing to have a heart grasp of the truth.
('72', 436, 5, 12, 803617) I can quite endorse the statement that all illness is sin, that when a man has even a cough it is due to sin.
('72', 436, 5, 13, 803727) My blood pressure is the result of strain and overwork.
('72', 436, 5, 14, 803783) But why should I have overworked myself?
('72', 436, 5, 15, 803824) All overwork and hurry is sin.
('72', 436, 5, 16, 803855) And 1 know only too well that it was perfectly possible for me to avoid all doctors.
('72', 436, 5, 17, 803940) What I do not understand about Christian Scientists is that they make altogether too much of physical health and disease.
('72', 436, 6, 18, 804062) So long as one recognizes that disease is sin it is all right.
('72', 436, 6, 19, 804125) Even the Gita says that one has to renounce the fruit of the five senses which is maya.
('72', 436, 6, 20, 804213) God is Life and Love and Health.
('72', 436, 6, 21, 804246) I have put it somewhat differently.
('72', 436, 6, 22, 804282) God is Truth, for as our scriptures say nothing is but Truth, which is the same thing as God is Life.
('72', 436, 6, 23, 804384) And then I have said that Truth and Love are faces of the same coin, and Love is the means to find Truth which is the end.
('72', 436, 7, 24, 804507) Harijan, 29 1 1938
('72', 436, 8, 25, 804526) 1 This is reproduced from Mahadev Desai’s “Notes”.
('72', 436, 8, 26, 804577) 2 Lord Lothian stayed in Segaon from January 18 to 20.
('72', 437, 0, 1, 804632) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 437, 1, 2, 804674) 576. A MESSAGE 1
('72', 437, 2, 3, 804691) SEGAON, January 20, 1938 My ambition is to see the Congress recognized as the one and only party that can successfully resist the Government and deliver the goods.
('72', 437, 2, 4, 804855) It is the only party which, from its inception, has represented all minorities.
('72', 437, 2, 5, 804935) If the British Government recognize this unique position of the Congress they will not hesitate to postpone inauguration of the Federation 2 till they have satisfied the Congress.
('72', 437, 2, 6, 805115) It should not be difficult to do so if, before taking in the Princes, elementary rights of the States people are guaranteed and their representation takes place through election.
('72', 437, 2, 7, 805294) In my opinion a crisis of the first magnitude may be precipitated if Federation is sought to be imposed.
('72', 437, 2, 8, 805399) The opposition to the Act will still remain even if the present difficulty is got over in the manner suggested.
('72', 437, 2, 9, 805511) Peace, humanly speaking, can only be assured when a constitution drawn up by a Constituent Assembly supplants the present Act.
('72', 437, 2, 10, 805638) Anyway, once the right status of the Congress is fully recognized the rest becomes easy.
('72', 437, 2, 11, 805727) This is my personal view which I have not discussed with any of my co workers.
('72', 437, 3, 12, 805806) M. K. GANDHI
('72', 437, 4, 13, 805819) From a copy: C.W. 7791. Courtesy: G. D. Birla
('72', 437, 5, 14, 805865) 1 This was written “For Lord Lothian and responsible statesmen only”.
('72', 437, 5, 15, 805935) 2 As proposed in the Government of India Act, 1935

('72', 438, 7, 10, 806439) 578. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('72', 438, 8, 11, 806470) SEGAON, WARDHA, January 21, 1938
('72', 438, 9, 12, 806503) DEAR FRIEND, Chander Singh Bhandari, an ex Havildar Major of the Garhwal Regiment, is a prisoner in the Naini Central Prison, undergoing 14 years’ imprisonment for disobedience of orders to fire at a crowd in Peshawar during the Civil Disobedience campaign of 1930. He has served more than half the sentence.
('72', 438, 9, 13, 806812) He wrote recently a long letter in Hindi to Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru to be passed on to me urging me to try to secure his release which he expected together with the other prisoners discharged by the United Provinces Government.
('72', 438, 9, 14, 807040) Before troubling you I wanted some information about the prisoner.
('72', 438, 9, 15, 807107) This appears in the letter and the enclosure received from Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
('72', 438, 9, 16, 807191) 1 On receipt of this I wired for reasons for this prisoner not
('72', 438, 10, 17, 807254) 1 Jawaharlal Nehru, in his letter to Gandhiji dated January 13, 1938, had rec ommended the case of Chander Singh, especially in view of the fact that, when in 1930 his companions of the Garhwal Regiment were contemplating not only refrain ing form shooting at their fellow countrymen but also shooting at their British officers, Chander Singh had dissuaded them from this violent action, stressing the non violent character of the civil disobedience movement.
('72', 439, 0, 1, 807714) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 439, 1, 2, 807756) being discharged by the United Provinces Government.
('72', 439, 1, 3, 807809) Enclosed is the wire received from the United Provinces Premier.
('72', 439, 1, 4, 807874) I venture to ask you, if it is at all possible, to secure the discharge of this prisoner.
('72', 439, 1, 5, 807964) His expectation seems to me to be justified.
('72', 439, 1, 6, 808009) He can see no distinction between the other discharged United Provinces prisoners and himself.
('72', 439, 1, 7, 808104) He was guilty of no violence.
('72', 439, 1, 8, 808134) It is true that insubordination is held by the military to be a very grave offence.
('72', 439, 1, 9, 808218) But I feel that there were extenuating circumstances in this case.
('72', 439, 1, 10, 808285) And in any event if the United Provinces Government enjoy real autonomous powers, their wishes in respect of such cases should be respected.
('72', 439, 3, 11, 808426) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('72', 444, 6, 17, 814753) 590. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('72', 444, 7, 18, 814781) SEGAON, WARDHA, February 3, 1938
('72', 444, 8, 19, 814814) DEAR MR. JINNAH,
('72', 444, 9, 20, 814831) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru told me yesterday that you were complaining to the Maulana Sahib about the absence of any reply from me to your letter 2 of 5th November in reply to one of 19th October.
('72', 444, 9, 21, 815025) The letter was received by me when I was pronounced by the doctors to be seriously ill in Calcutta.
('72', 444, 9, 22, 815125) The letter was shown to me three days after its receipt.
('72', 444, 9, 23, 815182) Had I thought it necessarily called for a reply, even though I was ill I would have sent one.
('72', 444, 9, 24, 815276) I have re read the letter.
('72', 444, 9, 25, 815303) I still think that there was nothing useful that I could have said in reply.
('72', 444, 9, 26, 815380) But, in a way, I am glad that you awaited a reply.
('72', 444, 9, 27, 815431) Here it is.
('72', 444, 9, 28, 815443) Mr. Kher told me definitely that he had a private message from you.
('72', 444, 9, 29, 815511) He delivered it to me when I was alone.
('72', 444, 9, 30, 815551) I couldhave sent you a verbal message in reply, but in order to give you a true picture of my mental state I sent you the short note.
('72', 444, 9, 31, 815685) There was nothing to hide in it.
('72', 444, 10, 32, 815718) 1 Ishopanishad, 1 2 Vide “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 5 11 1937
('72', 445, 0, 1, 815781) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 445, 1, 2, 815823) But I did feel, as I still do, that the way in which you used it came upon me as a painful surprise.
('72', 445, 1, 3, 815924) You complain of my silence.
('72', 445, 1, 4, 815952) The reason for my silence is literally and truly in my note.
('72', 445, 1, 5, 816013) Believe me, the moment I can do something that can bring the two communities together nothing in the world can prevent me from so doing.
('72', 445, 1, 6, 816150) You seem to deny that your speech was a declaration of war, but your latter pronouncements too confirm the first impression.
('72', 445, 1, 7, 816275) How can I prove what is a matter of feeling?
('72', 445, 1, 8, 816320) In your speeches I miss the old nationalist.
('72', 445, 1, 9, 816365) When in 1915 I returned from the self imposed exile in South Africa, everybody spoke of you as one of the staunchest of nationalists and the hope of both Hindus and Mussalmans.
('72', 445, 1, 10, 816542) Are you still the same Mr. Jinnah?
('72', 445, 1, 11, 816577) If you say you are, in spite of your speeches I shall accept your word.
('72', 445, 1, 12, 816649) Lastly, you want me to come forward with some proposal.
('72', 445, 1, 13, 816705) What proposal can I make except to ask you on bended knees to be what I had thought you were.
('72', 445, 1, 14, 816799) But the proposal to form a basis of unity between the two communities has surely got to come from you.
('72', 445, 1, 15, 816902) This is again not for publication but for your eyes.
('72', 445, 1, 16, 816955) It is the cry of a friend, not of an opponent.
('72', 445, 2, 17, 817002) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 16 6 1938

('72', 449, 1, 2, 821652) 598. DISCUSSION WITH JOHN DE BOER 1
('72', 449, 2, 3, 821688) [On or before February 8, 1938] 2
('72', 449, 3, 4, 821722) Dr. John De Boer said the scheme had appealed to him most strongly, because at the back of it was non violence.
('72', 449, 3, 5, 821834) His difficulty was why non violence figured so little on the syllabus.
('72', 449, 3, 6, 821905) [GANDHIJI:] The reason why it has appealed to you is quite all right.
('72', 449, 3, 7, 821975) But the whole syllabus cannot centre round non violence.
('72', 449, 3, 8, 822032) It is enough to remember that it emerges from a non violent brain.
('72', 449, 3, 9, 822099) But it does not presuppose the acceptance of non violence by those who accept it.
('72', 449, 3, 10, 822181) Thus, for instance, all the members of the Committee do not accept non violence as a creed.
('72', 449, 3, 11, 822273) Just as a vegetarian need not necessarily be a believer in non violence—he may be a vegetarian for reasons of health— even so those who accept the scheme need not be all believers in non violence.
('72', 449, 4, 12, 822470) I know some educationists who will have nothing to with the system because it is based on a non violent philosophy of life.
('72', 449, 4, 13, 822594) I know it.
('72', 449, 4, 14, 822605) But for that matter I know some leading men who would not accept khadi because it is based on my philosophy of life.
('72', 449, 4, 15, 822722) But how can I help it?
('72', 449, 4, 16, 822745) Non violence is certainly in the heart of the scheme, and I can easily demonstrate it, but I know that there will be little enthusiasm for it when I do so.
('72', 449, 4, 17, 822901) But those who accept the scheme accept the fact that in a land full of millions of hungry people you cannot teach their children by any other method, and that if you can get the thing going the result will be a new economic order.
('72', 449, 4, 18, 823132) That is quite enough for me, as it is enough for me that Congressmen accept non violence as a method for obtaining independence, but not as a way of life.
('72', 449, 4, 19, 823287) If the whole of India accepted non violence as a creed and a way of life, we should be able to establish a republic immediately.
('72', 449, 5, 20, 823416) There is one thing now which I do not understand.
('72', 449, 5, 21, 823466) I am a socialist, and whilst as a believer in non violence the scheme appeals to me most, I feel as a socialist that the scheme would cut India adrift from the world, whereas we have to integrate with the whole world, and socialism does it as nothing else does.
('72', 449, 5, 22, 823728) I have no difficulty.
('72', 449, 5, 23, 823750) We do not want to cut adrift from the whole world.
('72', 449, 5, 24, 823801) We will have a free interchange with all nations, but the present forced interchange has to go.
('72', 449, 5, 25, 823897) We do not want to be exploited, neither
('72', 449, 6, 26, 823937) 1 Reproduced from Mahadev Desai’s “Notes”.
('72', 449, 6, 27, 823980) Dr. John De Boer, incharge of an educational institution in South India, visited Gandhiji at Segaon before the latter’s departure for Haripura on February 8.
('72', 450, 0, 1, 824138) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 451
('72', 450, 1, 2, 824182) do we want to exploit any other nation.
('72', 450, 1, 3, 824222) Through the scheme we look forward to making all children producers, and so to change the face of the whole nation, for it will permeate the whole of our social being.
('72', 450, 1, 4, 824390) But that does not mean that we cut adrift from the whole world.
('72', 450, 1, 5, 824454) There will be nations that will want to interchange with others because they cannot produce certain things.
('72', 450, 1, 6, 824562) They will certainly depend on other nations for them, but the nations that will provide for them should not exploit them.
('72', 450, 2, 7, 824684) But if you simplify your life to an extent that you need nothing from other countries, you will isolate yourselves from them; whereas I want you to be responsible for America also.
('72', 450, 2, 8, 824865) It is by ceasing to exploit and to be exploited that we can be responsible for America.
('72', 450, 2, 9, 824953) For America will then follow our example and there will be no difficulty in a free interchange between us.
('72', 450, 3, 10, 825060) But you want to simplify life and cut out industrialization.
('72', 450, 3, 11, 825121) If I could produce all my country’s wants by means of the labour of 30,000 people instead of 30 million I should not mind it, provided that the thirty million are not rendered idle and unemp loyed.
('72', 450, 3, 12, 825319) I know that socialists would introduce industrialization to the extent of reducing working hours to one or two in a day, but I do not want it.
('72', 450, 4, 13, 825462) They would have leisure.
('72', 450, 4, 14, 825487) Leisure to play hockey?
('72', 450, 5, 15, 825511) Not only for that but for creative handicrafts for instance.
('72', 450, 5, 16, 825572) Creative handicrafts I am asking them to engage in.
('72', 450, 5, 17, 825624) But they will produce with their hands by working eight hours a day.
('72', 450, 6, 18, 825693) You do not of course look forward to a state of society when every house will have a radio and everyone a car.
('72', 450, 6, 19, 825804) That was President Hoover’s formula.
('72', 450, 6, 20, 825841) He wanted not one but two radios and two cars.
('72', 450, 6, 21, 825888) If we had so many cars there would be very little room left for walking.
('72', 450, 7, 22, 825961) I agree.
('72', 450, 7, 23, 825970) We have about 40,000 deaths by accidents every year and thrice as many cases of people being maimed.
('72', 450, 7, 24, 826071) At any rate I am not going to live to see the day when all villages in India will have radios.
('72', 450, 8, 25, 826166) Pandiit Jawaharlal seems to think in term of the economy of abundance.
('72', 450, 8, 26, 826237) I know.
('72', 450, 8, 27, 826245) But what is abundance?
('72', 450, 8, 28, 826268) Not the capacity to destroy millions of tons of wheat as you do in America?
('72', 451, 0, 1, 826344) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 451, 1, 2, 826386) Yes, that’s the nemesis of Capitalism.
('72', 451, 1, 3, 826425) They do not destroy now, but they are being paid for not producing wheat.
('72', 451, 1, 4, 826499) People indulged in the pastime of throwing eggs at one another because the prices of eggs had gone down.
('72', 451, 1, 5, 826604) That is what we do not want.
('72', 451, 1, 6, 826633) If by abundance you mean everyone having plenty to eat and drink and to clothe himself with, enough to keep his mind trained and educated, I should be satisfied.
('72', 451, 1, 7, 826795) But I should not like to pack more stuff in my belly than I can digest and more things than I can ever usefully use.
('72', 451, 1, 8, 826912) But neither do I want poverty, penury, misery, dirt and dust in India.
('72', 451, 2, 9, 826983) But Pandit Jawaharlal says in his autobiography you worship Daridranarayana and extol poverty for its own sake.
('72', 451, 3, 10, 827095) Gandhiji said with a laugh: I know.

('72', 452, 4, 8, 828253) 601. SPEECH AT KHADI AND VILLAGE INDUSTRIES EXHIBITION
('72', 452, 5, 9, 828308) HARIPURA, February 10, 1938 Bhai Shankerlal referred to the void created by Panditji’s passing away.
('72', 452, 5, 10, 828409) It is not surprising that I am pained because Panditji is no more among us.
('72', 452, 5, 11, 828485) When I sent the late Maganlal [Gandhi] to Pandit Vishnu Digambar [Paluskar] for acquiring for the newly established Satyagraha Ashram a good music teacher, the old Pandit knew whom he had to recommend.
('72', 452, 5, 12, 828687) Pandit Khare justified his choice and filled the position to which he was called as no one else could have done.
('72', 452, 5, 13, 828800) His death is likely to leave an unfillable gap.
('72', 452, 5, 14, 828848) Few people who have devoted themselves to art are known to have achieved such a unique combination of devotion to art and a pure and blameless life.
('72', 452, 5, 15, 828997) We have somehow accustomed ourselves to the belief that art is independent of the purity of private life.
('72', 452, 5, 16, 829103) I can say with all the experience at my command that nothing could be more untrue.
('72', 452, 5, 17, 829186) As I am nearing the end of my earthly life I can say that purity of life is the highest and truest art.
('72', 452, 5, 18, 829290) The art of producing good music from a cultivated voice can be achieved by many, but the art of producing that music from the harmony of a pure life is but achieved very rarely.
('72', 452, 5, 19, 829468) Pandit Khare was one of those rare people who had achieved it in full measure.
('72', 452, 5, 20, 829547) There has been no occasion when I had the slightest doubt about his purity.
('72', 452, 5, 21, 829623) Let Gujarat continue to take the interest in music awakened by the late Panditji.
('72', 452, 5, 22, 829705) I am hoping that his two children 2 will be worthy of him and I have no doubt that his brave wife 3 will give an example of
('72', 452, 6, 23, 829829) 1 Narayan Moreshwar Khare died on February 6 at Haripura.
('72', 452, 6, 24, 829887) 2 Mathuri and Ramachandra 3 Lakshmibehn
('72', 453, 0, 1, 829927) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 453, 1, 2, 829969) what a dedicated life an Indian widow’s can be.
('72', 453, 1, 3, 830017) As for Panditji, though he died in the prime of his life, anyone would envy him his death which came to him whilst he was working in a sacred place like this, fully conscious that his sands were running out and so went with Ramanama on his lips and with the echoes of the sacred name about him.
('72', 453, 1, 4, 830312) May Gujarat treasure his sweet memory.
('72', 453, 1, 5, 830351) When an exhibition of this kind was first opened at Lucknow 1 I had said that our exhibitions should be schools of instruction.
('72', 453, 1, 6, 830479) Since then we have been progressing successfully towards the ideal and the exhibition I have just now been through and am declaring open is such an annual training school.
('72', 453, 1, 7, 830651) It is not, as exhibitions of old used to be, a place of entertainment.
('72', 453, 1, 8, 830722) It is a place of instruction for the hundreds of thousands of those who will be visiting it during the week or two that it will be on.
('72', 453, 1, 9, 830857) It provides to the poor man who visits it a kind of victual for the next year’s journey.
('72', 453, 1, 10, 830946) It arms him with knowledge of an occupation which can carry him and his family through for the next year by his working at it for eight hours.
('72', 453, 1, 11, 831089) It ensures the training in securing an honest livelihood to everyone who will use his or her hands and feet, no matter how ignorant or illiterate he or she may be.
('72', 453, 1, 12, 831253) I have spent an hour this morning at the exhibition.
('72', 453, 1, 13, 831306) Please don’t think for a moment that there should be nothing new in it for one who is the President of the All India Spinners’ Association and who is guiding the All India Village Industries Association.
('72', 453, 1, 14, 831510) Even if you think so, I am not such a simpleton as to entertain the belief.
('72', 453, 1, 15, 831586) I would like to spend not one hour, but hours there learning something new every moment.
('72', 453, 1, 16, 831675) But I confess that I should not be able to earn my livelihood from an occupation that I might pick up there.
('72', 453, 1, 17, 831784) At the present moment I am begging for my livelihood, which perhaps is inevitable for one like me.
('72', 453, 1, 18, 831883) But I am sure that it is possible for any able bodied man or woman to choose one of the many industries exhibited here as a means of honest livelihood.
('72', 453, 1, 19, 832035) Shankerlal had suggested to me to point out any defects here.
('72', 453, 1, 20, 832097) It is of course my duty to do so.
('72', 453, 1, 21, 832131) One act of omission that I have noticed is that we do not preserve in the form of a book whatever we achieve in a year.

('72', 455, 2, 4, 835374) 602. TALK WITH WORKERS 1
('72', 455, 3, 5, 835399) [February 10, 1938] 2
('72', 455, 4, 6, 835421) Gandhiji was taken to where some of the children in some of the national schools and ashrams in Gujarat were shown to be earning from spinning three to four annas a day.
('72', 455, 4, 7, 835591) That is nothing.
('72', 455, 4, 8, 835608) So far as the schools are concerned, you have to concentrate on showing that we can teach everything through the handicrafts, e.g., that of spinning.
('72', 455, 4, 9, 835758) Literary education plus training in a handicraft is no novel conception.
('72', 455, 4, 10, 835831) The novel conception is that of making the handicraft the principal means of imparting literary training.
('72', 455, 5, 11, 835937) Then as regards the wage, he said: You are sadly mistaken if you think that you have achieved the ideal.
('72', 455, 5, 12, 836042) The ideal is one anna per hour, and when poor Maharashtra has been able to achieve the average wage of three to four annas per day, rich Gujarat cannot rest satisfied with giving its spinners that wage.
('72', 455, 5, 13, 836245) You have to think in terms of the wages obtainable in your province and should not be satisfied unless you have reached eight annas as the minimum wage.

('72', 455, 6, 15, 836464) That is no answer.
('72', 455, 6, 16, 836483) You must make up your mind that eight annas has to be made the minimum wage, and leave no stone unturned until you have achieved it.
('72', 455, 6, 17, 836616) Cut out the overhead charges, make the count finer and finer, but see that you reach the goal.
('72', 455, 6, 18, 836711) That khadi will not be sold is a superstition.

('72', 457, 8, 10, 838936) 606. SPEECH TO SANITATION VOLUNTEERS 2
('72', 457, 9, 11, 838975) February 11, 1938
('72', 457, 10, 12, 838993) Mahatma Gandhi urged the volunteers to do the work of Bhangis earnestly.
('72', 457, 10, 13, 839066) He added: Don’t think your work is inferior to that of Rashtrapati Bose or Jawaharlal Nehru.
('72', 457, 10, 14, 839159) No, not an atom.
('72', 457, 10, 15, 839176) They serve and you also serve and, in fact, I value your work more.
('72', 457, 10, 16, 839244) I myself am an experienced Bha ngi and a competent Bhangi.
('72', 457, 10, 17, 839303) Do your work sincerely and earnestly.
('72', 457, 10, 18, 839341) A large number of delegates will be shortly coming and if there are shortcomings in your work they will complain, though I cannot complain for I am not a delegate, nor do I intend to become one.
('72', 457, 11, 19, 839536) You know that you are engaged in a work that I like most.
('72', 457, 11, 20, 839594) The Bhangi has been the most despised of the Harjans, because his work has been regarded as the most degrading.
('72', 457, 11, 21, 839706) Many forget the important social service rendered by Bhangis.
('72', 457, 11, 22, 839768) 4 But we forgot that our mothers did that very work whilst we were babies innocent of all cleanliness.
('72', 457, 11, 23, 839871) If that work was ignoble the Bhangi’s would be ignoble, but if it was noble the Bhangi’s work is also noble.
('72', 457, 11, 24, 839980) But our mothers cleaned our filth because we were their babies, because they could not do otherwise, because they were wrapped up in us and adored their own selves in us.
('72', 457, 11, 25, 840151) Their work was thus selfish.
('72', 457, 11, 26, 840180) The volunteer Bhangi’s work is unselfish and so nobler than that of mothers.
('72', 457, 11, 27, 840257) And if I revere my mother and therefore the whole of womankind, is it not clear that I should adore the volunteer Bhangi even more?

('72', 460, 1, 2, 844876) 609. SPEECH AT EXHIBITION 1
('72', 460, 2, 3, 844904) February 13, 1938 Goraksha—‘cow protection’—is not the proper word, goseva— the service of the cow—is our ideal.
('72', 460, 2, 4, 845017) At the back of the present unfortunate state of things is our ignorance which in its turn is due to our lethargy.
('72', 460, 2, 5, 845131) If we try to go to the root of the pure science of cloth making, we will find that the spinning wheel is the sine qua non.
('72', 460, 2, 6, 845254) In the same way if you study the science of milk, you will find in India at any rate the service of the cow to be the sine qua non.
('72', 460, 2, 7, 845386) My study of the science as well as my consultations with experts have shown to me that it is impossible to save both the cow and the buffalo.
('72', 460, 2, 8, 845528) It is likely that after the cow has been saved the buffalo may also remain to a certain extent.
('72', 460, 2, 9, 845624) But if you allow the buffalo to compete with the cow, both the buffalo and the cow will be extinct.
('72', 460, 2, 10, 845724) What is necessary is to realize that the cow is really the more economic proposition as our own forefathers realized when they styled their kings as the protectors of the cow and the Brahmin.
('72', 460, 2, 11, 845916) But mark that they mentioned the cow first, because even the existence of the Brahmins, i.
('72', 460, 2, 12, 846007) e., the spiritual leaders of the community, depends on that of the cow.
('72', 460, 2, 13, 846079) You in Bardoli have laboured under the superstition that the cow cannot be economic and that the buffalo alone is your mainstay.
('72', 460, 2, 14, 846208) I tell you that it is a myth and that if you bestow on the cow the care that you do on the buffalo and try to understand the real economics of the cow, you will find in the long run that it is more economic than the buffalo.
('72', 460, 2, 15, 846433) We have wasted our energies so far in saving the cow from the butcher’s hands.
('72', 460, 2, 16, 846512) Why should we try to wrest it from the butcher’s hands?
('72', 460, 2, 17, 846568) The butcher has to pursue his profession.
('72', 460, 2, 18, 846610) To blame the butcher is like blaming the doctor for your fever.
('72', 460, 2, 19, 846674) We have allowed it to go into the butcher’s hands because of our gross neglect, and we are wholly responsible for its slaughter.
('72', 460, 2, 20, 846803) It is for us to make it economically unnecessary and so impossible to sell the cow to the butcher.
('72', 460, 2, 21, 846902) This exhibition and the tannery you will see in the bigger exhibition will show you that it is impossible to do so.
('72', 460, 2, 22, 847018) Harijan, 19 2 1938
('72', 460, 3, 23, 847037) 1 Reproduced from Mahadev Desai’s “Notes”.
('72', 460, 3, 24, 847080) Gandhiji visited the Exhibition pertaining to cattle breeding and dairy keeping which was declared open by Vallabhbhai Patel.

('72', 463, 1, 2, 849423) 615. INTERVIEW TO AMIN 1
('72', 463, 2, 3, 849448) HARIPURA, February 15, 1938
('72', 463, 3, 4, 849476) Mahatmaji advised Indians in Africa to do everything they could for the advancement of the Africans.
('72', 463, 3, 5, 849577) Gandhiji maintained that the Indians’ fight for equality of status with other emigrant races could not be divorced from our responsibility to assist the progress of the Africans in all manner possible politically and in the matter of higher education of the Africans in arts and science
('72', 463, 4, 6, 849864) The Mahatma also discussed the question of the Highlands and the disabilities of the Indians in East Africa.

('72', 469, 2, 8, 862265) 621. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('72', 469, 3, 9, 862295) HARIPURA, February 16, 1938 2
('72', 469, 4, 10, 862325) The Governor General’s interference with the proposal of the Bihar Ministers seems to be most unfortunate and uncalled for.
('72', 469, 4, 11, 862449) I have read and re read Section 126 (5 ) of the Government of India Act.
('72', 469, 4, 12, 862522) It authorizes interference when there is a grave menace to peace and tranquillity in any part of India through any action proposed by Ministers.
('72', 469, 4, 13, 862667) Surely the discharge of a few prisoners, even though they were convicted of crimes involving violence, for what they no doubt erringly believed to be the country’s cause, so far as I could see, could not endanger peace and tranquillity.
('72', 469, 4, 14, 862904) The Governor General’s interfer ence would come properly if there was disorder consequent upon such release.
('72', 469, 4, 15, 863013) In the case which has brought about the interference, I under stand the Bihar Prime Minister had been assured by the prisoners that they had changed their mentality and that they wanted to live, if they were discharged, as peaceful citizens.
('72', 469, 4, 16, 863255) The action of the Governor General bewilders me and makes me suspect whether the proposal to discharge the prisoners in question was merely the last straw and that the Congress Ministers in general had fatigued the British authority.
('72', 469, 4, 17, 863489) I hope that my suspicion is groundless, but, if it is so, I fail to understand the interference unless there are good grounds of which the public have no knowledge.
('72', 469, 4, 18, 863654) How I wish it was possible for the Governor General to retrace his step and avert a crisis whose consequences nobody can foretell.
('72', 469, 4, 19, 863785) Harijan, 19 2 1938
('72', 469, 5, 20, 863804) 1 Published under the title “Government Must Undo Mischief” 2 From The Bombay Chronicle, 17 2 1938
('72', 470, 0, 1, 863903) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 471
('72', 470, 1, 2, 863947) 622. RESOLUTION ON MINISTERIAL RESIGNATIONS
('72', 470, 2, 3, 863991) [Before February 18, 1938] 1
('72', 470, 3, 4, 864020) In accordance with the direction of the Faizpur Congress, the All India Congress Committee decided in March, 1937, the issue of acceptance of office in Provinces and permitted Congressmen to form Ministries, provided certain assurances were given by or on behalf of the British Government.
('72', 470, 3, 5, 864310) These assurances not being forthcoming, the leaders of Congress parties in the Provincial Assemblies declined at first to form Ministries.
('72', 470, 3, 6, 864449) Thereafter there was a considerable argument for some months regarding these assurances and various declarations were made by the Secretary of State for India, the Viceroy and the Governors of the Provinces.
('72', 470, 3, 7, 864657) In these declarations it was definitely stated, among other things, that there would be no interference with the day to day administration of provincial affairs by responsible Ministers.
('72', 470, 3, 8, 864844) The experience of office by Congress Ministers in the Provinces has shown that at least in two Provinces, the United Provinces and Bihar, there has in fact been interference in the day to day administration of provincial affairs as shown hereafter.
('72', 470, 3, 9, 865093) The Governors, when they invited Congress members to form Ministries, knew that the Congress Manifesto had mentioned the release of political prisoners as one of the major items of the Congress policy.
('72', 470, 3, 10, 865295) In pursuance thereof the Ministers began the release of political prisoners and they soon experienced delay, which was sometimes vexatious, before the Governors would endorse the orders of release.
('72', 470, 3, 11, 865493) The way releases have been repeatedly delayed is evidence of the exemplary patience of Ministers.
('72', 470, 3, 12, 865591) In the opinion of the Congress, release of prisoners is a matter coming essentially within the purview of day to day administration, which does not admit of protracted discussion with Governors.
('72', 470, 3, 13, 865786) The function of the Governor is to guide and advise Ministers and not to interfere with the free exercise of their judgment in the discharge of their day to day duty.
('72', 470, 3, 14, 865953) It was only when the time came for the Working Committee to give an annual account to the Congress delegates and to the masses of people backing them, that the Committee had to instruct Ministers, who were themselves sure of their ground, to order release of the political prisoners in their
('72', 470, 4, 15, 866245) 1 According to The Bombay Chronicle, 19 2 1938, the resolution drafted by Gandhiji was under discussion in the Working Committee meeting on February 18.
('72', 471, 0, 1, 866398) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 471, 1, 2, 866440) charge and to resign if their orders were countermanded.
('72', 471, 1, 3, 866497) The Congress approves of and endorses the action taken by the Ministers of the United Provinces and Bihar and congratulates them on it.
('72', 471, 1, 4, 866633) In the opinion of the Congress, the interference of the Governor General with the deliberate action of the respective Prime Ministers is not merely a violation of the assurance above referred to, but it is also a misapplication of Section 126 (5) of the Government of India Act.
('72', 471, 1, 5, 866912) There was no question of grave menace to peace and tranquillity involved.
('72', 471, 1, 6, 866986) The Prime Ministers had, besides, in both cases satisfied themselves from assurances from the prisoners concerned and otherwise of their change of mentality and acceptance of the Congress policy of non violence.
('72', 471, 1, 7, 867198) Indeed it is the Governor General’s interference which has undoubtedly created a situation that may easily, in spite of the Congress effort to the contrary, become such a grave menace.
('72', 471, 1, 8, 867383) The Congress has, during the short period that Congressmen have held office, given sufficient evidence of their self sacrifice, administrative capacity and constructive ability in the matter of enacting legislation for the amelioration of economic and social evils.
('72', 471, 1, 9, 867649) The Congress gladly admits that a measure of co operation was extended by the Governors to the Ministers.
('72', 471, 1, 10, 867755) It has been the sincere effort on the part of the Congress to extract what is possible from the Act for the public good and to strengthen the people in the pursuit of their goal of complete independence and the ending of imperialistic exploitation of the masses of India.
('72', 471, 1, 11, 868027) The Congress does not desire to precipitate a crisis which may involve non violent non co operation and direct action consistent with the Congress policy of truth and non violence.
('72', 471, 1, 12, 868208) The Congress is therefore at present reluctant to instruct Ministers in other Provinces to send in their resignations by way of protest against the Governor General’s action, and invites His Excellency the Governor General to reconsider his decision so that the Governors may act constitutionally and accept the advice of their Ministers in the matter of the release of the political prisoners.
('72', 471, 1, 13, 868603) The Congress regards the formation of irresponsible Ministries as a way of disguising the naked rule of the sword.
('72', 471, 1, 14, 868718) The formation of such Ministries is calculated to rouse extreme bitterness, internal quarrels, and further deepen the resentment against the British Government.
('72', 471, 1, 15, 868879) When the Congress approved of acceptance of office, with great reluctance and considerable hesitation, it had no misgivings about its own estimate of the real nature of the Government of India Act.
('72', 471, 1, 16, 869077) The latest action of the Governor General
('72', 472, 0, 1, 869119) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 473
('72', 472, 1, 2, 869163) justifies that estimate, and not only exposes the utter inadequacy of the Act to bring real liberty to the people, but also shows the intention of the British Government to use and interpret it not for the expansion of liberty but for its restriction.
('72', 472, 1, 3, 869415) Whatever, therefore, may be the ultimate result of the present crisis, the people of India should realize that there can be no true freedom for the country so long as this Act is not ended and a new constitution, framed by a Constituent Assembly, elected on the basis of adult franchise, takes its place.
('72', 472, 1, 4, 869720) The aim of all Congressmen, whether in office or out of office, in legislatures or out of legislatures, can only be to reach that goal, even though it may mean, as it often must mean, sacrifice of many a present advantage, however beneficial and worthy it might be for the time being.
('72', 472, 1, 5, 870005) On behalf of the U.P. Governor it has been stated that the demonstrations organized to welcome the Kakori prisoners and the speeches delivered by some of them had interfered with the policy of gradual release of political prisoners.
('72', 472, 1, 6, 870238) The Congress has always, discouraged unseemly demonstrations and other objectionable activities.
('72', 472, 1, 7, 870335) The demonstrations and speeches referred to by the U.P. Governor were strongly disapproved by Mahatma Gandhi.
('72', 472, 1, 8, 870445) 1 Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, President of the Congress, had similarly taken immediate notice of the indiscipline which was thus betrayed.
('72', 472, 1, 9, 870581) Nor were they ignored by the Ministers.
('72', 472, 1, 10, 870621) As a result of these corrective steps public opinion rapidly changed and even the persons concerned came to realize their mistake.
('72', 472, 1, 11, 870752) And when six prisoners, one of whom was a prominent member of the Kakori group, were released subsequently, about two months after the release of the Kakori prisoners, no demonstrations were held in their honour nor any reception was accorded to them.
('72', 472, 1, 12, 871004) Nearly four more months have since elapsed, and any delay in releasing the remaining fifteen prisoners, only on account of the demonstrations or the speeches connected with the prisoners who were released in August, is now utterly unjustified.
('72', 472, 1, 13, 871248) The responsibility for the maintenance of law and order is that of the Ministers and they are entitled to perform their functions in such manner as they deem proper.
('72', 472, 1, 14, 871414) It is their business to weigh all relevant factors in the light of prevailing circumstances, but their decisions once taken ought to be accepted and enforced.
('72', 472, 1, 15, 871573) Any interference with them in the exercise of their powers in the normal day to day administration is bound to undermine and weaken their position.
('72', 472, 2, 16, 871721) 1 Vide “Notes”, sub title, “Appeal to Discharged Prisoners”
('72', 473, 0, 1, 871781) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('72', 473, 1, 2, 871823) Congress Ministers have more than once declared their determination to take adequate action in the matter of violent crime, and the risk run in releasing prisoners, especially when they have abjured the path of violence, is altogether imaginary.
('72', 473, 1, 3, 872069) The Congress has given during the past few months ample evidence of its desire to take severe notice of indiscipline and breach of the code of non violence that the Congress has laid down for itself.
('72', 473, 1, 4, 872269) Nevertheless the Congress invites the attention of Congressmen to the fact that indiscipline in speech and action, calculated to promote or breed violence, retards the progress of the country towards its cherished goal.
('72', 473, 1, 5, 872489) In pursuit of its programme of release of political prisoners, the Congress has not hesitated to sacrifice office and the opportunity of passing ameliorative measures.
('72', 473, 1, 6, 872657) But the Congress wishes to make it clear that it strongly disapproves of hungerstrikes for release.
('72', 473, 1, 7, 872757) Hunger strikes embarrass the Congress in pursuit of its policy of securing release of political prisoners.
('72', 473, 1, 8, 872864) The Congress, therefore, urges those who are still continuing their hunger strike in the Punjab to give up their strike, and assures them that whether in Provinces where Congressmen hold ministerial offices or in other Provinces, Congress men will continue their efforts to secure the release of detenus and political prisoners by all legitimate and peaceful means.
('72', 473, 1, 9, 873230) In view of the situation that has arisen in the country, the Congress authorizes the Working Committee to take such action as it may consider necessary and to take the direction of the All India Congress Committee in dealing with the crisis whenever necessity arises for it.

('72', 477, 2, 3, 879080) APPENDIX I
('72', 477, 3, 4, 879091) VICEROY’S SPEECH 1
('72', 477, 4, 5, 879110) June 21, 1937
('72', 477, 5, 6, 879124) I dare say you will recall that when I spoke to you by wireless on the day I took charge of the office as Viceroy, I gave you my view that we should be wise not to expect that constitutional changes as profound as those into which we have now entered could come about altogether without difficulty.
('72', 477, 5, 7, 879423) I want today to say a few words to you about those difficulties as they have emerged, and to try my utmost to make some contribution towards their final dissipation.
('72', 477, 5, 8, 879589) As you read this message I would ask you to bear in mind two things.
('72', 477, 5, 9, 879658) The first, that while I am truly anxious not to be more formal or technical than my task requires .
('72', 477, 5, 10, 879758) I should not attempt to shorten too much or to oversimplify the various matters I propose to discuss.
('72', 477, 5, 11, 879860) The second, that, even though .
('72', 477, 5, 12, 879892) my words may seem to you a little formal, this does not mean that my personal approach to these problems is in the least degree cold or unsymp athetic.
('72', 477, 6, 13, 880044) I have refrained hitherto from making any public statement of any sort on the constitutional issues which have been raised by the refusal of the party which commands a majority of the votes in the Legislatures to accept office in certain Provinces.
('72', 477, 6, 14, 880293) My decision to do so was deliberate.
('72', 477, 6, 15, 880330) A point has now, however, been reached at which it will, I think, be of advantage that, for the benefit of the man in the street and the ordinary elector, I should myself take up the threads of this discussion in the light of the statements which have been made in Parliament by the Secretary of State, and in individual Provinces by the Governors, and that I should state comprehensively, in the most formal and public manner open to me, my attitude, which is equally the attitude of the Secretary of State and of the Governor of every Province in India, on the consititutional issues which have been brought to the fore in connection with this question of office acceptance.
('72', 477, 7, 16, 881007) Three months ago a great political party which commanded in six Provinces a majority in the Legislature felt that, even with the support of the majority in the
('72', 477, 8, 17, 881167) 1 Vide “Letter to Manilal and Sushila Gandhi”, 21 7 1937, “Letter to Lord Lothian”, 24 7 1937 and “Speech at Working Committee Meeting Wardha”,6 7 1937 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('72', 478, 0, 1, 881354) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 479
('72', 478, 1, 2, 881398) Legislature, it could not wisely accept office under the provisions of the Act unless it received certain specific assurances from Governors.
('72', 478, 1, 3, 881540) Three months experience of the operation of the Constitution, short as I agree that that period is, has conclusively shown from the practical point of view that, any legal difficulties in regard to the grant of such assurances apart, those assurances are not essential to the smooth and harmonious working of the Constitution .
('72', 478, 1, 4, 881868) Those three months have shown equally and beyond question that the apprehensions—even if I see no foundation of fact for them—that Governors would seek occasions for interfering with the policy of their Ministers or for the gratuitous and uncalled for exercise of the Special Responsibilities imposed upon them by the Act to impede or challenge the Ministers in the day to day administration of the Province, have no shadow of justification.
('72', 478, 2, 5, 882310) I have been intimately associated with the framing of the present Constit ution .
('72', 478, 2, 6, 882392) The Act, and the Instrument of Instructions which must be read with the Act, have been approved by Parliament.
('72', 478, 2, 7, 882503) Taken together, they represent the intention of Parliament and the Instruction given by Parliament to Governors.
('72', 478, 2, 8, 882616) Those documents make it clear beyond any possibility of question that, under Provincial Autonomy, in all matters falling within the ministerial field, including the position of the Minorities, the Services, etc., the Governor will ordinarily be guided, in the exercise of his powers, by the advice of his Ministers and that those Ministers will be responsible not to Parliament but to the provincial Legislature.
('72', 478, 2, 9, 883029) The only qualifications of this rule are in respect of certain specific and clearly defined matters.
('72', 478, 2, 10, 883130) The most important of these are those known as the Special Responsibilities; and of those Special Responsibilities again, the most important are the prevention of any grave menace to the peace or tranquillity of the Province or any part of the Province, the safeguarding of the legitimate interests of the miniorities and the securing to the Services and their dependents of any rights provided or preserved for them under the Act and the safeguarding of their legitimate interests.
('72', 478, 3, 11, 883613) Within the limited area of his Special Responsibilities a Governor is directly answerable to Parliament, whether he accepts or does not accept the advice of his Ministers, But if the Governor is unable to accept the advice of his Ministers then the responsibility for the decision is his and his alone.
('72', 478, 3, 12, 883916) In that event Ministers bear no responsibility for the decision and are entitled—if they so desire—publicly to state that they take no responsibility for that particular decision or even that they have advised the Governor in an opposite sense.
('72', 478, 3, 13, 884161) But every Governor will be concerned to have the support of his Ministry or to know that he is not silghtly at variance with his Ministry .
('72', 478, 3, 14, 884301) He will listen with a mind open to conviction to the arguments on the other side.
('72', 478, 3, 15, 884383) If he regards those arguments as valid, he will modify his proposal .
('72', 478, 3, 16, 884453) on the other hand, as invalid, he will do his utmost, before taking a final decision, to convince the Minister or the Ministry of the soundness of the
('72', 479, 0, 1, 884604) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 480
('72', 479, 1, 2, 884646) reasons for which he is unable to accept his or their view and if, in these circumstances, he still remains unable to influence their views in the direction he desires, he will take his decision .
('72', 479, 1, 3, 884843) and, before passing it, he will have exhausted all methods of convincing his Ministry that that decision was the right one, given the obligation imposed upon him by the Act.
('72', 479, 2, 4, 885017) I welcome for this reason the helpful suggestion recently made by Mr. Gandhi that it is only when the issue between a Governor and his Ministers constitutes a serious disagreement that any question of the severing of their partnership need arise.
('72', 479, 2, 5, 885264) “Serious disagreement” is a pharse which it is possible to define and to interpret in various ways.
('72', 479, 2, 6, 885364) But the general sense is clear enough to anyone with any political or administrative experience.
('72', 479, 2, 7, 885461) The matter involved must be of such really major importance.
('72', 479, 2, 8, 885522) It must, I would myself say, be of such a character that a compromise was ruled out by a particular action taken against their advice by a Governor in the discharge of his responsibilities under the Act, despite the fact that Ministers had no direct or indirect responsibility for that action and that a Governor had taken the utmost pains to satisfy his Ministry that he had no choice in the discharge of his responsibilities but to take the action in question.
('72', 479, 2, 9, 885985) I readily agree that where, on such an issue arising and where the Governor and his Ministers have both approached the matter, as I am confident that they would with open minds and with a full sense of responsibility—the Governor, in so far as his Special Responsibiliies are concerned to Parliament, the Ministry to the provincial Legislature no agreement could be reached, then the Ministry must either resign or be dismissed.
('72', 479, 2, 10, 886414) As between resignation and dismissal, normal constitutional practice leans very heavily indeed to the side of resignation.
('72', 479, 2, 11, 886537) Resignation is more consistent with the self respect of a Ministry and is an effective public indication of the attitude of Ministers towards the action of a Governor.
('72', 479, 2, 12, 886705) Resignation equally is an act taken spontaneously by a Ministry.
('72', 479, 2, 13, 886770) Dismissal, more unusual by far in constitutional practice, might seem to carry with it some suggestion which we are concerned at any cost to eliminate from the new constitutional arrangements.
('72', 479, 2, 14, 886963) I ought perhaps to add that the suggestion that the Governor should in certain circumstances demand the resignation of his Ministers is not the solution provided by the Act, so that it will not be possible for Governors to accept it.
('72', 479, 2, 15, 887197) Both resignation and dismissal are possible, the former at the option of the Ministers and the latter at the option of the Governors.
('72', 479, 2, 16, 887331) But the Act does not contemplate that the Governor’s option should be used to force the Minister’s option and thus to shift the responsibility from himself.
('72', 479, 3, 17, 887488) I have deliberately dealt with the extreme case of a conflict involving resignation or dismissal, for it is the extreme case on which attention has been riveted.
('72', 479, 3, 18, 887650) I feel no doubt whatever myself that on that basis deadlocks need not be anticipated in view of the anxiety of all Governors, to which I can myself testify, not merely not to provoke conflicts with their Ministers, to whatever party their
('72', 480, 0, 1, 887889) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 481
('72', 480, 1, 2, 887933) Ministers may belong, but to leave nothing undone to avoid or to resolve such conflicts.
('72', 480, 1, 3, 888022) I have been the more concerned to set out in some detail the position, as I see it, in that it is essential that those interests or communities or areas to which the Act extends the assurance of the Special Responsibilities should not, for a moment, think, or have the least ground for thinking, that any question will arise of sacrificing their interests for political reason.
('72', 480, 1, 4, 888400) What I am concerned to make clear is that, without any threat to those interests or any sacrifice of them, a Governor and his Ministers can, in my judgment, hope, within the provision of the Act, to operate the Constitution in the normal manner which the Act envisages and to avoid, save in circumstances which I find it not easy to contemplate, fundamental differences of opinion such as to endanger the relation between the Governor and his Ministry in that very limited area in which special obligations and responsibilities are imposed upon a Governor.
('72', 480, 2, 5, 888957) Before I take leave of you, I feel that you would wish me, setting aside all technicalities, to speak to you for a moment or two as one who has had a good deal of Parliamentary experience and some share in the shaping of the new Constitution.
('72', 480, 2, 6, 889200) Some of you, I know, hold and hold strongly, that the plan of reform does not go sufficiently far in the direction of complete self government.
('72', 480, 2, 7, 889344) I do not question the sincerity with which that view is held.
('72', 480, 2, 8, 889406) But I am certain that every responsible person, in deciding his position on this vital matter does so with a genuine anxiety in the best interests of India to take a balanced view and to reach a right decision as to what may best be done in the conditions of this time to serve those interests.
('72', 480, 3, 9, 889701) Let me at once assure you that in my best judgment and given goodwill on all sides this Constitution will work and that in experience it will be found to work well.
('72', 480, 3, 10, 889866) It stands now as the law of the land.
('72', 480, 3, 11, 889904) It stands too—and despite all the criticism that has been levelled against it—as the only complete and homogeneous scheme of political reform now before the country.
('72', 480, 3, 12, 890070) I am convinced that the shortest road to that fuller political life which many of you so greatly desire is to accept this constitution and to work it for all it is worth.
('72', 480, 3, 13, 890241) Of their nature, politics are ever dynamic and to imagine that their expression in terms of a written Constitution can render them static would be utterly to disregard the lessons of history and indeed the dictates of common sense.
('72', 480, 3, 14, 890473) Again, it is my firm conviction that this Constitution will be found to offer immense opportunities for beneficent public service and in this connection I may venture a word upon a matter very close to my heart.
('72', 480, 3, 15, 890685) It is my conviction that in the full working and development of this Constitution lies the best hope for that general and lasting amelioration in the condition of the rural population and of the humbler sections of society which all of us so ardently desire.
('72', 480, 4, 16, 890944) The discussions and debates of the last two months have, I think, placed before you every argument and point of view that bear upon this issue.
('72', 480, 4, 17, 891088) The choice—a
('72', 481, 0, 1, 891101) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 482
('72', 481, 1, 2, 891143) choice fraught with so much of profound significance for the future of India—must shortly be made.
('72', 481, 1, 3, 891242) I hope with all my heart that all, whether leaders or their followers, may find it their duty to choose the way of constructive effort.
('72', 481, 1, 4, 891378) Whatever emerges, you may count upon me, in face even of bitter disappointment, to strive unstirringly towards the full and final establishment in India of the principles of parliamentary government.
('72', 481, 1, 5, 891578) But if what I should regard as deplorable outcome should emerge from the present situation and if parliamentary and responsible government should, as a consequence, be suspended in a number of Provinces, it might, however much we might all of us regret it, be beyond the power of any of us rapidly to reverse the circumstances that must then supervene.
('72', 481, 1, 6, 891931) In that event invaluable time will be lost, and I greatly fear, no little hurt inflicted upon the cause of progressive reform.
('72', 481, 2, 7, 892058) But I do not believe that these sad things will come to pass, for I have faith in you and in the destiny of India.
('72', 481, 2, 8, 892173) The way we tread may seem dark and sometimes difficult.
('72', 481, 2, 9, 892229) The star that guides our course may seem sometimes to flicker and almost to fall.
('72', 481, 2, 10, 892311) Yet faith and courage are mighty forces.
('72', 481, 2, 11, 892352) Let us summon them to our aid in this difficult hour and together move steadily towards the fulfilment of our hopes.
('72', 481, 3, 12, 892469) The Indian Annual Register, 1937, Vol. I pp.
('72', 481, 4, 13, 892514) APPENDIX II
('72', 481, 5, 14, 892526) VALLABHBHAI PATEL’S STATEMENT 1
('72', 481, 6, 15, 892558) July 9, 1937
('72', 481, 7, 16, 892571) I have remained studiously silent regarding the unfortunate controversy that has been going on in the Press about the election of leader of the Congress Parliamentary Party in the Bombay Legislative Assembly.
('72', 481, 7, 17, 892780) I feel that the time has now come for me to make a brief statement for the information of the public.
('72', 481, 7, 18, 892882) Shri Nariman has suggested that I intervened in an unwarranted manner in the election of the leader.
('72', 481, 7, 19, 892983) He has persisted in this charge, although Gangadharrao Despande and Shankarrao Deo, the two individuals most concerned, have emphatically repudiated it.
('72', 481, 7, 20, 893136) As is well known, the bulk of the members of the Legislature have also repudiated the charge in writing.
('72', 481, 7, 21, 893241) I now say with a full sense of responsibility that I have never, directly or indirectly, influenced this election.
('72', 481, 7, 22, 893356) What happened was this: on the morning of the 4th of March, Nariman came to me and asked me for a private interview.
('72', 481, 7, 23, 893473) I readily agreed.
('72', 481, 7, 24, 893491) At his suggestion it was then arranged that we should go for a drive in the evening to Worli.
('72', 481, 7, 25, 893585) Accordingly he came and took me in his car to Worli.
('72', 481, 7, 26, 893638) He asked me to help him in the election.
('72', 481, 7, 27, 893679) I told him I could not do so for
('72', 481, 8, 28, 893712) 1Vide “Letter to K. F. Nariman”, 14 7 1937 and “Letter to K. F. Nariman”, 17 7 1937
('72', 482, 0, 1, 893796) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 483
('72', 482, 1, 2, 893840) reasons which I had already indicated to him.
('72', 482, 1, 3, 893886) At the same time, I also told him that I would not use my influence against him, or support anyone else.
('72', 482, 2, 4, 893991) Certain telegrams sent by me to Shri Gangadharrao Deshpande and Shri Shankarrao Deo have been quoted as proof of my intervention against Nariman.
('72', 482, 2, 5, 894137) Both Gangadharrao and Shankarrao have stated in unambiguons terms that the telegrams were not connected with the election of Nariman.
('72', 482, 2, 6, 894271) It is a matter of common knowledge that I have frequently entrusted Nariman with responsible tasks, which I felt he was the right person to discharge.
('72', 482, 2, 7, 894422) I have no personal grudge against him.
('72', 482, 3, 8, 894461) The suggestion that Nariman was not elected because he belonged to a minority community is false and malicious.
('72', 482, 3, 9, 894573) I am glad that Nariman has himself admitted that there was nothing communal in the matter.
('72', 482, 3, 10, 894664) Gangadharrao had informed Nariman on my behalf that if the allegations were to be investigated by a tribunal, I would abide by its award.
('72', 482, 4, 11, 894802) Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Vol. II, pp.
('72', 482, 5, 12, 894841) APPENDIX III
('72', 482, 6, 13, 894854) LIVERY OF FREEDOM 1
('72', 482, 7, 14, 894874) I suggest, therefore, that meetings for this purpose be held all over India, in towns and villages, on a particular day, Sunday, August 1st, when the Working Committe’s Resolution should be read out and explained and while offering camaraderie greeting to Congress Ministers, we should pledge ourselves anew to independence and removal of poverty of our people.
('72', 482, 7, 15, 895236) On that day also the flag salutation ceremony should be solemnly performed everywhere.
('72', 482, 7, 16, 895323) August 1st is a special significant day for us, the day dedicated to India’s freedom.
('72', 482, 7, 17, 895409) On that day seventeen years ago great Lokamanya passed away and on that very day India launched the non co operation movement and began wielding that weapon which has strengthened and vitalized our people so greatly.
('72', 482, 7, 18, 895626) It is fitting, therefore, that this day be suitably celebrated and we should remember the past and we should look to the future with the same determination which has held us for so long.
('72', 482, 8, 19, 895813) I trust that as an earnest of his sympathy and goodwill every Indian who stands for India’s freedom will wear khadi, the livery of our freedom, and will display and honour the National Flag.
('72', 482, 8, 20, 896004) I trust also that the police force, which has so long been hostile to our people, will think in terms of India and not of alien masters and will seek the co operation and goodwill of the masses.
('72', 482, 8, 21, 896199) Congress Ministries, if they mean anything at all, mean that the interests of these masses will be dominant.
('72', 482, 9, 22, 896308) Harijan, 31 7 1937
('72', 482, 10, 23, 896327) 1 Vide “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 30 7 1937
('72', 483, 0, 1, 896375) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 484
('72', 483, 1, 2, 896417) APPENDIX IV
('72', 483, 2, 3, 896429) THE QUESTION OF LANGUAGES 1
('72', 483, 3, 4, 896457) 1. Our public work should be carried on and State education should be given in the language of each linguistic area.
('72', 483, 3, 5, 896574) This language should be the dominant language in that area.
('72', 483, 3, 6, 896634) These Indian languages to be recognised officially for this purpose are: Hindustani (both Hindi and Urdu), Bengali, Gujarati, Marathi, Tamil, Telugu, Kannada, Malayalam, Oriya, Assamese, Sindhi, and to some extent, Pushtu and Punjabi.
('72', 483, 4, 7, 896869) 2. In the Hindustani speaking area both Hindi and Urdu, with their scripts, should be officially recognized.
('72', 483, 4, 8, 896978) Public notifications should be issued in both scripts.
('72', 483, 4, 9, 897033) Either script might be used by a person in addressing a court or a public office, and he should not be called upon to supply a copy in the other script.
('72', 483, 5, 10, 897186) 3. The medium of State instruction in the Hindustani area being Hindustani, both scripts will be recognized and used.
('72', 483, 5, 11, 897304) Each pupil or his parents will make a choice of scripts.
('72', 483, 5, 12, 897361) A pupil will not be compelled to learn both scripts but may be encouraged to do so in the secondary stage.
('72', 483, 6, 13, 897468) 4. Hindustani (both scripts) will be recognized as the all India language.
('72', 483, 6, 14, 897543) As such it will be open to any person throughout India to address a court or public office in Hindustani (either script) without any obligation to give a copy in another script or language.
('72', 483, 7, 15, 897733) 5. An attempt should be made to unify the Devanagari, Bengali, Gujarati and Marathi scripts and to produce a composite script suited to printing, typing and the use of modern mechanical devices.
('72', 483, 8, 16, 897928) 6. The Sindhi script should be absorbed in the Urdu script which should be simplified, to the extent that is possible, and suited to printing, typing, etc.
('72', 483, 9, 17, 898084) 7. The possibility of approximating the southern scripts to Devanagari should be explored.
('72', 483, 9, 18, 898175) If that is not considered feasible, then an attempt should be made to have a common script for the southern languages—Tamil, Telugu, Kannada and Malayalam.
('72', 483, 10, 19, 898331) 8. It is not possible for us to think in terms of the Latin script for our languages, for the present at least, in spite of the various advantages which that script possesses.
('72', 483, 10, 20, 898507) We must thus have two scripts: the composite Devanagari Bengali Gujarati Marathi; and the Urdu Sindhi; and if necessary, a script for the southern languages, unless this can be approximated to the first.
('72', 483, 11, 21, 898711) 1 Vide “Foreword to “The Question of Languages”, 3 8 1937
('72', 484, 0, 1, 898769) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 485
('72', 484, 1, 2, 898813) 9. The tendency for Hindi and Urdu in the Hindustani speaking area to diverge and develop separately need not be viewed with alarm, nor should any obstruction be placed in the development of either.
('72', 484, 1, 3, 899012) This is to some extent natural as new and more abstruse ideas come into the language.
('72', 484, 1, 4, 899098) The development of either will enrich the language.
('72', 484, 1, 5, 899150) There is bound to be an adjustment later on as world forces and nationalism press in this direction, and mass education will bring a measure of standardization and uniformity.
('72', 484, 2, 6, 899326) 10. We should lay stress on the language (Hindi, Urdu, as well as the other Indian languages) looking to the masses and speaking in terms of them.
('72', 484, 2, 7, 899473) Writers should write for the masses in simple language understood by them, and they should deal with problems affecting the masses.
('72', 484, 2, 8, 899605) Courtly and affected style and flowery phrases should be discouraged and a simple, vigorous style developed.
('72', 484, 2, 9, 899714) Apart from its other advantages, this will also lead to uniformity between Hindi and Urdu.
('72', 484, 3, 10, 899805) 11. A Basic Hindustani should be evolved out of Hindustani on the lines of Basic English.
('72', 484, 3, 11, 899895) This should be a simple language with very little grammar and a vocabulary of about a thousand words.
('72', 484, 3, 12, 899997) It must be a complete language, good enough for all ordinary speech and writing, and yet within the framework of Hindustani and a stepping stone for the further study of that language.
('72', 484, 4, 13, 900182) 12. Apart from Basic Hindustani, we should fix upon scientific, technical, political and commercial words to be used in Hindustani (both Hindi and Urdu) as well as, if possible, in other Indian languages.
('72', 484, 4, 14, 900387) Where necessary these words should be taken from foreign languages and bodily adopted.
('72', 484, 4, 15, 900474) Lists of other words from our own languages should be made, so that in all technical and suchlike matters we might have a precise and uniform vocabulary.
('72', 484, 5, 16, 900628) 13. The policy governing State education should be that education is to be given in the language of the student.
('72', 484, 5, 17, 900741) In each linguistic area education from the primary to the university stage will be given in the language of the province.
('72', 484, 5, 18, 900863) Even within a linguistic area, if there are a sufficient number of students whose mother tongue is some other Indian language, they will be entitled to receive primary education in their mother tongue, provided they are easily accessible from a convenient centre.
('72', 484, 5, 19, 901127) It may also be possible, if the number is large enough, to give them secondary education also in the mother tongue, but all such students will have to take, as a compulsory subject, the language of the linguistic area they live in.
('72', 484, 6, 20, 901359) 14. In the non Hindustani speaking areas, Basic Hindustani should be taught in the secondary stage, the script being left to the choice of the person concerned.
('72', 484, 7, 21, 901520) 15. The medium of instruction for university education will be the language of the linguistic area.
('72', 484, 7, 22, 901620) Hindustani (either script) and a foreign language should be compulsory subjects.
('72', 484, 7, 23, 901701) This compulsion of learning additional languages need not
('72', 485, 0, 1, 901759) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 486
('72', 485, 1, 2, 901801) apply to higher technical courses, though a knowledge of languages is desirable even there.
('72', 485, 2, 3, 901893) 16. Provision for teaching foreign languages, as well as our classical languages, should be made in our secondary schools, but the subjects should not be compulsory, except for certain special courses, or for preparation for the university stage.
('72', 485, 3, 4, 902140) 17. Translations should be made of a considerable number of classical and modern works in foreign literatures into the Indian languages, so that our languages might develop contact with the cultural, literary and social movements in other countries, and gain strength thereby.
('72', 485, 4, 5, 902417) Harijan, 21 8 1937
('72', 485, 5, 6, 902436) APPENDIX V
('72', 485, 6, 7, 902447) THE KOTTAPATAM SUMMER SCHOOL 1
('72', 485, 7, 8, 902478) While I was in Malaya I read a brief report in the papers of the Madras Government’s ban on the Summer School at Kottapatam and the subsequent lathi charge on the students.
('72', 485, 7, 9, 902651) Such a step would have been surprising and reprehensible even during the course of the civil disobedience movement.
('72', 485, 7, 10, 902767) At the present moment it came as a shock to me.
('72', 485, 7, 11, 902815) Since my return I have looked further into the matter and the sense of astonishment and shock has not lessened.
('72', 485, 7, 12, 902927) This incident has illuminated, as by a flash of lightning, the real nature of the new Constitution and the way the Madras Ministry is functioning, for it is this Ministry that is obviously responsible for the steps taken.
('72', 485, 7, 13, 903149) We see that this Ministry is as much a police ministry suppressing elementary rights of free speech and association as the previous Government was.
('72', 485, 7, 14, 903297) We see what the new Act means to the people.
('72', 485, 7, 15, 903342) The same intolerable state of affairs continues and all the soft words thrown out at us cannot stop the aggressive suppression of civil liberty or the use of the lathi on the bodies of our youth.
('72', 485, 7, 16, 903538) The lathi remains still under the new Ministers as it was before the true symbol of Government.
('72', 485, 8, 17, 903634) Some other important considerations arise.
('72', 485, 8, 18, 903677) The police reporters tried to force entry into the Summer School.
('72', 485, 8, 19, 903743) Very rightly this was objected to.
('72', 485, 8, 20, 903778) We have been giving facilities to police reporters at our public meetings but this does not mean that we admit their right to attend our committee meetings and summer schools and the like.
('72', 485, 8, 21, 903967) This cannot be agreed to.
('72', 485, 8, 22, 903993) Summer schools for the study of political and economic problems have been held in many places in India.
('72', 485, 8, 23, 904097) This is a healthy development which I trust will continue, for only by study and discussions can we understand our problems and find the way to their solution.
('72', 485, 9, 24, 904257) Another question that arises is the right of an individual or group to refuse to obey an order which it considers objectionable.
('72', 485, 9, 25, 904386) It is patent that civil disobedience
('72', 485, 10, 26, 904423) 1 Vide “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 8 8 1937
('72', 486, 0, 1, 904469) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 487
('72', 486, 1, 2, 904513) having been suspended disobedience of orders is not desirable.
('72', 486, 1, 3, 904576) Where such objectionable orders are made reference should immediately be made to superior committees for advice.
('72', 486, 1, 4, 904689) But sometimes cases arise when immediate decisions have to be made and the burden of such decision must lie on the individual or group concerned and cannot commit the organization.
('72', 486, 1, 5, 904870) I can conceive of instances of orders which are so derogatory to the dignity of the individual or of the Congress that the individual prefers to disobey them on his own responsibility.
('72', 486, 1, 6, 905055) This has nothing to do with civil disobedience.
('72', 486, 1, 7, 905103) It is the inherent right of an individual.
('72', 486, 1, 8, 905146) This right however must be exercised with every care and so as not to injure the large purposes we have in view, and the individual must take the risk of being judged by the organization.
('72', 486, 2, 9, 905334) The Indian Annual Register, 1937, Vol. I, p.

('72', 486, 6, 13, 905494) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
