('72', 487, 1, 2, 906801) APPENDIX VII
('72', 487, 2, 3, 906814) CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION ON ANDAMANS PRISONERS 1
('72', 487, 3, 4, 906876) The Working Committee has learnt with the deepest concern of the hunger strike of hundreds of political prisoners in the Andaman Islands.
('72', 487, 3, 5, 907014) The Committee has long been of opinion that the use of the Islands as a penal settlement, more especially for political prisoners, is barbarous.
('72', 487, 3, 6, 907159) Official enquiries and reports have already condemned such use and non official opinion has unanimously demanded that no prisoners be sent there.
('72', 487, 3, 7, 907305) Repeated hunger strikes by the political prisoners have demonstrated their desperation at the continuance of conditions which they cannot bear, and the present hunger strike has brought matters to a head and grave consequences are feared.
('72', 487, 3, 8, 907544) Public opinion all over India is agitated and strongly in favour of the release of the political prisoners there as they have already undergone many years of imprisonment under conditions which are far worse than those prevailing in Indian prisons.
('72', 487, 3, 9, 907793) The Committee’s attention has been drawn to the public statement issued by some ex prisoners, who were till recently imprisoned in the Andaman Islands and have been now released, in which they have stated on their own behalf and on behalf of the other political prisoners there, their dissociation from and disapproval of the policy of terrorism.
('72', 487, 3, 10, 908140) They have frankly stated that they have come to realize that such a policy is wrong and injurious to the national cause and they propose to have nothing to do with it.
('72', 487, 3, 11, 908308) This statement has been confirmed from other sources also.
('72', 487, 4, 12, 908367) In view of all these circumstances the Committee is emphatically of opinion that the political prisoners in the Andamans should be discharged.
('72', 487, 4, 13, 908510) The Committee is further of opinion that the non political prisoners in the Andamans should be repatriated and the penal settlement in the islands closed.
('72', 487, 4, 14, 908665) Any delay in taking adequate action is likely to lead to alarming consequences.
('72', 487, 5, 15, 908745) The Committee appeals to the prisoners in the Andamans to give up their hunger strike.
('72', 487, 6, 16, 908832) Congress Bulletin, No.
('72', 487, 6, 17, 908855) 6, September 1937. File No.
('72', 487, 6, 18, 908883) 4/15/37, Home, Political.
('72', 487, 6, 19, 908909) Courtesy: National Archives of India
('72', 487, 7, 20, 908946) 1 Vide “Telegram to Viceroy”, 27 8 1937

('72', 488, 1, 2, 909030) APPENDIX VIII
('72', 488, 2, 3, 909044) NOTES “SUFFICIENTLY ACQUAINTED” 1
('72', 488, 3, 4, 909078) The very first question on which our Assembly Speakers may have to give their ruling will be what, in their opinion, is the meaning of “sufficient acquaintance” with English.
('72', 488, 3, 5, 909253) For one of the most objectionable Sections of the Government of India Act, 1935, is Section 85, which reads:
('72', 488, 4, 6, 909362) “All proceedings in the Legislature of a Province shall be conducted in the English language.
('72', 488, 5, 7, 909456) Provided that the rules of procedure of the chamber or chambers, and the rules, if any, with respect to joint sittings, shall provide for enabling persons unacquainted, or not sufficiently acquainted, with the English language, to use another language.”
('72', 488, 6, 8, 909710) The first part of the Section is eloquently emphatic of the fact that the Act was meant not for the millions unacquainted with the English language but for the very few acquainted with it.
('72', 488, 6, 9, 909899) The insult to the millions is so obvious.
('72', 488, 6, 10, 909941) The permissive proviso offers a kind of healing balm to the injury of the insult.
('72', 488, 6, 11, 910023) In an Act framed by our own people the operative part of the Section would make the use of the language of the province or Hindi Hindustani obligatory and the permissive proviso would be for the benefit of the unfortunate ones who might not know either the language of the province or the nation, and therefore must use “another language”.
('72', 488, 6, 12, 910363) That, of course, is by way of comment on the Section.
('72', 488, 7, 13, 910417) Those, however, who occupy the Speaker’s chair cannot comment on the Section, they will have to interpret it for the members.
('72', 488, 7, 14, 910543) A commentator of the Act has already anticipated a difficulty and says: “This is a facility (viz., the one offered by the proviso) not open to those who, knowing English, would, as a matter of national self respect, insist upon using the vernacular language.” We shall not quarrel with the commentator’s own ignorance, here, of the correct use of the English language, or of the implications of “national self respect”.
('72', 488, 7, 15, 910963) (Otherwise he would not have used the objectionable word “vernacular” and would have used the words “national language” or “the language of the province”).
('72', 488, 8, 16, 911119) But apart from the question of “national self respect” which is bound to be foreign to an Act, on the face of it so disrespectful, any commentator ought to address himself to the meaning of the words “sufficiently acquainted”.
('72', 488, 8, 17, 911346) Does “sufficient knowledge” mean a mere nodding acquaintance or even a working knowledge?
('72', 488, 8, 18, 911436) Whilst the Speaker may not be guided by “national self respect” and reverse the disrespectful
('72', 488, 9, 19, 911530) 1 Vide “Sufficiently Acquainted”, 28 8 1937
('72', 489, 0, 1, 911574) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 490
('72', 489, 1, 2, 911616) spirit of the Acts he may certainly put a liberal interpretation on the proviso.
('72', 489, 1, 3, 911697) “Sufficient” according to the Oxford Dictionary means “adequate, enough”; also “Competent, of adequate ability or resources”; and “adequate” means “proportionate to the requirements” of the case.
('72', 489, 1, 4, 911893) Now what are the requirements here?
('72', 489, 1, 5, 911929) Two, viz., that the member of the legislature may give adequate expression to all that he is filled with; and that the rest of the members understand all that he has to say.
('72', 489, 1, 6, 912103) As regards the first of these requirements, does an ordinary knowledge of English enable one to express one’s thoughts adequately?
('72', 489, 1, 7, 912234) As I write this, I have before my mind’s eye a vivid picture of a newly elected M. L. A. who had occasion to travel with Gandhiji some time ago.
('72', 489, 1, 8, 912379) The M. L. A., as we found afterwards, had a double University degree, but lacked, if I may say without offence, the ability to express her thought either fully or correctly.
('72', 489, 1, 9, 912553) She was exceptionally refined and cultured but she lacked this gift.
('72', 489, 1, 10, 912622) She not only could not express herself fully or correctly, she failed to follow Gandhiji fully or correctly.
('72', 489, 1, 11, 912731) Not knowing Section 85 of the Act, I said to myself, “Thank God she need not speak in the Assembly in English.” But knowing the Section, I now ask, must she speak in English, because she is a double graduate and presumed to know English?
('72', 489, 1, 12, 912969) I should think not.
('72', 489, 1, 13, 912989) It should be open to our M. L. A.s to declare that it is not possible for them to express themselves adequately in English, or at any rate as well in English as they could in their own mother tongue.
('72', 489, 1, 14, 913189) And this lady, in spite of her double degree, seemed to me to possess a right truthfully to make such a declaration.
('72', 489, 1, 15, 913306) I am sure that there are many members who are in the same case as this sister.
('72', 489, 2, 16, 913385) Take now the second and equally important requirement of the case, viz., that the rest of the members should understand all that a member says.
('72', 489, 2, 17, 913529) In Bombay, I am told, no less than twenty two of the members of the Assembly do not know English at all.
('72', 489, 2, 18, 913634) Are they to sit with their ears closed when a brother member addresses them in choice or indifferent English?
('72', 489, 2, 19, 913744) The least they are entitled to, I think, is that whenever a member regarding himself as “sufficiently acquainted” with English speaks in English, he must also for the benefit of the non English knowing members explain the speech in the language of the province.
('72', 489, 3, 20, 914006) These two requirements of the case seem to me so obvious that any Speaker seeking to put a correct, not to say liberal, interpretation on the proviso is bound to have due regard to them.
('72', 489, 4, 21, 914193) Harijan, 31 7 1937
('72', 490, 0, 1, 914212) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 491
('72', 490, 1, 2, 914256) APPENDIX IX
('72', 490, 2, 3, 914268) K. F. NARIMAN’S STATEMENT 1
('72', 490, 3, 4, 914296) I am grateful to Mahatma Gandhi and D. N. Bahadurji for having taken me into their confidence and shown me a copy of their findings and judgment in an inquiry made by them.
('72', 490, 3, 5, 914469) I have studied them carefully and must accept them as findings arrived at by judges who were judges of my choice and whom I have the privilege of regarding as my friends.
('72', 490, 3, 6, 914640) It is open to them to publish their judgment but they have generously offered not to publish it if I publicly declare that I am satisfied with their verdict.
('72', 490, 3, 7, 914798) I accordingly do so and feel that in doing so I owe a statement to the public.
('72', 490, 4, 8, 914877) I am convinced that in the matter of the election of 1934 I neglected my duty as a responsible office bearer of the Congress and gave some of my friends cause to feel that my neglect amounted to a grave breach of trust.
('72', 490, 4, 9, 915097) In the matter of election of the leader of the Bombay Parliamentary Party in 1937, I am sorry to confess that I misjudged the general position and on the strength of the statement made by some of the legislators I felt a grievance which I allowed my friends and part of the Press to share with me.
('72', 490, 4, 10, 915395) As a result, considerable bitterness was aroused and Sardar Vallabhbhai was even charged by a section of the Press with having acted through communal prejudice.
('72', 490, 4, 11, 915556) I have publicly stated before and do so now that this charge was entirely unfounded and whatever the Sardar did or did not do, was from a sense of public duty.
('72', 490, 4, 12, 915716) I am sorry that the agitation against Sardar should have taken a personal aspect and even a communal aspect and that I should have been the cause of taking up so much of the time of Mahatma Gandhi and Bahadurji over a grievance which the public have a right to say was more fancied than real.
('72', 490, 5, 13, 916009) Having said this I feel that I owe some kind of reparation to the public whom I have all these years claimed to serve.
('72', 490, 5, 14, 916128) And in order that the confidence in me may be fully restored, I deliberately declare my intention not to seek on the expiry of my term of those offices re election to all positions and places of trust that I now enjoy and my determination to serve the Congress and the public by being out of those offices in order that passions and bitterness may cease and peace and harmony may be restored.
('72', 490, 6, 15, 916521) The Hindustan Times, 17 10 1937
('72', 490, 7, 16, 916553) 1 Vide “Stateent to the Press”, 16 10 1937. It is likely that this was originally drafted by Gandhiji; vide “Letter to K. F. Nariman”, 29 10 1937
('72', 491, 0, 1, 916699) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 492
('72', 491, 1, 2, 916741) APPENDIX X
('72', 491, 2, 3, 916752) (a) M. A. JINNAH’S SPEECH AT LUCKNOW 1
('72', 491, 3, 4, 916791) October 15, 1937
('72', 491, 4, 5, 916808) The Muslim League stands for full national democratic self government for India.
('72', 491, 4, 6, 916889) A great deal of capital is made as to phrases, more for the consumption of the ignorant and illiterate masses.
('72', 491, 4, 7, 917000) Various phrases are used such as purna swaraj, self government, complete independence, responsible government, substance of independence and dominion status.
('72', 491, 4, 8, 917158) There are some who talk of complete independence.
('72', 491, 4, 9, 917208) But it is no use having complete independence on your lips and the Government of India Act, 1935, in your hands.
('72', 491, 4, 10, 917321) Those who talk of complete independence the most mean the least what it means.
('72', 491, 4, 11, 917400) Was the Gandhi Irwin Pact in consonance with complete independence?
('72', 491, 4, 12, 917468) Were the assurances that were required before the offices would be accepted and the provincial constitutions could be worked consistent with purna swaraj, and was the resolution, after the assurances were refused, accepting offices and working the Constitution enacted by the British Parliament and forced upon the people of India by the imperialistic power, in keeping with the policy and programme and the declarations of the Congress Party?
('72', 491, 4, 13, 917912) Does wrecking mean working?
('72', 491, 5, 14, 917940) The present leadership of the Congress, especially during the last ten years, has been responsible for alienating the Mussalmans of India more and more by pursuing a policy which is exclusively Hindu, and since they have formed the governments in six provinces where they are in majority they have by their words, deeds and programmes shown more that the Mussalmans cannot expect any justice or fair play at their hands.
('72', 491, 5, 15, 918361) Wherever they are in a majority and wherever it suited them, they refused to co operate with the Muslim League Parties and demanded unconditional surrender and signing of their pledges.
('72', 491, 6, 16, 918547) Hindi is to be the national language of India and Bandemataram is to be the national song and is to be forced upon all.
('72', 491, 6, 17, 918667) The Congress flag is to be obeyed and revered by all and sundry.
('72', 491, 6, 18, 918732) On the very threshold of what little power and responsibility is given, the majority community have clearly shown their hand that Hindustan is for the Hindus; only, the Congress masquerades under the name of nationalism whereas the Hindu Mahasabha does not mince words.
('72', 491, 7, 19, 919002) Here it will not be out of place to state that the responsibility of the British Government is no less in the disastrous consequences which may issue.
('72', 491, 7, 20, 919153) It has been
('72', 491, 8, 21, 919165) 1 Vide “Letter to M. A. Jinnah”, 19 10 1937 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('72', 492, 0, 1, 919244) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 493
('72', 492, 1, 2, 919288) clearly demonstrated that the Governor and Governor General who have been given the special powers and special responsibility to safeguard and protect the minorities under the Constitution which was made so much of by .
('72', 492, 1, 3, 919508) the Secretary of State for India .
('72', 492, 1, 4, 919543) have failed to use them and have thereby been a party to the flagrant breach of the spirit of the Constitution and the instrument of instructions in the matter of appointment of Muslim Ministers.
('72', 492, 1, 5, 919739) On the contrary they have been a party to passing off men as Muslim Ministers by appointing them as such, though they know fully well that they do not command the confidence of the Muslim representatives or the public outside.
('72', 492, 2, 6, 919966) The Congress High Command speaks in different voices.
('72', 492, 2, 7, 920020) One opinion is that there is no such thing as Hindu Muslim question and there is no such thing as minorities’ question in the country.
('72', 492, 2, 8, 920155) The other High Command opinion is that if a few crumbs are thrown to the Mussalmans in their present disorganized and helpless state you can manage them.
('72', 492, 3, 9, 920309) The All India Muslim League certainly and definitely stands to safeguard the rights and interests of the Mussalmans and other minorities effectively.
('72', 492, 3, 10, 920459) That is its basic and conditional principle.
('72', 492, 3, 11, 920504) The Congress attempt under the guise of establishing mass contact with the Mussalmans is calculated to divide and weaken and break the Mussalmans and is an effort to detach them from their accredited leaders.
('72', 492, 3, 12, 920713) It is a dangerous move and it cannot mislead anyone.
('72', 492, 3, 13, 920766) All such manoeuvres will not succeed notwithstanding the various blandishments, catchwords and slogans.
('72', 492, 4, 14, 920870) Then he warned the Congress against the inadvisibility of asking for a Constituent Assembly and admonished them to see that the All India Federation Scheme embodied in the 1935 Act was not brought into being.
('72', 492, 4, 15, 921079) He also warned the British empire against their attitude regarding Palestine and concluded by exhorting Mussalmans to fear nothing and to be true and loyal to stand by their decisions as one man.

('72', 493, 8, 15, 922872) LETTER FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU 1
('72', 493, 9, 16, 922903) November 14, 1937
('72', 493, 10, 17, 922921) MY DEAR BAPU,
('72', 493, 11, 18, 922935) I have just read your article on the A. I. C. C. meeting.
('72', 493, 11, 19, 922993) Regarding the Mysore resolution you have said that it was ultra vires of the A. I. C. C. If this was so then I had no business to permit discussion on it and should have banned it.
('72', 493, 11, 20, 923174) I am not aware of any constitutional provision which leads to this result and only something in the nature of such a provision can bar a resolution moved in the ordinary way and supported by a majority of the A. I. C. C. Apart from the constitution itself, I am not aware of any previous decision of the Congress or the A. I. C. C. which lays down that such matters should not be considered.
('72', 493, 11, 21, 923566) Even if there was some such resolution, I do not see how it could prevent the A. I. C. C. from considering a matter if it so chose, unless the resolution was embodied in a rule of practice.
('72', 493, 11, 22, 923756) The A. I. C. C. is at complete liberty to consider a resolution which may go contrary to a previous resolution passed by itself.
('72', 493, 11, 23, 923885) If however there is a rule of practice or procedure, this has to be acted upon till the A. I. C. C. does not alter it [sic].
('72', 493, 11, 24, 924010) There is no question of such a rule, but I do not even know of a resolution which lays down a policy which the Mysore resolution infringes.
('72', 493, 11, 25, 924150) In statements issued by us in the past mention has been made that the Congress desires to follow a policy of non intervention in the States.
('72', 493, 12, 26, 924291) 1 Vide “The A.I.C.C.”,13 11 1937
('72', 494, 0, 1, 924324) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 495
('72', 494, 1, 2, 924368) Those statements cannot bar the A. I. C. C. itself from intervening if it chooses.
('72', 494, 1, 3, 924451) I cannot understand how the legal phrase, ultra vires, can be made to apply.
('72', 494, 2, 4, 924528) Another question arises, what is intervention?
('72', 494, 2, 5, 924575) Is a mention of a State in a resolution intervention?
('72', 494, 2, 6, 924629) Is a demand for civil liberties or a condemnation of repression, intervention?
('72', 494, 2, 7, 924708) If so, the Congress itself has been guilty of it in specific and unequivocal terms during the last two years.
('72', 494, 3, 8, 924818) The Mysore resolution of the A. I. C. C. is very badly worded and, in any event, I did not want it to be passed by the A. I. C. C. just then.
('72', 494, 3, 9, 924960) But my feelings have little to do with the matter.
('72', 494, 3, 10, 925011) I have to act as the president of a democratic assembly.
('72', 494, 3, 11, 925068) The resolution was one of condemnation of repression in Mysore.
('72', 494, 3, 12, 925132) Are we to refrain from condemning repression in a State in future whatever the nature of this repression?
('72', 494, 3, 13, 925238) If this repression consists in attacking the Congress itself, insulting our Flag, or banning our organization, are we to remain silent?
('72', 494, 3, 14, 925374) These matters must be cleared up so that our office and our organization might know definitely what line we are to take up.
('72', 494, 4, 15, 925498) You have said that the A. I. C. C. should not have passed the resolution without at least hearing the other side.
('72', 494, 4, 16, 925612) Do you think that it is feasible for us to appoint inquiry committees to go to States?
('72', 494, 4, 17, 925699) Will the States agree?
('72', 494, 4, 18, 925722) on several occasions I have suggested this to States—not a committee but just an individual to go there and inquire from both sides.
('72', 494, 4, 19, 925855) They have invariably turned this down.
('72', 494, 5, 20, 925894) This Mysore matter has been going on for a long time.
('72', 494, 5, 21, 925948) The Karnatak P. C. C. has taken some steps in the matter.
('72', 494, 5, 22, 926006) Their secretary has had a long interview with the Dewan of Mysore.
('72', 494, 5, 23, 926073) I have repeatedly written to the Dewan and put a large number of specific cases before him.
('72', 494, 5, 24, 926165) He has replied at length without, in my opinion, justifying the State policy.
('72', 494, 5, 25, 926243) For months past I have been restraining Congressmen in Mysore from indulging in any disobedience of orders and, in fact, no orders have been disobeyed, except by Nariman recently.
('72', 494, 5, 26, 926423) The Karnatak P. C. C. ultimately considered the situation and condemned the policy of repression in Mysore and asked us for further directions as to what they should do.
('72', 494, 5, 27, 926593) It is hardly correct therefore to say that the A. I. C. C. condemned anybody unheard or ex parte.
('72', 494, 5, 28, 926691) We pursued all the ordinary avenues open to us.
('72', 494, 6, 29, 926739) I am writing all this to you as I want to be clear in my own mind what our policy is.
('72', 494, 6, 30, 926825) You have censured the A. I. C. C. and me for the course we pursued.
('72', 494, 6, 31, 926893) I have not yet understood how and where I am wrong and so long as I do not understand it, I can hardly act otherwise.
('72', 494, 7, 32, 927011) Yours affectionately,
('72', 494, 8, 33, 927033) JAWAHARLAL
('72', 494, 9, 34, 927044) MAHATMA GANDHI

('72', 495, 1, 2, 927144) APPENDIX XII
('72', 495, 2, 3, 927157) BENGAL GOVERNMENT’S COMMUNIQUE 1
('72', 495, 3, 4, 927190) November 18, 1937 2
('72', 495, 4, 5, 927210) During the last session of the Provincial Legislature the Government of Bengal declared its policy of progressive release of detenus as the situation improved, and also gave an assurance that where adequate guarantees of good behaviour were forthcoming, any special cases would be separately considered.
('72', 495, 4, 6, 927514) In the then prevailing circumstances, Government considered that a wholesale release of over 2,000 detenus might lead to difficulties and possibly a recrudescence of violence.
('72', 495, 4, 7, 927690) Their policy of progressive release was enunciated in the Assembly on August 9 and was approved by the Chamber.
('72', 495, 4, 8, 927802) In pursuance of this policy a large number of persons have already been released and many others have been placed under modified forms of restriction.
('72', 495, 5, 9, 927953) There have since been observed definite indications of a change for the better in the general atmosphere.
('72', 495, 5, 10, 928059) Recent pronouncements by certain leaders also show that they are exerting themselves to discredit methods of violence.
('72', 495, 5, 11, 928178) Mr. Gandhi has also assured Government that he would do his best to improve the political situation in Bengal by preaching his cult of non violence and creating public opinion in favour of it.
('72', 495, 5, 12, 928371) He has also offered to meet detenus with the object of persuading them not to resort to or assist terrorism or other subversive activities in future.
('72', 495, 5, 13, 928521) In consideration of these circumstances and on a review of the present situation, Government have decided to accelerate the release of the detenus or the removal of restrictions on them, and have therefore issued orders for the immediate release of about 1,100 detenus subject only to the requirement that changes of address be communicated.
('72', 495, 6, 14, 928863) As regards the remaining detenus, no more than 450 in number, a large portion of whom are in camps and jails, Government propose to take up their cases in the near future.
('72', 495, 6, 15, 929035) Mr. Gandhi has offered to interview individual detenus, a task which he intends to undertake in about four months’ time and for which Government will gladly afford him every facility.
('72', 495, 6, 16, 929219) Government hopes then to be in a position to grant immediate release to those detenus in respect of whom Mr. Gandhi may be able to give Government satisfactory assurances after seeing the individual detenus.
('72', 495, 6, 17, 929427) In the mean while Government will continue to consider relaxation in individual cases and, if such action appears to be justified, complete release.
('72', 495, 7, 18, 929576) It is hoped that the steady development of the policy now set forth will result in the ultimate solution of this perplexing and difficult problem.
('72', 495, 7, 19, 929723) Its success must, however, depend on the co operation of the public and the leaders of public opinion
('72', 495, 8, 20, 929825) 1 Vide “Statement on Bengal Government’s Communique”, 21 11 1937 2 From The Statesman, 19 11 1937
('72', 496, 0, 1, 929923) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 497
('72', 496, 1, 2, 929967) in maintaining an atmosphere in which subversive movements will find no encouragement.
('72', 496, 1, 3, 930054) Government, who have throughout been most anxious to carry out the policy of release of detenus as rapidly as possible consistently with the public safety, cordially welcome Mr. Gandhi’s offer of assistance in creating the favourable atmosphere that is essential for the success of this policy.
('72', 496, 2, 4, 930349) Harijan, 27 11 1937
('72', 496, 3, 5, 930369) APPENDIX XIII
('72', 496, 4, 6, 930383) (a) LETTER FROM MAHADEV DESAI TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU 1
('72', 496, 5, 7, 930435) MAGANWADI, WARDHA,
('72', 496, 6, 8, 930454) November 19, 1937
('72', 496, 7, 9, 930472) MY DEAR JAWAHARBHAI,
('72', 496, 8, 10, 930493) Your letter of the 8th.
('72', 496, 8, 11, 930517) I understand all that you say about Samuel’s visit, and I am writing to Polak to say that you will gladly meet him if he desires to see you.
('72', 496, 9, 12, 930658) About Anupchand Shah’s offer it was so good of you to have written to him about the existence of the Gandhi Seva Sangh.
('72', 496, 9, 13, 930778) I am now writing to him.
('72', 496, 10, 14, 930803) Bapu would himself have replied to your letter of the 14th regarding his article 2 on the Mysore Resolution.
('72', 496, 10, 15, 930912) But he was unable even to dictate his reply.
('72', 496, 10, 16, 930957) He is so thoroughly washed out that the doctors think that it would be dangerous to allow him to exert himself.
('72', 496, 10, 17, 931069) But I gave him the gist of your letter.
('72', 496, 10, 18, 931109) He told me that he was clear that there was an infringement of the policy of non intervention.
('72', 496, 10, 19, 931204) He knows that the Congress has been guilty of intervention in the past, but he also knows that it was not proper, and he should not have written the article if he did not feel it imperative to cry a halt.
('72', 496, 10, 20, 931409) He was glad you recognize that the resolution was badly worded and he is sure that if the other members of the Working Committee had taken care to invite your attention to the fact that the Resolution was ultra vires, you would have effectively prevented the speeches to the resolution which were much worse than the resolution itself.
('72', 496, 10, 21, 931745) Bapu wants me to assure you that he never intended to censure you.
('72', 496, 10, 22, 931812) You were immersed to the ears in work, and it was the duty of your colleagues on the W. C. to have drawn your attention.
('72', 496, 10, 23, 931933) You are too good a disciplinarian to have disregarded their advice, but he feels that they failed in their duty.
('72', 496, 11, 24, 932046) This cold blunt language of mine fails to convey the feeling at the back of Bapu’s mind.
('72', 496, 11, 25, 932135) He was very deeply exercised over the resolution on the day of that breakdown 3 and he seemed to me to be in the same state as he was talking about the matter today.
('72', 496, 11, 26, 932301) I stopped him and said I should convey to you what he thought about it as best as I could.
('72', 496, 12, 27, 932392) 1 Vide “Letter to Mahadev Desai”, 22 111 1937 2 Vide “The A.I.C.C”, 13 11 1937 3 On November 1

('72', 497, 1, 4, 932773) He has promised to stay in bed at any rate until the pressure keeps steady for a fortnight or more.

('72', 497, 5, 7, 932909) (b) LETTER FROM MAHADEV DESAI TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU 1
('72', 497, 6, 8, 932961) MAGANWADI, WARDHA, December 2, 1937
('72', 497, 7, 9, 932997) MY DEAR JAWAHARBHAI.
('72', 497, 8, 10, 933018) I have your letter of the 27th.
('72', 497, 8, 11, 933050) It was a surprise to me that you had written at all, and all the greater surprise that you could write at such length.
('72', 497, 8, 12, 933169) I appreciate all that you say.
('72', 497, 8, 13, 933200) I simply did not inflict an argument on you as I assumed that you did not want an argument but simply Bapu’s opinion in the light of what you had urged in your letter.
('72', 497, 9, 14, 933368) There is no improvement in Bapu’s condition and we are withholding all correspondence from him.
('72', 497, 9, 15, 933464) But I decided that even in contravention of the doctors’ orders I must read out your letter to Bapu.
('72', 497, 9, 16, 933565) He was happy that I read it to him and if it had been at all possible for him to dictate a reply he would have done so.
('72', 497, 9, 17, 933685) But it was out of the question and I must try to tell you in my own language what was at the back of his mind when he wrote that the Mysore Resolution was ultra vires.
('72', 497, 9, 18, 933853) I wonder if you remember that Bapu said this very thing in the W. C. meeting too.
('72', 497, 9, 19, 933935) (He had that impression and on asking Jamnalalji he corroborated him.) And he had trusted that the resolution would not be allowed.
('72', 497, 9, 20, 934067) He was shocked when he found that it had been passed.
('72', 497, 10, 21, 934121) In your own letter you admit that the language of the resolution was bad.
('72', 497, 10, 22, 934195) But I suppose you will say that does not make it illegal.
('72', 497, 10, 23, 934253) Bapu thinks that it does inasmuch as it appeals to the people of British India to give all possible help to the people of Mysore.
('72', 497, 10, 24, 934383) If this does not go against the spirit and the letter of the Lucknow Resolution 2 what else does it do?
('72', 497, 10, 25, 934487) The Lucknow Resolution was arrived at after a good deal of discussion and deliberation, and reflected the declaration of policy made by Rajendra Babu on 1 8 1935 and adopted by the A. I. C. C. on 17 l0 1935. The relevant paragraph in this declaration was this: “It should be understood however that
('72', 497, 11, 26, 934786) 1 Vide “Letter to Mahadev Desai”, 22 11 1937 2 Passed at the Congress Session held in April 1936
('72', 498, 0, 1, 934883) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 499
('72', 498, 1, 2, 934927) the responsibility and the burden of carrying on that struggle with the States must necessarily fall on the States people themselves.
('72', 498, 1, 3, 935061) The Congress can exercise moral and friendly influence upon the States and this it is bound to do wherever possible.
('72', 498, 1, 4, 935178) The Congress has no other power under existing circumstances, although the people of India whether under the British, the Princes or any other power are geographically and historically one and indivisible.
('72', 498, 1, 5, 935384) In the heat of controversy the limitation of the Congress is often forgotten.
('72', 498, 1, 6, 935462) Indeed any other policy will defeat the common purpose.”
('72', 498, 2, 7, 935519) Now this declaration was but a reiteration of the policy that was being followed until then, and the Lucknow Resolution in laying down in the clearest possible terms that “the struggle for liberty within the States has, in the very nature of things, to be carried on by the people of the States themselves”, gave that declaration the status of a Congress enactment.
('72', 498, 2, 8, 935885) The sponsors of the Mysore Resolution forgot the self imposed limitation of the Congress and went against the spirit of the long accepted policy of the Congress.
('72', 498, 3, 9, 936047) I come now to your other question.
('72', 498, 3, 10, 936082) You say: “Bapu also refers to a violation of truth and non violence by the A. I. C. C. resolutions.
('72', 498, 3, 11, 936182) These are grave charges and should be substantiated,” and so on.
('72', 498, 3, 12, 936247) Naturally, when you were writing this, Bapu’s article was not before you.
('72', 498, 3, 13, 936321) The resolution (Masani’s) and the speeches were, he has said, “wide of the mark”.
('72', 498, 3, 14, 936403) He explains how they were wide of the mark, and then asks them “to study and take to heart what Jawaharlal Nehru has said in his elaborate statement on the matter.” Then follows the sentence: “I am convinced that in their action the critics departed from truth and non violence.” This is said more with reference to the speeches than the resolution itself.
('72', 498, 3, 15, 936760) You yourself had to pull up several speakers and ask them to confine themselves to principle and policy.
('72', 498, 3, 16, 936865) “Many political prisoners had been released and bans lifted,” said Mr. Masani, “but there are still some prisoners in the Congress provinces.” Is that enough to prove that the Ministers were identifying themselves with Imperialism or they were as bad as Haqs and Sikandar Hayat Khans?
('72', 498, 3, 17, 937150) Is it true to say that the whole armoury of repression remained, when the Moplah Outrages Act was repealed within two months of the Congress Ministers’ accepting office?
('72', 498, 3, 18, 937320) I will not refer to the other speeches.
('72', 498, 4, 19, 937360) As regards the Mysore resolution, Bapu was of opinion that it was untruthful to characterize the policy of the Mysore State as repressive, when we deliberately went there and defied the law.
('72', 498, 4, 20, 937551) “Abominable repressive measures” and “keeping printed orders ready to be served on those who passed through the State” is not truthful language.
('72', 498, 5, 21, 937696) As to the rest of your letter, Bapu deeply appreciated all that you have to say.
('72', 498, 5, 22, 937777) There can be no question of your accepting anything from Bapu because it came from Bapu, and discipline can never mean “a meek acceptance of one’s own view of the matter [sic].”
('72', 498, 6, 23, 937955) I do not know whether you will have issued your statement to the Press ere this.
('72', 498, 6, 24, 938036) But if you have not, perhaps you would alter in parts in the light of
('72', 499, 0, 1, 938106) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 500
('72', 499, 1, 2, 938148) this letter, of which or parts of which you may make whatever use you like—though of course it is my letter and not Bapu’s and I am posting is without showing it to him.
('72', 499, 1, 3, 938318) If you feel that the statement should go as it is, you are at liberty to release it—i.e.
('72', 499, 1, 4, 938407) to say, you may say that you have had an unconvincing answer and that you must act in accordance with the dictates of your own mind.
('72', 499, 2, 5, 938540) Regarding violation of truth and non violence as evidenced in the activities of some of our ministers, Bapu would like you to write frankly and fully, regardless of his recent state of health.
('72', 499, 2, 6, 938733) For that violation, no matter where it comes from, has to be denounced and if our Ministers are really guilty of it they would deserve to be turned out.
('72', 499, 3, 7, 938886) He understands all you say about the Bengal affairs.
('72', 499, 3, 8, 938939) Far from expecting you to get “wildly excited” over the releases, all he wanted you to say was whether the way he had interviewed the Governor and the Ministers on the question of the release of prisoners and detenus met with your approval or not.

('72', 499, 8, 13, 939258) LETTER FROM K. NAZIMUDDIN 1
('72', 499, 9, 14, 939286) Copy WRITERS’ BUILDINGS,
('72', 499, 10, 15, 939311) CALCUTTA, November 24, 1937
('72', 499, 11, 16, 939339) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('72', 499, 12, 17, 939356) Thanks very much for your letter.
('72', 499, 12, 18, 939390) I am sorry to learn about your indisposition.
('72', 499, 12, 19, 939436) I hope you will soon completely recover your health.
('72', 499, 13, 20, 939489) In our opinion your statement is very fair and we thank you for it.
('72', 499, 13, 21, 939557) The wording of the Government communique is not perhaps very happy as far as the four months’ period is concerned.
('72', 499, 13, 22, 939672) It certainly brings out the Government’s point of view, namely, that only after the end of four months the question of a large scale release of the remaining detenus will be considered whereas it misleads the public in giving the impression that you will take up the question at the end of four months.
('72', 499, 13, 23, 939975) But there is nothing in the communique to prevent your coming and interviewing these people before the expiry of four months.
('72', 499, 14, 24, 940101) In your letter you have asked that Mr. Sarat Bose should be allowed to carry on the conversation with the detenus in your absence.
('72', 499, 14, 25, 940232) I would like to make it
('72', 499, 15, 26, 940256) 1 Vide “Letter to K. Nazimuddin”, 28 11 1937
('72', 500, 0, 1, 940301) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 501
('72', 500, 1, 2, 940345) quite clear that my objection to this suggestion is not based on personal grounds but on the question of principle.
('72', 500, 1, 3, 940461) treat you differently from all other political leaders in India and therefore neither your purpose nor Govt.’s object will be served by anyone else but your interviewing the detenus.
('72', 500, 1, 4, 940644) After your visit to Hijli, Govt.
('72', 500, 1, 5, 940677) allowed Dr. B. C. Roy and Mrs. Sarojini Naidu to interview the State prisoners.
('72', 500, 1, 6, 940757) Dr. Roy went there more in the capacity of a physician than a political leader and we made an exception for Mrs. Sarojini Naidu but as far as I am concerned I do not propose to allow any other political leader in future to interview the State prisoners.
('72', 500, 2, 7, 941011) I had presumed that personal touch between you and the individual detenu or State prisoner was necessary in order that you might be assured that the individual concerned had become a convinced adherent to the principles of non violence, following upon a change of heart and as a matter of principle quite independently of personal or political advantage.
('72', 500, 2, 8, 941366) It was a matter then not of bargaining between you.
('72', 500, 2, 9, 941418) It was necessary for you of course to explain the principles of non violence and persuade the subject to their acceptance.
('72', 500, 2, 10, 941541) But so far as the prisoner was concerned, it was a matter of simple statement whether he had reached that position or not.
('72', 500, 2, 11, 941664) This point of view has bearing on the question of the correspondence as well as that of interviews with the prisoners by persons other than yourself.
('72', 500, 2, 12, 941814) We should not object to correspondence under sealed cover between you and any State prisoner or detenu provided that it is understood that such letters as you receive are shown to nobody else.
('72', 500, 3, 13, 942007) As long as I am Home Minister, you can rest assured that whatever may be the language of the communique everything that we agreed upon will —insha allah—be given effect to provided nothing untoward happens in the mean time.
('72', 500, 4, 14, 942231) I agree with your explanation or amplification of the phrase “subversive movement”.
('72', 500, 4, 15, 942315) The only portion in the letter on which we differ is the reference to the convicted political prisoners.
('72', 500, 4, 16, 942420) As you are aware we agreed to take certain steps in connection with the convicted political prisoners.
('72', 500, 4, 17, 942523) I have issued instructions for action being taken on these lines but beyond this Government are not prepared to go.
('72', 500, 4, 18, 942639) I agree with what you have stated in your PS.
('72', 500, 4, 19, 942685) Repatriation will take place according to plan mentioned to you.
('72', 500, 5, 20, 942750) Yours sincerely,
('72', 500, 6, 21, 942767) K. NAZIMUDDIN
('72', 500, 7, 22, 942781) M. K. GANDHI, ESQ.
('72', 500, 8, 23, 942800) SEGAON, WARDHA
('72', 500, 9, 24, 942815) From a copy: Birla Papers.

('72', 501, 0, 1, 942864) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 502
('72', 501, 1, 2, 942906) APPENDIX XV
('72', 501, 2, 3, 942918) LETTER FROM M. A. JINNAH 1
('72', 501, 3, 4, 942945) NEW DELHI,
('72', 501, 4, 5, 942956) February 15, 1938
('72', 501, 5, 6, 942974) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('72', 501, 6, 7, 942991) I have received your letter of the 3rd February 1938 which was redirected here.
('72', 501, 6, 8, 943071) I did not complain to the Maulana Sahib about the absence of any reply from you.
('72', 501, 6, 9, 943152) I only mentioned the facts as he was anxious that we two should meet.
('72', 501, 6, 10, 943222) Anyhow, I am glad to hear from you.
('72', 501, 6, 11, 943258) My message to you through Mr. Kher as I informed you in my last letter, was not private.
('72', 501, 6, 12, 943347) It was only when Mr. Kher went to see you at Wardha that I did say that he should not mention the matter to anyone except you and that if you yourself were inclined in the first instance to take up the matter, then it will be more than half the battle won.
('72', 501, 6, 13, 943604) On his return to Bombay Mr. Kher told me that it was difficult for you to give a reply as you were restricted not to disclose it to anyone or consult anybody else.
('72', 501, 7, 14, 943768) Thereupon I said that it was not intended to be a secret and that he was free and you were free to put your heads together and let me know whether at that juncture you were inclined to take up this matter with your powerful and overwhelming influence which you exercise over the Congress.
('72', 501, 7, 15, 944057) Then he saw you again at Teethal and from that moment it ceased to be a private matter between two individuals; and he brought me your reply in writing which I had to publish because you know of the controversy between me and Babu Rajendra Prasad and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru in the Press where it was sought to make out that I was putting every obstacle in the way of Hindu Muslim settlement.
('72', 501, 7, 16, 944450) As your letter was not marked confidential I used it.
('72', 501, 7, 17, 944504) Besides, what is wrong in my saying that I had approached you on my own accord and that was a reply I received from you?
('72', 501, 7, 18, 944625) I cannot understand why you feel so much about it.
('72', 501, 7, 19, 944676) You say that I complained of your silence.
('72', 501, 7, 20, 944719) Well, I do.
('72', 501, 7, 21, 944731) But you further proceed to say, “Believe me the moment I can do something that can bring the two communities together, nothing in the world can prevent me from so doing.” Now, what am I to gather from this?
('72', 501, 7, 22, 944938) Am I right in interpreting that the moment is not come?
('72', 501, 8, 23, 944994) With regard to your opinion that my speech at the Lucknow session and my later pronouncements, which you are pleased to call a declaration of war, I can only repeat that it is in self defence.
('72', 501, 8, 24, 945187) Evidently, you are not acquainted with what is going on in the Congress Press—the amount of vilification, misrepresentation and falsehood that is daily spread about me—otherwise, I am sure, you would not blame
('72', 501, 9, 25, 945397) 1 Vide “Letter to M. A. Jinnah”, 3 2 1938
('72', 502, 0, 1, 945439) VOL. 72 : 6 JULY 1937 20 FEBRUARY, 1938 503
('72', 502, 2, 2, 945483) With regard to your saying that when in 1915 you returned from South Africa everybody spoke of me as one of the staunchest of nationalists and the hope of both the Hindus and Mussalmans, and you ask me a question, “Are you still the same Mr. Jinnah ?” and proceed further to say, “If you say you are, in spite of your speeches I shall accept your word.” And you say that in my speeches you miss the old nationalist.
('72', 502, 2, 3, 945899) Do you think that you are justified in saying that?
('72', 502, 2, 4, 945951) I would not like to say what people spoke of you in 1915 and what they speak and think of you today.
('72', 502, 2, 5, 946052) Nationalism is not the monopoly of any single individual; and in these days it is very difficult to define it: but I don’t wish to pursue this line of controversy any further.
('72', 502, 3, 6, 946228) You conclude by saying: “Lastly you want me to come forward with some proposal.
('72', 502, 3, 7, 946308) What proposal can I make except to ask you on bended knees to be what I had thought you were.
('72', 502, 3, 8, 946402) But the proposals to form the basis of unity between the two communities have surely got to come from you.” I think you might have spared your appeal and need not have preached to me on your bended knees to be what you had thought I was.
('72', 502, 3, 9, 946640) As regards the formation of proposals which would form the basis of unity, do you think that this can be done by correspondence?
('72', 502, 3, 10, 946769) Surely, you know as much as I do what are the fundamental points in dispute.
('72', 502, 3, 11, 946846) In my opinion it is as much up to you to suggest ways and means of tackling the problem.
('72', 502, 3, 12, 946935) If you genuinely and sincerely desire and you feel that the moment has come for you to step in and with your position and influence you are prepared to take the matter up earnestly, I will not fail to render all the assistance I can.
('72', 502, 4, 13, 947169) Yours sincerely,
('72', 502, 5, 14, 947186) M. A. JINNAH
('72', 502, 6, 15, 947199) The Bombay Chronicle, 16 6 1938
